choices.text: Ministry of Health and Family Welfare
Ministry of Environment, Forests and Climate Change
Ministry of Social Justice and Empowerment

questions.text: Which is the Nodal Ministry for Disaster Management? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ministry of Home Affairs

 

The Ministry of Home Affairs is the nodal ministry for disaster management in India. The National Disaster Management Authority (NDMA) functions under the Ministry of Home Affairs, with the Prime Minister serving as its chairperson. The nodal center for disaster management is at the district level.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Ministry of Health and Family Welfare: While this ministry plays a role in health-related aspects of disasters, it is not the nodal ministry for overall disaster management.

 

Option C. Ministry of Environment, Forests and Climate Change: This ministry deals with environmental aspects but is not responsible for coordinating disaster management activities.

 

Option D. Ministry of Social Justice and Empowerment: This ministry focuses on social welfare programs but does not coordinate disaster management activities.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The Ministry of Home Affairs serves as the nodal ministry for disaster management in India, with the district being the nodal center for implementation. NDMA functions under the Ministry of Home Affairs with the Prime Minister as its chairperson.

choices.text: NLEP, leprosy has a vaccine available
NLEP, Leprosy is curable, reduce stigma, spread awareness

questions.text: The image of the mascot ‘Sapna’ shown below and identify what does she represent in the national health program: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) NLEP, Leprosy is curable, reduce stigma, spread awareness

 

'Sapna' is the mascot of National Leprosy Eradication Program (NLEP) in India. She represents the success story of leprosy treatment, as she herself was a leprosy patient who got completely cured after taking multi-drug therapy (MDT). Her role is to spread awareness about:

 

  • Curability of leprosy through MDT
  • Reducing stigma and discrimination associated with leprosy in society
  • Encouraging early detection and treatment seeking behavior
  • Demonstrating that leprosy patients can lead a normal life after treatment

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. NLEP, leprosy has a vaccine available: Incorrect because there is no widely accepted vaccine for leprosy currently available for public use

 

Option B. NLEP, Leprosy has been eliminated: While India achieved elimination status (<1 case/10,000 population) in December 2005, the program continues as new cases still occur

 

Option D. NLEP, leprosy can't affect children: Incorrect as leprosy can affect people of any age group including children

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Sapna is the mascot of NLEP who represents successful treatment of leprosy and aims to reduce stigma while spreading awareness about curability of the disease through multi-drug therapy.

questions.text: Best indicator for chronic malnutrition in children is: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Height for age

 

Height for age is the best indicator of chronic malnutrition in children. When height for age is low, it indicates stunting, which develops over a long period due to chronic nutritional deficiency. This is because:

 

  • Height takes a longer time to be affected by nutritional deficiency
  • Once affected, height also takes longer to recover
  • Therefore, low height for age (stunting) reflects long-term or chronic nutritional deficiency

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Weight for age:

 

  • Indicates underweight status
  • Reflects acute on chronic malnutrition
  • Can change relatively quickly with nutritional status

 

Option B. Weight for height:

 

  • Indicates wasting
  • Reflects acute malnutrition
  • Changes rapidly with current nutritional status

 

Option D. Head circumference:

 

  • Not a primary indicator for malnutrition
  • More relevant for neurological development assessment
  • Does not specifically reflect nutritional status

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Height for age is the best indicator of chronic malnutrition in children, with low values indicating stunting, while weight for height indicates acute malnutrition (wasting) and weight for age indicates acute on chronic malnutrition (underweight).

questions.text: In a community, a new disease led to 60 cases occurring in a year. There were 12 deaths in the given year due to the same disease. Calculate the case fatality rate for this new disease. (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 20%

 

Case Fatality Rate (CFR) is calculated using the formula:

 

  • CFR 
  • In this case: CFR = (12/60) × 100 = 20%
  • CFR is a proportion (not a rate) where numerator is part of denominator
  • It indicates that out of 100 cases of this disease, 20 are likely to die

 

Educational Objective: 

 


 

It is a proportion (not a rate) that indicates the percentage of cases of a disease that result in death.

questions.text: A patient presents to OPD with history suggestive of tuberculosis. Culture media used commonly in India is: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) LJ medium

 

In India, Lowenstein-Jensen (LJ) medium has been the traditional and most commonly used culture media for TB diagnosis. According to the transcript, under the National TB Elimination Program (NTEP), two main culture methods are used:

 

  • LJ medium (Lowenstein Jensen medium) - Traditional method
  • Automated liquid culture - Newer method (like Versatrack, BACTEC MGIT 960, BACTALERT)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Loeffler medium: Incorrect because. Used primarily for Corynebacterium diphtheriae isolation

 

Option C. Thayer Martin medium: Incorrect because. This is selective for Neisseria gonorrhoeae and N. meningitidis

 

Option D. Macconkey agar: Incorrect because. Used for differentiating lactose-fermenting from non-lactose fermenting gram-negative bacteria

 

Educational Objective:

 

LJ (Lowenstein Jensen) medium is the traditional and commonly used culture media for tuberculosis diagnosis in India, along with newer automated liquid culture systems under NTEP.

questions.text: In a normal distribution for weights of a class of college students, Mean value is 82 kg. The calculated SD is 1.5 kg. Calculate the range of weight for 95% students covering 2 SD. (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 79 – 85 kg

 

In a normal distribution:

 

  • Mean ± 2SD covers 95% of all values
  • Formula: Range = Mean ± (2 × SD)
  • Given: Mean = 82 kg, SD = 1.5 kg
  • Therefore: Range = 82 ± (2 × 1.5) = 82 ± 3 = 79 to 85 kg This means 95% of students will have weights between 79 and 85 kg.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

In a normal distribution:

 

  • Mean ± 1SD includes 68% of values
  • Mean ± 2SD includes 95% of values
  • Mean ± 3SD includes 99.7% of values

questions.text: In a class trip there were 75 camper school students, of which 50 had been immunized for Measles previously. During the trip, a child developed Measles. Subsequently, upon returning home, 12 more children developed Measles. Calculate the Secondary attack rate for Measles. (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 50%

 

Secondary Attack Rate (SAR) is calculated using the formula: 


SAR 

 

 

  • Total students = 75
  • Previously immunized = 50 (these are immune and not susceptible)
  • Susceptible students initially = 75 - 50 = 25
  • One student developed measles first (primary case)
  • Therefore, remaining susceptibles = 24
  • Secondary cases = 12

 

Applying the formula: SAR = (12/24) × 100 = 50%

 

The primary case is excluded both from numerator and denominator as they cannot be a secondary case.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Secondary Attack Rate (SAR) is the number of cases occurring within the incubation period following exposure to a primary case, expressed as a percentage of the total number of exposed susceptible persons. The primary case should be excluded from both numerator and denominator.

questions.text: For ASHA worker in an urban area, what is the recommended population norm? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1000-2500

 

In urban areas, USHA (Urban Social Health Activist) worker, which is equivalent to ASHA worker in rural areas, is deployed under the National Urban Health Mission (NUHM) launched in 2013. The recommended population norm for USHA worker is 1 per 1000-2500 population. This is different from rural ASHA workers who have a population norm of 2 per 1000.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Population norm for USHA (Urban Social Health Activist) worker under NUHM is 1 per 1000-2500 population.

questions.text: A total of 2000 patients were assessed for HIV. 200 were diagnosed positive. A new ELISA screening test was tested on the same group. It showed 260 as positive, out of which only 130 had the disease. What is the specificity of the test? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 93%

 

To calculate specificity

 

  • Total patients = 2000
  • True disease positive = 200
  • True disease negative = 1800
  • ELISA positive = 260 (130 true positive + 130 false positive)
  • ELISA negative = 1740 (70 false negative + 1670 true negative)

 

 

Specificity = True Negatives/(True Negatives + False Positives) × 100 = 1670/1800 × 100 = 93%

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Specificity is the ability of a test to correctly identify those without the disease (true negatives) and is calculated as True Negatives/(True Negatives + False Positives) × 100.

questions.text: Particle diameter size most commonly responsible for causation of Pneumoconioses in industries is? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 0.5-3 micron

 

The particle size of dust plays a crucial role in causing pneumoconiosis. Particles of size 0.5-3 micron are most dangerous because:

 

  • They are small enough to be inhaled deep into the lungs
  • Can reach up to alveoli
  • Stick to alveolar walls
  • Cause pneumoconiosis by damaging lung tissue

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. <5 micron: This option is too broad and includes particles below 0.5 micron which are in Brownian motion and don't cause damage as they move in and out with respiration 

 

Option C. 5-10 micron: These particles are too large to reach deep lung tissue and get trapped in the upper respiratory tract 

 

Option D. >10 micron: These particles are so large that they fall on the machine where they are generated and don't enter respiratory system

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Dust particles of size 0.5-3 micron are most dangerous for causing pneumoconiosis as they can reach and damage alveoli.

 

PNEUMOCONIOSES

 

  • D/t occupational exposure to dust
  • < 0.5 µ → Always in Brownian motion [Moves in & out]
  • 0.5 - 3µ → Most dangerous particle size
    • 3- 5µ → Trapped by mid respiratory tract
    • 5- 10µ → Trapped by upper resp. tract
    • 10µ → Fall on machine

- Common Pneumoconiosis

questions.text: Which of the following vaccines is contraindicated in pregnancy? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Varicella

 

Live attenuated vaccines are contraindicated in pregnancy because pregnancy is an immunocompromised state. Among the given options, Varicella (chickenpox) vaccine is a live attenuated vaccine and therefore contraindicated during pregnancy. This is due to the theoretical risk of transmission of the attenuated virus to the fetus, which could potentially cause harm.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Influenza: Incorrect because it is an inactivated vaccine and is actually recommended during pregnancy to protect both mother and baby.

 

Option C. Rabies: Incorrect because it is a killed vaccine and can be safely administered during pregnancy if indicated.

 

Option D. TDaP: Incorrect because it is a toxoid/inactivated vaccine and is recommended during pregnancy to provide passive immunity to the newborn.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Live attenuated vaccines (like Varicella, MMR, Yellow fever) are contraindicated during pregnancy, while killed/inactivated vaccines and toxoids are safe and often recommended during pregnancy.

 

CONTRAINDICATIONS, AEFI

 

Contraindications

questions.text: Identify A and B in the image given: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) A-Anopheles, B-Culex

 

The image shows mosquito larvae in water. Anopheles larvae (A) rest parallel to the water surface because they have no siphon tube and can take oxygen directly through the water surface and skin. In contrast, Culex larvae (B) have a siphon tube (like a nose) so they attach to water surface at an angle using this siphon tube. The characteristic positioning of these larvae helps in their identification - Anopheles parallel to surface, while Culex at an angle.

 

Other Options:

 

 Option A. A-Culex, B-Aedes: Incorrect because Culex larvae rest at an angle to water surface, not parallel like shown in A.

 

Option C. A-Culex, B-Anopheles: Incorrect because the positioning is reversed. Anopheles rests parallel (A), not B.

 

Option D. A-Aedes, B-Culex: Incorrect because Aedes larvae, like Culex, have a siphon tube and rest at an angle, not parallel like shown in A.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: National Deworming Day is observed on:(FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 10 February and 10 August

 

National Deworming Day is observed on 10th February, with a repeat round conducted after six months on 10th August. During this program, albendazole is used for deworming. In many states, the 10th date of every month is observed as national deworming day, but the main nationwide observance is on these two dates.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

National Deworming Day is observed on 10th February with a repeat round after 6 months on 10th August, using albendazole for deworming.

questions.text: Identify the deficiency of the nutrient as given in the image of a child: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Zinc deficiency

 

The image shows acrodermatitis enteropathica, which is a characteristic manifestation of zinc deficiency. This condition presents with skin manifestations along with other symptoms like diarrhea, brittle nails, and in severe cases can lead to sterility in older patients. The skin lesions typically appear as eczematous and psoriasiform plaques in acral and periorificial locations.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Vitamin A deficiency: Incorrect because Vitamin A deficiency primarily manifests as xerophthalmia with ocular changes like Bitot's spots, night blindness, and corneal changes, not the skin manifestations shown in the image.

 

Option C. Vitamin C deficiency: Incorrect because Vitamin C deficiency (scurvy) presents with bleeding gums, poor wound healing, and petechial hemorrhages, not the characteristic skin lesions shown.

 

Option D. Copper deficiency: Incorrect because copper deficiency (pseudoscurvy) has different manifestations including anemia and neurological symptoms, not the skin manifestations shown in the image.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Characteristic skin manifestations of acrodermatitis enteropathica as a sign of zinc deficiency, which includes eczematous lesions accompanied by systemic symptoms like diarrhea and brittle nails.

questions.text: In a study based in Delhi from 2012-2022, doctors followed up 100 people who did exercise on a daily basis for a year. Later, they checked who all had developed coronary heart disease among them. This is a type of: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Prospective study

 

This is a prospective or cohort study because:

 

  • The exposure (exercise) was identified first
  • The subjects were followed up over time (10 years from 2012 to 2022)
  • The outcome (coronary heart disease) was measured later
  • The direction of the study is forward in time (from exposure to outcome)
  • The study follows a group of similar individuals (cohort) over time

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Case control study: Incorrect because case control studies are retrospective, starting with the outcome (disease) and looking back at exposures. Here, the study started with exposure and looked forward.

 

Option C. Cross sectional study: Incorrect because cross sectional studies measure exposure and outcome at the same point in time. This study involved follow-up over 10 years.

 

Option D. Ecological study: Incorrect because ecological studies analyze population-level data rather than individual data. This study followed individual subjects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A study that starts with exposure, follows subjects over time, and measures outcomes later is a prospective/cohort study.

choices.text: At birth, 6 weeks, 10 weeks, 14 weeks, 16-24 months, 5 years
At birth, 6 weeks, 10 weeks, 14 weeks

questions.text: What is the f-IPV dose schedule under the National Immunization Schedule of India? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 6 weeks, 14 weeks, 9 months

 

Under the National Immunization Schedule of India, fractional IPV (f-IPV) is given in three doses:

 

  • First dose at 6 weeks
  • Second dose at 14 weeks (no dose at 10 weeks)
  • Third dose at 9 months

 

Educational Objective:

 

The fractional IPV (f-IPV) schedule in India's National Immunization Schedule consists of three doses at 6 weeks, 14 weeks, and 9 months.

questions.text: A tourist group was headed by a tour guide. They were seen many times in an area. Which kind of group dynamics does this represent? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Herd

 

A herd is a group of people with a leader whom they follow without questioning - like a political party leader being followed by party workers. In this case, the tourist group follows their tour guide without questioning, making it a classic example of herd behavior.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Crowd: Incorrect because a crowd is a temporary gathering of people who come together due to common interest without any leader or organization, like people gathering to watch a cricket match.

 

Option B. Band: Incorrect because a band is a community comprised of groups of families who not only live together but follow a certain pattern of life and culture.

 

Option D. Mob: Incorrect because while a mob has a leader, it is highly emotional, unstable, disorganized and sometimes acts against the law.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Rabies vaccine + Immunoglobulin + Wound management

questions.text: Management of an HIV-positive patient with multiple punctured wound bites caused by a dog is: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Rabies vaccine + Immunoglobulin + Wound management

 

Multiple punctured wounds classify as Class III bite according to WHO classification. For Class III bites, the standard protocol includes:

 

  • Wound management - washing with running water and soap for 15-20 minutes
  • Local antiseptics if there isn't much bleeding
  • Avoid suturing
  • Administration of both rabies vaccine and immunoglobulin due to severity of exposure The HIV status of the patient doesn't alter this protocol.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Only wound management: Incorrect because Class III bites require comprehensive management including both immunological interventions along with wound care.

 

Option B. Rabies vaccine + Wound management: Incorrect because Class III bites require immunoglobulin in addition to vaccine and wound management.

 

Option D. Immunoglobulin + Wound management: Incorrect because rabies vaccine is essential component of post-exposure prophylaxis and cannot be omitted.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Class III rabies exposure (multiple punctured wounds) requires complete post-exposure prophylaxis including:

 

  • Local wound management
  • Rabies vaccine
  • Rabies immunoglobulin regardless of patient's immune status.

choices.text: Symptomatic treatment + Treat Vit-A deficiency
Isolation + Symptomatic treatment + Treat Vit-A deficiency
Give MR vaccine + Treat Vit-A deficiency + Treat Vit-A deficiency
Give aspirin for fever + Treat Vit-A deficiency

questions.text: A child has Measles. He presents to OPD at PHC with red congestion of eyes, fever, and coryza. On examination, he has got Bitot spots. Management protocol for this child will be: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Isolation + Symptomatic treatment + Treat Vit-A deficiency

 

The child presents with classic symptoms of measles (red eyes, fever, coryza) along with Bitot spots indicating Vitamin A deficiency. The management protocol should include:

 

  • Isolation - since measles is highly infectious
  • Symptomatic management - Supportive care includes adequate hydration, fever management and addressing secondary bacterial infections if present.
  • Treatment of Vitamin A deficiency - WHO recommends Vitamin A supplementation in all children with measles to reduce mortality and prevent ocular complications.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Symptomatic treatment + Treat Vit-A deficiency: Incorrect as it misses isolation, which is crucial to prevent transmission 

 

Option C. Give MR vaccine + Treat Vit-A deficiency + Treat Vit-A deficiency: Incorrect as MR vaccine is not indicated during active measles infection

 

Option D. Give aspirin for fever + Treat Vit-A deficiency: Incorrect as aspirin should be avoided in viral infections in children due to risk of Reye's syndrome

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Management of measles with concurrent Vitamin A deficiency are:

 

  • Isolation
  • Symptomatic treatment 
  • Vitamin A supplementation

choices.text: Network analysis and machinery installed
Equipment ordered and staff training
Work sampling and machinery installed

questions.text: Study the management technique given in the diagram. Identify the technique and find out the critical path. (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Network analysis and machinery installed

 

The diagram shows a network analysis technique that includes PERT (Program Evaluation and Review Technique) and CPM (Critical Path Method). When analyzing the two possible paths:

 

  • Path 1: 4 + 2 + 1 + 1 = 8 months total duration
  • Path 2: 2 + 10 + 1 = 13 months total duration The critical path is the longer duration path (13 months), where equipment installation takes the longest time (10 months), making it the most critical component.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Equipment ordered and staff training: Incorrect as these are components but not the critical path which has the longest duration 

 

Option C. Work sampling and machinery installed: Incorrect as this is not a work sampling technique, which is used for observing work activities 

 

Option D. Work sampling and staff training: Incorrect as the diagram shows network analysis, not work sampling

 

Educational Objective:

 

 Network analysis consists of two components:

 

  • PERT (Program Evaluation and Review Technique) - Shows sequence of activities

 

 

CPM (Critical Path Method) - Identifies the longest duration path in the network

questions.text: A person’s father had colon cancer. He was having bloody stool. So, he just came for the check-up. Before, he had not undergone any screening. He was recommended to do colonoscopy screening. Screening is which level of prevention? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Secondary

 

Screening falls under secondary level of prevention as it involves early detection and prompt treatment of diseases. In this case, colonoscopy screening is being done to detect potential colon cancer early, given the patient's family history and symptoms (bloody stools). Secondary prevention aims to detect disease in its early stages before it progresses to a more severe form.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Primordial: Incorrect as primordial prevention occurs before risk factors emerge. It involves preventing the emergence of environmental, economic, social, and behavioral conditions known to increase disease risk.

 

Option B. Primary: Incorrect as primary prevention involves interventions that prevent disease development after risk factors are present but before disease occurs. Examples include vaccination and specific protection.

 

Option D. Tertiary: Incorrect as tertiary prevention focuses on rehabilitation and disability limitation after disease has progressed. It's aimed at preventing complications in those who already have established disease.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Screening tests are part of secondary prevention, which focuses on early detection and prompt treatment of diseases before they progress to more severe stages.

 

Levels of Prevention of Disease

choices.text: Medical colleges and hospitals are primary level, CHC is secondary level, Subcentre and PHC are tertiary level
Subcentre and PHC are primary level, CHC is secondary level, Medical colleges and hospitals are tertiary level
CHC is primary level, Subcentre and PHC are secondary level, Medical colleges and hospitals are tertiary level
CHC is primary level, Medical colleges and hospitals are secondary level, Subcentre and PHC are tertiary level

questions.text: The image regarding health care system levels in the country. Correct arrangement about the levels of health care is: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Subcentre and PHC are primary level, CHC is secondary level, Medical colleges and hospitals are tertiary level

 

The healthcare system in India is organized into three levels:

 

  • Primary Level: First level of contact between population and health system, comprising of sub-centers and primary health centers (PHCs)
  • Secondary Level: First referral level, specialized care provided through community health centers (CHCs)
  • Tertiary Level: Second referral level, highly specialized care provided through medical colleges and their attached hospitals

 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Medical colleges and hospitals are primary level, CHC is secondary level, Subcentre and PHC are tertiary level: Incorrect. This completely reverses the actual arrangement. Medical colleges provide tertiary care, not primary care.

 

Option C. CHC is primary level, Subcentre and PHC are secondary level, Medical colleges and hospitals are tertiary level: Incorrect. CHC cannot be primary level as it provides specialized care and serves as first referral unit. Sub-centers and PHCs are primary care facilities, not secondary.

 

Option D. CHC is primary level, Medical colleges and hospitals are secondary level, Subcentre and PHC are tertiary level: Incorrect. This arrangement is completely wrong. CHC provides secondary care, medical colleges provide tertiary care, and sub-centers/PHCs provide primary care.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The three-tier healthcare delivery system in India consists of:

 

  • Primary level: Sub-centers and PHCs (First contact point)
  • Secondary level: CHCs (First referral level)
  • Tertiary level: Medical colleges and hospitals (Second referral level)

questions.text: International health agency - DANIDA is supporting which health program of India? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Blindness

 

DANIDA (Danish International Development Agency) supports the National Program for Control of Blindness and Visual Impairment (NPCBVI) in India. This international collaboration helps strengthen India's efforts to prevent and control blindness through various initiatives and interventions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. TB: Incorrect. TB program in India is supported by SIDA (Swedish International Development Agency), not DANIDA.

 

Option C. Malaria: Incorrect. Malaria control is part of the National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme (NVBDCP) and does not receive specific support from DANIDA.

 

Option D. Vector-borne diseases: Incorrect. Vector-borne diseases are covered under NVBDCP and do not receive specific support from DANIDA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The DANIDA (Danish International Development Agency) provides support specifically to India's National Program for Control of Blindness and Visual Impairment.

questions.text: A group organized a mass gathering on handwashing awareness. Arrange the steps in the correct chronological sequence: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Awareness – Interest – Evaluation – Trial – Adoption 

 

When motivating a group to adopt a new practice like handwashing, there is a specific sequence of steps that follows the AITA principle:

 

  • Awareness - First, people need to be made aware that handwashing exists and is beneficial for health
  • Interest - Once aware, they develop interest in understanding how it benefits their health
  • Evaluation - They evaluate the information they've learned about handwashing
  • Trial - They try the practice of handwashing
  • Adoption - If found useful, they incorporate handwashing into their daily routine

 

Educational Objective: 

 

 The correct sequence for behavior change adoption in health education:

 

 Awareness → Interest → Evaluation → Trial → Adoption (AITA)

questions.text: It is being planned to put posters in the whole city for health promotion. Which type of health education approach is this? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mass based

 

Posters are a type of mass-based health education approach. Health education approaches can be divided into three main categories:

 

  • Individual-based methods (like interpersonal communication, personal letters, home visits)
  • Group-based methods (like lectures, focus group discussions, panel discussions)
  • Mass-based methods (like posters, television, radio, newsprint, banners, charts)

 

Posters placed throughout a city reach a large audience simultaneously and are therefore classified as a mass-based approach to health education.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Individual based: Incorrect as individual-based approaches involve one-on-one interactions like personal counseling or home visits 

 

Option B. Group-based: Incorrect as group-based approaches involve interactive sessions with specific groups like lectures or workshops 

 

Option D. One to one: Incorrect as this is a form of individual communication and not suitable for city-wide health promotion through posters

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Posters are a mass-based health education approach used for reaching large populations simultaneously with health messages.

 

Approaches For Health Communication

questions.text: Mr. X got married to Ms. Y in 1999. They had overall two children - Ms. M in 2002 and Ms. N in 2009. Mr. X’s father was a bank employee who moved in, post-retirement in 2008, with them along with his wife. Which stage of the family cycle do they belong to?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Complete extension

 

The family cycle has 6 stages:

 

  • Formation: From marriage till first childbirth
  • Extension: From first childbirth till last childbirth
  • Complete extension: From last childbirth till first child leaves home
  • Contraction: From first child leaves home till last child leaves home
  • Complete contraction: From last child leaves home till death of first spouse
  • Dissolution: From death of first spouse till death of survivor

 

In this case:

 

  • Last childbirth (Ms. N) occurred in 2009
  • No children have left home yet
  • The family is therefore in the complete extension stage, which starts after last childbirth and continues until the first child leaves home

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Complete contraction: Incorrect as this stage occurs when all children have left home, which hasn't happened in this case

 

Option B. Extension: Incorrect as this stage is between first and last childbirth. The family has already had their last child in 2009

 

Option D. Dissolution: Incorrect as this stage occurs after death of first spouse, which hasn't happened in this case

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Complete extension stage of family cycle starts after last childbirth and continues until first child leaves home.

 

Family system in INDIA

 

Family cycle

questions.text: Under Integrated Disease Surveillance Program, which of the following diseases are covered under Sentinel surveillance? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) HIV and HBV

 

IDSP has three types of surveillance:

 

  1. Regular surveillance: Covers common diseases like malaria, dengue, TB, URI, typhoid, cholera, leptospirosis, plague, road traffic accidents, meningococcal meningitis, and viral hemorrhagic fevers
  2. Sentinel surveillance: Covers HIV, hepatitis B virus (HBV), hepatitis C virus (HCV), along with air quality and water quality monitoring
  3. Periodic surveys: For non-communicable disease risk factors and anthropometry

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. TB and URI: Incorrect as these diseases are covered under regular surveillance, not sentinel surveillance 

 

Option B. Malaria and Dengue: Incorrect as these vector-borne diseases are covered under regular surveillance 

 

Option C. Cholera and Typhoid: Incorrect as these water-borne diseases are covered under regular surveillance

 

Educational Objective:

 

Under IDSP, sentinel surveillance specifically covers HIV, HBV, HCV, and environmental factors like air and water quality.

 

Integrated diseases surveillance project (IDSP)

 

Encompasses

choices.text: Barrier methods for 4 months and then Semen analysis to confirm
Barrier methods for 3 months and then Semen analysis to confirm
Barrier methods for 4 months with no need to come back
Barrier methods for 3 months with no need to come back

questions.text: Which of the following guidelines are true for the client post-vasectomy? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Barrier methods for 3 months and then Semen analysis to confirm

 

After vasectomy, a person is not immediately sterile. It takes 3 months for spermatozoa to clear from the reproductive tract. During this period, the client must use barrier methods of contraception. After 3 months, semen analysis should be done to confirm the success of sterilization.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Post-vasectomy guidelines require:

 

  1. Use of barrier methods for 3 months
  2. Mandatory semen analysis after 3 months to confirm success of sterilization

questions.text: Combined OCPs are least protective for? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Breast Ca

 

Combined OCPs provide protective effects against several gynecological conditions. However, they offer minimal to no protection against breast carcinoma. Combined OCPs are only protective against benign breast diseases like fibroadenoma, but not against breast cancer.

 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. PID (Incorrect)

 

  • Combined OCPs provide significant protection against Pelvic Inflammatory Disease (PID)
  • The thickened cervical mucus and other mechanisms help prevent ascending infections

 

Option B. Endometrial Ca (Incorrect)

 

  • Combined OCPs offer strong protection against endometrial cancer
  • The hormonal effects help prevent endometrial hyperplasia and subsequent cancer risk

 

Option C. Ovarian Ca (Incorrect)

 

  • OCPs provide substantial protection against both benign and malignant ovarian diseases
  • The suppression of ovulation and other mechanisms contribute to this protective effect

 

Educational Objective:

 

While combined oral contraceptive pills provide protection against several gynecological conditions (PID, endometrial cancer, ovarian cancer), they do not provide significant protection against breast cancer.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a food adulteration disease? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Fluorosis

 

Fluorosis is not a food adulteration disease. It occurs naturally due to excessive fluoride intake, primarily through drinking water. 

 

Food adulteration diseases are caused by deliberate addition or modification of food items by someone like a shopkeeper for profits.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Aflatoxicosis: Incorrect because it is a food adulteration disease caused by aflatoxin produced by Aspergillus fungus contamination.

 

Option B. Lathyrism: Incorrect because it is a food adulteration disease caused by consumption of Lathyrus sativus (kesari dal) containing the toxin beta-oxalyl aminoalanine (BOAA).

 

Option D. Epidemic dropsy: Incorrect because it is a food adulteration disease caused by mixing of argemone mexicana oil in mustard oil, which leads to generation of the toxin sanguinarine.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Fluorosis is a natural disease caused by excessive fluoride intake through drinking water and is not a food adulteration disease, unlike aflatoxicosis, lathyrism, and epidemic dropsy which are caused by deliberate food contamination or adulteration.

 

Food Adulteration Disease

questions.text: A 2-Year-old child is being screened for malnutrition at a health Centre with a MAC of 105 mm. What is his nutritional status? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Severe malnutrition

 

According to the criteria for Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM), there are four key criteria:

 

  • Weight for height less than minus three standard deviation
  • Visible bipedal edema
  • Visible severe wasting
  • Mid-upper arm circumference (MUAC) less than 115 millimeter

 

In this case, the child's MUAC is 105 mm, which is below the cutoff of 115 mm, indicating severe malnutrition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Normal nutrition: MUAC ≥ 13.5 cm indicates normal nutritional status, which can be managed at home

 

Option B. Mild malnutrition: Not applicable as per MUAC criteria

 

Option C. Moderate malnutrition: MUAC between 12.5-13.5 cm indicates moderate malnutrition requiring PHC management

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mid-upper arm circumference (MUAC) < 115 mm is one of the diagnostic criteria for severe acute malnutrition (SAM) in children.

choices.text: IPV is more efficacious in combating epidemics
IPV is simpler to administer
Only OPV is associated with paralysis

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct reason for why f-IPV is preferred over OPV? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Only OPV is associated with paralysis

 

The main reason for preferring fractionated IPV over OPV is that OPV has a significant risk of causing vaccine-associated paralytic polio (VAPP) and vaccine-derived poliovirus (VDPV). VAPP is specifically associated with poliovirus type 3, while VDPV is associated with poliovirus type 2 subtype C.  Injectable IPV, being an inactivated vaccine, does not carry this risk of paralysis.

 

Other Options: 


Option A. IPV is more efficacious in combating epidemics: Incorrect. OPV is actually more useful in controlling epidemics due to its ability to provide intestinal immunity.

 

Option B. IPV is more cost-effective: Incorrect. OPV is actually more cost-effective compared to IPV.

 

Option C. IPV is simpler to administer: Incorrect. OPV is actually simpler to administer as it is given in the form of drops, while IPV requires injection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The key advantage of IPV over OPV is its safety profile, specifically the absence of risk of vaccine-associated paralytic polio (VAPP) and vaccine-derived poliovirus (VDPV).

questions.text: After cataract surgery, a patient developed vision problems. OCT finding is shown below. This is associated with which syndrome? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Irvine-Gass syndrome

 

Explanation:

 

Irvine-Gass syndrome, is a well-known complication in which cystoid macular edema (CME occurs 4 to 6 weeks after cataract surgery. It is characterized by the development of cystoid spaces in the macula, which appear as hyporeflective spaces on Optical Coherence Tomography (OCT).

 

This syndrome is commonly associated with:

 

  • Post-cataract surgery patients, particularly those with pre-existing conditions like diabetes or uveitis or glaucoma patients on PG analogues.
  • Inflammatory mediators such as prostaglandins and cytokines are released post-surgery, leading to increased vascular permeability and leakage of fluid into the macular layers.
  • Fluorescein angiography (FFA) typically shows a petalloid pattern of hyperfluorescence due to leakage from perifoveal capillaries.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Central Serous Retinopathy (CSR):

 

  • CSR is characterized by serous detachment of the neurosensory retina at the macula due to increased choroidal permeability.
  • OCT shows serous elevation of the retina without cystic spaces, unlike the cystoid spaces in CME.
  • FFA typically shows an inkblot or smokestack pattern.

 

 

Option B. Elschnig Pearls:

 

  • These are seen in cases of posterior capsular opacification (PCO), which can occur months to years after cataract surgery.
  • This condition is seen on the posterior capsule of the lens bag and not on Retina
  • Patients complain of gradual, painless vision deterioration, unlike the acute onset of CME.

 

Option D. Posner-Schlossman Syndrome:

 

  • Also known as glaucomatocyclitic crisis, it is an inflammatory condition that presents with elevated intraocular pressure (IOP) and mild anterior uveitis.
  • It does not cause cystoid macular edema (CME) or changes seen in Irvine-Gass syndrome.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Irvine-Gass syndrome (cystoid macular edema) is a complication of cataract surgery that presents 4 to 6 weeks postoperatively. It is best diagnosed using OCT and treated with NSAIDs or steroids.

questions.text: Presence of different refractive powers (-2D in right eye and +1D in left eye) in a 6-year-old child with normal visual acuity and retinal findings on fundus examination, is suggestive of: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anisometropia

 

Explanation:

 

Anisometropia refers to a significant difference in refractive power between the two eyes. In this case:

 

  • The right eye has myopia (-2D).
  • The left eye has hypermetropia (+1D).
  • This meets the criteria for anisometropia, which is defined as a difference of at least 2.5 diopters between the two eyes.
  • A difference in refractive errors between both eyes leads to different image sizes (anisokonia).
  • If untreated, the brain may suppress the image from one eye, potentially leading to anisometropic amblyopia.
  • It can be corrected using glasses, contact lenses, or refractive surgery if needed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mixed Astigmatism:

 

  • In mixed astigmatism, both myopia and hypermetropia occur within the same eye, affecting different meridians.
  • This patient has different refractive errors in each eye, not within the same eye.

 

Option C. Myopia:

 

  • Myopia (near-sightedness) occurs when light focuses in front of the retina, causing blurred distance vision.
  • Since the left eye is hypermetropic, this case is not pure myopia.

 

Option D. Hypermetropia:

 

  • Hypermetropia (far-sightedness) occurs when light focuses behind the retina, making near vision more difficult.
  • Since the right eye is myopic, the child does not have bilateral hypermetropia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anisometropia is a condition where the two eyes have significantly different refractive errors, which can lead to amblyopia if untreated. Early correction with spectacles or contact lenses is essential to prevent visual impairment.

questions.text: Which of the following findings is not associated with Pancoast tumor? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Exophthalmos

 

Explanation:

 
Pancoast tumor (superior sulcus tumor) is a lung tumor at the apex that affects the sympathetic pathway leading to Horner's syndrome. The classic triad of Horner's syndrome includes ptosis (due to paralysis of Müller's muscle), miosis (due to paralysis of dilator pupillae), and anhidrosis (due to involvement of sweat glands). Patients exhibit apparent enophthalmos (not exophthalmos) due to the narrowing of the palpebral aperture from ptosis, making the eye appear sunken.

 

Other Options: 


Option B. Ptosis: Is a classic finding in Pancoast tumor due to involvement of sympathetic supply to Müller's muscle, causing 2mm of ptosis.

 

Option C. Anhidrosis: Is a characteristic finding due to involvement of sympathetic supply to sweat glands on the affected side.

 

Option D. Miosis: Is present due to unopposed parasympathetic action on the pupil following sympathetic denervation of the dilator pupillae.

 

Educational Objective:


Pancoast tumor can invade the sympathetic chain, causing Horner syndrome (ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis). However, it does NOT cause exophthalmos, which is more commonly seen in conditions like thyroid eye disease or orbital tumors

questions.text: The mother of a 5-month-old child complains that the child’s upper eyelid moves up and down during breastfeeding. This disappears when the baby is not being fed. What can be the likely cause? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Marcus Gunn jaw-winking syndrome

 

Explanation: 


Marcus Gunn jaw-winking syndrome is characterized by an abnormal connection between the 3rd and 5th cranial nerve nuclei. The levator palpebrae superioris (normally supplied by CN III) receives aberrant innervation from the pterygoid muscles (supplied by CN V). This results in synkinetic movement of the upper eyelid during jaw movements like sucking, chewing, or speaking. Treatment involves complete disinsertion of the levator muscle (to prevent the synkinetic movements) followed by frontalis sling surgery (for correction of Ptosis).

 

 

Other Options: 


Option A. 3rd cranial nerve palsy: Results in complete ptosis without any movement. There is no correlation with jaw movements.

 

Option B. Lagophthalmos: Refers to inability to close the eyes completely, typically seen in facial nerve palsy. Does not involve synkinetic movements with jaw activity.

 

Option D. Myasthenia gravis: An autoimmune disorder affecting acetylcholine receptors. Shows progressive ptosis throughout the day without correlation to jaw movements. Responds to ice pack test and edrophonium (Tensilon) test.

 

Educational Objective: 


Marcus Gunn jaw-winking syndrome as a congenital synkinetic movement of the upper eyelid during jaw activity due to misdirection between CN III and CN V.

questions.text: Cover-uncover test can be used in all conditions EXCEPT: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Visual acuity & Amblyopia

 

Explanation: 


The cover-uncover test is a clinical examination technique used to detect and assess strabismus (ocular misalignment). It is particularly useful for both manifest squint (tropia) and latent squint (phoria), as well as latent nystagmus. However, it has no role in assessing visual acuity or diagnosing amblyopia.

 

In the cover-uncover test, when examining a patient with tropia (manifest squint), first a cover test is performed where the normal eye is covered to observe if the squinting eye takes up fixation. Then, in the cover-uncover test, the cover is removed to observe the movement of the previously covered eye (secondary deviation).

 

For phoria (latent squint), the cover-uncover test is used to break fusion and reveal the hidden misalignment. When one eye is covered, fusion is disrupted, and upon uncovering, the eye movement can be observed as the eyes attempt to regain fusion.

 

In latent nystagmus, covering one eye can induce or intensify nystagmus, which can be observed when the cover is removed.



 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Latent nystagmus: Incorrect. The cover-uncover test is useful for diagnosing latent nystagmus. When one eye is covered in patients with latent nystagmus, the uncovered eye may exhibit nystagmus (eye dancing movement) that was not visible when both eyes were open. The test helps reveal this hidden nystagmus.

 

Option B. Latent squint: Incorrect. The cover-uncover test is specifically designed to detect latent squint (phoria). In phoria, both eyes appear straight when open, but when fusion is disrupted by covering one eye, the hidden misalignment is revealed. Upon uncovering, the eye movement that occurs to regain fusion can be observed.

 

Option C. Manifest squint: Incorrect. For manifest squint (tropia), the cover test is initially performed by covering the normal eye to observe if the squinting eye takes up fixation. Then, the cover-uncover test is used to assess the secondary deviation as the cover is removed from the normal eye. This helps differentiate between different types of tropias.

 

Educational Objective: 


The cover-uncover test is a clinical examination technique used to detect and assess strabismus (ocular misalignment) including manifest squint (tropia), latent squint (phoria), and latent nystagmus, but it has no role in assessing visual acuity or diagnosing amblyopia.

questions.text: Which nerve is responsible for eliciting the corneal reflex during the corneal wisp test? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Trigeminal nerve

 

Explanation:


The corneal reflex (also known as the blink reflex) is a protective mechanism that causes involuntary blinking when the cornea is touched. This reflex involves both sensory and motor components. During a corneal wisp test, a cotton wisp or similar object is brought in from the side (to avoid eliciting a visual reflex) and gently touches the cornea.

 

The trigeminal nerve (cranial nerve V) serves as the afferent (sensory) pathway for this reflex. Specifically, the ophthalmic division (V1) of the trigeminal nerve carries the sensory information from the cornea when it is stimulated. The sensory information is then processed, and an efferent (motor) response is generated via the facial nerve (cranial nerve VII), which innervates the orbicularis oculi muscle, resulting in the blink.

 

The corneal sensitivity can be tested more precisely using an instrument called an aesthesiometer, which measures the minimal stimulus required to elicit the blink reflex. Corneal sensation is characteristically decreased in viral corneal ulcers, making this test diagnostically valuable.



 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oculomotor nerve: Incorrect. The oculomotor nerve (cranial nerve III) is responsible for most eye movements by controlling four of the six extraocular muscles (superior rectus, inferior rectus, medial rectus, and inferior oblique). It also innervates the levator palpebrae superioris muscle (responsible for eyelid elevation) and carries parasympathetic fibers that control pupillary constriction and lens accommodation. It has no role in corneal sensation or the blink reflex pathway.

 

Option C. Abducens nerve: Incorrect. The abducens nerve (cranial nerve VI) innervates the lateral rectus muscle, which is responsible for abduction of the eye (moving the eye outward, away from the nose). It has no sensory function and does not participate in the corneal reflex pathway.

 

Option D. Facial nerve: Incorrect, but partially involved in the reflex arc. While the facial nerve (cranial nerve VII) is involved in the corneal reflex, it serves as the efferent (motor) pathway, not the afferent pathway. The facial nerve innervates the orbicularis oculi muscle, which causes the eyelid to close during blinking. The question specifically asks about the nerve responsible for "eliciting" the reflex, which refers to the sensory component (trigeminal nerve), not the motor response.

 

Educational Objective: 


The corneal reflex is mediated by the trigeminal nerve (cranial nerve V) as the afferent (sensory) pathway and the facial nerve (cranial nerve VII) as the efferent (motor) pathway.

questions.text: In a patient, a flying foreign body injured his eye. This led to heterochromia iridis. Ocular findings showed iris pigmentation. Which substance is responsible for the deposition in his eye? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Iron

 

Explanation:


Heterochromia iridis refers to a difference in color between the two irises or different parts of the same iris. In this case, the heterochromia is acquired due to an intraocular foreign body injury. The pigmentation of the iris associated with a metallic foreign body is characteristic of siderosis bulbi, which is caused by iron deposition.

 

Siderosis bulbi occurs when an iron-containing foreign body remains in the eye for a prolonged period. The iron gradually dissolves and deposits throughout the ocular tissues, including the corneal endothelium, iris, lens, and retina. This deposition gives the affected iris a darker, rusty-brown appearance compared to the normal eye, resulting in heterochromia.

 

The most common scenario for such injuries is a "chisel and hammer" accident, where a person is striking metal with a hammer, causing metal fragments to fly off at high velocity and penetrate the eye. If the patient does not seek immediate medical attention, the retained intraocular foreign body can lead to progressive damage through iron toxicity.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Glass: Incorrect. Glass is relatively inert when retained within the eye and does not cause significant tissue reaction or pigmentation changes. It doesn't dissolve to release substances that would cause heterochromia iridis. While glass foreign bodies should be removed if possible, they don't cause the characteristic pigmentation changes seen with iron.

 

Option C. Wood: Incorrect. Wood foreign bodies typically cause severe inflammatory reactions and potential infections rather than pigmentation changes. Wood is organic and tends to harbor microorganisms, leading to endophthalmitis or orbital cellulitis. It would not cause the heterochromia iridis.

 

Option D. Aluminum: Incorrect. While aluminum is a metal, it is relatively inert compared to iron and copper. Aluminum foreign bodies do not typically cause the extensive pigmentation seen in siderosis bulbi. They can cause a local inflammatory reaction but do not dissolve and distribute throughout the eye to cause widespread tissue staining and heterochromia.

 

Educational Objective: 


Iron-containing intraocular foreign bodies cause siderosis bulbi, a condition characterized by iron deposition throughout ocular tissues, resulting in heterochromia iridis and potential damage to various eye structures.

questions.text: A person experiences proptosis when he bends down. This can be due to: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Orbital varices

 

Explanation:


Proptosis (forward protrusion of the eyeball) that occurs or worsens when a person bends down and resolves when standing upright is a characteristic presentation of orbital varices. Orbital varices are venous malformations consisting of dilated, thin-walled vessels that distend when venous pressure increases, such as during Valsalva maneuver or when the head is in a dependent position (bending down).

 

When the patient bends forward, gravity and increased venous pressure cause the varicose veins to fill with blood and expand, pushing the eyeball forward and resulting in temporary proptosis. When the patient returns to an upright position, the venous pressure normalizes, the varices deflate, and the proptosis resolves.

 

This positional or intermittent nature of the proptosis is a key diagnostic feature of orbital varices, distinguishing it from other causes of proptosis that present with constant or fixed protrusion of the eyeball.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Orbital cellulitis: Incorrect. Orbital cellulitis is an acute infection of the orbital tissues posterior to the orbital septum. It presents with sudden onset of painful proptosis, restricted ocular motility, conjunctival chemosis, and often systemic symptoms like fever. The proptosis in orbital cellulitis is fixed and does not vary with position or Valsalva maneuver. It is typically accompanied by signs of inflammation such as redness, warmth, and tenderness of the eyelids.

 

Option C. Thyroid eye disease: Incorrect. Thyroid eye disease (TED) is the most common cause of proptosis in adults. It is an autoimmune inflammatory disorder associated with dysfunction of the thyroid gland. The proptosis in TED is persistent and bilateral (though often asymmetric), rather than positional or intermittent. It is characterized by lid retraction, restricted extraocular movements, and exposure keratopathy. The proptosis in TED does not vary with position changes or Valsalva maneuver.

 

Option D. Cavernous sinus thrombosis: Incorrect. Cavernous sinus thrombosis is a serious and potentially life-threatening condition caused by infection or thrombosis of the cavernous sinus. It typically presents with bilateral proptosis, severe headache, fever, and ophthalmoplegia due to involvement of cranial nerves III, IV, VI, and V1 that pass through the cavernous sinus. The proptosis is fixed and progressive rather than positional or intermittent, and it is accompanied by other signs of inflammation and cranial nerve dysfunction.

 

Educational Objective: 


Orbital varices cause position-dependent proptosis that worsens when bending forward or during Valsalva maneuver due to increased venous pressure causing distension of the abnormal vessels.

choices.text: Erect and real image is formed
Need to keep condenser close to patient’s eye

questions.text: Which of the following is correct regarding Indirect Ophthalmoscopy? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 3-5x magnification is provided

 

Explanation:


Indirect ophthalmoscopy is a technique used to examine the fundus of the eye from a distance, typically at arm's length. It provides a stereoscopic (three-dimensional) view of the retina with a wide field of view, allowing visualization up to the ora serrata (peripheral retina). One of its key characteristics is the lower magnification compared to direct ophthalmoscopy.

 

Indirect ophthalmoscopy provides approximately 3-5x magnification of the fundus. This lower magnification is a trade-off for the wider field of view that it offers. The 20 diopter lens is most commonly used for indirect ophthalmoscopy, and the examination is typically performed with the patient in a lying position.

 

The indirect ophthalmoscope consists of a head-mounted light source and a handheld condensing lens (usually 20D). This setup creates an inverted and reverted real image between the observer and the condensing lens, providing binocular vision and excellent stereopsis, which helps in detecting elevations and depressions in the retina.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Erect and real image is formed: Incorrect. In indirect ophthalmoscopy, an inverted and real image is formed. This is in contrast to direct ophthalmoscopy, which produces an erect and virtual image. The inverted nature of the image in indirect ophthalmoscopy requires the examiner to mentally reorient the image for proper interpretation.

 

Option B. Need to keep condenser close to patient's eye: Incorrect. In indirect ophthalmoscopy, the examiner stays at a distance (around arm's length) from the patient, and the condensing lens is held approximately 1-2 inches in front of the patient's eye. This is in contrast to direct ophthalmoscopy, where the examiner needs to be close to the patient's eye (approximately 2-3 cm).

 

Option C. 15x magnification is provided: Incorrect. Direct ophthalmoscopy provides approximately 15x magnification, not indirect ophthalmoscopy. The higher magnification in direct ophthalmoscopy allows for detailed examination of small structures but limits the field of view compared to indirect ophthalmoscopy.

 

Educational Objective:


Indirect ophthalmoscopy provides a wide field of view with lower magnification (3-5x) compared to direct ophthalmoscopy, forming an inverted and real image that allows examination of the peripheral retina up to the ora serrata with good stereopsis.

questions.text: A patient presents with right-sided defect in both eyes with central sparing. What can be the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing

 

Explanation: 


The patient presents with a right-sided visual field defect in both eyes with central (macular) sparing. This pattern is characteristic of a homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing, which is caused by a lesion in the posterior cerebral artery (PCA) territory affecting the occipital cortex.

 

Homonymous means "same-sided," referring to the fact that the same side of the visual field is affected in both eyes (in this case, the right side). The term hemianopia indicates that approximately half of the visual field is lost. The macular sparing (preservation of central vision) occurs because the macular representation in the occipital cortex often has dual blood supply from both the posterior and middle cerebral arteries, making it less vulnerable to a single vascular insult.

 

This visual field defect is typically caused by a left occipital lobe lesion, as visual pathways cross at the optic chiasm, resulting in contralateral field defects. The most common cause is a posterior cerebral artery (PCA) occlusion or embolism affecting the occipital lobe.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Optic tract lesion: Incorrect. Optic tract lesions also produce homonymous hemianopia, but they typically do not spare the macula. Additionally, optic tract lesions often cause incongruous defects (slightly different patterns in each eye) and may be associated with relative afferent pupillary defect. The defects from optic tract lesions tend to be less symmetric between the two eyes compared to occipital cortex lesions.

 

Option C. Optic chiasma lesion: Incorrect. Lesions at the optic chiasm typically produce bitemporal hemianopia (loss of the temporal visual fields in both eyes) due to compression of the crossing nasal retinal fibers. This pattern is described as a heteronymous hemianopia, not a homonymous one. Common causes include pituitary adenomas, craniopharyngiomas, or meningiomas. Chiasmal lesions do not produce the right-sided defect in both eyes.

 

Option D. Heteronymous hemianopia with central sparing: Incorrect. Heteronymous hemianopia refers to visual field defects on opposite sides in the two eyes (e.g., right temporal and left nasal, which is bitemporal hemianopia; or right nasal and left temporal, which is binasal hemianopia). This pattern is typically seen with lesions affecting the optic chiasm or the immediate pre- or post-chiasmal pathways. 

 

Educational Objective: 


Homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing is characterized by loss of the same half of the visual field in both eyes with preservation of central vision, typically resulting from an occipital lobe lesion in the territory of the posterior cerebral artery (contralateral to the field defect).

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presented with epiphora. Probing revealed a soft block at 7 mm. This can be treated by: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Conjunctival DCR

 

Explanation: 

 

Epiphora refers to the overflow of tears onto the face due to inadequate drainage. In this case, probing revealed a blockage at the 7 mm mark of the lacrimal drainage system. 

 

The lacrimal drainage system begins at the punctum and continues through the canaliculus, which has a 2 mm vertical segment followed by an 8 mm horizontal segment. The canaliculi then join to form a common canaliculus before entering the lacrimal sac. The total distance from the punctum to the lacrimal sac is approximately 10 mm.

 

Since the block is at 7 mm, it is located within the horizontal portion of the canaliculus, before reaching the lacrimal sac. When the obstruction is in the canaliculus itself, neither external DCR nor endoscopic DCR would be effective because these procedures address nasolacrimal duct obstruction, not canalicular obstruction.

 

Conjunctival DCR (also known as conjunctivodacryocystorhinostomy or CDCR) is the appropriate procedure, as it bypasses the obstructed canalicular system entirely by creating a new passage directly from the conjunctival sac to the nasal cavity. This is typically done using a Jones tube, which is a glass or silicone tube that connects the medial canthus to the middle meatus of the nose.



 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Extranasal DCR: Incorrect. External dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR) is a procedure that creates a new pathway between the lacrimal sac and the nasal cavity by removing the bone between them. It is indicated when the obstruction is in the nasolacrimal duct, not in the canaliculus. Since the block in this case is at 7 mm (within the canaliculus), an external DCR would not address the site of obstruction.

 

Option B. Endoscopic DCR: Incorrect. Endoscopic DCR, like external DCR, creates a passage between the lacrimal sac and nasal cavity, but it is performed using an endoscope through the nasal cavity without an external incision. It is also used for nasolacrimal duct obstructions, not canalicular obstructions. Since the block in this case is in the canaliculus, endoscopic DCR would not be effective.

 

Option D. Dacryocystectomy: Incorrect. Dacryocystectomy involves the surgical removal of the lacrimal sac. It is typically performed in cases of chronic dacryocystitis with an atonic (non-functioning) lacrimal sac or in certain lacrimal sac tumors. This procedure completely eliminates the tear drainage system without providing an alternative drainage pathway, resulting in permanent epiphora. It is not appropriate for a canalicular obstruction in a young child were preserving or creating a functional drainage system is the goal.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Canalicular obstructions (as evidenced by a block at 7 mm from the punctum) are treated with conjunctival DCR (CDCR) using a Jones tube, which bypasses the obstructed lacrimal drainage system by creating a direct connection between the conjunctival sac and the nasal cavity.

questions.text: What is the side effect of PG analogue Latanoprost? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hyperemia

 

Explanation: 

 

Prostaglandin (PG) analogues are commonly used first-line medications for glaucoma treatment. The most characteristic side effect of these medications is hyperemia, which is redness or inflammation of the conjunctiva. This occurs because prostaglandin analogues are inflammatory mediators that can cause local vascular changes and conjunctival irritation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Orbital cellulitis: Incorrect. PG analogues do not cause orbital cellulitis, which is an infection of the orbital tissues.

 

Option C. Uveitis: Incorrect. While PG analogues are contraindicated in patients with existing uveitis (as they might worsen the condition), they do not directly cause uveitis by themselves. They are, in fact, very rarely associated with uveitis as a side effect.

 

Option D. Keratitis: Incorrect. Similar to uveitis, PG analogues are contraindicated in patients with existing keratitis, but they do not directly cause keratitis. Patients with pre-existing keratitis might find their condition worsened, but the medication itself does not induce keratitis.

 

Educational Objective: 


Latanoprost, a prostaglandin analogue used for glaucoma, commonly causes conjunctival hyperemia, iris pigmentation changes, and eyelash growth. Hyperemia is the most frequently reported side effect.

questions.text: Till how many hours, eye donation is viable? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 6 hrs

 

Explanation: 

 

In tropical countries, eye donation is viable for 6 hours from the time of death. During this critical time window, the cornea can be harvested for transplantation. 

 

  • Keep the entire eyeball or corneal-scleral button covered 
  • Short-term preservation: Moist chamber storage (up to 48 hours).
  • Medium-term preservation: McCarey-Kaufman (MK) medium or Optisol-GS (up to 7-14 days).
  • Long-term preservation: Organ culture or cryopreservation

 

Storage:

 

Educational Objective:


Eye donation is viable for 6 hours after death, and proper preservation techniques are crucial to maintain corneal tissue quality.

  • Time duration:
    1. In a tropical country – 4-6 hrs
    2. Colder countries – 12-24 hrs
  • Depends on the health of the donor cornea
  • Entire eyeball is retrieved and kept in a moist chamber for transportation to the eye bank
  • In the eye bank-corneoscleral button is cut and preserved
  • Most common organ transplant, no blood grouping matching or HLA matching is required

choices.text: Measles vaccine and Vitamin A supplementation

questions.text: An unvaccinated 4-year-old child presents with rashes, fever, and Bitot spot. This can be managed appropriately by: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Isolation and Vitamin A supplementation

 

Explanation: 


When a child presents with measles (characterized by rashes, fever, and Bitot spots), the management involves two critical components:

 

  1. Isolation: Measles is highly contagious, so the child must be isolated to prevent spread to other individuals, especially those who are unvaccinated or immunocompromised.
  2. Vitamin A Supplementation: Vitamin A is crucial in managing measles because:
    • It reduces the severity of the disease
    • Decreases complications
    • Helps reduce mortality, especially in children with vitamin A deficiency
    • Supports immune system function during the infection

 

Other Options: 


Option B. Supportive care only: Incorrect. While supportive care is important, it is insufficient. Vitamin A supplementation is a critical intervention in measles management.

 

Option C. Measles vaccine and Vitamin A supplementation: Incorrect. Once a child has active measles, vaccination is no longer beneficial. The vaccine is preventive, not a treatment for ongoing infection.

 

Option D. Measles vaccine only: Incorrect. A child with active measles cannot be vaccinated during the acute phase of the illness. Vaccination is ineffective and potentially harmful at this stage.

 

Educational Objective: 


In active measles infection, isolation and Vitamin A supplementation are the key management strategies, with Vitamin A playing a crucial role in reducing disease severity and complications.

questions.text: Eyelid crusting and gritty sensation between the lids is associated with: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Chronic blepharitis

 

Explanation: 


Chronic blepharitis is a persistent inflammation of the eyelids characterized by:

 

  • Eyelid crusting (dried secretions along the eyelid margins)
  • Gritty sensation between the eyelids
  • Chronic discharge
  • Inflammation of the lid margins

 

The typical management includes:

 

  1. Oral doxycycline (100 mg twice daily)
  2. Topical antibiotics
  3. Lid hygiene: 
    • Cleaning lids with mild detergents (e.g., Johnson's baby shampoo)
    • Using hypochlorous solution
    • Frequent lid cleaning to remove crusts and debris

 

 

Other Options:


Option A. Conjunctivitis: Incorrect. While conjunctivitis can cause eye discomfort, it typically presents with more pronounced redness, discharge, and does not specifically cause eyelid crusting.

 

Option B. Dry eye syndrome: Incorrect. Dry eye syndrome causes discomfort and a gritty sensation, but does not typically result in significant eyelid crusting.

 

Option C. Meibomian gland dysfunction: Partially related, but not the most comprehensive answer. While meibomian gland dysfunction can contribute to blepharitis, chronic blepharitis encompasses a broader inflammatory condition of the eyelids.

 

Educational Objective: 


Chronic blepharitis is characterized by persistent eyelid inflammation, manifesting as crusting and a gritty sensation, requiring comprehensive management including oral antibiotics, topical treatments, and rigorous lid hygiene.

questions.text: Calculate Amplitude in case of near vision of 20 cm and far point of infinity. (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 5D

 

Explanation:


To calculate the amplitude of accommodation, we use the formula:

 

Amplitude = 1/Near Point (in meters)

 

Calculation steps:

 

  1. Convert 20 cm to meters: 20 cm = 0.2 meters
  2. Apply the formula: 1/0.2 = 5 diopters

 

When the far point is at infinity (no refractive error), the amplitude is simply calculated by taking the inverse of the near point distance in meters.

 

Educational Objective: 


The amplitude of accommodation using the formula: 1/Near Point (in meters), with the far point at infinity resulting in a direct inverse calculation of the near point distance.

questions.text: A patient suffered a blunt trauma to the eye 6 months ago. He now complains of blurred vision. On examination, the following finding is seen. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Iridodialysis

 

Explanation:


 Iridodialysis is a specific type of traumatic eye injury characterized by:

 

  • Separation of the iris from its root (ciliary body attachment)
  • Typically caused by blunt trauma
  • Results in a D-shaped pupil
  • Occurs due to direct mechanical force disrupting the iris attachment

 

Other potential traumatic eye findings include:

 

  • Sphincter tear
  • Hyphema (blood in anterior chamber)
  • Traumatic cataract
  • Vossius ring (iron deposition on anterior lens capsule)

 

 

  • Retinal or zonular dialysis

 

 

Other Options: 


Option B. Vossius ring: Incorrect. While a Vossius ring is a traumatic finding (pigment deposition on anterior lens capsule), it does not explain the D-shaped pupil or significant structural change described in the question.

 

 

Option C. Cycloiriditis: Incorrect. This refers to inflammation of the ciliary body and iris, which is not specifically associated with blunt trauma or a D-shaped pupil.

 

Option D. Ankyloblepharon: Incorrect. This is an adhesion of the upper and lower eyelids, which is not related to the described traumatic finding or D-shaped pupil.



 

Educational Objective:


Iridodialysis is a specific traumatic eye injury characterized by separation of the iris from its root, typically resulting from blunt force trauma and presenting with a distinctive D-shaped pupil.

questions.text: Which metabolic product is responsible for causing cataract in a patient with a long-standing history of diabetes? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sorbitol

 

Explanation: 

 

In patients with long-standing diabetes, excess glucose metabolism leads to cataract formation through the sorbitol pathway:

 

  1. Excess glucose is converted to sorbitol by the enzyme aldose reductase
  2. Normally, sorbitol would be further metabolized to fructose, but in diabetes: 
    • The lens lacks sufficient sorbitol dehydrogenase enzyme
    • Sorbitol accumulates inside the lens
    • Causes osmotic stress and water accumulation
    • Leads to membrane damage and cataract formation

 

The mechanism involves:

 

  • Accumulation of sorbitol
  • Increased osmotic pressure
  • Fluid collection in lens
  • Structural damage to lens proteins

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Galactitol: Incorrect. While similar to sorbitol, galactitol is not the primary metabolic product causing diabetic cataracts.

 

Option B. Fructose: Incorrect. Fructose is a potential end product of sorbitol metabolism, not the primary cause of diabetic cataract formation.

 

Option D. Mannitol: Incorrect. Mannitol is a sugar alcohol used as a diuretic, not involved in the diabetic cataract formation process.

 

Educational Objective: 


Diabetes, sorbitol accumulation in the lens due to insufficient enzyme activity leads to osmotic stress and cataract formation through the aldose reductase pathway.

questions.text: A patient presents with a history of trauma and the following radiological image. What is the most probable diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Blow Out Fracture

 

Explanation: 

 

A blow out fracture is characterized by:

 

  • Tear drop sign on radiological imaging
  • Fracture of the orbital floor
  • Herniation of contents into the maxillary sinus
  • Typically results from blunt trauma

 

Clinical findings include:

 

  • Restriction of upward gaze
  • Diplopia in up gaze
  • Decreased sensation in infraorbital cheek area
  • Potential enophthalmos (sunken eye)

 

Diagnostic confirmation is done through:

 

  • Forced duction test (FDT) to differentiate restrictive from paralytic pathology

 

Other Options: 


Option A. Orbital Lateral Wall Fracture : Incorrect. Does not match the characteristic tear drop sign of floor fracture.

 

Option B. Orbital Medial Wall Fracture : Incorrect. Location does not correspond to the radiological findings.

 

Option D. Orbital Cellulitis : Incorrect. This is an inflammatory condition, not a traumatic fracture.

 

Educational Objective: 


Recognize the radiological tear drop sign as a key indicator of an orbital floor blow out fracture following blunt trauma.

questions.text: A child presents with Patent Ductus Arteriosus, Cataract, and Salt & Pepper Retinopathy. This is suggestive of which intrauterine infection? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Rubella

 

Explanation: 

 

Congenital Rubella Syndrome is characterized by the classic triad:

 

  • C: Cataract (nuclear pearly or lamellar)
  • H: Heart disease (Patent Ductus Arteriosus)
  • D: Deafness

 

Additional specific findings include:

 

  • Salt and pepper retinopathy
  • Micro-ophthalmia
  • Potential glaucoma
  • Characteristic nuclear pearly cataract

 

The syndrome results from maternal rubella infection during pregnancy, particularly in the first trimester.
 

 

Other Options: 


Option A. Toxoplasma: Incorrect. While it can cause congenital infections, it does not match the specific triad described.

 

  • Toxoplasma triad: Intracranial calcification, chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus

 

Option B. Varicella: Incorrect. Does not cause the described constellation of symptoms.

 

Option D. Cytomegalovirus: Incorrect. While it can cause congenital infections, the specific triad is not consistent with CMV.

 

Educational Objective: 


Classic CHD (Cataract, Heart disease, Deafness) triad of Congenital Rubella Syndrome, with salt and pepper retinopathy as a characteristic finding.

choices.text: Peak systolic velocity in the fetal middle cerebral artery (MCA)

questions.text: A 29-year-old pregnant woman at 28 weeks of gestation is undergoing routine obstetric evaluation. She has a history of Rh incompatibility, and recent laboratory results show the presence of elevated maternal anti-D antibody titers. The obstetrician is concerned about possible fetal anemia. Which of the following methods is most commonly used to assess fetal anemia in this situation? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Peak systolic velocity in the fetal middle cerebral artery (MCA)

 

Explanation:

 

Fetal anemia in Rh-incompatible pregnancies is primarily assessed using Doppler ultrasound of the fetal middle cerebral artery (MCA). The peak systolic velocity (PSV) of the MCA increases in response to anemia due to a brain-sparing effect, where blood flow is redistributed to essential organs like the brain.

 

  • When maternal anti-D titers are elevated, the fetus is monitored using MCA Doppler ultrasonography.
  • If the MCA-PSV is >1.5 multiples of the median (MoM) for gestational age, this suggests moderate-to-severe fetal anemia.
  • If significant anemia is suspected, cordocentesis (cord blood sampling) may be performed for direct measurement of fetal hemoglobin levels and possible intrauterine transfusion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cord blood sampling (Cordocentesis):
