  • This is the gold standard for diagnosing fetal anemia but is an invasive procedure associated with risks like preterm labor and fetal loss. It is only performed when MCA Doppler findings suggest severe anemia.

 

Option B. Chorionic villus sampling (CVS):

 

  • This is used primarily for chromosomal and genetic analysis in the first trimester.
  • It has no role in detecting fetal anemia.

 

Option D. Umbilical artery Doppler:

 

  • This is used in cases of intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR) to assess placental insufficiency.
  • It is not useful for detecting fetal anemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The peak systolic velocity of the fetal middle cerebral artery (MCA-PSV) is the most commonly used non-invasive method to assess fetal anemia in cases of Rh incompatibility. A value greater than 1.5 MoM indicates moderate-to-severe anemia, warranting further invasive testing like cordocentesis.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman with a history of breast cancer treated with radiation therapy presents to the emergency department with progressive shortness of breath and a non-productive cough for the past 3 weeks. A chest X-ray reveals a hazy opacification over the left lung field. What is the most likely diagnosis?  (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Radiation pneumonitis

 

Explanation:

 

Radiation pneumonitis is the most likely diagnosis. This condition typically develops 3-12 weeks after radiation therapy. The features supporting this diagnosis are:

 

  • History of radiation therapy for breast cancer
  • Progressive shortness of breath and non-productive cough
  • Chest X-ray showing hazy opacification in the left lung field (corresponding to the radiation field near the breast)
  • Timing of symptoms (3 weeks post-radiation): If left untreated, radiation pneumonitis can progress to radiation-induced fibrosis after several years.

 

Early (Acute) Radiation Pneumonitis:

 

  • Occurs 3-12 weeks post-radiation therapy
  • Caused by direct radiation damage to lung tissue leading to inflammation
  • Symptoms include: 
    • Progressive dyspnea
    • Non-productive cough
    • Sometimes low-grade fever
  • Radiological findings: 
    • Hazy opacification confined to the radiation port
    • Often shows a straight edge corresponding to radiation field
    • May show ground-glass appearance

 

Late (Chronic) Radiation Pneumonitis:

 

  • Develops 6-12 months after radiation
  • Can progress to radiation fibrosis
  • Shows permanent scarring and volume loss in affected area

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pulmonary embolism:

 

  • More acute onset of sudden dyspnea, often with pleuritic chest pain and possibly hemoptysis.
  • Usually diagnosed via CT pulmonary angiography rather than chest X-ray.

 

Option B. Infective pneumonia:

 

  • Presents with productive cough, fever, leukocytosis.
  • Chest X-ray may show lobar consolidation, rather than hazy opacification.

 

Option D. Lung metastasis:

 

  • Typically presents as multiple nodular lesions on chest imaging.
  • Less likely to cause progressive dyspnea and non-productive cough alone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Radiation pneumonitis is a delayed inflammatory reaction to radiation therapy, presenting with progressive dyspnea, non-productive cough, and localized hazy opacification on imaging. Diagnosis is clinical and radiologic, and treatment involves corticosteroids to reduce inflammation.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with progressive dysphagia that is more pronounced for liquids than solids. He reports occasional regurgitation of undigested food and has significant weight loss over the past few months. A barium swallow study is performed. Which radiological sign is most likely to be observed? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Rat-tail sign

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical presentation strongly suggests achalasia cardia, a primary motility disorder of the esophagus. 

 

  • Dysphagia more pronounced for liquids than solids (characteristic of achalasia)
  • The pattern is explained by the pathophysiology: liquids lack the mass and gravity effect to push through the non-relaxing lower esophageal sphincter, while solids can generate more pressure to pass through
  • Regurgitation of undigested food
  • Weight loss due to feeding difficulties 
  • The bird beak sign, showing a smooth, symmetrical tapering of the distal esophagus, is the classic radiological finding in achalasia on barium swallow. 
  • The rat tail sign, often used for carcinoma esophagus has also been described for achalasia. 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Corkscrew esophagus: This appearance is seen in diffuse esophageal spasm, a different motility disorder with intermittent dysphagia.

 

Option B. Apple-core lesion: This is typically seen in colonic carcinoma, appearing as a symmetric narrowing with overhanging edges. It's not associated with esophageal disorders.

 

Option C. String sign: This is typically seen in CHPS in the pylorus and TB and Chron’s disease in the ileum and represents narrowing. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

In achalasia, dysphagia is characteristically worse for liquids than solids due to the underlying motility disorder affecting lower esophageal sphincter relaxation, with bird beak sign and rat tail sign being the characteristic radiological finding on barium swallow.

questions.text: The imaging shows a detailed cross-sectional view of the esophageal wall and surrounding structures. What is the primary use of this imaging modality? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Staging of esophageal cancer

 

Explanation:

 

  • Endoscopic ultrasound (EUS) is primarily used for staging esophageal cancer, particularly for T (tumor) and N (nodal) staging. Its high-resolution imaging capabilities allow detailed visualization of the esophageal wall layers and surrounding lymph nodes. However, for M (metastasis) staging, PET-CT remains the investigation of choice, as is true for most cancers.

 

Additional uses of EUS include:

 

  • Assessment of pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors, particularly gastrinomas in the duodenum
  • Evaluation of biliary microlithiasis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Identifying the cause of dysphagia: While EUS can visualize esophageal structures, it's not the primary tool for diagnosing causes of dysphagia. Standard endoscopy and barium studies are more commonly used for this purpose.

 

Option C. Assessing cardiac and aortic pathology: This is done using transesophageal echocardiography (TEE), which is a different procedure where the ultrasound probe faces anteriorly to examine the heart, rather than examining the esophageal wall itself.

 

Option D. Evaluation of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD): 24-hour pH monitoring is the standard test for GERD evaluation. EUS is not routinely used for this purpose.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Endoscopic ultrasound is the investigation of choice for T and N staging of esophageal cancer, while PET-CT is used for M staging.

questions.text: Identify the X-ray shown below: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pulmonary edema

 

Explanation:

 

Pulmonary edema is characterized by the bat-wing appearance on chest X-ray, which consists of bilateral perihilar opacities with a central distribution. This pattern is due to fluid accumulation in the lung interstitium and alveoli, commonly seen in cardiogenic pulmonary edema.

 

Typical X-ray findings of pulmonary edema include:

 

  • Bilateral perihilar opacities (bat-wing distribution)
  • Kerley B lines (horizontal lines indicating interstitial edema)
  • Cardiomegaly (if due to heart failure)
  • Pleural effusions in severe cases

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pleural Effusion: Characterized by blunting of the costophrenic angles and a meniscus sign due to fluid accumulation in the pleural space.

 

Option B. Pulmonary Fibrosis: Shows reticular opacities in the lower lung zones, often with honeycombing and volume loss. It does not have a central perihilar distribution.

 

Option D. Hydrothorax: Similar to pleural effusion, hydrothorax refers to fluid accumulation in the pleural space, seen as homogeneous opacity with a fluid level

​

Educational Objective:

 

Pulmonary edema presents with a bat-wing appearance on chest X-ray, characterized by bilateral perihilar opacities, Kerley B lines, and signs of interstitial fluid accumulation.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man presents with severe abdominal distension, pain, and absolute constipation for the past two days. Physical examination reveals a distended, tympanic abdomen. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sigmoid volvulus

 

Explanation: 


The case presents classical features of sigmoid volvulus, which is confirmed by the radiological findings showing:

 

  • Classic "coffee bean" sign - two dilated bowel loops without haustra
  • Common in elderly patients
  • Presents with severe abdominal distension and constipation The diagnosis is supported by typical patient demographics (elderly) and clinical presentation (constipation, distension). Sigmoid volvulus is the most common type of colonic volvulus, particularly in older patients with chronic constipation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Small bowel volvulus: Shows different radiological pattern with "step ladder" appearance of dilated small bowel loops. Small bowel shows complete mucosal folds (valvulae connivence’s), unlike the pattern seen here.

 

 

Option B. Intestinal obstruction: While present here, this is a general term. The specific type (sigmoid volvulus) can be identified by the characteristic radiological appearance. Small bowel obstruction shows complete mucosal folds, while large bowel obstruction shows haustra.

 

Option D. Caecal volvulus: Shows a single dilated loop with haustral pattern forming a "C" sign, unlike the double-loop "coffee bean" appearance seen in sigmoid volvulus. Cecal volvulus is less common than sigmoid volvulus.

 

 

Educational Objective: 


Sigmoid volvulus presents with the characteristic "coffee bean" sign on X-ray (two dilated loops without haustra) and typically occurs in elderly patients with chronic constipation.



Sigmoid Volvulus vs Cecal Volvulus

questions.text: A 24-year-old male, previously diagnosed with a psychiatric disorder, has become aggressive with his neighbors, is speaking rapidly, and is sleeping very little. He also exhibits hyperactive behavior after discontinuing his prescribed medication. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bipolar disorder (manic episode)

 

The patient presents with classical symptoms of a manic episode, which is a characteristic feature of bipolar disorder.

 

  • Speaking rapidly 
  • Decreased sleep (characteristic reduced need for sleep in mania)
  • Hyperactivity (increased psychomotor activity)
  • Aggression (can occur due to irritability/dysphoria in mania)

 

These symptoms appeared after discontinuing medication, suggesting a recurrence of a previously diagnosed bipolar disorder.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Depression: Incorrect because depression presents with opposite symptoms like low mood, decreased activity, and social withdrawal rather than hyperactivity and aggression.

 

Option C. Schizophrenia: Incorrect because schizophrenia primarily presents with delusions, hallucinations, and disorganized behavior. While aggression can occur, rapid speech and decreased sleep needs are not characteristic features.

 

Option D. Substance-induced mood disorder: Incorrect because the symptoms appeared after discontinuing medication rather than due to substance use. The temporal relationship with medication discontinuation suggests underlying bipolar disorder.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The classic presentation of a manic episode: rapid speech, decreased need for sleep, hyperactivity, and aggressive behavior, especially in context of medication discontinuation in a previously diagnosed psychiatric patient.

 

Symptoms of Mania

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the hospital with complaints of seeing snakes crawling and an inability to recognize his own family members. He reports his last alcohol intake was 48 hours ago. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Delirium tremens

 

This case presents with classic features of delirium tremens:

 

  • Onset 48 hours after last alcohol intake (characteristic 48–72-hour onset)
  • Visual hallucinations (snakes crawling)
  • Disorientation (inability to recognize family members) 

 

Delirium tremens is characterized by confusion, disorientation to time/place/person, and hallucinations (usually visual). It typically appears 48-72 hours after the last alcohol intake and represents a severe form of alcohol withdrawal.

 

Alcohol Withdrawal Symptoms

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alcohol-Induced Psychosis:

 

  • Alcohol-induced psychosis involves hallucinations and delusions but NO disorientation.
  • The presence of disorientation in this case strongly suggests delirium tremens rather than alcohol-induced psychosis.

 

Option C. Schizophrenia:

 

  • Schizophrenia is not associated with acute alcohol withdrawal.
  • Hallucinations in schizophrenia are typically auditory, rather than visual, and there is no acute disorientation as seen in Delirium Tremens.

 

Option D. Alcoholic Hallucinosis:

 

  • Alcoholic hallucinosis is characterized by persistent auditory hallucinations, typically without disorientation or disturbances of consciousness. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Delirium Tremens is a severe form of alcohol withdrawal syndrome presenting 48-72 hours after last alcohol intake, characterized by confusion, disorientation, and hallucinations.

questions.text: A young female reports episodes of binge eating followed by self-induced vomiting. Which of the following acid-base disturbances is she most likely to have? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Metabolic alkalosis

 

The case is suggestive of bulimia nervosa with purging behavior (self-induced vomiting). This leads to:

 

  • Loss of gastric acid (HCl) through repeated vomiting
  • Loss of chloride ions leading to hypochloremia
  • Loss of potassium leading to hypokalemia
  • The combined loss of acid and electrolytes results in metabolic alkalosis This condition is specifically characterized as hypokalemic, hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis due to the loss of acid and electrolytes through repeated purging.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Respiratory acidosis: Incorrect because this occurs due to CO2 retention from respiratory problems, not from purging behavior. Self-induced vomiting doesn't affect the respiratory system directly.

 

Option B. Respiratory alkalosis: Incorrect because this results from hyperventilation leading to excessive CO2 loss, not from purging behavior. The acid-base disturbance here is metabolic, not respiratory.

 

Option C. Metabolic acidosis: Incorrect because purging through vomiting causes loss of acid, not accumulation. Metabolic acidosis occurs when there's excess acid retention or bicarbonate loss, which isn't the case here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bulimia Nervosa

questions.text: A doctor asks a patient about her age. The patient responds: "You know, doctor, I’m from a village. We were married at a very young age—at 12—with my husband, who is just 5 years older than me. Then, I had two kids when I was around 18 or something. Now, I look like their older sister. I’m just 32, doctor. "What is the thought disorder most likely displayed by the patient? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Circumstantiality

 

This is a classic example of Circumstantiality, which refers to a pattern of speech in which the patient includes excessive and unnecessary details but eventually returns to the main point.

 

In this case, the patient eventually answers the doctor's question about her age but takes a long, indirect route with additional, unnecessary details about marriage, children,  appearance and returns to the main point.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tangentiality: Incorrect because in tangentiality, the patient never reaches the goal of thought. Here, the patient eventually stated her age (32 years), or in other words, reached the goal.

 

Option C. Derailment: Incorrect because in derailment, thoughts are not connected to each other. Here, though lengthy, the thoughts were connected (village life → marriage → children → current age).

 

Option D. Flight of ideas: Incorrect because flight of ideas involves rapid shifts between thoughts based on chance connections, often with pressured speech. Here, the speech wasn't rapid, and connections weren't based on chance but followed a logical (though unnecessarily detailed) progression.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thought Disorders

questions.text: What kind of symptoms does the term affective flattening imply? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Negative symptoms

 

Affective flattening is a negative symptom characterized by:

 

  • Lack of emotional response/emotional blunting
  • Decreased expression of emotions
    • It is one of the 6 A's of negative symptoms (others being Avolition, Apathy, Anhedonia, Asociality, and Alogia). 
    • Negative symptoms represent a reduction or loss of normal functions, unlike positive symptoms which represent an excess or distortion of normal functions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Positive symptoms: Incorrect because positive symptoms represent excess or distortion of normal functions (like hallucinations and delusions). Affective flattening represents a reduction in emotional expression, making it a negative symptom.

 

Option C. Affect symptoms: Incorrect because while affective flattening involves affect, it's specifically categorized as a negative symptom due to its nature of representing a reduction in normal emotional expression.

 

Option D. Cognitive symptoms: Incorrect because cognitive symptoms relate to thinking and mental processes like attention, memory, and executive function. Affective flattening is related to emotional expression, not cognitive function.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A lady presents to the hospital after having a fight with her husband. She reports that she is unable to speak. However, all neurological and physical examinations are normal, and she does not seem concerned about her health status. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) La belle indifférence

 

This case presents classic features of la belle indifférence, which is a characteristic finding in Conversion Disorder:

 

  • Neurological symptom (inability to speak)
  • Normal neurological examination
  • Lack of concern about the symptoms (characteristic of la belle indifférence)
  • Clear psychological stressor (fight with husband) 
    La belle indifférence refers to a paradoxical lack of concern about serious symptoms, typically seen in conversion disorder.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Malingering: Incorrect because malingering involves conscious faking of symptoms for external benefits (like financial gain or avoiding work). Here, the symptoms developed after an emotional stressor and the patient shows a characteristic lack of concern rather and there is no evidence given for intentional deception.

 

Option C. Somatic symptom disorder: Incorrect because in somatic symptom disorder, patients are typically extremely concerned and preoccupied with their symptoms, unlike this patient who shows lack of concern (la belle indifférence).

 

Option D. Generalised Anxiety Disorder: Incorrect because GAD presents with excessive anxiety and worry about various life circumstances, not with specific neurological symptoms. The lack of anxiety about symptoms also makes this diagnosis unlikely.

 

Educational Objective:

 

La belle indifférence is a characteristic feature of conversion disorder, and is marked by paradoxical lack of concern about serious symptoms, typically occurring after psychological stressors.

 

Comparison of Somatic and Related Disorders

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman diagnosed with schizophrenia had been compliant with her prescribed olanzapine for several months. However, she discontinued the treatment. Which of the following is the most likely reason for her discontinuation? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Weight gain

 

Olanzapine is known to cause significant weight gain and metabolic side effects. In fact, among atypical antipsychotics, olanzapine causes the second-highest weight gain (after clozapine). This metabolic side effect is often a major reason for treatment discontinuation in patients, especially young women who may be concerned about body image and health implications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tardive dyskinesia (TD): Incorrect because atypical antipsychotics like olanzapine have a very low propensity for causing tardive dyskinesia compared to typical antipsychotics. Olanzapine in particular has a very low propensity for TD.

 

Option C. Acute dystonia: Incorrect because acute dystonia is usually caused by typical antipsychotics, particularly with parenteral administration. It is unlikely with olanzapine.

 

Option D. Akathisia: Incorrect because among atypical antipsychotics, aripiprazole is more likely to cause akathisia. Olanzapine is not particularly associated with this side effect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Weight gain is a significant side effect of olanzapine (second highest among atypical antipsychotics after clozapine) and is often a major reason for treatment non-compliance, especially in young patients.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is contraindicated for hypertension in pregnancy? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Enalapril

 

Explanation: 

 

Enalapril and other ACE inhibitors (drugs ending in -pril), ARBs (drugs ending in -sartan) are contraindicated in pregnancy as they can cause severe fetal abnormalities. The safe antihypertensive drugs in pregnancy can be remembered by the mnemonic

 "BETTER MOTHER CARE During Hypertensive Pregnancy":

 

  • B (Beta blockers) - Labetalol (DOC)
  • M (Methyldopa)
  • C (Clonidine)
  • D (Dihydropyridine CCBs like nifedipine)
  • HY (Hydralazine)
  • P (Prazosin)

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Nifedipine: Calcium channel blockers are safe in pregnancy and help control blood pressure effectively 

 

Option B. Labetalol: Beta blocker is drug of choice for hypertension in pregnancy 

 

Option C. Methyldopa: Safe centrally acting antihypertensive that has been used extensively in pregnancy

 

Educational Objective: 

 

ACE inhibitors and ARBs are contraindicated in all trimesters of pregnancy due to risk of fetal abnormalities.

questions.text: Adverse effect of bleomycin on which system can be worsened by radiation therapy? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pulmonary

 

Explanation:

 

Bleomycin is metabolized by bleomycin hydrolase enzyme which is deficient in lungs and skin. This makes these two organs most susceptible to bleomycin toxicity. 

 

In lungs, bleomycin causes pulmonary fibrosis. When combined with radiation therapy, pulmonary fibrosis can be significantly worsened as radiation itself can cause lung damage and fibrosis. This makes pulmonary toxicity a major concern when using bleomycin with radiation therapy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Skin: While skin is also susceptible to bleomycin toxicity due to deficiency of bleomycin hydrolase (causing flagellated pigmentation), radiation therapy does not specifically worsen the cutaneous side effects.

 

 

Option B. Nerves: Bleomycin does not have significant neurotoxicity as its main adverse effects. Radiation therapy does not interact with bleomycin to cause neurological problems.

 

Option D. Gastric: Bleomycin does not have significant gastrointestinal toxicity as a major side effect. Radiation therapy does not specifically worsen any gastrointestinal effects of bleomycin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bleomycin is Metabolized by bleomycin hydrolase which is Deficient at

questions.text: Which of the following antidiabetic drugs is preferred in a patient with heart and kidney disease? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) SGLT-2 inhibitors

 

Explanation: 

 

SGLT-2 inhibitors (drugs ending in -gliflozin like canagliflozin, empagliflozin, dapagliflozin) are the preferred choice because:

 

  • They work by inhibiting SGLT-2 in proximal tubules, preventing reabsorption of both glucose and sodium
  • They reduce mortality in patients with congestive heart failure
  • They slow the progression of diabetic kidney disease
  • Their mechanism of promoting glucose and sodium excretion provides cardiovascular and renal benefits beyond glycemic control

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Biguanides (Incorrect)

 

  • While effective for diabetes, metformin (Biguanides) has limitations in patients with significant kidney disease
  • Must be used cautiously or avoided in patients with renal impairment due to risk of lactic acidosis
  • Does not provide direct cardiovascular benefits like SGLT-2 inhibitors

 

Option B. GLP-1 analogs (Incorrect)

 

  • While they have some cardiovascular benefits, they don't have the same level of evidence for combined cardiac and renal protection as SGLT-2 inhibitors

 

Option D. Sulfonylureas (Incorrect)

 

  • Associated with risk of hypoglycemia
  • No proven cardiovascular benefits
  • May need dose adjustment in kidney disease
  • Can cause fluid retention which may worsen heart failure

 

Educational Objective:

 

SGLT-2 inhibitors are the preferred antidiabetic agents in patients with coexisting heart and kidney disease due to their proven benefits in reducing cardiovascular mortality and slowing the progression of diabetic kidney disease.

choices.text: It inhibits the cytochrome P450 enzyme responsible for NAPQI formation
It acts as a direct antioxidant to neutralize NAPQI
It enhances renal clearance of NAPQI

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of N-acetylcysteine in paracetamol toxicity? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) It replenishes glutathione levels

 

Explanation: 

 

N-acetylcysteine works by replenishing glutathione levels in paracetamol toxicity. Paracetamol is metabolized by cytochrome P450 enzymes to form NAPQI (N-acetyl-para-benzoquinoneimine), which is a toxic metabolite. 

 

Normally, glutathione in the liver neutralizes NAPQI. However, toxicity occurs in three scenarios:

 

  1. High doses of paracetamol leading to excessive NAPQI formation
  2. Chronic alcoholism causing increased CYP enzyme activity
  3. Liver disease reducing glutathione production

 

N-acetylcysteine is converted to glutathione, which then binds and neutralizes NAPQI. For maximum effectiveness, N-acetylcysteine should be administered within 8 hours of paracetamol ingestion.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. It inhibits the cytochrome P450 enzyme responsible for NAPQI formation: Incorrect - N-acetylcysteine does not inhibit cytochrome P450 enzymes. It works by replenishing glutathione which neutralizes NAPQI after its formation.

 

Option C. It acts as a direct antioxidant to neutralize NAPQI: Incorrect - N-acetylcysteine does not directly neutralize NAPQI. It is first converted to glutathione, which then neutralizes NAPQI.

 

Option D. It enhances renal clearance of NAPQI: Incorrect - N-acetylcysteine does not enhance renal clearance of NAPQI. Its mechanism involves glutathione replenishment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

N-acetylcysteine is the antidote for paracetamol toxicity and works by replenishing glutathione levels, which helps neutralize the toxic metabolite NAPQI.

 

Antidotes

questions.text: A person went for a trip on hills and developed difficulty breathing. He was given a diuretic which is considered as the drug of choice for this condition. What is the site of action of this drug? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) PCT (Proximal Convoluted Tubule)

 

Explanation: 

 

The clinical scenario describes acute mountain sickness, characterized by breathing difficulty at high altitudes due to hypoxia. The drug of choice for both prevention and treatment of mountain sickness is acetazolamide. Acetazolamide is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor that acts primarily in the proximal convoluted tubule (PCT). It inhibits the reabsorption of bicarbonate in the PCT, causing mild metabolic acidosis which stimulates breathing and helps acclimatization to high altitude.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Thick ascending loop - Loop diuretics like furosemide act here, not acetazolamide 

 

Option C. DCT (Distal Convoluted Tubule) - Thiazide diuretics act here, not carbonic anhydrase inhibitors 

 

Option D. Collecting duct - Potassium-sparing diuretics and aldosterone antagonists act here, not carbonic anhydrase inhibitors

 

Educational Objective:

 

A carbonic anhydrase inhibitor, is the drug of choice for mountain sickness and acts in the proximal convoluted tubule.

 

Diuretics Classification Table

choices.text: Cisplatin is more neurotoxic than carboplatin
Cisplatin is more nephrotoxic than carboplatin
Cisplatin causes more bone marrow suppression than carboplatin
Carboplatin causes more vomiting than cisplatin

questions.text: Which of the following statements about anticancer drugs is correct? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cisplatin is more nephrotoxic than carboplatin

 

Explanation:

 

 Cisplatin has three major adverse effects remembered with three C's:

 

  • C of ears – Ototoxicity (Irreversible)
  • C of kidney - Nephrotoxicity (most prominent)
  • C of smiling face - Maximum nausea and vomiting Cisplatin is known to be more nephrotoxic than carboplatin. 
  • Slow intravenous infusion is given
  • Saline loading should be done
  • Amifostine can be used (which can also prevent radiation-induced xerostomia)

 

To prevent nephrotoxicity:

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cisplatin is more neurotoxic than carboplatin: Incorrect as carboplatin causes more neurotoxicity than cisplatin

 

Option C. Cisplatin causes more bone marrow suppression than carboplatin: Incorrect as cisplatin is one of the bone marrow-sparing anticancer drugs

 

Option D. Carboplatin causes more vomiting than cisplatin: Incorrect as cisplatin is the most emetogenic anticancer drug, causing maximum nausea and vomiting compared to other platinum compounds

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cisplatin has more nephrotoxicity compared to carboplatin, requiring preventive measures like slow IV infusion, saline loading and Amifostine.

 

Rescue Therapy

 

To teat advese effects pf amto-cancer drugs

questions.text: A patient was started on ATT and ART together, Symptoms worsened after 2 months. What can be the cause? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Immune reconstitution syndrome

 

Explanation:

 

In patients with both TB and HIV, ATT should be started first. After the patient starts tolerating ATT (approximately 2 weeks), ART should be initiated. This approach is important because if ART is started, it improves immunity which can lead to increased inflammatory response against TB antigens present in various organs. This excessive inflammatory response is called Immune Reconstitution Inflammatory Syndrome (IRIS). 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Drug-drug interaction: While interactions can occur between ATT and ART drugs (especially between rifampicin and protease inhibitors), this would manifest differently and not typically cause worsening of symptoms after 2 months of therapy.

 

Option C. Anti-tubercular drug resistance: Anti-tubercular Drug resistance would present as failure to improve rather than initial improvement followed by worsening. Additionally, drug resistance typically develops over a longer period.

 

Option D. Anti-HIV drug resistance: HIV drug resistance typically presents with virological failure rather than worsening of TB symptoms. Additionally, 2 months is too early for HIV drug resistance to develop.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 In patients with both TB and HIV, worsening of symptoms after starting ART is most likely due to IRIS (Immune Reconstitution Inflammatory Syndrome), which occurs due to improved immunity leading to increased inflammatory response against TB antigens.

 

HIV with TB

 

  • Start ATT first
  • After 2 weeks, start ART

questions.text: Which of the following is the best antibiotic choice for a patient with otitis media who is allergic to penicillins? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Azithromycin

 

Explanation: 

 

For patients with penicillin allergy, azithromycin is the best choice because:

 

  • It doesn't belong to β-lactam family, so no cross-allergenicity
  • Can be administered orally unlike amikacin which needs injection
  • Effective against gram-positive bacteria which commonly cause otitis media

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ceftriaxone: Incorrect

 

  • It's a cephalosporin which belongs to β-lactam family
  • Contraindicated in patients with penicillin allergy due to cross-allergenicity

 

Option C. Amikacin: Incorrect

 

  • Although amikacin is safe in penicillin-allergic patients, it is primarily effective against gram-negative bacteria, while otitis media is commonly caused by gram-positive organisms. 

 

Option D. Meropenem: Incorrect

 

  • It's a carbapenem which belongs to β-lactam family
  • Contraindicated in penicillin allergy due to cross-allergenicity

 

Educational Objective: 

 

In penicillin-allergic patients, β-lactam antibiotics (penicillins, cephalosporins, carbapenems) are contraindicated due to cross-allergenicity. Azithromycin is a safe and effective alternative.

questions.text: Following intravenous administration of noradrenaline, a decrease in heart rate is observed. What is the physiological mechanism responsible for this effect? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Baroreceptor activation

 

Explanation:

 

When noradrenaline is administered intravenously, it primarily stimulates alpha-1 receptors in blood vessels, causing vasoconstriction. This vasoconstriction leads to an increase in diastolic blood pressure and mean arterial pressure. Our body has compensatory mechanisms to maintain homeostasis. When blood pressure increases, baroreceptors located in the blood vessels (particularly in the carotid sinus and aortic arch) detect this change.

 

These baroreceptors sense the elevated blood pressure and become activated. Once activated, they send signals to the central nervous system, specifically stimulating the parasympathetic nervous system. The parasympathetic activation results in the release of acetylcholine, which acts on the heart to slow the heart rate (bradycardia). This is a reflex mechanism known as the baroreceptor reflex or baroreflex.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Stimulation of alpha-1 receptors: This is incorrect because. While noradrenaline does stimulate alpha-1 receptors (causing vasoconstriction and increased blood pressure), the direct effect of alpha-1 stimulation does not cause a decrease in heart rate. Alpha-1 receptors are primarily located on blood vessels, not on the heart. The decrease in heart rate is an indirect effect mediated through the baroreceptor reflex.

 

Option C. Activation of beta-1 receptors: This is incorrect because. Activation of beta-1 receptors would increase heart rate (tachycardia), not decrease it. Beta-1 receptors are present in the heart, and their stimulation leads to positive chronotropic (increased heart rate) and inotropic (increased contractility) effects. While noradrenaline does have some beta-1 agonist activity, the reflex bradycardia from baroreceptor activation usually overrides this direct effect.

 

Option D. Inhibition of baroreceptors: This is incorrect because. Noradrenaline causes activation, not inhibition, of baroreceptors. When baroreceptors are inhibited, they would fail to detect the increase in blood pressure, which would cause a failure of the compensatory mechanism that decreases heart rate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

IV administration of noradrenaline causes reflex bradycardia through baroreceptor activation, which is a physiological compensatory mechanism in response to the drug-induced increase in blood pressure.

 

Effect of IV administration of NA on heart rate

questions.text: An epileptic patient presents with gum hypertrophy and bleeding. Which antiepileptic drug is the likely cause? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Phenytoin

 

Explanation:

 

Phenytoin is known to cause gum hypertrophy (gingival hyperplasia) and bleeding as adverse effects. The adverse effects of phenytoin can be remembered using the mnemonic 

 

"HOT MALIKA":

 

H: Hirsutism and Hypertrophy of gums

O: Osteomalacia

T: Teratogenicity (fetal hydantoin syndrome)

M: Megaloblastic anemia (due to folate deficiency)

A: Arrhythmias (in overdose)

L: Lymph node enlargement (lymphadenopathy)

I: Inhibition of insulin secretion (can lead to hyperglycemia)

K: Vitamin K deficiency (can result in bleeding)

A: Ataxia, nystagmus, vertigo (cerebellar side effects in overdose)

 

The gum hypertrophy is a direct effect of phenytoin on gingival tissue, while the bleeding is due to vitamin K deficiency caused by phenytoin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Valproate: 

 

Valproate's adverse effects include 

 

V - Vomiting

A - Alopecia/Curling of hair

L - Liver disease (hepatotoxicity: in young children has high incidence)

P - Pancreatitis, ↑ risk of PCOD (gender Specific S/E)

R - Rash, allergy

O - Obesity

A - Ataxia (in overdose)

TE - Teratogenicity (most teratogenic Antiepileptic drug)

 

Therefore, if administered during pregnancy, a high dose of folic acid (4000μg/day) should be supplemented to prevent neural tube defects.

 

Option C. Carbamazepine: 

 

Carbamazepine's adverse effects can be remembered as "4 A's":

 

  • Auto-induction (increases metabolism of itself and other drugs)
  • Aplastic anemia (bone marrow suppression)
  • ADH release (which can cause SIADH and dilutional hyponatremia)
  • Ataxia/nystagmus/vertigo (in overdose)

 

It does not cause gum hypertrophy or vitamin K deficiency leading to bleeding.

 

Option D. Ethosuximide: Ethosuximide primarily affects T-type calcium channels and is used mainly for absence seizures. Its adverse effects are relatively mild compared to other antiepileptics and do not include gum hypertrophy or bleeding. The main side effects are gastrointestinal disturbances and CNS effects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phenytoin causes gum hypertrophy (gingival hyperplasia) and vitamin K deficiency leading to bleeding as characteristic adverse effects, which can be remembered using the mnemonic 

 

"HOT MALIKA."

 

Adverse Effects 

 

H - Hirsutism, Hypertrophy of gums 

O-Osteomalacia 

T- Teratogenicity [Fetal Hydantoin syndrome] 

M - Megaloblastic Anemia [↓ Folate] 

A- Arrhythmia [Only in overdose] 

L- Lymph node enlargement 

I - ↓Insulin (avoided in DM) 

K-↓ Vitamin K 

A - Ataxias, vertigo [cerebellar symptoms] only at high dose]

questions.text: Resistance to which of the following antitubercular drugs occurs due to mutation in kat G? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Isoniazid

 

Explanation

 

  • Isoniazid (INH) is a prodrug which activated by catalase peroxidase (formed by Kat G) enzyme of mycobacteria. It acts by inhibiting the formation of mycolic acid.
  • Mutation in Kat G or inh A can result in resistance.
  • When there is a mutation in the katG gene, the catalase-peroxidase enzyme is either not produced or is produced in a dysfunctional form. As a result, isoniazid cannot be activated and can’t inhibit the formation of mycolic acid. This leads to resistance to isoniazid.
  • The katG gene mutation is one of the most common mechanisms of isoniazid resistance in M. tuberculosis. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Rifampicin: Incorrect. Rifampicin resistance is primarily associated with mutations in the rpo B gene, which encodes the β-subunit of RNA polymerase. Rifampicin acts by binding to this β-subunit, inhibiting transcription. When mutations occur in the rpoB gene, rifampicin cannot bind effectively, leading to resistance.

 

Option C. Levofloxacin: Incorrect. Levofloxacin is a fluoroquinolone antibiotic that targets DNA gyrase (topoisomerase II) and topoisomerase IV in bacteria. Resistance to levofloxacin typically occurs due to mutations in gyr A or gyr B genes, which encode DNA gyrase.

 

Option D. Pyrazinamide: Incorrect. Pyrazinamide resistance is mainly associated with mutations in the pncA gene, which encodes pyrazinamidase. This enzyme converts pyrazinamide to its active form, pyrazinoic acid. Mutations in pncA result in reduced pyrazinamidase activity, leading to pyrazinamide resistance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Resistance to isoniazid occurs due to mutations in the katG gene, which encodes the catalase-peroxidase enzyme required for isoniazid activation.

choices.text: Block release of acetylcholine from presynaptic terminal

questions.text: The mechanism of action of botulinum toxin is? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Block release of acetylcholine from presynaptic terminal

 

Explanation:

 

Botulinum toxin works by inhibiting the exocytosis of acetylcholine from presynaptic nerve terminals. In normal neurotransmission, acetylcholine is stored in vesicles in the presynaptic neuron and released when an action potential arrives. 

 

Botulinum toxin prevents the release of acetylcholine into the synaptic cleft, effectively blocking neuromuscular transmission and causing flaccid paralysis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Block postsynaptic receptors of acetylcholine:  Incorrect. Botulinum toxin doesn't affect postsynaptic receptors. Drugs that block postsynaptic acetylcholine receptors include anticholinergic agents like atropine (for muscarinic receptors) or agents like curare (for nicotinic receptors).

 

Option B. Inhibit reuptake of acetylcholine: Incorrect. Unlike noradrenaline or serotonin, acetylcholine's action is not terminated by reuptake into the presynaptic neuron. Instead, it is hydrolyzed by acetylcholinesterase in the synaptic cleft. 

 

Option D. Inhibit acetylcholinesterase: Incorrect. Acetylcholinesterase inhibitors (like physostigmine, neostigmine, or pyridostigmine) increase acetylcholine levels by preventing its breakdown, resulting in enhanced cholinergic transmission. This mechanism is opposite to botulinum toxin's effect, which decreases cholinergic transmission.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Acetyl choline [Ach]

 

 

→Rate limiting step is: Uptake of choline

↓Parasympathetic activity

1. Hemicholinium

2. Vesamicol

3. Botulinum toxin

Ach Esterase Inhibitor→↑Parasympathetic activity

4. Physostigmine

questions.text: Which of the following is not the correct dose in the treatment of multibacillary leprosy in adults? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Rifampicin 450 mg weekly

 

Explanation:

 

The correct treatment regimen for multibacillary leprosy in adults consists of three drugs: rifampicin, clofazimine, and dapsone. The standard WHO recommended regimen includes 

 

Rifampicin 600 mg given once monthly under supervision. This is combined with clofazimine 300 mg once monthly (supervised) and clofazimine 50 mg daily (unsupervised) along with dapsone 100 mg daily (unsupervised). The treatment for multibacillary leprosy is continued for 12 months.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Leprosy

 

 

Above regimen is given for

 

  • 12 months in multi-bacillary leprosy
  • 6 months in pauci-bacillary leprosy

questions.text: A patient with schizophrenia was on olanzapine therapy for a few months. It was effective in controlling the symptoms, but the patient stopped taking this drug. What can be the most likely reason? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Weight gain

 

Explanation:

 

  • Olanzapine is an atypical antipsychotic drug used in the treatment of schizophrenia. While it is effective in controlling both positive and negative symptoms of schizophrenia, it is associated with several adverse effects. 
  • The most common reason patients discontinue olanzapine therapy is weight gain. 
  • Olanzapine, along with clozapine, has the highest risk of causing metabolic side effects collectively known as lipodystrophy syndrome. This syndrome includes hyperglycemia, hyperlipidemia, insulin resistance, and significant weight gain. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tardive dyskinesia: This is incorrect. Because tardive dyskinesia is more commonly associated with typical (first-generation) antipsychotic drugs like haloperidol rather than atypical antipsychotics like olanzapine. Atypical antipsychotics have a lower risk of causing extrapyramidal symptoms including tardive dyskinesia.

 

Option C. Agranulocytosis: This is incorrect. Because agranulocytosis is a characteristic adverse effect of clozapine, not olanzapine. Clozapine requires regular monitoring of white blood cell counts due to this potentially fatal side effect.

 

Option D. Muscular dystonia: This is incorrect. Because muscular dystonia is an extrapyramidal symptom more commonly associated with typical antipsychotic drugs. Atypical antipsychotics like olanzapine have a much lower risk of causing extrapyramidal symptoms compared to typical antipsychotics.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Side effects of Atypical anti- Psychotics:

 

Side effects

 

  • Cause lipodystrophy syndrome characterized by
    • ↑Glucose
    • ↑Lipids
    • Weight gain
    • Insulin Resistance
  • Risk is highest with clozapine and olanzapine

questions.text: Drug of choice for the treatment of cryptococcal meningitis is? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Liposomal Amphotericin B plus 5-FC

 

Explanation:

 

The drug of choice for the treatment of cryptococcal meningitis is liposomal amphotericin B plus 5-flucytosine (5-FC). This combination is used during the initial induction phase of treatment. 

 

Liposomal amphotericin B is a polyene antifungal that binds to ergosterol in the fungal cell membrane, creating pores that lead to cell death. 

 

 

5-flucytosine is an antimetabolite that inhibits DNA and protein synthesis in fungal cells. The combination therapy provides synergistic effects against Cryptococcus, especially in the central nervous system infections like meningitis.

 

Treatment of cryptococcal meningitis typically follows a three-phase approach:

 

  1. Induction phase - liposomal amphotericin B plus 5-flucytosine
  2. Consolidation phase - fluconazole
  3. Maintenance phase- fluconazole

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fluconazole: Fluconazole is used in the maintenance & Consolidation phase of cryptococcal meningitis treatment, not as the primary drug of choice for acute infection. It's less effective than amphotericin B for the initial treatment of cryptococcal meningitis.

 

Option C. 5-Flucytosine: While 5-flucytosine is an important component of the treatment regimen for cryptococcal meningitis, it is not used as monotherapy. It has limited efficacy when used alone and is primarily used in combination with amphotericin B to enhance fungicidal activity.

 

Option D. Terbinafine: Terbinafine is an allylamine antifungal that inhibits squalene epoxidase, interfering with ergosterol synthesis. It is primarily used for dermatophyte infections (tinea infections of skin, hair, and nails).

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The drug of choice for the treatment of cryptococcal meningitis is the combination of liposomal amphotericin B plus 5-flucytosine for induction therapy, followed by fluconazole for maintenance & Consolidation therapy.

questions.text: A patient was administered succinylcholine and halothane before surgery. The patient developed sudden rigidity. Core temperature was elevated to 104°F, and there was an elevation in EtCO2 as well. Which of the following is the most suitable medication to treat this condition? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dantrolene

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical scenario described is characteristic of malignant hyperthermia, a rare but life-threatening condition that can be triggered by volatile anaesthetic agents (like halothane) and depolarizing muscle relaxants (like succinylcholine). 

 

The classic clinical features include muscle rigidity, rapidly increasing body temperature, elevated end-tidal CO2 (due to increased metabolism) and if left untreated, can progress to rhabdomyolysis, acidosis, hyperkalemia and eventually death.

 

Dantrolene is the specific antidote and drug of choice for malignant hyperthermia. It acts by inhibiting calcium release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum in skeletal muscle, thereby reducing the hypermetabolic state and muscle contraction. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sodium bicarbonate: While acidosis may develop during malignant hyperthermia and sodium bicarbonate might be used as a supportive measure to correct metabolic acidosis. Dantrolene specifically targets the calcium dysregulation that is central to malignant hyperthermia.

 

Option C. Lorazepam: This is a benzodiazepine used primarily for seizures, anxiety, and sedation. It has no role in the management of malignant hyperthermia and would not address the hypermetabolic crisis.

 

Option D. Mannitol: This is an osmotic diuretic that might be used as a supportive measure in malignant hyperthermia to prevent or treat renal failure from myoglobinuria (resulting from muscle breakdown). However, like sodium bicarbonate, it is not the specific treatment for malignant hyperthermia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Malignant hyperthermia as a potential complication of succinylcholine and halothane administration, Dantrolene is the specific antidote and drug of choice for malignant hyperthermia.

questions.text: Indomethacin should not be given with ACE inhibitors because: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hyperkalemia

 

Explanation:

 

ACE inhibitors work by inhibiting the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS). Aldosterone normally promotes potassium excretion in the distal tubule. When ACE inhibitors block this pathway, aldosterone levels decrease, resulting in reduced potassium excretion and a tendency toward hyperkalemia.

 

NSAIDs like indomethacin further increase this risk through several mechanisms:

 

  • They reduce renal blood flow by inhibiting prostaglandin synthesis
  • They decrease glomerular filtration rate (GFR)
  • They impair renin release
  • They directly interfere with potassium excretion

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hyponatremia: While ACE inhibitors can occasionally cause hyponatremia by increasing water retention through ADH mechanisms, this is not significantly worsened by the addition of NSAIDs. The primary concern when combining these drug classes is hyperkalemia.

 

Option C. Hyperuricemia: Although both ACE inhibitors and NSAIDs can independently affect uric acid levels (NSAIDs can increase uric acid levels by decreasing its excretion), hyperuricemia is not the primary concern when combining these medications. The risk of hyperkalemia is more significant and potentially more dangerous.

 

Option D. It may cause severe hypotension: While both ACE inhibitors and NSAIDs can affect blood pressure, their combined effect typically results in a reduction of the antihypertensive efficacy of ACE inhibitors rather than severe hypotension. NSAIDs tend to increase blood pressure by inhibiting prostaglandin synthesis, which opposes the blood pressure-lowering effects of ACE inhibitors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

NSAIDs like indomethacin should not be given with ACE inhibitors due to increased risk of hyperkalemia, as both drug classes can interfere with potassium excretion through different mechanisms.

questions.text: A patient has throbbing unilateral headache and photophobia, which is treated by sumatriptan. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Migraine

 

Explanation:

 

Migraine is characterized by unilateral, pulsatile headache often associated with photophobia (sensitivity to light), phonophobia (sensitivity to sound), nausea, and vomiting. Symptoms of "throbbing unilateral headache with photophobia" are classic presentation of migraine.

 

Sumatriptan is a 5-HT1B/1D receptor agonist are the drug of choice for acute severe migraine attacks. They work by:

 

  • Causing vasoconstriction of blood vessels in the brain
  • Inhibiting the release of inflammatory neuropeptides, particularly Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide (CGRP)

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tension headache: Incorrect because. Tension headaches typically present as bilateral, non-pulsatile, "band-like" pain around the head. They are usually not associated with photophobia and are not typically treated with triptans like sumatriptan. First-line treatments for tension headaches are NSAIDs.

 

Option C. Cluster headache: Incorrect because. Cluster headaches, while unilateral, are extremely severe and often described as "boring" or "stabbing" rather than throbbing. They are typically associated with ipsilateral autonomic symptoms like lacrimation, nasal congestion, or rhinorrhoea. While triptans can be used for cluster headaches, first-line treatments usually include high-flow oxygen therapy.

 

Option D. Frontal headache: Incorrect because. "Frontal headache" refers to pain localized to the frontal region of the head and can be a symptom of various conditions including sinusitis, tension headache, or migraine. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Treatment of acute attack:

 

  • Drug of choice for mild to moderate headache – NSAIDs (Paracetamol, diclofenac)
  • Drug of choice for Acute severe attack – Triptans
  • Other drug for Acute severe migraine – Ergotamine

questions.text: A tissue sample shows significant cellular damage. Which of the following changes is most indicative of irreversible cell injury in the sample? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Amorphous density of mitochondria

 

Amorphous densities in mitochondria are characteristic features of irreversible cell injury. These densities represent calcium phosphate deposits within damaged mitochondria, which occur as the mitochondrial membrane becomes increasingly permeable during severe cell injury. When mitochondria are severely damaged, they can no longer maintain calcium homeostasis, leading to calcium influx and the formation of these dense deposits. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cellular swelling: This is an early change that can be seen in both reversible and irreversible cell injury. It occurs due to the failure of the sodium-potassium pump resulting in sodium accumulation within the cell, followed by water influx. Since this is a nonspecific finding that can be present in both reversible and irreversible injury, it's not the most indicative of irreversible damage.

 

Option B. Bleb formation: Blebs are outpouchings of the plasma membrane that form due to focal weakening of the cytoskeleton. Like cellular swelling, bleb formation can be seen in both reversible and irreversible cell injury, so it's not specifically indicative of irreversible damage.

 

Option D. Cytoplasmic vacuolation: Vacuoles can form in the cytoplasm during cell injury due to dilation of the endoplasmic reticulum or increased autophagy. This change is commonly seen in reversible cell injury and is therefore not the most reliable indicator of irreversible damage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of amorphous densities in mitochondria is a morphological feature that indicates irreversible cell injury, distinguishing it from changes that can be seen in both reversible and irreversible injury such as cellular swelling, bleb formation, and cytoplasmic vacuolation.

questions.text: A patient with a bleeding disorder is suspected of having von Willebrand disease. What does vWF primarily bind to in the process of platelet adhesion? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Gp Ib/IX

 

Von Willebrand factor (vWF) is a large multimeric glycoprotein that plays an important role in primary hemostasis. In the process of platelet adhesion, vWF primarily binds to glycoprotein Ib/IX complex (GpIb/IX) on the platelet surface. This interaction is essential for platelet adhesion to damaged endothelium, particularly under high shear stress conditions like those found in small arteries and arterioles. VWF is produced by endothelial cells and megakaryocytes and is stored in Weibel-Palade bodies within endothelial cells. When vessel injury occurs, vWF functions as a bridge between exposed subendothelial collagen and platelets through the GpIb/IX receptor complex, initiating the hemostatic process.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gp IIb: Glycoprotein IIb (GpIIb) is part of the GpIIb/IIIa complex on platelets, which binds fibrinogen during platelet aggregation, not platelet adhesion. GpIIb/IIIa is involved in platelet-platelet interaction (aggregation), whereas vWF-GpIb/IX interaction is critical for platelet-endothelium interaction (adhesion). Defects in GpIIb/IIIa result in Glanzmann thrombasthenia, not von Willebrand disease.

 

Option B. Prothrombin: Prothrombin (Factor II) is a coagulation factor that is converted to thrombin during the coagulation cascade. While thrombin is a potent activator of platelets, it doesn't interact directly with vWF during the initial adhesion process.

 

Option D. ADP: Adenosine diphosphate (ADP) is a platelet agonist released from platelet dense granules upon activation. It binds to platelet ADP receptors (P2Y1 and P2Y12) and promotes platelet aggregation. While important in platelet function, ADP is not a binding partner for vWF in the adhesion process.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Von Willebrand factor (vWF) binds to glycoprotein Ib/IX (GpIb/IX) on platelets during the initial adhesion process, which is essential for normal hemostasis. Deficiency or dysfunction of VWF results in von Willebrand disease, characterized by mucocutaneous bleeding due to impaired platelet adhesion.

questions.text: Which family member is responsible for transmission of the disease in mitochondrial inheritance? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mother

 

Mitochondrial inheritance follows a maternal pattern of transmission. This is because the mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) is exclusively transmitted from the mother to all her children. During fertilization, the sperm contributes its nuclear DNA but its mitochondria are destroyed, so all mitochondria in the zygote come from the egg. This results in what is known as maternal inheritance, where diseases caused by mutations in mitochondrial DNA are transmitted only through the mother.

 

  • Examples
    • MELAS → Mitochondrial Encephalopathy, Lactic Acidosis, Stroke
    • Leigh's Disease
    • NARP SYNDROME → Neuropathy, Ataxia, Retinitis Pigmentosal
    • Leber's Optic Neuropathy
  • Mitochondrial DNA is present in ovum & not in sperms

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Grandfather (maternal): Incorrect. Though the maternal grandfather carries mitochondrial DNA, he cannot transmit it to his grandchildren. His daughters receive his nuclear DNA but their mitochondrial DNA comes from their mother (the maternal grandmother).

 

Option B. Grandfather (paternal): Incorrect. The paternal grandfather's mitochondrial DNA is not transmitted to his son, and consequently not to his grandchildren.

 

Option C. Father: Incorrect. Although the father contributes half of the nuclear DNA to the child, he does not contribute any mitochondrial DNA, as paternal mitochondria are destroyed after fertilization.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mitochondrial inheritance follows a maternal transmission pattern in which only mothers can pass mitochondrial DNA mutations to their children. This occurs because all mitochondria in humans are inherited from the mother's egg cell, while paternal mitochondria are eliminated during fertilization.

questions.text: A child presents with intellectual disability, short stature, hypotonia, obesity, small hands and feet, and hypogonadism. He has been diagnosed with Prader-Willi syndrome. Which of the following chromosomes is affected in this patient? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chromosome 15

 

Prader-Willi syndrome is a genetic disorder caused by abnormalities on chromosome 15.

 

This occurs due to one of three mechanisms:

 

  • Deletion of the paternal chromosome 15 (most common, about 70% of cases)
  • Maternal uniparental disomy (both copies of chromosome 15 come from the mother)
  • Imprinting defect.

 

Prader willi syndrome

 

Etiology

 

  • Deletion of paternal chromosome (MC cause)
  • Uniparental Disomy (maternal chromosome)
  • ↓↓ SNORP (Small nucleolar RNA Proteins)

 

Clinical features

 

  • Mental Retardation
  • Obesity
  • Hypotonia
  • Hypogonadism

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chromosome 11: Incorrect. Chromosome 11 abnormalities are associated with other conditions like Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome and Wilms tumor, not Prader-Willi syndrome.

 

Option B. Chromosome 12: Incorrect. Chromosome 12 is not associated with Prader-Willi syndrome. Abnormalities of this chromosome may be linked to other conditions.

 

Option D. Chromosome 17: Incorrect. Chromosome 17 is associated with conditions like Miller-Dieker syndrome and Smith-Magenis syndrome, not Prader-Willi syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prader-Willi syndrome is caused by abnormalities on chromosome 15, specifically the absence of paternally expressed genes in the 15q11-q13 region.

questions.text: A male infant presents with recurrent infections. Laboratory examination shows reduced B-cells and low levels of different antibodies. There is a normal reaction to environmental antigens on the skin. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bruton's agammaglobulinemia

 

Bruton's agammaglobulinemia is an X-linked recessive disorder characterized by a defect in B-cell tyrosine kinase (BTK), resulting in a severe reduction or absence of B lymphocytes and all immunoglobulin isotypes. This condition primarily affects male infants who present with recurrent bacterial infections after 6 months of age when maternal antibodies wane. The normal reaction to environmental antigens on the skin indicates intact T-cell immunity, which is characteristic of Bruton's agammaglobulinemia where only B-cell function is affected.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. DiGeorge syndrome: Incorrect. DiGeorge syndrome is a T-cell problem characterized by thymic hypoplasia, resulting in defective T-cell immunity. Patients would show abnormal reactions to environmental antigens on the skin due to impaired T-cell function. Additionally, patients typically present with hypocalcemia due to parathyroid issues, cardiac defects, and characteristic facial features.

 

Option C. Common variable immunodeficiency (CVID): Incorrect. While CVID also affects B cells, it typically presents later in life (usually after puberty) and is characterized by hyperplastic lymph nodes and tonsils. In CVID, B cells are present but do not function properly, which differs from the reduced B-cell numbers .

 

Option D. Selective IgA deficiency: Incorrect. Selective IgA deficiency is the most common immunoglobulin deficiency but involves only IgA. Patients have normal B-cell counts and normal levels of other immunoglobulins. It is associated with increased risk of respiratory and GI infections but typically less severe than what would be expected with Bruton's agammaglobulinemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bruton's agammaglobulinemia is an X-linked recessive disorder characterized by absent B cells, low or absent immunoglobulins of all classes, and normal T-cell function, resulting in recurrent bacterial infections in male infants.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with intermittent right upper quadrant pain and episodes of jaundice. Ultrasound shows multiple pigmented gallstones in the gallbladder. Laboratory tests reveal elevated bilirubin levels. Hemoglobin electrophoresis shows abnormal hemoglobin patterns. The patient has a history of beta-thalassemia minor. Which of the following is least likely to be associated with the formation of pigmented gallstones? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Beta-thalassemia minor

 

Beta-thalassemia minor (also called beta-thalassemia trait) is the least likely cause of pigmented gallstones among the options because it is typically asymptomatic and represents an incidental diagnosis. Patients with beta-thalassemia minor usually have mild or no hemolysis, and therefore do not develop the excessive bilirubin production that leads to pigmented gallstone formation. They generally have minimal symptoms, with only mild anemia that does not require treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hemoglobin D (HbD) Punjab: Incorrect. While Hemoglobin D Punjab by itself may cause minimal symptoms, it can lead to increased hemolysis when co-existing with other hemoglobinopathies like thalassemia or sickle cell disease. This hemolysis can result in increased bilirubin production and subsequent pigmented gallstone formation.

 

Option C. G6PD deficiency: Incorrect. G6PD deficiency causes episodes of acute hemolysis typically triggered by certain drugs, infections, or foods like fava beans. During these hemolytic episodes, there is increased bilirubin production that can contribute to pigmented gallstone formation over time.

 

Option D. Sickle cell disease: Incorrect. Sickle cell disease is strongly associated with pigmented gallstone formation due to chronic hemolysis. The sickle hemoglobin causes red blood cells to become rigid and break down prematurely, resulting in increased bilirubin production. This makes sickle cell disease one of the most common causes of pigmented gallstones among hemoglobinopathies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Beta-thalassemia minor (trait) is typically asymptomatic and not associated with significant hemolysis or pigmented gallstone formation, in contrast to other hemoglobinopathies like sickle cell disease that cause chronic hemolysis and increased bilirubin production.

questions.text: A tumor marker analysis shows elevated alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) levels in a patient. Which of the following conditions is most commonly associated with increased AFP? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hepatocellular carcinoma

 

Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) is a tumor marker that is most strongly associated with hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). AFP is a glycoprotein normally produced during fetal development by the yolk sac and fetal liver. After birth, AFP levels decrease rapidly and remain low throughout adult life. In HCC, malignant hepatocytes revert to a more primitive state and resume AFP production, leading to elevated serum levels. AFP is considered one of the most important diagnostic and monitoring markers for HCC.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Seminoma: Incorrect. Pure seminomas typically do not produce AFP. AFP elevation in testicular tumors is characteristic of non-seminomatous germ cell tumors (NSGCTs) like yolk sac tumors and embryonal carcinomas. The presence of elevated AFP in a patient with testicular cancer would rule out pure seminoma.

 

Option B. Hepatic adenoma: Incorrect. Hepatic adenomas are benign liver tumors that generally do not produce AFP. While there might be mild elevations in some cases, significant AFP elevation is not characteristic of hepatic adenomas.

 

Option D. Bronchogenic carcinoma: Incorrect. Bronchogenic carcinoma is not typically associated with elevated AFP levels. The tumor markers more commonly associated with lung cancer include CEA, CYFRA 21-1, NSE (for small cell carcinoma), and ProGRP.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hepatocellular carcinoma is the most common malignancy associated with significantly elevated alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) levels, making AFP an important diagnostic and monitoring marker for this cancer.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man presents with an ulcerative lesion near the medial canthus of his eye, featuring pearly margins. Microscopic examination reveals a palisading arrangement of cells, along with keratin pearls. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Basal cell carcinoma

 

The clinical presentation of an ulcerative lesion with pearly margins in the medial canthus (inner corner) of the eye is highly characteristic of basal cell carcinoma (BCC). This location is a common site for BCC, which is also known as "rodent ulcer" or "tear cancer" due to its predilection for the periocular region. The microscopic finding of palisading arrangement of cells is a hallmark feature of BCC, where the peripheral cells arrange themselves in a palisade-like pattern. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Keratoacanthoma: Incorrect. While keratoacanthoma may present as an ulcerative lesion, it typically has a central keratin-filled crater rather than pearly margins. It usually grows rapidly over a few weeks and is most commonly found on sun-exposed areas like the face, forearms, and hands. It lacks the characteristic palisading arrangement seen in this case.

 

Option B. Melanocytic melanoma: Incorrect. Melanoma presents as a pigmented lesion with irregular borders and color variations. It does not typically have pearly margins or palisading arrangement of cells on microscopy. Instead, it shows atypical melanocytes with nuclear pleomorphism and invasion.

 

Option C. Squamous cell carcinoma: Incorrect. While squamous cell carcinoma can present as an ulcerative lesion and does feature keratin pearls microscopically, it typically lacks the pearly margins described in this case. Additionally, the palisading arrangement of cells is not characteristic of squamous cell carcinoma but is a hallmark feature of basal cell carcinoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Basal cell carcinoma presenting as an ulcerative lesion with pearly margins (rodent ulcer) is characteristic, especially in the periocular region, with microscopic findings of peripheral palisading arrangement of basaloid cells.

questions.text: A young patient presents with rapidly growing lymph nodes around the jaw. His biopsy confirms the diagnosis of Burkitt's lymphoma. Which gene mutation is most commonly implicated in this condition? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) C-myc

 

Burkitt's lymphoma is characterized by translocation involving the C-myc proto-oncogene. The most common translocation is t(8;14), which places the C-myc gene (located on chromosome 8) under the control of immunoglobulin heavy chain enhancers (located on chromosome 14). Less commonly, translocations t(2;8) or t(8;22) may occur. These translocations result in overexpression of the C-myc proto-oncogene, leading to uncontrolled cell proliferation. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rb: Incorrect. The Rb (Retinoblastoma) gene is a tumor suppressor gene located on chromosome 13q14. Mutations in this gene are associated with retinoblastoma, not Burkitt's lymphoma. Rb gene inactivation is also found in other cancers like osteosarcoma and small cell lung carcinoma.

 

Option B. p53: Incorrect. The p53 gene is often called the "guardian of the genome" and is a key tumor suppressor gene. While p53 mutations are common in many cancers, they are not the characteristic genetic alteration in Burkitt's lymphoma. p53 mutations are more commonly associated with Li-Fraumeni syndrome and play a role in many sporadic cancers.

 

Option D. K-RAS: Incorrect. K-RAS gene mutations are commonly associated with cancers of the gastrointestinal tract, particularly colorectal and pancreatic cancers. They are not typically implicated in the pathogenesis of Burkitt's lymphoma. K-RAS mutations lead to constitutive activation of the RAS signaling pathway, resulting in uncontrolled cell growth.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Burkitt's lymphoma is characterized by translocation of the C-myc proto-oncogene, most commonly t(8;14), resulting in overexpression of C-myc and rapid cellular proliferation.

questions.text: Which of the following is the earliest time when triphenyltetrazolium chloride (TTC) staining can detect changes after a myocardial infarction? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 2-3 hours

 

Triphenyltetrazolium chloride (TTC) staining is used for the gross assessment of myocardial infarction. TTC reacts with the lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) enzyme present in viable cardiac myocytes, producing a brick-red color in normal, viable myocardium. In infarcted areas, where the LDH enzyme has leaked out of damaged cells into the bloodstream, the tissue remains unstained (pale or white). This change can be detected as early as 2-3 hours after infarction, making it one of the earliest gross diagnostic methods for myocardial infarction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 6-12 hours: Incorrect. By 6-12 hours, TTC staining would already show clear evidence of infarction. This timeframe is too late to be considered the earliest time for detection using TTC staining.

 

Option C. 12-24 hours: Incorrect. At this stage, myocardial infarction would show extensive changes on TTC staining, with well-defined areas of pallor representing infarcted tissue. This is well beyond the earliest detection time.

 

Option D. After 24 hours: Incorrect. This represents a late stage in the evolution of myocardial infarction, when multiple other changes including coagulative necrosis and inflammatory cell infiltration are occurring. TTC staining can detect changes much earlier than this timeframe.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Triphenyl Tetrazolium Chloride (TTC) staining can detect myocardial infarction changes as early as 2-3 hours post-infarction by identifying areas where LDH enzyme has leaked from damaged cardiac cells.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents with recurrent headaches, visual disturbances, and features of increased intracranial tension. CT imaging reveals a well-circumscribed brain lesion, and its biopsy shows psammoma bodies. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Meningioma

 

Meningioma is the most likely diagnosis based on the clinical presentation and histopathological findings. Meningiomas are typically well-circumscribed, slow-growing tumors arising from the arachnoid meningothelial cells. The hallmark histological finding of psammoma bodies—concentric rings of calcification—is characteristic of meningiomas. These tumors commonly present with symptoms of increased intracranial pressure such as headaches and visual disturbances.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Schwannoma: Incorrect. Schwannomas arise from Schwann cells of peripheral nerves or cranial nerves (most commonly CN VIII). They typically present with symptoms related to the affected nerve rather than generalized increased intracranial pressure. Histologically, they show Antoni A (hypercellular) and Antoni B (hypocellular) areas with Verocay bodies, not psammoma bodies.

 

Option B. Medulloblastoma: Incorrect. Medulloblastomas are aggressive, highly malignant tumors that primarily affect children and typically arise in the cerebellum. They present with cerebellar symptoms and features of increased intracranial pressure due to obstruction of CSF flow. Histologically, they show small round blue cells with Homer Wright rosettes, not psammoma bodies.

 

 

Option C. Ependymoma: Incorrect. Ependymomas arise from ependymal cells lining the ventricles and central canal of the spinal cord. They typically occur in children and young adults, often presenting with hydrocephalus due to CSF obstruction. Microscopically, they show perivascular pseudorosettes and true ependymal rosettes, not psammoma bodies.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Meningiomas are characterized by the presence of psammoma bodies (concentric calcifications) on histopathological examination and typically present as well-circumscribed lesions causing symptoms of increased intracranial pressure.

questions.text: A thyroid biopsy shows follicular cells with eosinophilic cytoplasm and extracellular amyloid depositions.  In which of the following thyroid conditions is this finding commonly seen? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Medullary carcinoma

 

Medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC) is characterized by the presence of extracellular amyloid deposits, which are composed of calcitonin. This is a distinctive feature of MTC that helps differentiate it from other thyroid cancers. MTC originates from the parafollicular C cells of the thyroid gland, which normally produce calcitonin. Amyloid deposition is a key diagnostic feature of MTC and appears as an extracellular pinkish material that stains positive with Congo red and shows apple-green birefringence under polarized light.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hurthle cell carcinoma: Incorrect. While Hurthle cell carcinoma does feature cells with abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm (due to mitochondrial accumulation), it does not typically show extracellular amyloid deposition. Hurthle cells are characterized by their large size, granular eosinophilic cytoplasm, and prominent nucleoli.

 

 

Option C. Papillary carcinoma: Incorrect. Papillary thyroid carcinoma is characterized by papillary architecture and distinctive nuclear features (orphan Annie nuclei, nuclear grooves, and pseudoinclusions). While calcifications may be present (psammoma bodies), extracellular amyloid deposition is not a feature of papillary carcinoma.

 

Option D. Anaplastic carcinoma: Incorrect. Anaplastic thyroid carcinoma is a highly aggressive undifferentiated tumor characterized by pleomorphic giant cells, spindle cells, and marked nuclear atypia. It does not show the organized pattern of amyloid deposition seen in medullary carcinoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Medullary Thyroid Cancer

 

  • Only thyroid cancer that arises from parafollicular cells known as 'C cells.
  • Gene association: RET Gene mutation.
  • Tumor markers: Calcitonin and Carcinoembryonic
    • Antigen; CEA in calcitonin negative cancer
  • Acal: Amyloid (Congo red positive)
  • Histology: Polygonal cells with/without Amyloid deposition.
  • Electon microscopy: Neurosecretory granules.

 

 

Clinical features: due to secretion of ACTH (Cushing syndrome) and VIP (Diarrhoea)

 

Variants → Sporadic (Unilateral solitary mass) OR Familial (Bilateral & Multicentric)

questions.text: A 50-year-old female presents with a 3 cm breast mass. The mass was excised, and microscopic examination reveals abundant extracellular mucin surrounding tumor cells. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mucinous carcinoma of the breast

 

Mucinous carcinoma of the breast (also called colloid carcinoma) is characterized by the presence of abundant extracellular mucin surrounding clusters of tumor cells. This creates the distinctive histological appearance of "islands of tumor cells floating in lakes of mucin." Mucinous carcinoma typically presents as a well-circumscribed, soft, gelatinous mass and is more common in older women. It generally has a better prognosis than other types of invasive breast carcinoma.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lobular carcinoma of the breast: Incorrect. Invasive lobular carcinoma is characterized by small, uniform cells arranged in single file or "Indian file" pattern.
