The cells often have an intracytoplasmic lumen containing mucin (signet ring appearance), but the extracellular abundant mucin pools described in the question are not a feature of lobular carcinoma.

 

Option C. Medullary carcinoma of the breast: Incorrect. Medullary carcinoma features sheets of large, pleomorphic cells with prominent nucleoli and a syncytial growth pattern. It is typically well-circumscribed and has prominent lymphoplasmacytic infiltration. Extracellular mucin is not a characteristic feature of medullary carcinoma.

 

Option D. Phyllodes tumor: Incorrect. Phyllodes tumor is a fibroepithelial lesion characterized by leaf-like projections into cystic spaces. It has both epithelial and stromal components, with the stroma showing increased cellularity. Extracellular mucin is not a feature of phyllodes tumor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mucinous carcinoma of the breast is characterized histologically by clusters of tumor cells floating in abundant extracellular mucin pools, giving it a distinctive appearance and generally conferring a better prognosis than other invasive breast carcinomas.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with fever and fatigue 3 weeks after undergoing mitral valve replacement surgery. Blood cultures are positive for a gram-positive cocci that produces a biofilm. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism of his condition? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Staphylococcus epidermidis

 

Staphylococcus epidermidis is the most likely causative organism in this case. It is a coagulase-negative staphylococcus that commonly causes infections associated with prosthetic devices, including prosthetic heart valves. S. epidermidis is known for its ability to produce biofilms, which are extracellular polymeric substances that allow the bacteria to adhere to foreign materials like prosthetic valves. The biofilm also protects the bacteria from antibiotics and host immune responses, making these infections difficult to treat. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Streptococcus pyogenes: Incorrect. S. pyogenes (Group A Streptococcus) is not typically associated with prosthetic valve endocarditis. It more commonly causes pharyngitis, impetigo, necrotizing fasciitis, and rheumatic fever. It does not characteristically form biofilms on prosthetic materials.

 

Option C. Streptococcus pneumoniae: Incorrect. While S. pneumoniae can cause native valve endocarditis, it is not commonly associated with prosthetic valve infections or biofilm formation. It is primarily a respiratory pathogen causing pneumonia, sinusitis, otitis media, and meningitis.

 

Option D. Escherichia coli: Incorrect. E. coli is a gram-negative rod, not a gram-positive cocci. While it can cause various infections including urinary tract infections and sepsis, it is not a common cause of prosthetic valve endocarditis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Staphylococcus epidermidis is a coagulase-negative staphylococcus that commonly causes prosthetic valve endocarditis due to its ability to form biofilms on foreign materials, typically presenting weeks after valve replacement surgery.

questions.text: A female patient with dysphagia more for liquids in comparison to solids is likely to have which of the following finding in her barium swallow? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Smooth tapering of lower end

 

In achalasia cardia, there is a selective loss of inhibitory neurons in the lower esophagus, particularly affecting the lower esophageal sphincter. This neuronal loss leads to a characteristic radiological appearance of smooth tapering at the lower end of the esophagus, often referred to as the "bird beak" appearance. The patient experiences dysphagia, with more difficulty swallowing liquids compared to solids due to the impaired esophageal motility.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Irregular filling defect: Typically associated with other esophageal pathologies like tumors or strictures, not characteristic of achalasia.

 

Option B. Rat tail appearance: Classically associated with gastric carcinoma during barium studies. This sign indicates an infiltrative tumor at the pylorus or distal stomach, creating a narrowed, tapered appearance resembling a rat's tail. It is not a characteristic finding in esophageal disorders.

 

Option D. Corkscrew appearance: This radiological sign is typically seen in diffuse esophageal spasm. This is not a characteristic radiological feature of achalasia cardia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The radiological hallmark of achalasia cardia: smooth tapering of the lower esophageal end (bird beak appearance) due to loss of inhibitory neurons.

questions.text: A long-standing smoker has shortness of breath, and spirometry shows FEV₁ 60% with FEV₁/FVC ratio <0.6. Which of the following is the likely cause of the findings in this patient? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) COPD

 

The spirometry findings are classic for an obstructive lung disorder. An FEV₁ less than 80% and an FEV₁/FVC ratio less than 0.7 are diagnostic criteria for obstructive lung disease. The patient's long-standing smoking history and these specific spirometry results strongly point to Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD), which includes conditions like chronic bronchitis and emphysema.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Silicosis: This is a restrictive lung disorder caused by inhalation of silica dust, typically seen in workers like miners and sandblasters. It would show a reduced FEV₁/FVC ratio characteristic of restrictive lung diseases, not obstructive.

 

Option B. Interstitial lung disease: Another restrictive lung disorder characterized by inflammation and scarring of lung tissue. It would also demonstrate reduced lung volumes and a decreased FEV₁/FVC ratio typical of restrictive diseases.

 

Option D. Bronchogenic carcinoma: While associated with smoking, this is a space-occupying lesion that might affect lung function but is not primarily a cause of obstructive lung disease. It would not typically cause the classic spirometry changes seen in this question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

FEV₁/FVC ratio <0.7 indicates obstructive lung disease. COPD is the most common obstructive lung disease in smokers, while conditions like silicosis and interstitial lung disease present with restrictive patterns (normal or increased FEV₁/FVC ratio).

questions.text: In a patient with electrical burns and stable vital signs, red-coloured urine is observed with increased levels of creatinine kinase. Which of the following is a likely finding in the patient’s examination? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Increased creatinine levels

 

Electrical burns cause significant skeletal muscle damage, leading to the release of myoglobin into the bloodstream. Myoglobin can cause acute kidney injury, resulting in increased creatinine levels. The red-coloured urine is due to myoglobinuria, which is a hallmark of severe muscle damage. The elevated creatinine kinase levels confirm extensive muscle injury.

 

Other Options: 


Option A. Red blood cells in urine: This is not characteristic of electrical burn injury. The red coloration is due to myoglobin, not red blood cells, and would not be the primary finding in this scenario.

 

Option C. Decreased hemoglobin levels: Electrical burns primarily cause muscle damage, not significant blood loss. There's no direct mechanism in this scenario to explain a decrease in hemoglobin levels.

 

Option D. Increased bilirubin levels: This is not a typical finding in electrical burns. Hemolysis is not the primary concern in this type of injury, and bilirubin levels would not be significantly elevated.

 

Educational Objective: 


Electrical burns can cause myoglobinuria and acute kidney injury, leading to increased creatinine levels.

questions.text: A 18-year-old patient with anasarca is found to have proteinuria of 4.5 g/day, increased cholesterol levels, and hypoalbuminemia. Which of the following is a recommended treatment for this individual? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Prednisolone

 

The clinical presentation describes classic nephrotic syndrome, characterized by massive proteinuria (>3.5 g/day), hypoalbuminemia, and increased cholesterol levels. In such cases, especially in younger patients, the initial treatment is prednisolone, an immunosuppressive therapy aimed at reducing podocyte damage. The goal is to control proteinuria and prevent further kidney damage.

 

Other Options: 


Option A. Intravenous albumin: Not an effective long-term treatment. Albumin infusion is ineffective because the patient continues to lose albumin through urine, making it a temporary and ultimately futile intervention.

 

Option C. Cyclophosphamide: This is a more aggressive immunosuppressive therapy typically reserved for steroid-resistant or more severe cases of nephrotic syndrome, not as first-line treatment.

 

Option D. Prednisolone and cyclophosphamide: Combination therapy is usually considered only in advanced or treatment-resistant cases, not as initial management for a typical nephrotic syndrome presentation.

 

Educational Objective:


Prednisolone is the first-line immunosuppressive treatment for nephrotic syndrome, particularly in younger patients.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of Pancoast tumor? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Exophthalmos

 

Pancoast tumor is a tumor of the lung apex that involves compression of the sympathetic chain (particularly the stellate ganglion), causing a constellation of symptoms known as Horner's syndrome. 

 

This syndrome includes;

 

  • Miosis (Pupillary Constriction)
  • Anhidrosis (Decreased Sweating)
  • Ptosis (Drooping of The Upper Eyelid)
  • Enophthalmos (Sunken Eye)

 

Exophthalmos, which is the protrusion of the eyeball, is not a feature of Pancoast tumor or Horner's syndrome. 

 

Educational Objective: 


Pancoast tumor causes Horner's syndrome, which includes miosis, anhidrosis, ptosis, and enophthalmos (MAPE). Exophthalmos is not a feature of Pancoast tumor

questions.text: Identify the type of epiphysis marked in the given image: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pressure epiphysis

 

Pressure epiphysis is the part of the bone that bear weight or pressure during movement and are located at the ends of long bones. In the image, the tibia and fibula clearly show the ends where pressure is applied during articulation and weight-bearing, marking these regions as pressure epiphyses.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Traction epiphysis: Incorrect. Traction epiphyses are involved with ligament or tendon attachment points, such as the trochanters of the femur (like greater and lesser trochanters). These do not bear direct weight.

 

Option C. Aberrant epiphysis: Incorrect. Aberrant epiphyses are usually abnormal and occur in locations where epiphyses are not typically present, like the head of the first metacarpal​. They are not typically found at major weight-bearing joints.

 

Option D. Atavistic epiphysis: Incorrect. Atavistic epiphyses are evolutionary remnants that were previously separate bones in ancestral species but are fused now, such as the coracoid process of the scapula​. They are not related to weight-bearing functions.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A person presents to the clinic with normal eye closure and intact facial wrinkles but paralysis of the lower half of the face on the right side. Which structure is most likely involved in this case? ((FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) left CN 7 supranuclear lesion 

 

The presentation describes a supranuclear (upper motor neuron) lesion of the facial nerve on the right side. 

 

In supranuclear lesions of CN7

 

  • The upper facial muscles (for eye closure and forehead wrinkles) receive bilateral cortical innervation, so they are spared in supranuclear lesions  
  • The lower facial muscles receive only contralateral cortical innervation 
  • Due to decussation of nerve fibers, a left supranuclear lesion causes right-sided lower facial weakness
    • Since the right lower face is paralyzed, the lesion must be in the left corticobulbar tract, making the correct answer "Left CN 7 Supranuclear lesion" 

 

Other Options:

 

 Option A. Left CN 7 Infranuclear lesion: Incorrect because infranuclear (lower motor neuron) lesions cause complete ipsilateral facial paralysis affecting both upper and lower face.

 

Option B. Right CN 7 Supranuclear lesion: Incorrect because a right supranuclear lesion would cause left sided lower facial weakness due to decussation of fibers.

 

Option D. Right CN 7 Infranuclear lesion: Incorrect because infranuclear lesions cause complete facial paralysis on the same side, including forehead and eye closure.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  1. Supranuclear lesions: Preserve forehead wrinkles and eye closure but affect contralateral lower face
  2. Infranuclear lesions: Cause complete ipsilateral facial paralysis affecting both upper and lower face

questions.text: A Child presents with asymmetric crying face and inability to close the left eye as shown in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Facial nerve palsy

 

The clinical features shown in the image are characteristic of facial nerve (CN VII) palsy, also known as Bell's palsy.

 

Important features: 

 

  • Inability to close the eye (loss of orbicularis oculi function) 
  • Asymmetry of face 
  • Deviation of mouth to the normal side 
  • Loss of wrinkling and nasolabial fold on affected side This is due to damage to the facial nerve which supplies all muscles of facial expression including orbicularis oculi, buccinator, and other facial muscles.
  • The facial nerve emerges at the pontomedullary junction and exits through the stylomastoid foramen.
  • Facial nerve palsy can be idiopathic (Bell’s palsy) or secondary to infections (e.g., Herpes simplex, Ramsay Hunt syndrome), trauma, tumors, or stroke.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Oculomotor nerve palsy: 

 

  • Causes ptosis, an enlarged pupil, and an eye deviated "down and out" due to loss of extraocular muscle function.

 

Option C. Orbicularis oculi palsy:

 

  • This muscle is supplied by cranial nerve VII (facial nerve).
  • While paralysis of orbicularis oculi can cause incomplete eyelid closure, it does not affect other facial muscles as seen in facial nerve palsy.

 

Option D. Erb’s palsy

 

  • A brachial plexus injury (C5-C6), often seen in newborns after traumatic delivery.
  • Characterized by "waiter's tip" deformity (adducted, internally rotated arm with extended elbow and flexed wrist).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bell’s palsy - Loss of Wrinkling, Wide palpebral fissure, Whistling loss, loss of nasolabial fold and drooling of saliva

questions.text: A person presents with clawing of the 4th and 5th fingers, accompanied by sensory loss at the tips of the same fingers. Which nerve is most commonly affected in this case? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ulnar nerve

 

The ulnar nerve is responsible for innervating the intrinsic muscles of the hand, including the third and fourth lumbricals, which control the 4th and 5th fingers. A lesion of the ulnar nerve leads to ulnar claw hand, characterized by hyperextension at the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joints and flexion at the interphalangeal (IP) joints of the 4th and 5th fingers.

 

Additionally, sensory loss at the tips of the 4th and 5th fingers aligns with the cutaneous innervation of the ulnar nerve, which supplies the medial one and a half fingers (little finger and half of the ring finger), including their tips.

 

Ulnar nerve injury commonly occurs at:

 

  • The medial epicondyle of the humerus (fracture at this site can damage the ulnar nerve).
  • Guyon's canal (wrist level), which can be compressed in cyclists or due to repetitive trauma (Guyon canal syndrome).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Radial nerve: Incorrect because Radial nerve injury leads to wrist drop, affecting wrist and finger extension. It does not affect the intrinsic muscles of the hand or cause claw deformity.

 

Option C. Median nerve: Incorrect because median nerve supplies the lateral three and a half fingers (thumb, index, middle, and half of the ring finger) and controls the first and second lumbricals. Injury leads to "hand of benediction" when attempting to make a fist, rather than clawing of the 4th and 5th fingers.

 

Option D. Anterior Interosseous nerve: Incorrect because it’s a branch of the median nerve and primarily affects deep forearm muscles (flexor pollicis longus, pronator quadratus, and the lateral half of flexor digitorum profundus), leading to inability to form the "OK" sign (anterior interosseous syndrome). It does not cause clawing of the fingers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ulnar nerve injury leads to ulnar claw hand, which involves hyperextension at the MCP joints and flexion at the IP joints of the 4th and 5th fingers, along with sensory loss in the medial one and a half fingers. The median nerve affects the lateral three and a half fingers, and the radial nerve controls wrist and finger extension.

 

Ulnar Claw hand - Ulnar nerve damage

 

Complete Claw hand - injury of both Ulnar and Median nerve.

questions.text: A patient presents with complains of numbness, tingling, and paresthesia in the lateral three and a half fingers, along with numbness at the base of the thumb. Which nerve is most commonly affected in this case? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Median nerve

 

The median nerve originates from the brachial plexus (C5-T1) and supplies sensory and motor innervation to specific regions of the upper limb. Sensory innervation of the lateral three and a half fingers (thumb, index finger, middle finger, and lateral half of the ring finger) on the palmar side, along with the base of the thumb, is provided by the median nerve.

 

The palmar cutaneous branch of the median nerve supplies sensation to the base of the thumb and The digital cutaneous branches of the median nerve provide sensation to the lateral three and a half fingers.

 

In median nerve compression, such as carpal tunnel syndrome, patients often report numbness, tingling, and paresthesia in the lateral three fingers. This condition occurs due to entrapment of the median nerve at the carpal tunnel, causing dysfunction in the sensory and motor functions it supplies.

 

Injury or compression of the median nerve at the wrist level spares the palmar cutaneous branch but affects the thumb, index, middle fingers, and part of the ring finger on the palmar aspect, leading to characteristic symptoms of numbness and tingling.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Radial nerve: The radial nerve supplies the dorsal aspect of the hand and the posterior forearm. It is not responsible for sensation over the lateral three fingers on the palmar side. Radial nerve injury typically causes wrist drop and loss of sensation over the dorsum of the hand, not numbness in the fingers.

 

Option B. Anterior Interosseous nerve (AIN): The AIN is a motor branch of the median nerve that does not carry sensory fibers. It supplies deep muscles of the forearm, including flexor pollicis longus (FPL), pronator quadratus, and the lateral half of flexor digitorum profundus (FDP). AIN syndrome results in motor deficits such as the inability to make an "OK" sign (due to weakness of FPL and FDP), but no sensory loss, making it an incorrect choice.

 

Option C. Ulnar nerve: The ulnar nerve supplies the medial one and a half fingers (ring finger and little finger) and the hypothenar muscles. Damage to the ulnar nerve would lead to clawing of the 4th and 5th fingers, sensory loss on the medial aspect of the hand, and difficulty with fine motor movements due to intrinsic hand muscle involvement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The median nerve provides sensory innervation to the lateral three and a half fingers on the palmar side and the base of the thumb. Compression of the median nerve at the wrist (e.g., carpal tunnel syndrome) leads to numbness, tingling, and paresthesia in the affected digits without dorsal hand involvement.

questions.text: A patient is undergoing breast surgery, during which several structures are retracted, as shown in the image. Identify the marked muscle given in the image: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Serratus anterior

 

The serratus anterior muscle is clearly visible and marked in the provided image

 

  • The serratus anterior muscle is located on the lateral aspect of the thoracic wall and plays a critical role in scapular protraction and stabilization.
  • It originates from the first to eighth ribs and inserts on the medial border of the scapula.
  • This muscle is often encountered during breast surgeries, mastectomies, and axillary lymph node dissections, where it may need to be retracted to access deeper structures.
  • Is innervated by the long thoracic nerve (nerve of Bell) 
  • Acts as the "boxer's muscle" as it has punching and pushing ability 
  • Its paralysis leads to winging of scapula

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Subscapularis: Incorrect. The subscapularis muscle is part of the rotator cuff muscles and lies deep to the scapula. It is not visible in this view as it is located in Bicipital Groove. Also called as “Forgotten muscle of the Rotator Cuff”

 

Option B. Teres major: Incorrect. It lies posterior wall of axilla, It is not visible in the surgical field during breast surgery

 

Option C. Latissimus dorsi: Incorrect. While the latissimus dorsi muscle is in proximity to the posterior thoracic wall and can be involved in breast reconstruction surgeries (e.g., flap procedures), it does not align with the location or appearance of the marked muscle in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The serratus anterior is a critical muscle encountered in breast surgeries due to its position along the lateral thoracic wall and proximity to the axilla.

questions.text: A carpenter complains of swelling around knee as shown in the given image. What is most probable diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Housemaid knee

 

The condition shown in the image is most consistent with prepatellar bursitis, commonly known as "Housemaid's knee." The bursa acts as a cushion between the patella and skin to reduce friction during movement. prepatellar bursitis is characterized by inflammation of the prepatellar bursa, located just in front of the patella (kneecap). It is often associated with occupations or activities that involve prolonged kneeling, such as carpentry.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Clergyman knee: Incorrect. Also known as infrapatellar bursitis, where the inflammation occurs below the patella due to prolonged kneeling. However, the swelling is typically observed in the infrapatellar region, not over the prepatellar area as seen in this case.

 

Option C. Abscess: Incorrect. While an abscess can cause localized swelling, it is often accompanied by additional signs of infection such as redness, warmth, pain, and systemic symptoms like fever

 

Option D. Oedema: Incorrect. Oedema is generalized swelling due to fluid accumulation, not be localized to just the prepatellar area it typically affects both legs and show pitting on pressure

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prepatellar bursitis, or "Housemaid's knee," results from repetitive trauma or prolonged kneeling. It presents as localized swelling over the prepatellar area and is a common occupational hazard for individuals who frequently kneel, such as carpenters.

questions.text: A patient presents with post-auricular numbness and a thickened cord-like structure in the cervical region. Identify the most likely structure involved: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Greater auricular nerve

 

The greater auricular nerve (C2, C3) branch of the cervical plexus is the most likely structure involved in this case. The symptoms described - post-auricular numbness and a thickened cord-like structure - are characteristic of great auricular nerve involvement. This nerve has two important divisions:

 

  • Anterior division: supplies the angle of the mandible (shaving area)
  • Posterior division: supplies the auricle (pinna) The nerve runs towards the ear/pinna and is responsible for sensory innervation of this region. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. External jugular vein: Incorrect. This vein is located superficially in the cervical region, but its pathology, such as thrombosis, typically presents with redness, swelling, and engorgement. 

 

Option B. Cervical lymph nodes: Incorrect. Enlarged or inflamed lymph nodes are usually nodular and can cause tenderness but not numbness unless compressing a nearby nerve. 

 

Option C. Superficial thrombophlebitis: Incorrect. This condition involves inflammation of superficial veins and is characterized by redness, pain, and warmth along the course of the vein. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The greater auricular nerve (C2, C3) provides sensory innervation to the skin over the parotid region, auricle, and angle of the mandible. Lesions or compression of this nerve can lead to post-auricular numbness and symptoms along its anatomical path.

questions.text: What is the level of the lymph nodes marked in the image? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Level III

 

In the image, the arrow points to the middle portion of the sternocleidomastoid muscle, which corresponds to Level III cervical lymph nodes. Level III nodes are located around the middle third of the internal jugular vein and sternocleidomastoid muscle, between the level II and level IV nodes. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Level I: Incorrect as Level I includes submental (IA) and submandibular (IB) lymph nodes, located below the mandible and chin.

 

Option C. Level IV: Incorrect as Level IV nodes are located in the lower third of the sternocleidomastoid muscle, below the level indicated by the arrow.

 

Option D. Level II: Incorrect as Level II nodes are located in the upper third of the sternocleidomastoid muscle, above the level indicated by the arrow.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Level III nodes are located around the middle third of the internal jugular vein and sternocleidomastoid muscle.

questions.text: Identify the marked structure in the given image. (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pharyngobasilar Fascia

 

The arrow in the image points to the pharyngobasilar fascia, which is a key fascia in the tonsillar region. The pharyngobasilar fascia is a modification of the deep cervical fascia that extends between the skull base and the pharyngeal muscles. It helps form the bed of the tonsil along with other structures and provides structural support to the pharynx. In the tonsillar region, the pharyngobasilar fascia forms part of the complex fascial arrangements that include the capsule, loose areolar tissue, and other fascial layers.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Superior Constrictor: Incorrect because the superior constrictor muscle lies deep to the marked structure and is a muscular component rather than a fascial layer.

 

Option B. Capsule: Incorrect because the tonsillar capsule is a distinct structure that immediately surrounds the tonsillar tissue, whereas the marked structure is a broader fascial layer.

 

Option C. Buccopharyngeal Fascia: Incorrect because the buccopharyngeal fascia is another fascial modification that lies external to the pharyngobasilar fascia and covers the buccinator muscle and pharyngeal muscles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fig: Relations of tonsil. Tonsil is related laterally to its capsule (1), loose areolar tissue containing paraton- sillar vein (2), superior constrictor muscle (3), styloglossus (4), glossopharyngeal nerve (5), facial artery (6), medial pterygoid muscle (7), angle of mandible (8) and sub- mandibular salivary gland (9), pharyngobasilar fascia (10), buccopharyngeal fascia (11).

questions.text: A patient experienced difficulty maintaining balance immediately after a roller coaster ride. Which of the following is most likely involved in the normal balance mechanism?(FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vestibulospinal tract

 

The vestibulospinal tract is responsible for maintaining balance and posture. It originates from the vestibular nuclei in the brainstem and plays a crucial role in equilibrium. When balance is disrupted, as in this case after a roller coaster ride, the vestibulospinal tract helps in regaining postural stability by:

 

  • Receiving input from the vestibular apparatus
  • Coordinating with antigravity muscles
  • Making postural adjustments to maintain balance
  • Working with the vestibular system for maintaining equilibrium

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rubrospinal tract: (Incorrect)

 

  • This tract is part of the extrapyramidal system
  • It helps in flexor muscle control
  • Not primarily involved in balance maintenance
  • Works with rubrospinal tract and reticulospinal tract for gross motor movements

 

Option C. Corticospinal tract: (Incorrect)

 

  • This is the main motor pathway for voluntary movements
  • Originates from the motor cortex
  • Not directly involved in balance maintenance
  • Controls fine, skilled movements

 

Option D. Reticulospinal tract: (Incorrect)

 

  • Part of the extrapyramidal system
  • Involved in autonomic functions and crude movements
  • While it contributes to posture, it's not the primary tract for balance
  • Originates from reticular formation

 

Educational Objective:

 

The vestibulospinal tract is primarily responsible for maintaining balance and posture by integrating vestibular system input and facilitating extensor muscle activity to stabilize the body during motion and positional changes. It plays a crucial role in postural adjustments following vestibular disturbances, such as those experienced after rapid or erratic motion, like a roller coaster ride.

questions.text: Identify the pointed structure shown in the image. (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Right Hepatic artery

 

The image shows the blood supply of the gallbladder region. The arrow pointed towards  the Right Hepatic artery. It’s a branch of the Proper Hepatic artery and supplies the right lobe of the liver. The Right Hepatic artery gives off the Cystic artery which supplies the gallbladder. It is important because:

 

  • It is one of the components of Calot's triangle
  • Landmark for surgical procedures like cholecystectomy
  • It has a relatively constant anatomical position in relation to the bile duct and portal vein

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Left Hepatic artery: Incorrect because Left Hepatic artery supplies the left lobe of liver.It does not have a direct relationship with gallbladder and it Would be located on the other side of the proper hepatic artery bifurcation

 

Option C. Common Hepatic artery: Incorrect because Common Hepatic artery is a branch of celiac trunk.It divides into Proper Hepatic artery and Gastroduodenal artery

 

Option D. Cystic artery: Incorrect because Cystic artery is a branch of Right Hepatic artery. It directly supplies the gallbladder

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Right Hepatic artery is a branch of the proper hepatic artery that supplies the right lobe of the liver. It is an important anatomical structure in hepatobiliary surgery, as it gives rise to the cystic artery within Calot's triangle.

questions.text: Identify the structure marked by the arrow in the image. (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pouch of Douglas

 

The arrow in the image points to the pouch of Douglas, also known as the rectouterine pouch. It is located between the rectum posteriorly and the uterus anteriorly in females. This is the most dependent part of the peritoneal cavity in the supine position. The pouch of Douglas is clinically significant as it is a common site for collection of pathological fluids like pus, blood, or malignant cells due to its dependent position.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vesicouterine pouch: This is incorrect as the vesicouterine pouch is located between the bladder and uterus anteriorly, not between the rectum and uterus as shown in the image.

 

Option B. Morrison's pouch: This is incorrect as Morrison's pouch (hepatorenal pouch) is located between the liver and right kidney in the upper abdomen, not in the pelvis.

 

Option D. Supravesical fossa: This is a small peritoneal depression located above the bladder, but it is not a significant space for fluid accumulation compared to the Pouch of Douglas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Pouch of Douglas is the rectouterine pouch, the most dependent part of the peritoneal cavity in females, where pathological fluid collections are often found during clinical evaluation.

questions.text: A patient has an urge to urinate but he is not able to do. He has history of a fall astride injury. On examination blood is seen at meatus. Which of the following injury is most common? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bulbar urethra rupture

 

A patient with a fall astride injury, presenting with an inability to urinate and blood at the urethral meatus, strongly suggests a bulbar urethral rupture. The bulbar urethra is the most commonly injured part of the urethra in straddle injuries, which occur due to forceful compression against the pubic symphysis (e.g., falling onto a hard object like a bicycle crossbar or a beam).

 

  • The bulbar urethra is located within the superficial perineal pouch, and when it ruptures, urine and blood can accumulate in the superficial perineal space, leading to perineal swelling and hematoma.
  • Blood at the meatus is a classical sign of anterior urethral injury, which is often associated with bulbar urethral trauma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Membranous urethra rupture: Incorrect

 

  • The membranous urethra is commonly injured in pelvic fractures (e.g., motor vehicle accidents), not in straddle injuries. It is located in the deep perineal pouch, and its rupture leads to urine accumulation in the deep perineal space and retropubic space.
  • Patients with membranous urethral injuries often present with high-riding prostate on rectal examination, which is absent in this case.

 

Option C. Extraperitoneal urethra rupture: Incorrect

 

  • Extraperitoneal urethral rupture usually occurs with pelvic fractures, affecting the posterior urethra (prostatic or membranous urethra).
  • It leads to urine extravasation around the bladder, visible as fluid collection in the retropubic space on imaging.

 

Option D. Intraperitoneal urethra rupture: Incorrect

 

  • Intraperitoneal rupture typically refers to bladder rupture, not urethral injury.
  • It occurs due to a direct blow to a full bladder, leading to urine leakage into the peritoneal cavity, which presents with peritonitis symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bulbar urethral rupture is the most common site of urethral injury in straddle injuries, presenting with blood at the urethral meatus, perineal hematoma, and urinary retention.

questions.text: Identify the structure shown in the image: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Blastocyst

 

The image shows a blastocyst, which is a developmental stage formed on the 4th day of embryonic development. 

 

  • An outer cell mass (trophoblast) that appears as a single layer of cells forming the wall
  • An inner cell mass which will form the embryo proper
  • A fluid-filled cavity is clearly visible, which is characteristic of a blastocyst The blastocyst contains approximately 32 cells and is formed from the morula stage when fluid begins to accumulate between the cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Morula: Incorrect because a morula is a solid ball of 16 cells without any cavity, formed on day 3 of development. The image clearly shows a cavity and cell differentiation.

 

Option C. Zygote: Incorrect because a zygote is a single cell formed by fusion of sperm and egg. The image shows multiple cells arranged in a specific pattern.

 

Option D. Gastrula: Incorrect because gastrula is a later stage of development after blastocyst, characterized by three germ layers. The image shows only two cell populations typical of a blastocyst.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The blastocyst is a key structure in early human development that forms around day 5 post-fertilization and is essential for implantation. It consists of a trophoblast and an inner cell mass, which give rise to the placenta and embryo, respectively.

questions.text: Identify the congenital abnormality shown in the image? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Open Neural Tube Defect

 

The image shows an open neural tube defect (ONTD) where there is complete non-closure of the neural tube during embryonic development. It specifically shows anterior neuropore defect characterized by:

 

  • Absent cranial vault
  • Exposed neural tissue
  • Exophthalmos (prominent eyes)
  • Chin resting on chest This represents a severe form of neural tube defect where both anterior and posterior neuropores have failed to close by day 28 of embryonic development.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Myelomeningocele: While this is also a neural tube defect, it specifically refers to protrusion of spinal cord and meninges through a defect in vertebral column. The image shows a more extensive defect.

 

Option B. Spina bifida occulta: This is a mild form where vertebral arches fail to fuse but spinal cord remains intact and covered by skin. The image shows exposed neural tissue.

 

 

Option C. Anencephaly: A failure of the cranial neuropore to close, leading to absence of the skull and most of the brain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 Open Neural Tube Defects (ONTDs) result from incomplete closure of the neural tube during early development. They can manifest in various forms, including myelomeningocele and anencephaly, depending on the site of the defect. Adequate maternal folate supplementation is critical for reducing the risk of ONTDs.

questions.text: Identify the cell shown in the image. (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Purkinje cell


Purkinje cells are large, flask-shaped neurons located in the cerebellar cortex. The image clearly demonstrates a Purkinje cell with its prominent size, distinctive flask-shaped soma, and its arrangement within the cerebellum. These cells are crucial for cerebellar function as they integrate excitatory and inhibitory inputs to modulate motor coordination and balance. They are positioned in the Purkinje cell layer, sandwiched between the molecular layer and the granular layer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Basket cell: Incorrect.Basket cells are inhibitory interneurons found in the molecular layer of the cerebellum. They are smaller and have dendritic arbors that do not resemble the prominent flask-shaped soma of Purkinje cells.

 

Option B. Stellate cell: Incorrect. Stellate cells are also located in the molecular layer and are smaller interneurons with star-like dendritic arbors. They lack the unique morphology of Purkinje cells.

 

Option D. Golgi cell: Incorrect. Golgi cells are found in the granular layer of the cerebellum and are larger interneurons but do not have the flask-shaped soma characteristic of Purkinje cells.

 

Educational Objective:


Purkinje cells are large, flask-shaped neurons located in the Purkinje layer of the cerebellum. They play a critical role in motor coordination by integrating multiple inputs and sending inhibitory signals to the cerebellar nuclei.

questions.text: Identify the type of cartilage shown in the image. (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Elastic cartilage

 

The image shows elastic cartilage, characterized by:

 

  • More loosely arranged chondrocytes
  • Matrix containing fine elastic fibers (appearing as thin branching lines)
  • Less ground substance compared to hyaline cartilage
  • Multiple nuclei visible in each lacuna
  • The elastic fibers provide flexibility while maintaining shape
  • Found in structures like ear pinna, epiglottis, and parts of the larynx

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hyaline cartilage: Incorrect because hyaline cartilage has a more homogeneous glassy matrix without visible fibers and more regularly arranged chondrocytes.

 

Option C. Fibrocartilage: Incorrect because fibrocartilage shows dense parallel bundles of collagen fibers with chondrocytes arranged in rows between them, which is not seen here.

 

Option D. Articular cartilage: Incorrect because articular cartilage is a type of hyaline cartilage found at joint surfaces. The histological features shown here are characteristic of elastic cartilage, not articular cartilage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Elastic cartilage is identified by the presence of elastic fibers within its matrix, which provides flexibility and strength. It is found in the pinna of the ear, epiglottis, and Eustachian tube.

questions.text: Identify the structure shown in the image.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Thymus

 

The histological image shows the thymus, a primary lymphoid organ responsible for T-cell maturation. Key features of the thymus seen in the image include:

 

  • Lobular architecture with a cortex (darker staining due to densely packed immature T cells) and a medulla (lighter staining due to less dense mature T cells).
  • Presence of Hassall's corpuscles in the medulla, which are unique to the thymus.
  • Absence of lymphoid follicles, which differentiates it from secondary lymphoid organs like lymph nodes and spleen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lymph Node: Incorrect. A lymph node has distinct cortical follicles, germinal centers, and a medullary sinus. The image does not show any of these structures, ruling out the lymph node.

 

Option B. Palatine Tonsil: Incorrect. Palatine tonsils contain lymphoid follicles and crypts. Crypts are absent in the given image, making this option incorrect.

 

Option D. Spleen: Incorrect. The spleen exhibits red pulp (vascular sinusoidal spaces) and white pulp (lymphoid nodules with central arterioles). These features are absent in the image, excluding the spleen as the answer.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A child present with congenital defect in diaphragm which is located on posterior/postero-lateral aspect of chest. What is your diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bochdalek hernia

 

Bochdalek hernia is a congenital diaphragmatic hernia that occurs posterolaterally due to failure of fusion of pleuroperitoneal membrane during development. Based on a mnemonic “BPLLAR” used for diaphragmatic hernias:

 

  • B stands for Bochdalek hernia
  • P stands for posterior location
  • L stands for left side (more common) This type of hernia is more common posteriorly and on the left side.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Morgagni hernia: This occurs anteriorly and on the right side of the diaphragm. Using the same mnemonic BPLLAR:

 

 LAR 

 

  • Larry's hernia (Morgagni)
  • A stands for anterior location
  • R stands for right side

 

Option C. Hiatal hernia: This is a protrusion of stomach through the esophageal hiatus. It's not a posterolateral defect.

 

Option D. Eventration: This is an abnormal elevation of part of the diaphragm due to thinning of the muscle. It's not a true hernia and doesn't involve a posterolateral defect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bochdalek hernia is the most common type of congenital diaphragmatic hernia, characterized by a posterior or posterolateral defect in the diaphragm, usually on the left side. It results from the failure of the pleuroperitoneal membrane to close and leads to pulmonary hypoplasia due to the herniation of abdominal organs into the thoracic cavity.

questions.text: In a patient, eye blinking occurs when a doctor touches the eye with a piece of cotton. Which of the following nerves is responsible for carrying sensation? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) V CN (Trigeminal Nerve)

 

The ophthalmic division (V1) of trigeminal nerve carries sensory information from:

  • The cornea and conjunctiva
  • The skin of upper eyelid
  • Forehead and upper face
    • When cotton touches the cornea, V1 carries this sensory information to the brain 
    • This triggers the corneal reflex (protective blinking)

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. II CN (Optic Nerve):

 

  • This nerve is purely sensory but specifically for vision
  • It carries visual information from the retina to the brain
  • It does not carry touch/tactile sensation from the surface of the eye

 

Option B. III CN (Oculomotor Nerve):

 

  • This is mainly a motor nerve
  • Controls eye movements and pupil constriction
  • Also controls upper eyelid elevation
  • Does not carry sensory information from the eye surface

 

Option D. VII CN (Facial Nerve):

 

  • This is mainly a motor nerve
  • It controls facial muscle movements including eyelid closure
  • While it participates in the blinking reflex by closing the eye (motor part), it does not carry the initial sensory information
  • It is the "output" part of the reflex, not the "input" sensory part

 

Educational Objective:

 

The trigeminal nerve (CN V) carries sensory information from the face and eye region, while the facial nerve (CN VII) provides motor innervation for facial expressions including blinking.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old female presents to the emergency department with complaints of dizziness and weakness. She reports a history of binge eating followed by self-induced vomiting for weight control. Arterial blood gas analysis reveals the following: (FMGE JAN 2025)

 

  • pH: 7.50
  • PaCO₂: 48 mmHg
  • HCO₃: 33 mmol/L

 

What is the most likely acid-base disturbance in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Metabolic alkalosis

 

Explanation:

 

This patient has metabolic alkalosis due to:

 

  • Elevated pH (> 7.45), indicating alkalemia.
  • Elevated HCO₃ (> 26 mEq/L), indicating metabolic alkalosis.
  • Clinical history of vomiting, which leads to the loss of chloride (via gastric acid - Hcl), resulting in hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis.
  • Binge eating followed by self-induced vomiting suggests that the patient may suffer from bulimia nervosa, a psychiatric illness.
  • Compensatory increase in PaCO₂ (normal: 35-45 mmHg), as per expected compensation using the Modified Winter's formula for Metabolic Alkalosis:
    • Expected PaCO₂ = 0.7 × HCO₃ + 20 (or) 0.9 × HCO₃ + 16
    • In this case, let us use the second one: 0.9 × 33 + 16 = 45.7 mmHg (± 2)
      So the expected range would be 44-48 mm Hg. 
    • The patient’s PaCO₂ of 48 mmHg falls within the expected range. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Metabolic acidosis: Incorrect, as this would present with low pH (<7.4) and low HCO₃ (<24)

 

Option C. Respiratory acidosis: Incorrect, as the patient’s pH is 7.5 (alkalotic) and in acidosis pH would generally be low (< 7.4)

 

Option D. Respiratory alkalosis: Incorrect, as this would present with low PaCO₂ (< 40) and high pH (>7.4)

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic vomiting results in loss of chloride (in the vomitus), resulting in hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis. Metabolic Alkalosis is usually characterized by elevated pH and HCO₃, with appropriate respiratory compensation (elevated PaCO₂ - due to hypoventilation).

questions.text: What is the most likely underlying condition associated with the Graham Steell murmur? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pulmonary regurgitation

 

Explanation:

 

Graham Steell murmur is a characteristic early diastolic murmur caused by pulmonary regurgitation in the setting of pulmonary hypertension. It occurs when increased pulmonary artery pressure causes dilation of the pulmonary valve ring, leading to incompetence and regurgitation. The murmur is best heard in the left second or third intercostal space and is characterized as an early diastolic, high-pitched, blowing murmur that decreases in intensity during inspiration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ventricular septal defect (VSD): Produces a pansystolic murmur heard best at the left lower sternal border. A small VSD producing a loud murmur is called Maladie de Roger, not Graham Steell murmur.

 

Option C. Pulmonary stenosis: Produces an ejection systolic murmur best heard in the pulmonary area (left upper sternal border). It does not produce a diastolic murmur, which is characteristic of Graham Steell murmur.

 

Option D. Mitral stenosis: Produces a mid-diastolic murmur best heard at the apex, with presystolic accentuation. It is associated with rheumatic heart disease and does not cause an early diastolic murmur characteristic of Graham Steell.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Graham Steell murmur is a high-pitched early diastolic murmur caused by pulmonary regurgitation in the setting of pulmonary hypertension.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with breathlessness. She is a known case of rheumatic heart disease. On examination, the apical impulse is hyperdynamic, and a "pistol shot" sound is heard over the femoral artery. The pulse is collapsing and water hammer-like. Auscultation reveals a pansystolic murmur and an early diastolic murmur. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Aortic regurgitation + Mitral regurgitation

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical features suggest a combined valvular lesion with predominant aortic regurgitation (AR) and mitral regurgitation (MR):

 

  • Pistol shot sounds (also called Traube’s sign or pistol shot femorals)
  • Collapsing/water hammer pulse (Watson’s water hammer pulse)
  • Early diastolic murmur – Characteristic of AR
  • Pansystolic murmur – Characteristic of MR
  • Hyperdynamic apex – Seen in volume overload conditions like AR and MR
  • History of rheumatic heart disease, which commonly affects the mitral and aortic valves

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mitral stenosis + Mitral regurgitation: Incorrect because:

 

  • MS produces a mid-diastolic murmur, not early diastolic
  • MS does not cause collapsing pulse or pistol shot sounds
  • MS typically causes a tapping apex, not hyperdynamic

 

Option C. Mitral stenosis + Aortic regurgitation: Incorrect because:

 

  • No mid-diastolic murmur of MS described
  • Pansystolic murmur indicates MR, not MS

 

Option D. Mitral regurgitation + Aortic stenosis: Incorrect because:

 

  • AS produces an ejection systolic murmur, not early diastolic
  • AS does not cause collapsing pulse or pistol shot sounds
  • AS typically causes a sustained apex beat, not hyperdynamic

 

Educational Objective:

 

The characteristic clinical features of combined aortic regurgitation and mitral regurgitation include:

 

  • Early diastolic murmur (AR)
  • Pansystolic murmur (MR)
  • Pistol shot sounds and water hammer pulse (AR)
  • Hyperdynamic apex (volume overload)

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with palpitations and giddiness. Her blood pressure is 80/60 mmHg. ECG shows absent P waves and an irregularly irregular RR interval. What is the next step in management? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cardioversion

 

Explanation:

 

This is a case of atrial fibrillation (AF) with hemodynamic instability. The diagnosis is supported by:

 

  • ECG findings of absent P waves and an irregularly irregular RR interval – Classic for AF
  • Low blood pressure (80/60 mmHg) – Indicates hemodynamic compromise
  • Symptoms of palpitations and giddiness – Suggest compromised cardiac output

 

In any tachyarrhythmia with hemodynamic instability (systolic BP < 90 mmHg), immediate synchronized cardioversion is the treatment of choice, regardless of the specific arrhythmia. This is because unstable blood pressure indicates that the patient is in shock and requires immediate rhythm restoration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adenosine: Incorrect

 

  • Used primarily for PSVT (Paroxysmal Supraventricular Tachycardia)
  • Not effective in atrial fibrillation (in fact C/I !!)

 

Option B. Verapamil: Incorrect

 

  • Useful in rate control for stable AF
  • Contraindicated in hypotensive patients as it can worsen hypotension
  • Reserved for hemodynamically stable patients

 

Option C. Amiodarone: Incorrect

 

  • Effective for AF, but has a delayed onset of action
  • Not appropriate when immediate rhythm restoration is needed due to instability
  • Better suited for maintenance therapy or rhythm control in stable patients

 

Educational Objective:

 

In tachyarrhythmia with hemodynamic instability (systolic BP < 90 mmHg), immediate synchronized cardioversion is the treatment of choice, regardless of the specific arrhythmia type.

choices.text: Gradual prolongation of PR interval followed by a non-conducted P wave
Prolonged PR interval, and each P wave is followed by a QRS complex
Normal PR interval followed by a non-conducted P wave

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding first-degree AV block? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Prolonged PR interval, and each P wave is followed by a QRS complex

 

Explanation:

 

First-degree AV block is characterized by prolongation of the PR interval (>0.2 seconds or >200 milliseconds) with each P wave being followed by a QRS complex. This represents a delay in conduction through the AV node, but every atrial impulse still successfully conducts to the ventricles. On ECG, this appears as more than five small boxes between the P wave and QRS complex.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gradual prolongation of PR interval followed by a non-conducted P wave: Incorrect

 

  • Describes Mobitz
  • type I (Wenckebach) second-degree AV block, where PR lengthens progressively until a P wave fails to conduct

 

Option C. Presence of atrioventricular dissociation: Incorrect

 

  • Seen in third-degree (complete) heart block, where the atria and ventricles beat independently
  • P waves and QRS complexes have no relation to each other

 

Option D. Normal PR interval followed by a non-conducted P wave: Incorrect

 

  • Describes Mobitz type II second-degree AV block, where PR remains constant but occasional P waves fail to conduct

 

Educational Objective:

 

First-degree AV block is characterized by a prolonged PR interval (>0.2 seconds) with 1:1 conduction, where each P wave is followed by a QRS complex.

questions.text: In the jugular venous pressure (JVP) waveform, the a-wave corresponds to: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Atrial contraction

 

Explanation:

 

The a-wave in the jugular venous pressure (JVP) waveform corresponds to atrial contraction. When the right atrium contracts, it causes an increase in pressure, which is transmitted backward into the jugular veins, creating the a-wave. This wave appears just before the carotid pulse and the first heart sound (S1).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ventricular contraction: Incorrect

 

  • Ventricular contraction corresponds to the c-wave in the JVP waveform, caused by bulging of the tricuspid valve into the right atrium during isovolumetric ventricular contraction

 

Option C. Passive atrial filling: Incorrect

 

  • Corresponds to the v-wave in the JVP waveform
  • Occurs during ventricular systole when the tricuspid valve is closed and blood continues to flow into the right atrium from the venae cavae

 

Option D. Tricuspid valve closure: Incorrect

 

  • Associated with the c-wave, not a distinct wave of its own

 

Educational Objective:

 

The a-wave in the JVP waveform corresponds to atrial contraction and is a key marker of normal atrial function.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents with persistent hypertension. Laboratory evaluation shows elevated aldosterone levels with suppressed renin activity. Which of the following findings is not seen? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sodium loss

 

Explanation:

 

Primary hyperaldosteronism presents with hypertension and elevated aldosterone levels with suppressed renin activity. Key features:

 

  • Increased sodium reabsorption → Sodium retention (NOT loss)
  • Increased potassium excretion → Hypokalemia
  • Metabolic alkalosis → Due to increased hydrogen ion excretion
  • Muscle cramps → Due to hypokalemia and electrolyte imbalance

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypokalemia: Incorrect, as it is a classic finding in primary hyperaldosteronism due to increased urinary potassium excretion

 

Option C. Metabolic alkalosis: Incorrect, as it occurs due to hydrogen ion loss and potassium depletion

 

Option D. Muscle cramps: Incorrect, as they are commonly seen in primary hyperaldosteronism, primarily due to hypokalemia

 

Educational Objective:

 

Primary hyperaldosteronism causes sodium retention (not sodium loss) and presents with hypertension, hypokalemia, metabolic alkalosis, and muscle cramps.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old male smoker presents with a history of progressive dyspnea and chronic cough. Pulmonary function tests (PFTs) reveal the following: (FMGE JAN 2025)

 

  • Decreased FEV₁
  • Decreased FEV₁/FVC ratio (<70%)
  • Minimal improvement in FEV₁ after bronchodilator therapy

 

What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)

 

Explanation:

 

This case presents a classic presentation of COPD with the following diagnostic features:

 

  • History of smoking (major risk factor)
  • Progressive dyspnea and chronic cough (typical symptoms)
  • PFT findings:
    • Decreased FEV₁ and FEV₁/FVC ratio <70% (diagnostic of obstructive airway disease)
    • Fixed obstruction with minimal bronchodilator response (distinguishing it from asthma, which shows significant bronchodilator response)

 

According to the GOLD criteria, a post-bronchodilator FEV₁/FVC ratio <70% confirms COPD in patients with appropriate symptoms and risk factors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pulmonary fibrosis: Incorrect

 

  • Shows a restrictive pattern on PFTs with FEV₁/FVC >70% and reduced total lung capacity (TLC)

 

Option C. Interstitial lung disease (ILD): Incorrect

 

  • ILD also shows a restrictive pattern, not obstruction
  • Would present with decreased lung volumes and preserved FEV₁/FVC ratio

 

Option D. Asthma: Incorrect

 

  • Asthma can show decreased FEV₁ and FEV₁/FVC ratio, but it typically demonstrates significant bronchodilator reversibility (>12% and >200 mL improvement in FEV₁), which is not seen in this case

 

Educational Objective:

 

COPD is diagnosed by a post-bronchodilator FEV₁/FVC ratio <70%, minimal bronchodilator response, and risk factors such as smoking.

questions.text: Identify the X-ray shown below. (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pulmonary edema

 

Explanation:

 

The chest X-ray demonstrates the classic "bat wing" appearance characteristic of pulmonary edema. This pattern shows:

 

  • Bilateral hilar infiltrates with a perihilar distribution
  • Butterfly or bat-wing-shaped opacity
  • Edema fluid accumulation in the interstitial and alveolar spaces due to:
    • Increased hydrostatic pressure in the pulmonary circulation (e.g., left heart failure)
    • Increased capillary permeability

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pleural effusion: Incorrect

 

  • Typically shows blunting of the costophrenic angles with a meniscus sign
  • The pattern seen here is more central and perihilar, rather than at the lung bases

 

Option B. Pulmonary fibrosis: Incorrect

 

  • Pulmonary fibrosis shows reticular opacities, honeycombing, and traction bronchiectasis
  • The pattern is usually peripheral and basal, not central and perihilar

 

Option D. Hydrothorax: Incorrect

 

  • A pleural effusion containing transudative fluid
  • Would show a meniscus sign and blunting of costophrenic angles, rather than a central bat-wing distribution

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize the classic "bat wing" or "butterfly" pattern on chest X-ray as characteristic of pulmonary edema, which presents as bilateral perihilar infiltrates with a central distribution.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with recurrent migraines characterized by throbbing unilateral headaches, nausea, and photophobia. She has not responded to over-the-counter analgesics. Which of the following medications is most appropriate for acute treatment? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sumatriptan

 

Explanation:

 

Sumatriptan is the most appropriate choice for acute migraine treatment. It belongs to the triptan class (5-HT₁B/1D receptor agonists) and:

 

  • Works through vasoconstriction and blocking pain pathways
  • Most effective when taken early in a migraine attack

 

The patient presents with classic migraine symptoms (unilateral throbbing headache, nausea, photophobia) and has failed over-the-counter medications, making triptans the next step in management.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Propranolol: Incorrect. Beta-blocker used for migraine prophylaxis rather than acute treatment

 

Option C. Amitriptyline: Incorrect. Tricyclic antidepressant used for migraine prevention, not acute attacks

 

Option D. Verapamil: Incorrect. Calcium channel blocker used for cluster headache prophylaxis, not migraines

 

Educational Objective:

 

Triptans (e.g., sumatriptan) are first-line medications for acute treatment of moderate-to-severe migraines that have not responded to over-the-counter analgesics.

questions.text: Which of the following antidiabetic drugs is preferred in a patient with heart and kidney disease? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) SGLT-2 inhibitors

 

Explanation:

 

SGLT-2 inhibitors (e.g., dapagliflozin, empagliflozin, canagliflozin) are the preferred first-line agents in diabetic patients with heart and kidney disease because they:

 

  • Reduce major adverse cardiovascular events
  • Decrease heart failure hospitalizations
  • Slow progression of diabetic kidney disease
  • Reduce proteinuria and lower blood pressure
  • Provide cardio-protection independent of glucose control

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Biguanides (Metformin): While first-line for type 2 diabetes, it does not provide cardiovascular benefits and requires caution in kidney disease due to the risk of lactic acidosis

 

Option B. GLP-1 receptor agonists: While cardioprotective, they do not provide as strong heart failure or renal benefits as SGLT-2 inhibitors

 

Option D. Sulfonylureas: Not preferred because:

 

  • High risk of hypoglycemia, especially in renal disease
  • No proven cardiovascular benefits
  • Possible increased cardiovascular risk with certain sulfonylureas

 

Educational Objective:

 

SGLT-2 inhibitors are the preferred antidiabetic agents in patients with heart failure and chronic kidney disease (CKD) due to their proven cardiovascular and renal benefits.

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with palpitations, dizziness, and mild shortness of breath. Her ECG shows a narrow complex tachycardia with a regular rhythm, consistent with supraventricular tachycardia (SVT). Her blood pressure is stable. What is the first-line drug of choice for treating this condition? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Adenosine

 

Explanation:

 

In a hemodynamically stable patient with supraventricular tachycardia (SVT), adenosine is the first-line pharmacological treatment after attempting vagal maneuvers.

 

Adenosine is preferred because:

 

  • Extremely short half-life (8-10 seconds)
  • Effectively terminates most forms of SVT by blocking AV nodal conduction
  • Administered as a rapid IV push (6 mg initial dose, followed by 12 mg if needed)

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Amiodarone: Not first-line therapy for acute SVT. More commonly used for ventricular arrhythmias or refractory SVT

 

Option C. Metoprolol: Effective for rate control in AF, but not the first choice for acute SVT termination

 

Option D. Verapamil: Used for SVT treatment, but not first-line due to risk of hypotension and bradycardia

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adenosine is the first-line treatment for hemodynamically stable supraventricular tachycardia (SVT), administered as a rapid IV push following vagal maneuvers.

questions.text: A patient presents with progressive weakness that started in his lower limbs and is now ascending to involve his upper limbs. Examination reveals absent reflexes in the affected limbs and no significant sensory deficits. He had an upper respiratory tract infection two weeks ago. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Guillain-Barré Syndrome (GBS)

 

Explanation:

 

The diagnosis of GBS is supported by the classic triad of symptoms known as the "three A's":

 

  • Acute onset
  • Ascending paralysis (starting in the lower limbs and progressing upwards)
  • Areflexia (absent reflexes)

 

Additional supporting features include:

 

  • Recent upper respiratory tract infection (often Mycoplasma pneumoniae)
  • Symmetrical weakness
  • Relative preservation of sensory function
  • Post-infectious immune-mediated process

 

(If the patient had a history of diarrhea, the most likely pathogen would be Campylobacter jejuni.)

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Transverse myelitis: Incorrect

 

  • Usually has bladder/bowel involvement
  • Reflexes may be increased below the lesion, not absent

 

Option C. Myasthenia gravis: Incorrect

 

  • Causes descending weakness, often affecting ocular and bulbar muscles first
  • Normal reflexes and fluctuating weakness with fatigue

 

Option D. Multiple sclerosis: Incorrect

 

  • Presents with upper motor neuron signs (hyperreflexia, Babinski sign)
  • Often associated with optic neuritis and sensory symptoms

 

Educational Objective:

 

Guillain-Barré Syndrome (GBS) should be suspected in a patient with acute, ascending areflexic paralysis, particularly following a recent infection.

choices.text: Supranuclear facial palsy on the left side
Infranuclear facial palsy on the right side
Supranuclear facial palsy on the right side
Infranuclear facial palsy on the left side

questions.text: A young man presents with drooping of the corner of his mouth and weakness in the lower half of the right side of his face. He can raise his eyebrows and close his eyes on both sides. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Supranuclear facial palsy on the left side

 

Explanation:

 

This is a case of supranuclear (upper motor neuron) facial palsy affecting the right side of the face, which means the lesion is on the left side of the brain due to crossed innervation.

 

Key features supporting this diagnosis:

 

  • Only the lower half of the face is affected (sparing of the upper face)
  • Ability to raise eyebrows and close eyes bilaterally (preserved upper facial function)
  • Right-sided facial weakness indicates a left-sided lesion

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Infranuclear facial palsy on the right side: Incorrect

 

  • Lower motor neuron (LMN) lesions affect the entire half of the face
  • Patients cannot raise their eyebrows or close their eyes on the affected side

 

Option C. Supranuclear facial palsy on the right side: Incorrect

 

  • Would cause left-sided lower facial weakness, not right-sided

 

Option D. Infranuclear facial palsy on the left side: Incorrect

 

  • Would cause left-sided full facial weakness

 

Educational Objective:

 

Supranuclear (UMN) facial palsy affects the lower face on the opposite side of the lesion, while LMN facial palsy affects the entire ipsilateral face.

questions.text: What is the key mechanism leading to tissue damage in patients with prolonged diabetes? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hyperglycemia

 

The primary mechanism leading to tissue damage in diabetes is persistent hyperglycemia, which:

 

  • Leads to oxidative stress
  • Promotes formation of advanced glycation end-products (AGEs)
  • Causes endothelial dysfunction and inflammation

 

Most microvascular complications (neuropathy, nephropathy, retinopathy) are directly attributed to chronic hyperglycemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sorbitol accumulation: Plays a secondary role, particularly in diabetic neuropathy and cataracts, but is not the primary cause of damage

 

Option C. Insulin resistance: Contributes to hyperglycemia, but does not directly cause tissue damage

 

Option D. Decreased insulin secretion: Leads to hyperglycemia, but tissue damage occurs due to persistent high glucose levels

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hyperglycemia is the fundamental mechanism causing tissue damage in prolonged diabetes, leading to various microvascular complications.

questions.text: A patient presents with difficulty switching between movements and exhibits uncontrollable hand movements during a neurological examination. What is the most likely term used to describe this condition? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Diadochokinesis

 

Explanation:

 

Diadochokinesis refers to the ability to perform rapid alternating movements (e.g., pronation-supination of hands or tapping fingers). Difficulty switching between movements is termed dysdiadochokinesis, which is a clinical sign of cerebellar dysfunction. It is commonly seen in:

 

  • Cerebellar ataxia
  • Multiple sclerosis
  • Stroke affecting the cerebellum

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Resting tremor: Incorrect

 

  • Occurs at rest and improves with voluntary movement
  • Characteristic of Parkinson’s disease ("pill-rolling" tremor)

 

Option B. Metamorphosis: Incorrect

 

  • Not a neurological term related to movement disorders

 

Option D. Intention tremor: Incorrect

 

  • A slow, coarse tremor that worsens as the limb approaches a target (seen in cerebellar lesions)
  • Does not specifically describe difficulty switching between movements

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dysdiadochokinesis is the inability to perform rapid alternating movements and is a key sign of cerebellar dysfunction.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with muscle cramps, tingling around her mouth, and a history of hypocalcemia. During the physical examination, tapping on the facial nerve just anterior to the ear elicits twitching of the facial muscles. What is this finding called? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chvostek’s sign

 

Explanation:

 

Chvostek’s sign is a clinical manifestation of hypocalcemia, where tapping the facial nerve anterior to the ear causes ipsilateral facial muscle twitching. This sign indicates neuromuscular irritability due to hypocalcemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trousseau’s sign: Also seen in hypocalcemia, but involves carpopedal spasm induced by inflating a blood pressure cuff above systolic pressure for 3 minutes

 

Option C. Babinski sign: Indicates upper motor neuron lesions, not related to calcium homeostasis

 

Option D. Homan’s sign: Associated with deep vein thrombosis (DVT), not calcium metabolism

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chvostek’s sign is facial muscle twitching elicited by tapping the facial nerve in hypocalcemia, representing neuromuscular irritability.

choices.text: Add a second oral hypoglycemic agent

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient with type 2 diabetes mellitus is on metformin therapy (500 mg BD). Their recent HbA1c is 7.6%, and their last blood glucose reading was 169 mg/dL. What is the most appropriate next step in management? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Increase the dose of metformin

 

Explanation:

 

The patient’s HbA1c of 7.6% is above the target of <7%, indicating suboptimal glycemic control.

 

  • Metformin is the first-line therapy for type 2 diabetes
  • The current dose (500 mg BD) is below the maximum effective dose
  • Metformin can be increased up to 2000 mg/day (1000 mg BD) before adding another agent

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Discontinue metformin: Incorrect, as it is the first-line treatment for diabetes

 

Option C. Add a second agent: Not necessary until maximizing metformin dose

 

Option D. Initiate insulin therapy: Reserved for severely uncontrolled diabetes (HbA1c >9% or symptomatic hyperglycemia)

 

Educational Objective:

 

Optimization of metformin dosage (up to 2000 mg/day) should be attempted before adding additional diabetes medications when glycemic control is suboptimal.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with weight loss, heat intolerance, and palpitations over the past two months. Laboratory tests reveal decreased TSH and elevated T3 and T4 levels. She is started on iodine-131 therapy. What is the most common long-term side effect of this treatment? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hypothyroidism

 

Explanation:

 

I-131 (radioactive iodine) therapy is commonly used for hyperthyroidism (Graves' disease). The most common long-term side effect is hypothyroidism, due to:

 

  • Destruction of thyroid tissue
  • Permanent reduction in thyroid hormone production

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hyperthyroidism relapse: Rare, as radioactive iodine typically leads to permanent thyroid destruction

 

Option B. Thyroid storm: Acute complication, not a long-term effect

 

Option D. Radiation-induced thyroiditis: Can occur but is a transient complication

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypothyroidism is the most common long-term side effect of radioactive iodine (I-131) therapy, requiring lifelong thyroid hormone replacement.

questions.text: A patient with a history of smoking presents with a cough and hemoptysis. A chest X-ray is done and it is shown below. Which of the following findings is least likely to be associated with this condition? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Exophthalmos

 

Explanation:

 

The X-ray findings suggest a Pancoast tumor (superior sulcus tumor), which can invade adjacent structures, causing:

 

  • Brachial plexopathy (compression of lower brachial plexus)
  • Horner’s syndrome (ptosis, miosis, anhidrosis) due to sympathetic chain involvement
  • Superior vena cava syndrome due to compression of the superior vena cava

 

Exophthalmos is more commonly associated with Graves’ disease and is not a feature of Pancoast tumors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Horner syndrome: Incorrect because this is a common finding in Pancoast tumor due to involvement of the sympathetic chain

 

Option B. Brachial plexopathy: Incorrect because this is commonly seen due to compression of the lower part of the brachial plexus by the tumor

 

Option C. Superior vena cava syndrome: Incorrect because SVC syndrome can occur in Pancoast tumors due to compression or invasion of the superior vena cava

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pancoast tumors present with Horner’s syndrome, brachial plexopathy, and superior vena cava syndrome, but exophthalmos is not part of the presentation.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient diagnosed with chronic hepatitis B infection is being evaluated for infectivity status. Which of the following markers indicates high infectivity? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) HBeAg

 

Explanation:

 

HBeAg (Hepatitis B e antigen) is a marker of viral replication and infectivity in chronic hepatitis B infection. Its presence indicates:

 

  • High levels of viral replication
  • Higher risk of transmission
  • Greater infectivity
  • Usually associated with higher HBV DNA levels
  • Important prognostic marker for complications like cirrhosis and hepatocellular carcinoma

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anti-HBc: Indicates current or past HBV infection, but not infectivity

 

Option B. Anti-HBs: Indicates immunity (through vaccination or recovery), not infectivity

 

Option D. HBsAg: Indicates infection, but does not differentiate between high and low infectivity

 

Educational Objective:

 

HBeAg is a key marker of high viral replication and infectivity in chronic hepatitis B infection.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man with chronic hepatitis B presents with right upper quadrant pain, weight loss, jaundice, and a palpable liver edge. His laboratory results show elevated liver enzymes and significantly raised AFP levels. Imaging reveals a hypoechoic liver lesion with arterial enhancement and early washout. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC)

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical presentation strongly suggests HCC, supported by:

 

  • Risk factor: Chronic hepatitis B
  • Clinical symptoms: RUQ pain, weight loss, jaundice, hepatomegaly
  • Lab findings: Elevated liver enzymes and significantly raised alpha-fetoprotein (AFP)
  • Imaging: Hypoechoic lesion with arterial enhancement and early washout, classic for HCC

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cholangiocarcinoma: More commonly associated with PSC, liver flukes, or biliary disease

 

Option C. Focal nodular hyperplasia: Usually incidental, benign, seen in young women

 

Option D. Hepatic adenoma: More common in young women on OCPs, lacks early washout

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hepatocellular carcinoma presents with characteristic imaging (arterial enhancement with early washout) in a patient with chronic hepatitis B.

choices.text: Give aspirin and discharge the patient

questions.text: A 64-year-old male presents to the emergency department with chest pain radiating to the left arm and shoulder for the past 20 minutes. The ECG demonstrates ST-segment depression, and troponin levels are positive. What is the next best step in the patient’s management? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Give aspirin + clopidogrel

 

Explanation:

 

The patient presents with Non-ST-Elevation Myocardial Infarction (NSTEMI), characterized by:

 

  • Chest pain radiating to the arm
  • ST-segment depression on ECG
  • Positive troponins

 

Initial management follows the MONA-B protocol, and dual antiplatelet therapy (aspirin + clopidogrel) is the first step.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aspirin alone and discharge: Incorrect, as NSTEMI requires hospital admission and further evaluation

 

Option C. Thrombolysis: Contraindicated in NSTEMI (only indicated for STEMI)

 

Option D. Stress test: Contraindicated in acute coronary syndrome

 

Educational Objective:

 

NSTEMI management includes dual antiplatelet therapy (aspirin + clopidogrel), and thrombolysis is contraindicated.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient reports a gradual increase in breathlessness over the past few months. On physical examination, a prominent left parasternal heave is noted, along with hepatomegaly. Auscultation reveals a loud systolic murmur. What is the most probable diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pulmonary arterial hypertension

 

Explanation:

 

The key findings strongly suggest pulmonary hypertension (PAH):

 

  • Gradual onset of dyspnea
  • Left parasternal heave (right ventricular hypertrophy)
  • Hepatomegaly (right heart failure)
  • Loud systolic murmur (functional tricuspid regurgitation)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pulmonary regurgitation: Produces an early diastolic murmur, not systolic

 

Option B. Pulmonary embolism: Usually acute onset, not gradual progression

 

Option C. Pulmonic stenosis: Produces an ejection systolic murmur, but lacks right heart failure features

 

Educational Objective:

 

A triad of chronic dyspnea, left parasternal heave, and hepatomegaly is highly suggestive of pulmonary arterial hypertension.

questions.text: A patient presents with an intense headache, repeated vomiting, and neck stiffness. Lumbar puncture yields turbid cerebrospinal fluid (CSF).
