Microscopic analysis shows 90% polymorphonuclear leukocytes, a CSF glucose of 40 mg/dL (serum glucose: 120 mg/dL), and a protein concentration of 200 mg/dL. What is the most suitable treatment approach for this patient? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ceftriaxone plus vancomycin

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical presentation and CSF findings strongly suggest bacterial meningitis, characterized by:

 

  • Headache, vomiting, neck stiffness (classic triad)
  • Turbid CSF with neutrophilic pleocytosis (90% PMNs)
  • Low CSF glucose (<50% of serum glucose)
  • Elevated protein (>45 mg/dL)

 

Empirical treatment for adult bacterial meningitis:

 

  • Ceftriaxone – Covers Neisseria meningitidis and most pneumococci
  • Vancomycin – Added to cover resistant Streptococcus pneumoniae

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. HRZE (anti-TB therapy): Used for tuberculous meningitis, which presents with chronic symptoms and lymphocytic pleocytosis

 

Option B. Ceftriaxone + acyclovir: Used for HSV encephalitis, which shows lymphocytic pleocytosis and temporal lobe involvement

 

Option D. Cefotaxime + ampicillin: Used in neonatal, elderly, or immunocompromised patients (for Listeria monocytogenes)

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bacterial meningitis treatment involves empiric ceftriaxone + vancomycin to cover resistant pneumococci and meningococci.

questions.text: A 40-year-old electrical worker is brought to the emergency department after sustaining a high-voltage electric shock at work. He reports muscle pain, weakness, and dark-colored urine since the incident. Physical examination reveals tender, swollen muscles in the upper limbs. What is the most likely substance found in his urine? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Myoglobin

 

Explanation:

 

This patient presents with rhabdomyolysis following a high-voltage electrical injury, characterized by:

 

  • Muscle pain, weakness, and dark-colored urine (myoglobinuria)
  • Elevated creatine kinase (CK) levels
  • Tender, swollen muscles

 

Myoglobin is released into circulation from damaged muscle cells and subsequently filtered by the kidneys, leading to myoglobinuria, which can cause acute kidney injury (AKI) due to tubular toxicity and obstruction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. RBCs: Would indicate hematuria, which is not the main feature of rhabdomyolysis

 

Option C. Creatine kinase: Although CK levels are elevated, CK is not excreted in urine

 

Option D. Bilirubin: Suggests liver dysfunction or hemolysis, not muscle breakdown

 

Educational Objective:

 

In rhabdomyolysis, myoglobin is released from damaged muscles, leading to myoglobinuria and a risk of acute kidney injury.

choices.text: Time interval between S2 and the opening snap

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with mitral stenosis is being evaluated. Which clinical finding best indicates the severity of the condition? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Time interval between S2 and the opening snap

 

Explanation:

 

The S2-OS (second heart sound to opening snap) interval is the best indicator of mitral stenosis severity:

 

  • Mild MS: S2-OS interval is longer (~100 ms or more)
  • Severe MS: S2-OS interval is short (~60 ms or less), indicating higher left atrial pressure

 

The earlier the opening snap occurs, the more severe the stenosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Muffled heart sounds: Seen in pericardial effusion, cardiac tamponade, not mitral stenosis

 

Option B. Loud S1: Common in MS, but may become soft in severe cases due to valve calcification

 

Option C. S3 gallop: Associated with heart failure, mitral regurgitation, not mitral stenosis

 

Educational Objective:

 

The S2-OS interval is the best clinical indicator of mitral stenosis severity, as a shorter interval reflects higher left atrial pressure and more severe disease progression.

questions.text: A 19-year-old patient presents with generalized edema (anasarca). Laboratory tests reveal proteinuria of 4.5 g/day, hypoalbuminemia, and hyperlipidemia. What is the recommended treatment for this condition? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Steroids

 

Explanation:

 

This patient has nephrotic syndrome, characterized by:

 

  • Proteinuria >3.5 g/day
  • Hypoalbuminemia
  • Generalized edema (anasarca)
  • Hyperlipidemia

 

In young adults and children, one of the most common causes is Minimal Change Disease (MCD), which is highly responsive to corticosteroids.

 

First-line therapy:

 

  • High-dose steroids (prednisone 1 mg/kg/day) for 4–8 weeks
  • 80-90% remission rate

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IV albumin: Provides temporary relief but does not treat the underlying disease

 

Option B. Cyclophosphamide: Reserved for steroid-resistant or frequently relapsing nephrotic syndrome

 

Option D. Steroids and cyclophosphamide: Combination therapy is not needed initially. Can be used for immune mediated disorders like lupus nehritis as a part of induction therapy. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nephrotic syndrome in children (and some times in young adults) is most commonly due to Minimal Change Disease and is highly responsive to corticosteroids.

choices.text: Pleural fluid LDH more than 2/3 of ULN serum LDH
Pleural fluid protein-to-serum protein ratio more than 0.5
Pleural fluid LDH more than 0.6 of serum LDH

questions.text: A patient with a recent diagnosis of pneumonia presents with pleural effusion. Pleural fluid analysis is performed. Which of the following findings is not consistent with a diagnosis of exudative parapneumonic effusion? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pleural fluid pH greater than 7.4

 

Explanation:

 

Parapneumonic effusions are exudative pleural effusions associated with pneumonia, lung abscess, or bronchiectasis.

 

Light’s criteria define exudates as having at least one of the following:

 

  • Pleural fluid LDH >2/3 of upper normal serum LDH
  • Pleural fluid protein-to-serum protein ratio >0.5
  • Pleural fluid LDH/serum LDH ratio >0.6

 

Pleural fluid pH is typically <7.2 in complicated parapneumonic effusions and empyema.

 

Other Options:

 

Options A, B, and D – Correctly describe exudative effusions

 

Educational Objective:

 

Exudative parapneumonic effusions meet at least one of Light’s criteria, and pH is usually <7.4.

choices.text: Drug interaction between anti-tuberculosis (ATT) drugs and ART

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with both TB and AIDS is started on antiretroviral therapy (ART). Shortly after, he experiences a worsening of symptoms, including fever and malaise. What is the most likely cause of this clinical deterioration? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome (IRIS)

 

Explanation:

 

IRIS occurs after initiating ART in HIV patients with an underlying opportunistic infection (e.g., TB).

 

  • Pathophysiology:
    • Before ART: Severe immunosuppression limits the immune response against TB
    • After ART initiation: Rapid immune restoration triggers an exaggerated inflammatory response against pre-existing but previously unrecognized TB
    • Result: Clinical worsening with fever, lymphadenopathy, worsening respiratory symptoms

 

Types of IRIS:

 

  • Paradoxical IRIS: Worsening of TB symptoms despite adequate treatment
  • Unmasking IRIS: New onset TB symptoms after ART initiation

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Drug interaction between ATT and ART: Rifampin reduces ART drug levels, but this does not cause fever and malaise

 

Option B. Resistance to MTB: Would cause persistent infection, not acute worsening

 

Option D. Development of extrapulmonary TB: IRIS can exacerbate existing TB, but it is not a new TB infection

 

Educational Objective:

 

Immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome (IRIS) occurs after ART initiation, leading to an exaggerated inflammatory response against pre-existing infections.

choices.text: Ascites occurs due to secondary hyperaldosteronism
Simultaneous measurement of serum and ascitic fluid albumin levels is necessary
The serum-ascites albumin gradient (SAAG) is typically less than 1.1 g/dL in cirrhosis-related ascites
The serum-ascites albumin gradient (SAAG) is typically greater than 1.1 g/dL in cirrhosis-related ascites

questions.text: A patient with decompensated liver cirrhosis presents with difficulty breathing due to significant ascites accumulation. Which of the following statements regarding the evaluation and cause of ascites is incorrect? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The serum-ascites albumin gradient (SAAG) is typically less than 1.1 g/dL in cirrhosis-related ascites

 

Explanation:

 

Ascites in cirrhosis is caused by portal hypertension, which increases hydrostatic pressure, leading to fluid accumulation in the peritoneal cavity.

 

SAAG classification:

 

  • SAAG > 1.1 g/dL → Portal hypertension-related ascites (e.g., cirrhosis, heart failure, Budd-Chiari syndrome)
  • SAAG < 1.1 g/dL → Non-portal hypertension causes (e.g., malignancy, tuberculosis, pancreatitis)

 

Since cirrhosis-related ascites results from increased portal pressure, SAAG is typically >1.1 g/dL.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ascites occurs due to secondary hyperaldosteronism: Correct; cirrhosis leads to RAAS activation, causing sodium and water retention

 

Option B. Simultaneous measurement of serum and ascitic fluid albumin levels is necessary: Correct; SAAG is calculated using these values

 

Option D. SAAG is typically >1.1 g/dL in cirrhosis-related ascites:  Correct, as it reflects portal hypertension

 

Educational Objective:

 

The SAAG value helps differentiate portal hypertension-related ascites (>1.1 g/dL) from non-portal hypertension causes (<1.1 g/dL).

questions.text: Based on the given X-ray image, what is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hollow viscus perforation

 

Explanation:

 

The X-ray shows free air under both domes of diaphragm, which is pathognomonic of hollow viscus perforation. This occurs when there is a breach in the wall of a hollow organ (like stomach or intestine) leading to escape of air into the peritoneal cavity. The free air rises and collects under the diaphragm, visible as a dark area on chest X-ray when the patient is erect X-ray.


The common causes include:

 

  • Peptic ulcer perforation (most common)
  • Traumatic bowel injury
  • Typhoid ileal perforation
  • Appendicular perforation

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sub-acute intestinal obstruction: Incorrect because X-ray would show dilated bowel loops with multiple air-fluid levels, not free air under the diaphragm

 

Option B. Paralytic ileus: Incorrect as X-ray would show dilated bowel loops with air throughout, no free air under diaphragm

 

Option C. Pleural effusion: Incorrect as X-ray would show homogeneous opacity in pleural space with obliteration of costophrenic angles, not free air under diaphragm

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hollow viscus perforation is diagnosed radiologically by the presence of free air under the diaphragm, typically seen in an erect chest X-ray or CT scan of the abdomen. It is a surgical emergency requiring immediate laparotomy.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents with progressive dysphagia, which is more pronounced for liquids than solids. A barium swallow study is performed. Which characteristic radiological finding is most likely to be observed? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rat tail deformity

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical presentation strongly suggests achalasia cardia:

 

  • Young patient (25 years)
  • Dysphagia to both liquids and solids, with liquids being affected more
  • In achalasia, barium swallow characteristically shows a "bird beak" or "rat tail" appearance due to smooth tapering at the gastroesophageal junction with proximal dilation of esophagus
  • This appearance is due to failure of LES relaxation with preserved peristalsis in body of esophagus, which is the hallmark of achalasia

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Smooth filling defect: Incorrect as this suggests a benign mass/tumor 

 

Option C. Irregular filling defect: Incorrect as this suggests malignant mass causing infiltration of the esophageal wall

 

Option D. Corkscrew esophagus: Incorrect as this is seen in diffuse esophageal spasm where the primary symptom is chest pain rather than dysphagia

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rat tail/bird beak appearance on barium swallow is characteristic of achalasia cardia, which presents with dysphagia to liquids more than solids.

questions.text: A patient complains of epigastric pain radiating to back after alcohol binge for the last 48 hours. What is the next step? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Serum amylase

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical scenario describes a classic presentation of acute pancreatitis. The patient has epigastric pain radiating to the back following an alcohol binge. Alcohol is the second most common cause of acute pancreatitis after gallstones. The first step in diagnosing acute pancreatitis is to check pancreatic enzyme levels in the blood.

 

Serum amylase rises early (within 4-6 hours) after the onset of acute pancreatitis and is part of the initial workup. Though serum lipase is more specific and remains elevated longer (12-24 hours), amylase is still widely used as the first investigation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. USG abdomen: While ultrasound is useful to evaluate for gallstones as a cause of pancreatitis, it's not the first investigation in suspected acute pancreatitis. USG is typically performed after confirming the diagnosis with pancreatic enzymes.

 

Option C. CECT abdomen: CT scan is not indicated initially and should be performed only after 72 hours of symptom onset if the diagnosis is uncertain or to assess for complications. 

 

Option D. X-ray abdomen: X-ray has limited utility in diagnosing acute pancreatitis. It may show some non-specific findings like "sentinel loop sign, colon cut-off sign, renal halo sign, gasless abdomen.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The initial investigation of choice in acute pancreatitis is serum amylase or lipase. CECT abdomen is reserved for severe cases or complications after 48-72 hours.

 

1st investigation:

 

1. Pancreatic enzymes are elevated in blood

 

  • Serum amylase (nonspecific)→rises early (4-6 hours of attack)
  • Serum lipase → rises 12-24 hours later (sensitive and specific, test of choice)

 

2. Imaging → no need for diagnosis, only when unsure of dx, rule out etiology like gall stone Imaging modality of choice → CECT abdomen (done after 72 hours of symptoms)

questions.text: Which anatomical structure is marked in the given image? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Right hepatic artery

 

Explanation:

 

The image shows Calot's triangle anatomy where:

 

  • Right hepatic artery is a branch of common hepatic artery
  • It gives off the cystic artery which supplies the gallbladder
  • The artery marked in the image is entering the liver, making it the right hepatic artery
  • Mistaking the right hepatic artery for the cystic artery during surgery can lead to catastrophic haemorrhage or liver ischemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cystic artery: Incorrect as cystic artery is a branch of right hepatic artery that supplies the gallbladder, not the vessel marked which is entering liver

 

Option B. Cystic duct: Incorrect as cystic duct drains gallbladder and joins common hepatic duct to form common bile duct

 

Option D. Hepatic duct: Incorrect as hepatic ducts are biliary drainage channels, not arteries

 

Educational Objective:

 

The right hepatic artery is a key structure in hepatobiliary surgery, running within Calot’s Triangle and supplying the right lobe of the liver. Identifying it correctly during cholecystectomy is crucial to avoid vascular injury.

questions.text: Identify the device shown in the given image. (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Veress needle

 

Explanation:

 

The image shows a Veress needle which has distinctive features:

 

  • Used for creating pneumoperitoneum in laparoscopic surgery using closed technique
  • Has a blunt tip that advances and spring-loaded sharp outer cannula
  • When resistance is overcome, blunt tip springs forward preventing injury to intraabdominal organs
  • Usually inserted in left hypochondrium (Palmer's point) or periumbilical
  • Characteristic "pop" sound heard when it enters peritoneal cavity
  • Can be confirmed by saline drop test

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Quincke needle: Incorrect as this is a spinal needle with sharp bevel used for diagnostic/therapeutic lumbar puncture

 

Option C. Jamshidi needle: Incorrect as this is a bone marrow biopsy needle

 

Option D. Aspiration needle: Incorrect as this is for aspiration of fluid collections

 

Educational Objective:

 

Veress needle is used for creating pneumoperitoneum in laparoscopic surgery using closed technique and has a characteristic spring-loaded mechanism.

questions.text: A Patient after head trauma is opening eyes to verbal commands, localizing pain and is confused. What is his Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 12

Explanation:

Glasgow Coma Scale calculation:

Eye Opening (E): Opening to verbal commands = 3 points

Motor Response (M): Localizing pain = 5 points

Verbal Response (V): Confused = 4 points

Total GCS = E(3) + M(5) + V(4) = 12 points

Educational Objective:

Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS)

questions.text: A male bartender, following a fight was brought to the emergency with respiratory distress. On clinical evaluation, the breath sounds were absent with increased resonance on right side, and tracheal deviation on the left side was noted. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Traumatic Pneumothorax

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical features point to traumatic pneumothorax:

 

  • History of trauma (fight)
  • Respiratory distress
  • Absent breath sounds on one side (indicates collapsed lung)
  • Tracheal deviation to opposite side

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Collapse of lung: Incorrect as collapse is a consequence of pneumothorax, not the primary diagnosis. Additionally, isolated collapse without pneumothorax doesn't cause increased resonance

 

Option C. Pleural effusion: Incorrect as pleural effusion develops gradually, gives dull percussion note and doesn't typically cause tracheal deviation unless massive

 

Option D. Consolidation of lung: Incorrect as consolidation shows increased vocal resonance, bronchial breathing and doesn't cause tracheal deviation

 

Educational Objective:

 

Traumatic pneumothorax presents with respiratory distress, absent breath sounds on affected side and possible tracheal deviation after trauma.

questions.text: Based on the given image, calculate the total percentage of body surface area affected. (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 20-30%

 

Explanation:

 

To calculate burn surface area in this scenario:

 

  • Image shows only anterior burns (no posterior burns mentioned)
  • Total anterior surface = 50% of body surface area

 

Areas involved:

 

  • Half of face and neck (~1%)
  • Partial chest and abdomen (~13-14%)
  • Parts of upper limb (~4-5%)
  • Parts of thigh (~4-5%)

 

Approximate calculation:

 

  • About half of anterior surface is burned
  • Half of 50% = ~25%
  • Therefore, the total burn area falls in 20-30% range

 

While Lund and Browder charts are more accurate for children, this approximation method gives similar results.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 10-20%: Incorrect as burns involve significant anterior surface area

 

Option C. 40-50%: Incorrect as only anterior burns are present, not circumferential

 

Option D. 60%: Incorrect as this would indicate extensive circumferential burns

 

Educational Objective:

 

Burn surface area is calculated using the Rule of Nines for adults or the Lund and Browder Chart for children. In the given case, the estimated burn area was 20-30%.

choices.text: Laser ablation can be used for treatment

questions.text: A patient presents to the outpatient department (OPD) with dilated, tortuous veins in the leg. Which of the following statements is correct regarding this condition? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Laser ablation can be used for treatment

 

Explanation:

 

Endovenous laser ablation (EVLA) is an effective minimally invasive treatment for varicose veins

 

  • EVLA works by using laser energy to cause thermal damage to vein wall
  • It has high success rate and faster recovery compared to traditional surgery
  • It is currently the treatment of choice for great saphenous vein varicosities
  • Done under local tumescent anesthesia as daycare procedure

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Clinical stage is C6: Incorrect as C6 indicates active venous ulcer. This patient only shows varicose veins which is C2 in CEAP classification (C2S if symptomatic, C2A if asymptomatic)

 

Option C. Sclerotherapy is the first-line treatment: Incorrect as sclerotherapy is primarily used for small reticular veins and telangiectasias, not for large varicose veins

 

Option D. Compression stockings are curative: Incorrect as compression stockings only provide symptomatic relief and don't cure varicose veins. They help manage symptoms but disease continues to progress

 

Educational Objective:

 

Endovenous Laser Ablation (EVLA) is an effective, first-line treatment for symptomatic varicose veins. Compression stockings provide symptom relief but are not curative.

questions.text: Identify the correct labelling of the ulcer in the given image. (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Edge

 

Parts of an ulcer are clearly defined:

 

 

Edge: Junction between floor and skin 

 

Floor: Visible surface of ulcer that can be seen

 

Base: Tissue on which floor rests (not visible but can be palpated)

 

Margin: Where edge merges with surrounding healthy skin

 

Key characteristics:

 

Edge provides important diagnostic clues:

 

  • Punched out in trophic ulcer
  • Undermined in tuberculous ulcer
  • Everted in malignant ulcer
  • Sloping in healing ulcer

 

Educational Objective:

 

Edge of an ulcer is the junction between floor and surrounding skin, and its characteristics provide important diagnostic clues.

questions.text: A woman few months after delivery complains of bloody discharge from the nipple. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ductal papilloma

 

Explanation:

 

In a young lactating woman with bloody nipple discharge:

 

  • Ductal papilloma is the most common cause of bloody nipple discharge in young women
  • It is a benign tumor arising from a single duct

 

Characteristics include:

 

  • Spontaneous discharge
  • Usually from single duct
  • May be serous or bloody
  • More common in young women
  • Diagnosed by ductoscopy
  • Treated by microdochectomy via tennis racket incision

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Duct ectasia: Incorrect as it typically causes greenish discharge and is associated with smoking

 

Option C. Galactocele: Incorrect as it presents as a swelling that may have milky discharge during lactation

 

Option D. Mondors disease: Incorrect as it is thrombophlebitis of superficial veins of breast/chest wall presenting as a cord-like tender structure, not nipple discharge

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ductal papilloma is the most common cause of bloody nipple discharge in young women, characterized by spontaneous discharge from a single duct.

questions.text: Identify the modality shown in the image? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Retrograde pyelogram

 

The X-ray shows characteristics of retrograde pyelogram:

 

  • Contrast visible in only one ureter and renal pelvis
  • Presence of catheter visible (placed via cystoscopy)
  • No nephrogram phase visible (kidney shadow not seen)
  • Shows renal pelvis in claw-like appearance
  • Performed by injecting contrast directly into ureter via cystoscopy
  • Used when IVU fails or in non-functioning kidney

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IVU: Incorrect as IVU shows bilateral ureter and renal system, includes nephrogram phase, and no catheter is visible

 

 

Option C. Ureteric stent: Incorrect as a stent would appear as a distinct radio-opaque tube with curved ends (double-J appearance), without contrast
 

 

Option D. Nephrostomy tube: Incorrect as nephrostomy tube enters directly through flank into kidney, not via ureter

 

Educational Objective:

 

A Retrograde Pyelogram (RGP) is a contrast study performed via cystoscopy, allowing visualization of one-sided ureters and renal pelvis. It is used to diagnose ureteric strictures, stones, and tumors.

questions.text: Spread of prostate cancer to lumbar vertebra occurs via? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Venous

 

Explanation:

 

Prostate cancer spreads to lumbar vertebrae through:

 

  • Bateson's venous plexus (vertebral venous plexus)
  • This is a valveless system allowing bidirectional flow
  • Connects prostatic venous plexus to vertebral veins
  • Most common cancer in men with bone metastasis
  • Typically produces osteoblastic lesions in bones

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Direct: Incorrect as prostate is anatomically distant from lumbar vertebrae making direct spread impossible

 

Option B. Arterial: Incorrect as prostatic venous plexus connection to vertebrae via Bateson's plexus is the established pathway

 

Option D. Lymphatic: Incorrect as lymphatic spread of prostate cancer is typically to pelvic and para-aortic nodes, not directly to vertebrae

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prostate cancer spreads to lumbar vertebrae through Bateson's venous plexus, making it the most common cancer in men with bone metastasis.



Spread of CA Prostate

questions.text: A 4-week-old infant presents with vomiting and constipation. On examination, a palpable abdominal mass is noted. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) CHPS

 

Explanation:

 

Clinical features strongly suggest CHPS:

 

  • CHPS is caused by hypertrophy of the pyloric sphincter, leading to gastric outlet obstruction.
  • It typically presents in males, around 4-8 weeks of age.
  • Electrolyte abnormality: Hypokalemic, hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis due to loss of gastric acid and dehydration.
  • Best initial test: Ultrasound abdomen → Shows a thickened pyloric muscle (> 4mm thick, > 16mm long).
  • Treatment: Ramstedt’s pyloromyotomy (surgical incision of the hypertrophied pyloric muscle).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Duodenal atresia: Incorrect as it presents at birth with bilious vomiting and double-bubble sign on X-ray

 

 

Option B. Intussusception: Incorrect as it occurs in infants 6-18 months of age and presents with red currant jelly stools

 

 

Option D. Hirschsprung's disease: Incorrect as it presents at birth with failure to pass meconium within 48 hours and has delayed passage of stools

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

CHPS classically presents at 4-8 weeks of age with non-bilious projectile vomiting and palpable olive-shaped mass in epigastrium.

 

Infantile Pyloric Stenosis (IHPS)

questions.text: A patient with a history of hematochezia undergoes a procedure using the device shown in the image. Identify the device. (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pile banding kit

 

Explanation:

 

The image shows Barron's band ligator:

 

  • Used for rubber band ligation of internal hemorrhoids
  • Has bands loaded that are deployed around hemorrhoid base
  • Causes strangulation of hemorrhoid tissue
  • Most commonly used for grade II hemorrhoids
  • Done as outpatient procedure

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Stapler for hemorrhoids: Incorrect as a stapler is a circular device used for stapled hemorrhoidopexy (PPH procedure)

 

Option C. Hemorrhoidectomy kit: Incorrect as this would include surgical instruments for excision

 

Option D. Fistula surgery kit: Incorrect as this would include instruments for fistula surgery like probes, curettes and scissors



Educational Objective:

 

A Pile Banding Kit is used in rubber band ligation for treating Grade II and III hemorrhoids. It applies a rubber band at the base of the hemorrhoid, leading to necrosis and sloughing.


Haemorrhoids Grading and Treatment

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient came with diffuse, severely contaminated perforation peritonitis due to hollow viscus. He underwent laparotomy for it. On day 7 post-op, he developed signs of wound infection and subsequently, the wound showed dehiscence with exposure of underlying tissues as shown below. His vital signs are stable with no evidence of intra-abdominal sepsis. What is the appropriate management? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vacuum assisted closure (VAC)

 

Explanation:

 

The patient underwent laparotomy for perforation peritonitis and developed wound infection followed by wound dehiscence on postoperative day 7. Given that:

 

  • The wound is open with exposed underlying tissues.
  • Vital signs are stable.
  • No evidence of intra-abdominal sepsis.

 

This suggests a "burst abdomen" or post-op wound dehiscence, which is best managed using Vacuum-Assisted Closure (VAC therapy).

 

  • Promotes granulation tissue formation and wound healing.
  • Reduces bacterial load and infection risk.
  • Decreases edema and maintains a moist environment.
  • Prepares the wound for secondary closure or grafting if necessary.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Suturing of Wound → Incorrect

 

  • Primary closure is not recommended because the wound is infected and dehiscent.
  • Attempting suturing would increase the risk of abscess formation and wound breakdown.

 

Option C. Normal Saline-Soaked Gauze → Partially Correct but Not Ideal

 

  • Saline dressings can be used but do not actively promote wound healing as well as VAC therapy.
  • More suitable for minor dehiscence, not large wounds with exposed tissue.

 

Option D. None of the Above → Incorrect

 

  • The patient requires wound management to prevent secondary infections and facilitate healing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vacuum-Assisted Closure (VAC) therapy is the best treatment for wound dehiscence after laparotomy, as it promotes granulation tissue formation, reduces infection risk, and optimizes healing.

questions.text: During laparoscopic surgery, which vessels are most prone to injury while inserting trocars? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Both B and C (Inferior Epigastric Artery & Superior Epigastric Artery)

 

Explanation:

 

During laparoscopic surgery, trocars are inserted through the abdominal wall, and the most commonly injured vessels are epigastric arteries, specifically:

 

  1. Inferior Epigastric Artery (IEA) → Runs posterior to the rectus abdominis, arising from the external iliac artery. It is commonly injured during trocar placement at the lateral ports (midclavicular line or lateral to rectus muscle).
  2. Superior Epigastric Artery (SEA) → Arises from the internal thoracic artery, supplying the upper abdominal wall. It is less commonly injured but still at risk in upper trocar insertions near the midline.

 

Risk factors 

 

  • Inferior epigastric artery (IEA) runs lateral to the rectus muscle.
  • Most laparoscopic trocars are placed in the periumbilical region and lateral ports, near IEA’s path.
  • Injury to these vessels can lead to significant bleeding or hematoma formation, especially retroperitoneal hematoma.

 

Other Option:

 

Option A. Abdominal Aorta → Incorrect

 

  • The aorta is a retroperitoneal structure, located deep in the abdomen.
  • It is not commonly injured during standard trocar placement unless there is misplacement of a Veress needle or excessive force.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Inferior and Superior Epigastric Arteries are the most commonly injured vessels during laparoscopic trocar insertion. Using transillumination and proper trocar placement can prevent vascular injury.



Management of Epigastric Artery Injury:

 

  1. Preventive Measure:
    • Use transillumination to identify epigastric vessels before inserting trocars.
    • Place lateral trocars either lateral or medial to epigastric artery path.
  2. If Injury Occurs:
    • Immediate control using electrocautery or direct pressure.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy was brought to the ER with complaints of melena. The child had intermittent pain in the right iliac region. On surgical exploration, the following was found. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Meckel’s diverticulum

 

Explanation:

 

Meckel’s Diverticulum:

 

  • Congenital anomaly resulting from incomplete obliteration of the vitelline duct.
  • Rule of 2’s:
    • Found in 2% of the population.
    • 2 feet from the ileocecal valve.
    • 2 inches long.
    • 2 types of ectopic mucosa (gastric & pancreatic).
    • 2:1 male predominance.
  • Complications:
    • Bleeding (painless hematochezia/melena) due to acid secretion from ectopic gastric mucosa, leading to ulceration.
    • Intestinal obstruction (due to volvulus or intussusception).

    • Diverticulitis, mimicking appendicitis.

       

Other Options:

 

Option B. Obstructed Bowel Loops → Incorrect

 

  • Would present with bilious vomiting, abdominal distension, and absent bowel sounds.
  • No mention of melena or ectopic gastric tissue.

 

Option C. Appendicitis → Incorrect

 

  • While pain is in the right iliac fossa, melena is not a feature of appendicitis.
  • Would present with fever, localized tenderness, rebound tenderness, and leukocytosis.

 

Option D. Appendicular Mucocele → Incorrect

 

  • A mucocele is a mucus-filled dilatation of the appendix, usually seen in adults.
  • Presents as a mass in the right iliac fossa, but not with melena.

 

Educational Objective:

 

It presents with painless lower gastrointestinal bleeding due to ectopic gastric mucosa, mimicking appendicitis. Diagnosis is confirmed by Meckel’s scan, and treatment is surgical resection in symptomatic cases.

questions.text: A 28-year-old patient presented with painless right scrotal swelling for 2 months. The left testis was normal. There were enlarged para-aortic nodes. USG showed right testicular mass. What will be the management? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) High inguinal orchiectomy

 

Explanation: 


This is a classic presentation of testicular tumor (likely seminoma) with para-aortic lymph node metastasis. High inguinal orchiectomy is the standard initial management. The procedure involves removing the entire testis with spermatic cord through an inguinal incision. This approach is crucial because:

 

  • It allows control of lymphatic and vascular supply at the deep inguinal ring
  • Prevents tumor spillage and local spread
  • Avoids breaching the scrotum which could lead to tumor seeding
  • Helps maintain proper oncological principles

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Biopsy of scrotal mass - Incorrect

 

  • Biopsy or FNAC is contraindicated in testicular tumors as it may cause tumor spillage and upstaging
  • Can lead to scrotal violation and altered lymphatic drainage

 

Option C. Scrotal orchiectomy - Incorrect

 

  • Associated with high risk of local recurrence
  • Breaches scrotal skin which can lead to tumor seeding
  • Changes the lymphatic drainage pattern
  • Can cause upstaging of the tumor

 

Option D. Biopsy of lymph node - Incorrect

 

  • Not needed at initial diagnosis
  • Primary management is always removal of the testicular mass
  • Para-aortic nodes are consistent with the natural lymphatic spread pattern
  • Further staging can be done after orchiectomy

 

Educational Objective:


High inguinal orchiectomy is the standard initial management for testicular tumors. Scrotal violation must be avoided to prevent tumor spillage and upstaging.

questions.text: An elderly patient complains of multiple clots in his urine. Which catheter should be used in this patient which can facilitate irrigation and clot removal from the urinary bladder? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 22 French Foley's 3 lumen catheter

 

Explanation: 


A triple lumen catheter is ideal for managing clots in bladder as it has:

 

  • First channel for urine drainage
  • Second channel for balloon inflation
  • Third channel specifically for continuous irrigation
  • 22 French size is appropriate for adequate drainage of clots
  • Commonly used after procedures like TURP where post-operative clots are expected
  • Allows simultaneous irrigation and drainage

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 22 French Foley's 4 lumen catheter - Incorrect

 

  • Does not exist in clinical practice
  • No requirement for fourth lumen

 

Option C. 22 French Foley's 2 lumen catheter - Incorrect

 

  • Has only drainage and balloon inflation channels
  • No separate channel for irrigation
  • Cannot perform continuous irrigation effectively

 

Option D. 22 French Foley's 1 lumen catheter - Incorrect

 

  • Cannot be self-retaining as no balloon inflation channel
  • No irrigation capability
  • Inadequate for managing clots
  • Not practical for this clinical scenario

 

Educational Objective: 


A three-way Foley's catheter (22Fr) is the appropriate choice for managing bladder clots as it allows simultaneous drainage and irrigation through separate channels.

questions.text: A patient presents six months after an abdominal hysterectomy with a swelling at the scar site. Initially reducible, the swelling has now become irreducible and tender. The rest of the abdomen is normal on palpation. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Bowel strangulation

 

Explanation:

 

This is a case of strangulated incisional hernia because:

 

  • History of previous surgery (hysterectomy) leading to incisional hernia
  • Initially reducible swelling suggests hernia
  • Progression to irreducibility with tenderness indicates strangulation
  • Strangulation occurs when blood supply to herniated bowel is compromised
  • Requires urgent surgical intervention to prevent bowel gangrene

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Paralytic ileus: Incorrect

 

  • Presents with generalized abdominal distention, not localized swelling
  • No history of recent surgery or precipitating factors
  • Usually associated with absent bowel sounds
  • Does not present as reducible turning irreducible swelling

 

Option B. Perforation peritonitis: Incorrect

 

  • Presents with generalized abdominal pain and distention
  • Associated with severe systemic symptoms
  • Shows signs of peritonitis all over abdomen
  • Not localized to surgical scar

 

Option D. Ascites: Incorrect

 

  • Causes generalized abdominal distention
  • Fluid collects in dependent areas
  • Shows shifting dullness
  • Not localized to surgical scar

 

Educational Objective:

 

A previously reducible hernia becoming irreducible with tenderness indicates strangulation, which is a surgical emergency requiring immediate intervention.

questions.text: An 18-year-old male presents with severe nodulocystic acne involving the face and back, as shown in the image. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Isotretinoin

 

This is a case of grade 4 (nodulocystic) acne, which is the most severe form of acne vulgaris. In grade 4 acne:

 

  • Patients present with deep nodules and cysts
  • Lesions are typically present on face and back
  • Treatment choice is oral isotretinoin (13-cis-retinoic acid)
  • Dosage: 0.5-1 mg/kg/day with total cumulative dose of 120-150 mg/kg
  • Isotretinoin requires monitoring of lipid profile and liver function tests.

 

Oral isotretinoin is the treatment of choice for severe nodulocystic acne due to its ability to target all four pathophysiological factors of acne:

 

  1. Reduces sebum production by shrinking sebaceous glands.
  2. Inhibits follicular keratinization, preventing comedone formation.
  3. Exerts anti-inflammatory effects.
  4. Reduces the population of Propionibacterium acnes, the bacteria involved in acne pathogenesis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Prednisolone/Steroids

 

  • Systemic steroids are not indicated for routine acne treatment
  • Can actually worsen acne on withdrawal
  • May have role in severe inflammatory acne but not as monotherapy

 

Option C. Topical tretinoin

 

  • Only indicated for grade 1 (comedonal) acne
  • Used along with topical antibiotics in grade 2 acne
  • Insufficient for severe nodulocystic acne

 

Option D. Azithromycin

 

  • Oral antibiotics like azithromycin are used in grade 3 acne
  • Not potent enough for severe nodulocystic lesions
  • Oral Minocycline, Azithromycin and Doxycycline can be used in grade 3 acne

 

Grades of Acne:

 

  1. Grade 1 : Non-inflammatory open and closed comedones. Treated with topical retinoids (Tretinoin, Adapalene).
  2. Grade 2 (Mild inflammatory acne): Presence of papules and mild erythema. Treated with topical retinoids + topical antibiotics (Clindamycin, Nadifloxacin).
  3. Grade 3 (Moderate inflammatory acne): Predominance of pustules. Treated with topical retinoids + oral antibiotics (Minocycline, Azithromycin, Doxycycline).
  4. Grade 4 (Severe nodulocystic acne): Deep, painful nodules and cysts on the face, chest, and back. Treatment of choice: Oral isotretinoin.

 

Educational Objective:


Oral isotretinoin is the drug of choice for grade 4 (nodulocystic) acne vulgaris.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female undergoing chemotherapy for breast cancer develops diffuse hair loss following the treatment. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anagen effluvium

 

This is a classic case of anagen effluvium where:

 

  • Hair loss occurs 3-4 weeks after chemotherapy/radiotherapy
  • Actively dividing anagen hair follicles (80-90% of scalp hair) are directly damaged
  • Complete destruction of anagen phase leads to diffuse hair loss
  • No conversion of anagen to telogen phase occurs
  • Loss is abrupt and extensive due to direct damage to growing follicles

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Telogen effluvium

 

  • Occurs 3 months after a stressful trigger (not immediately)
  • Triggers include surgery, pregnancy, infections like typhoid/dengue/COVID
  • Involves premature conversion of anagen to telogen phase
  • Not associated with direct follicular damage


 

Option C. Trichotillomania

 

  • Associated with psychiatric issues/OCD
  • Compulsive hair pulling disorder
  • Shows incomplete patch of hair loss with varying lengths
  • Not related to chemotherapy

 


Option D. Alopecia areata

 

  • Presents as well-defined patches of complete hair loss
  • Autoimmune targeting of anagen hair bulb
  • Shows exclamation mark hairs at margins
  • No association with chemotherapy


 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Chemotherapy-induced hair loss is due to anagen effluvium, where rapidly dividing hair follicle cells are damaged. 
  • Hair loss starts within weeks of chemotherapy initiation and is diffuse and non-scarring. 
  • Hair typically regrows within a few months after stopping chemotherapy.

questions.text: Which test would you perform to assess the underlying cause of this patient? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Grattage test

 

The image shows erythematous plaques with silvery white scales over the lumbosacral area, this is consistent with psoriasis. Grattage test is the diagnostic test of choice because:

 

  • It is a component of Auspitz sign used to diagnose psoriasis
  • Involves scraping the scales with a glass slide
  • Shows three sequential changes: 
  1. Candle wax sign - scales falling like candle wax
  2. Exposure of underlying bulkeley membrane
  3. Pinpoint bleeding spots (end point of Auspitz sign)

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Nikolsky test

 

  • Used in vesiculobullous disorders like pemphigus
  • Nikolsky sign rather than Nikolsky test.
  • Involves applying tangential pressure to separate epidermis
  • Tests for acantholysis in epidermis 
  • Not relevant for scaly plaques of psoriasis

 

 

Option C. Asboe Hansen test

 

  • Variant of bulla spread sign
  • Asboe Hansen sign rather than Asboe Hansen test.
  • Used in vesiculobullous disorders
  • Involves applying perpendicular pressure to center of intact bulla
  • Not applicable for psoriatic plaques

 

 

Option D. Patch test

 

  • Investigation of choice for allergic contact dermatitis
  • Tests for type IV hypersensitivity reaction
  • Not indicated for psoriasis diagnosis
  • Used to identify specific allergens

 

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Grattage test, demonstrating candle wax scaling, bulkeley membrane, and pinpoint bleeding (Auspitz sign), is the diagnostic test for psoriasis.

questions.text: An infant with a history of multiple episodes of diarrhea presents with an erythematous, scaly rash, as shown in the image. Which nutritional deficiency is responsible for this condition, and which supplementation should be administered to reverse the clinical features? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Zinc

 

The case describes classic acrodermatitis enteropathica (AE), characterized by:

 

  • Presents around 6 months when weaning from breast milk occurs
  • Diagnostic triad: 
  1. Periorificial and acral dermatitis (erythematous scaly lesions)
  2. Diarrhea
  3. Alopecia
  • Caused by zinc deficiency due to SLC39A4 gene mutation
  • Inheritance: Autosomal recessive
  • Affects zinc absorption in intestine
  • Treatment requires lifelong zinc supplementation

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin A

 

  • Deficiency causes follicular hyperkeratosis
  • Does not present with periorificial dermatitis
  • No specific association with diarrhea
  • Different pattern of skin manifestations

 

Option C. Vitamin C

 

  • Deficiency causes scurvy
  • Presents with follicular hyperkeratosis and perifollicular hemorrhages
  • Characteristic corkscrew hair changes
  • Gum bleeding is prominent

 

 

Option D. Iron

 

  • Deficiency causes koilonychia (spoon-shaped nails)
  • Associated with angular cheilitis
  • Does not cause periorificial dermatitis
  • No direct association with diarrhea

 


 

Educational Objective: 


Acrodermatitis enteropathica presents with the triad of periorificial dermatitis, diarrhea, and alopecia due to zinc deficiency, requiring lifelong zinc supplementation.

choices.text: Wide local excision with skin grafting

questions.text: A 4-week-old baby presented with an erythematous lesion which was blanching and increasing in size as shown in the image below. What is the next best step in the management of this condition? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Observe

 

Presentation & Diagnosis

 

  • Neonate presenting with an erythematous, blanching lesion on the abdomen. 
  • Characteristic features point to an infantile hemangioma, a benign vascular tumor common in neonates.

 

Natural History 

 

Proliferative Phase: 

 

  • Rapid growth typically observed until about 9 months of age. 

 

Involution Phase: 

 

  • A slow regression phase follows, extending over several years until spontaneous resolution.

 

Location & Complication Assessment 

 

Location: 

 

  • The lesion is on the abdomen, a non-vital area (not affecting vision, breathing, or feeding). 

 

Complications: 

 

  • No signs of ulceration, bleeding, or interference with vital functions.

 

Management Strategy 

 

Observation: 

 

  • Given the predictable natural history and absence of complications, the best approach is conservative management through observation.    

 

Parental Reassurance: 

 

  • It is essential to inform and reassure parents about the benign nature and expected spontaneous regression of the lesion.

 

Regular Monitoring: 

 

  • Continuous follow-up is necessary to ensure proper regression and to monitor for any potential complications.

 

Indications for Intervention

 

Active treatment is reserved for cases where the hemangioma: 

 

  • Compromises vital structures (e.g., near the eyes, nose, or airway). 

 

 

  • Is associated with complications such as ulceration or bleeding. 
  • Is large and disfiguring.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CO2 laser

 

  • Not first-line treatment for uncomplicated infantile hemangiomas
  • Unnecessarily aggressive for a self-resolving condition
  • May cause scarring in a condition that naturally resolves
  • Reserved for residual telangiectasias after involution

 

Option B. Wide local excision with skin grafting

 

  • Too aggressive for a benign, self-limiting condition
  • Surgery indicated only for specific cases like ulcerated lesions
  • Unnecessary scarring and surgical risk
  • Not justified when natural resolution is expected

 

Option D. Injection triamcinolone

 

  • Not indicated for uncomplicated infantile hemangiomas
  • Local complications like atrophy can occur
  • Systemic beta-blockers like propranolol have largely replaced steroids as the treatment of choice for complicated hemangiomas. 
  • No indication for intralesional steroids in this case

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Infantile hemangiomas are benign vascular tumors that undergo spontaneous involution. 
  • Observation is the best initial management for uncomplicated cases. 
  • Propranolol is the first-line treatment for high-risk or complicated hemangiomas.

questions.text: A patient presented with erythema and soreness on the glans penis and pigmentation over chin. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lichen sclerosus

 

Lichen sclerosus is a chronic inflammatory dermatosis that primarily affects the anogenital region and is more common in uncircumcised males. The clinical presentation includes:

 

1. Erythema and soreness: These are typical symptoms due to thinning of the epithelium and chronic irritation.

 

2. White atrophic plaques or changes on the glans penis: Progression may lead to sclerotic plaques with scarring.

 

 

3. Pigmentation or associated lesions elsewhere: While uncommon, extragenital pigmentation can occur in related inflammatory or dermatological conditions.

 

Histologically, lichen sclerosus shows epidermal thinning, loss of rete ridges, and dermal fibrosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Condyloma acuminata

 

  • Presents as verrucous lesions with rough surface
  • Caused by HPV (types 6 and 11)
  • No association with facial pigmentation
  • Shows papillomatous growth pattern
  • No erythema or soreness as primary symptoms

 

 

Option C. Fournier’s gangrene


Fournier’s gangrene is a necrotizing fasciitis of the perineal region and presents with severe pain, swelling, systemic signs of sepsis, and crepitus. This condition is a medical emergency and does not present as erythema and soreness without systemic signs.

 

 

Option D. Peyronies disease

 

  • Involves fibrotic plaque within penis causing curvature

 

 

  • Affects the internal structure rather than surface
  • Associated with erectile dysfunction
  • No association with facial pigmentation
  • No erythema or soreness of glans

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lichen sclerosus presents with genital erythema and soreness, progressing to atrophic white plaques, and can be associated with extragenital manifestations like facial pigmentation.

questions.text: A patient got prick by rose thorn and after that there are linear lesions noted along the lymphatics. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sporotrichosis

 

The clinical presentation suggests lymphocutaneous sporotrichosis, a subcutaneous fungal infection caused by Sporothrix schenckii. This fungus is commonly found in soil, plants, and decaying vegetation, and rose thorn injury is a classic risk factor.

 

Features of Sporotrichosis:

 

  • Causative agent: Sporothrix schenckii (a dimorphic fungus).
  • Mode of infection: Traumatic implantation (e.g., rose thorn, gardening injury).
  • Clinical progression:
    • Initial painless papule or ulcer at the site of injury.
    • Spreads along the lymphatics, forming linear nodular lesions (sporotrichoid pattern).

 

 

  • Lesions ulcerate over time but remain relatively painless.

 

Diagnosis:

 

  • Culture (gold standard): S. schenckii grows as cigar-shaped yeast in tissue.
  • Histopathology: Granulomatous inflammation.
  • Direct microscopy: Asteroid bodies (yeast cells surrounded by eosinophilic material).

 

Treatment:

 

  • First-line therapy: Itraconazole (for cutaneous and lymphocutaneous forms).
  • Severe/systemic cases: Amphotericin B.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Chromoblastomycosis

 

  • Develops verrucous lesion at site of thorn prick

 

 

  • Caused by dematiaceous fungi
  • Shows copper penny bodies on KOH mount

 

 

  • Localized lesion without lymphatic spread

 

Option C. Tinea corporis

 

  • Superficial dermatophyte infection of glabrous skin
  • Shows annular plaque with active borders 

 

 

  • No relation to thorn prick
  • No lymphatic spread

 

Option D. Mycetoma

 

  • Shows classic triad after thorn prick: 
    • Granules
    • Sinuses
    • Swelling

 

 

  • No linear spread along lymphatics
  • More localized presentation
  • Can be caused by bacteria or fungi

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sporotrichosis should be suspected in patients with a history of rose thorn injury and linear nodular lesions along lymphatics. It is treated with itraconazole.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female having a new sexual partner / boyfriend presented with painful ulcer on the vulva and bilateral inguinal lymphadenopathy. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chancroid

 

The clinical presentation of a painful genital ulcer along with bilateral inguinal lymphadenopathy strongly suggests chancroid, a sexually transmitted infection caused by Haemophilus ducreyi.

 

Chancroid:

 

  • Causative agent: Haemophilus ducreyi (Gram-negative coccobacillus).
  • Incubation period: 2-5 days after sexual exposure.
  • Genital ulcer characteristics:
    • Multiple, painful ulcers.

 

 

  • Irregular, soft edges (hence the term soft chancre).
  • Necrotic, yellow-gray base with purulent discharge.
  • Bleeds on touch.

 

Inguinal lymphadenopathy (Bubo):

 

  • Painful, unilateral or bilateral lymph nodes.

 

 

  • May progress to suppuration and rupture.

 

Diagnosis:

 

  • Clinical diagnosis is common.
  • Gram stain of ulcer exudate: "School of fish" or "railroad track" appearance.
  • Culture on Mueller-Hinton agar (low sensitivity).

 

Treatment:

 

  • First-line therapy: Azithromycin (1 g single dose) or Ceftriaxone (250 mg IM single dose).
  • Alternative therapy: Erythromycin or Ciprofloxacin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Neisseria (Gonorrhea):

 

  • Causes purulent urethral or cervical discharge.
  • Does not cause genital ulcers.

 

Option C. Granuloma inguinale (Donovanosis):

 

  • Caused by Klebsiella granulomatis.
  • Presents with a painless, beefy-red ulcer that bleeds easily.
  • No lymphadenopathy (pseudo-bubo may be seen).

 

 

Option D. Lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV):

 

  • Caused by Chlamydia trachomatis (L1-L3 serovars).
  • Begins with a small, painless ulcer that heals spontaneously.
  • Followed by painful inguinal lymphadenopathy (Bubo) associated with groove sign.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chancroid is a sexually transmitted disease caused by Haemophilus ducreyi, presenting as painful genital ulcers with inguinal lymphadenopathy. It is treated with Azithromycin or Ceftriaxone.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents with an ulcerative lesion near the medial canthus of his eye, featuring pearly margins. Microscopic examination reveals a palisading arrangement of cells. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Basal cell carcinoma

 

This case presents classic features of basal cell carcinoma (BCC):

 

  • Most common malignancy of skin
  • Location above the line joining angle of mouth and ear lobe
  • Medial canthus involvement is common
  • Characteristic pearly white beaded borders

 

 

  • Locally invasive tumor, can undergo ulceration which are called as rodent ulcers with rolled out edges.

 

 

  • Surface shows telangiectasia
  • Histologically shows peripheral palisading pattern

 

 

Palisading granuloma

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Keratoacanthoma

 

  • Rapidly growing tumor with central keratotic plug
  • Dome-shaped lesion resembling molluscum

 

 

  • Self-limiting nature
  • Different clinical and histological appearance
  • No pearly margins

 

Option B. Melanocytic melanoma

 

  • Pigmented lesion with ABCDE features

 

 

  • Shows asymmetry, border irregularity
  • Colour variation and diameter >6mm
  • No pearly margins
  • Different histological pattern

 

 

Option C. Squamous cell carcinoma

 

  • Presents as papulosquamous lesion
  • Shows erythematous base with scaling

 

 

  • More aggressive behaviour
  • Histopathology shows keratin pearls but no palisading
  • Different clinical appearance

 

 

Educational Objective:


Basal cell carcinoma typically presents with pearly margins and palisading arrangement of cells on histology, commonly occurring above the line joining angle of mouth and ear lobe. It is a locally invasive tumor that rarely metastasizes.

questions.text: Identify the inappropriate drug dosage of leprosy medications in adults among the following options? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Rifampicin 450 mg weekly

 

In adults with leprosy, rifampicin should be given as 600mg ONCE MONTHLY, not 450mg weekly. The correct dosing regimen for adults includes:

 

  • Rifampicin: 600mg once monthly (supervised)
  • Dapsone: 100mg daily
  • Clofazimine: 300mg once monthly (supervised) + 50mg daily
  • Clofazimine dosage is half of rifampicin for monthly dose (300mg) and half of dapsone for daily dose (50mg)
  • The dose of 450 mg once a month is typically reserved for children weighing less than 35 kg.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Clofazimine 300 mg once a month

 

  • Correct supervised monthly dose
  • Equal to half the monthly rifampicin dose

 

Option B. Clofazimine 50 mg daily

 

  • Correct daily unsupervised dose
  • Equal to half the daily dapsone dose

 

Option D. Dapsone 100 mg daily

 

  • Correct daily unsupervised dose
  • Standard component of both PB and MB regimens
  • Well-established dosage

 

 

WHO Regimen

 

 

 

Educational Objective:


In adult leprosy treatment, rifampicin is given as 600mg once monthly (supervised dose), not 450mg weekly.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with heavy menstrual bleeding and is diagnosed with endometrial hyperplasia without atypia based on an endometrial biopsy. What is the most appropriate treatment option for her? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Levonorgestrel Intrauterine System (LNG-IUS)

 

Endometrial hyperplasia without atypia is a premalignant condition caused by unopposed estrogen stimulation of the endometrium, leading to excessive proliferation of the endometrial glands. 

 

The primary concern with endometrial hyperplasia is its potential progression to endometrial carcinoma, though the risk is much lower in cases without atypia (approximately 1%).

 

LNG-IUS (Mirena) -progesterone is the mainstay treatment because it induces endometrial atrophy and prevents further proliferation.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. COCPs (Incorrect): Although Combined contraceptive pills are protective for endometrial cancer, they are not a treatment option for endometrial hyperplasia due to the estrogen component. 

 

Option C. Danazol (Incorrect): Danazol is an antigonadotropin with significant androgenic side effects. While it was historically used for endometriosis, it is not used for treating endometrial hyperplasia.

 

Option D. Mifepristone (Incorrect): Mifepristone is primarily used for medical termination of pregnancy and occasionally for emergency contraception or fibroid treatment. It is not indicated for treating endometrial hyperplasia.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Remember that LNG-IUS is the preferred treatment for endometrial hyperplasia without atypia due to its local progesterone delivery, which causes endometrial atrophy. This condition has a lower risk of malignancy (~1%) compared to hyperplasia with atypia, which requires hysterectomy.

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman presents to the outpatient department (OPD) with a history of 2 months of amenorrhea. A urine pregnancy test is positive. On speculum examination, the following finding is observed. Identify the sign seen? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chadwick’s sign

 

The image shows a speculum examination of the cervix demonstrating a bluish/purplish discoloration, which is known as Chadwick's sign or Jacquemier's sign. This is one of the earliest visible signs of pregnancy, caused by increased vascularity and venous congestion of the cervix and vagina during early pregnancy.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Osiander sign: This is incorrect. Osiander sign refers to the pulsations felt in the lateral fornix due to increased vascularity of uterine arteries in early pregnancy.

 

Option B. Hegar sign: This is incorrect. Hegar sign is elicited during bimanual examination where there is softening of the lower uterine segment, allowing the examiner's fingers to almost meet between the cervix and uterine body.

 

Option D. Placental sign: This is incorrect. Placental sign refers to implantation bleeding that occurs when the embryo implants in the uterus.

 

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Chadwick's sign (bluish discoloration of cervix and vagina) as one of the early visible signs of pregnancy during speculum examination, distinguishing it from other early pregnancy signs like Hegar's and Osiander's signs.

questions.text: A 23-year-old primigravida presents at 8 weeks of pregnancy. During the examination, a specific clinical sign is observed. What is the name of the sign being elicited? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hegar sign

 

The image demonstrates Hegar's sign, which is elicited during bimanual examination in early pregnancy. Due to the softening of the lower uterine segment at the level of the isthmus, the examining fingers can be approximated between the cervix and the uterine body. This softening allows the examiner's hands to almost meet at the isthmus level during bimanual examination, which is characteristic of Hegar's sign.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Palmer sign: This is incorrect. Palmer sign refers to the detection of subtle uterine contractions felt during bimanual examination in early pregnancy, not the softening at isthmus.

 

Option C. Internal ballotment: This is incorrect. Internal ballotment is a second-trimester finding (after 16 weeks) where the fetus can be balloted between the examining fingers during vaginal examination.

 

Option D. External ballotment: This is incorrect. External ballotment is also a second-trimester finding elicited through abdominal examination, not applicable at 8 weeks of pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hegar's sign as the softening of the lower uterine segment at the isthmus level during early pregnancy, allowing approximation of examining fingers during bimanual examination, and distinguishing it from other pregnancy signs.

questions.text: Identify this laparoscopic image? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Genital tuberculosis

 

The laparoscopic image shows two key diagnostic features of genital tuberculosis:

 

  1. "Kissing fallopian tube sign" - where the fallopian tubes are stuck together posteriorly
  2. Presence of caseous (whitish) nodules These findings are pathognomonic for genital tuberculosis on laparoscopy.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Tubal endometriosis: In tubal endometriosis, the tubes are typically adherent to the posterior surface of the uterus, and reddish-blackish or whitish lesions are seen over the tube. This pattern is not seen in the image.

 

Option C. Hydrosalpinx: While hydrosalpinx can occur in genital tuberculosis, it has a different appearance with dilated fallopian tubes. The image does not show dilated tubes.

 

Option D. Chocolate cyst: This is an endometriotic ovarian cyst containing dark brown material. In the image, the ovaries are not visible as they are likely behind the uterus.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • The "kissing fallopian tube sign" along with caseous nodules on laparoscopy is diagnostic of genital tuberculosis.
  • Fallopian tubes are the most common organs affected in genital TB

questions.text: The earliest sign of pregnancy on Trans Vaginal Scan is: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Gestational sac

 

On transvaginal ultrasound (TVS), the gestational sac is the first visible sign of pregnancy, appearing at 5 weeks of gestation. This is approximately one week earlier than when it becomes visible on transabdominal scan (TAS, visible at 6 weeks). The gestational sac appears as an anechoic structure within the endometrial cavity.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Yolk sac: This is incorrect as the yolk sac appears at 5.5 weeks on TVS, after the gestational sac is visible.

 

Option C. Fetal pole: This is incorrect as the fetal pole appears at 6 weeks on TVS, after both the gestational sac and yolk sac are visible.

 

Option D. Cardiac activity: This is incorrect as cardiac activity also becomes visible at 6 weeks on TVS, along with the fetal pole, making it one of the later findings in early pregnancy ultrasound.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The chronological order of appearance of early pregnancy structures on TVS:

 

  • Gestational sac: 5 weeks
  • Yolk sac: 5.5 weeks
  • Fetal pole with cardiac activity: 6 weeks 
  • On trans-abdominal scan; these structures appear 1 week later

questions.text: Which vaccine is not safe in pregnancy? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Varicella

 

Varicella (chickenpox) vaccine is a live vaccine that is contraindicated during pregnancy. Live vaccines are generally avoided during pregnancy due to the theoretical risk of transmitting the attenuated virus to the fetus, which could potentially cause infection and teratogenicity. The only exception to this rule is the yellow fever vaccine, which may be given if travel to an endemic area is absolutely necessary.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Influenza: Incorrect. While influenza vaccine is available in both live and inactivated forms, the inactivated influenza vaccine is commonly used and is safe during pregnancy.

 

Option C. Rabies: Incorrect. Rabies vaccine is a killed vaccine and is safe to administer during pregnancy if indicated.

 

Option D. Td: Incorrect. Tetanus and diphtheria (Td) vaccine is routinely recommended and safely administered during pregnancy to prevent maternal and neonatal tetanus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

All live vaccines except yellow fever are contra-indicated due to the theoretical risk of fetal infection and teratogenicity

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman with a BMI of 27 presents with increased facial hair (hirsutism), acne, and irregular/delayed periods. An ultrasound is performed, showing characteristic findings. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) PCOS

 

The ultrasound image shows the classic "string of pearls" appearance characteristic of polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS). This appearance is created by multiple small follicles arranged in a peripheral pattern within the ovary. In this case, the diagnosis of PCOS is supported by:

 

Rotterdam criteria is used to diagnose PCOS. As per this criteria; 2 out of 3 following characteristics should be present: 

 

  1. Anovulation/oligo ovulation 
  2. Hyperandrogenism (Clinical: acne, hirsutism; Biochemical: raised testosterone, DHEAS levels) 
  3. Polycystic morphology on USG, one or both ovaries showing small follicles on the periphery of the ovary.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ovarian Cyst: Incorrect. A simple ovarian cyst would appear as a single, large, anechoic (dark) structure rather than multiple small follicles.

 

Option C. Endometriosis: Incorrect. Endometriosis typically appear as well-defined, homogeneous, hypoechoic cysts with internal echoes, often called "chocolate cysts." They don't show the characteristic string of pearls appearance.

 

 

Option D. Normal Ovary: Incorrect. A normal ovary would show fewer follicles (usually 8-10) and would not demonstrate the characteristic peripheral arrangement seen in PCOS.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • The "string of pearls" appearance on ultrasound, characterized by multiple peripheral follicles in the ovary, is a diagnostic imaging feature of PCOS
  • Rotterdam criteria is the criteria for diagnosing PCOS wherein at least 2 out of 3 of the following should be there:
    • Oligoovulation (Delayed periods)
    • Hyperandrogenism (clinical or biochemical)
    • Polycystic morphology of ovaries on ultrasound (string of pearls)

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents with irregular periods, acne, and excessive hair growth (hirsutism). What is the initial treatment of choice? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lifestyle measures

 

In PCOS management, lifestyle modifications are always the first-line approach before initiating any pharmacological treatment. patients should be counseled for lifestyle measures for at least 6 months before starting any medications. This includes focus on improving BMI through diet and exercise.

 

Other Options:

 

 Option A. Metformin: While metformin can be used in PCOS management, particularly for insulin resistance, it is not the first-line treatment. It is considered after lifestyle modifications have been attempted.

 

Option B. Combined OCPs: Though OCPs are effective in managing PCOS symptoms like irregular periods and hyperandrogenism, they are typically started only if lifestyle modifications fail to show improvement after 6 months.

 

Option C. Clomiphene citrate: This is used specifically for ovulation induction in PCOS patients seeking fertility. It is not the first-line treatment for general PCOS management.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lifestyle modifications (diet and exercise) are the first-line treatment for PCOS, to be tried for 6 months before considering pharmacological options.

questions.text: A gynecologist is examining the placenta and notices that the side she is holding has the umbilical cord and vessels. This side is the: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fetal side

 

The fetal side of the placenta is characterized by the presence of the umbilical cord insertion and visible branching blood vessels (chorionic vessels) radiating from it beneath the transparent amnion. This surface is smooth and shiny due to the amniotic membrane covering it. The umbilical cord contains fetal blood vessels that branch out across this surface, forming a network that facilitates nutrient and gas exchange between mother and fetus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Maternal side: Incorrect because the maternal side has a rough, cobblestone appearance with 15-20 cotyledons. It does not have the umbilical cord attachment.

 

Option C. Decidual surface: Incorrect because this is another name for the maternal side of the placenta. It has an irregular surface with visible cotyledons and does not contain the umbilical cord.

 

Option D. Basal surface: Incorrect because this is also another term for the maternal side of the placenta. Like the decidual surface, it refers to the rough side that was attached to the uterine wall.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The fetal side of the placenta can be identified by:

 

  • Presence of umbilical cord insertion
  • Visible branching blood vessels (chorionic vessels)
  • Smooth, shiny surface due to amniotic membrane covering

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with delayed periods and vaginal bleeding. An ultrasound reveals retained products of conception, and a suction evacuation is performed. The extracted tissue is sent for histopathology, which reports a karyotype of 46XX and is p57kip2 negative. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Complete mole

 

The diagnosis is complete mole based on two key findings:

 

  1. Diploid karyotype (46XX) - Complete moles typically have a diploid karyotype
  2. p57kip2 negative staining - p57kip2 is a paternally imprinted, maternally expressed gene. Its negative expression is diagnostic of complete mole as there is no maternal genetic material

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Partial mole - Incorrect because:

 

  • Partial moles have triploid karyotype (69XXX or 69XXY)
  • p57kip2 is positive in partial moles due to presence of maternal genetic material

 

Option C. Invasive mole - Incorrect because:

 

  • This is a complication of molar pregnancy where the mole invades the myometrium
  • Diagnosis requires imaging evidence of myometrial invasion
  • Karyotype alone cannot diagnose invasive mole

 

Option D. Choriocarcinoma - Incorrect because:

 

  • This is a malignant form of gestational trophoblastic disease
  • Diagnosis is based on histopathology showing malignant trophoblastic tissue
  • Cannot be diagnosed by karyotype and p57kip2 staining alone

 

Educational Objective: 

 

complete molar pregnancy is characterized by:

 

  1. Diploid karyotype (46XX)
  2. Negative p57kip2 staining
  3. Complete absence of maternal genetic material

questions.text: A few hours following forceps delivery, patient complained of pain in perineum. On examination, she had hypotension, tachycardia and the episiotomy site had a large bluish swelling. Which of the following should not be done? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Repair in ward

 

The clinical scenario describes a vulval hematoma, which is a serious postpartum complication. The patient presents with classical symptoms:

 

  • Pain in perineum
  • Hypotension and tachycardia indicating shock
  • Large bluish swelling at episiotomy site. This condition requires immediate intervention, but attempting repair in the ward would be dangerous and inappropriate. The patient requires proper surgical management in controlled conditions.
  • A repair in the ward is hence completely un-indicated in her. Drainage of the hematoma and obliteration of dead space has to be done in the OT with proper lighting and assistance and at the same time shock needs to be managed by resuscitation with fluids and blood

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Blood transfusion: Correct step. The patient is in shock with hypotension and tachycardia, indicating significant blood loss into the hematoma. Blood transfusion is essential for resuscitation.

 

Option C. Inform senior: Correct step. Given the severity of the condition and need for surgical intervention, senior consultation is necessary.

 

Option D. Shift to OT: Correct step. The patient requires evacuation of hematoma and obliteration of dead space under proper anesthesia, which can only be done in an operation theater.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

A vulval hematoma presenting after delivery requires immediate resuscitation and surgical evacuation in the operation theater, never repair in the ward, due to:

 

  • Need for proper anesthesia
  • Potential for significant blood loss
  • Presence of dead space requiring proper surgical obliteration
  • Risk of shock

questions.text: Where is use of this instrument contra-indicated? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Obstructed labor

 

  • This image shows an obstetric forceps. 
  • Forceps are contraindicated in obstructed labor because attempting instrumental delivery in this condition would be dangerous and fatal. In obstructed labor, the fetus cannot descend through the birth canal due to mechanical obstruction, making it a direct indication for cesarean section. Any attempt at instrumental delivery could cause serious maternal and fetal trauma.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Cesarean section: Incorrect. Forceps can be used during cesarean section, especially with a mobile free-floating head. For deeply engaged heads, one blade of the forceps can be used to dislodge the head.

 

Option B. After coming head of breech: Incorrect. Piper's forceps are specifically designed and commonly used for delivering the after-coming head in breech deliveries.

 

Option D. Occipito posterior: Incorrect. Forceps can be safely used in occipito posterior position. The baby will be delivered face-to-pubis, but both forceps and vacuum extraction are acceptable options.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Obstructed labor is an absolute contraindication for instrumental delivery (both forceps and vacuum) and is a direct indication for cesarean section.

questions.text: Which of the following cancers is not protective by use of combined oral contraceptives? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Breast cancer

 

Combined oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) provide protection against several types of cancers through their hormonal effects. This protective effect can be remembered using the mnemonic "CEO" - Colorectal, Endometrial, and Ovarian cancers. However, OCPs are associated with an increased risk of breast cancer and possibly cervical cancer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Endometrial cancer: Incorrect. OCPs are protective against endometrial cancer due to the progesterone component which counteracts unopposed estrogen effects on the endometrium.

 

Option C. Colorectal cancer: Incorrect. OCPs provide protection against colorectal cancer through their hormonal mechanisms.

 

Option D. Ovarian cancer: Incorrect. OCPs significantly reduce the risk of ovarian cancer by suppressing ovulation and reducing the repetitive damage to ovarian epithelium.

 

Educational Objective:

 

OCPs provide protection against three types of cancers (CEO - Colorectal, Endometrial, and Ovarian) but increase the risk of breast cancer and potentially cervical cancer.

questions.text: Which of the following is contra-indicated in pregnancy? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Enalapril

 

Enalapril, an ACE inhibitor, is absolutely contraindicated in pregnancy because it causes fetal renal hypoplasia or agenesis. This leads to early-onset oligohydramnios due to reduced fetal urine production. Both ACE inhibitors and ARBs (Angiotensin Receptor Blockers) are teratogenic drugs that should not be used during pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alpha-methyl dopa: Incorrect because it is a safe antihypertensive drug that is safe to use during pregnancy.

 

Option B. Nifedipine: Incorrect because it is a calcium channel blocker that can be safely used to treat hypertension during pregnancy.

 

Option C. Labetalol: Incorrect because it is a combined alpha and beta blocker that is considered safe and is commonly used to treat hypertension during pregnancy. It is the drug of choice in hypertension in pregnancy. 

 

Educational Objective: 

 

ACE inhibitors and ARBs are absolutely contraindicated during pregnancy as they cause fetal renal hypoplasia/agenesis leading to oligohydramnios.

questions.text: Shoulder dystocia is defined as delay in delivery of shoulders after delivery of head by? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 60 sec
