Shoulder dystocia is technically defined as a delay in delivery of shoulders for more than 60 seconds after delivery of the head. 

 

Once the head is delivered and external rotation/restitution occurs, if the anterior shoulder doesn't deliver with gentle traction, maneuvers to relieve shoulder dystocia should be initiated immediately.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 Shoulder dystocia has two definitions:

 

  1. Technical: Delay in shoulder delivery >60 seconds after head delivery
  2. Practical: Need for additional maneuvers beyond gentle traction to deliver shoulders after head delivery
  3. Turtle Sign: Seen in Shoulder dystocia

questions.text: Home based urine pregnancy tests detect which hormone? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Beta hCG

 

Home-based urine pregnancy tests detect human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG), specifically the beta subunit of hCG (β-hCG).

 

  • hCG is the earliest detectable hormone in pregnancy
  • hCG is secreted by the trophoblastic cells of the developing placenta soon after implantation, which occurs approximately 6-10 days post-fertilization.
  • The hormone helps maintain the corpus luteum, ensuring continued progesterone production to support early pregnancy.
  • Urine pregnancy tests typically detect hCG levels at or above 20-25 mIU/mL, allowing for early pregnancy confirmation.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. FSH (Follicle Stimulating Hormone): This is a pituitary hormone involved in follicular development and not specific to pregnancy. It is not used for pregnancy detection as its levels fluctuate throughout the menstrual cycle.

 

Option C. Estrogen: While estrogen levels do increase during pregnancy, it is not specific enough for pregnancy detection as it is also present during normal menstrual cycles.

 

Option D. Progesterone: Although progesterone levels rise during pregnancy, it is not used in home pregnancy tests as it is also present during the luteal phase of menstrual cycles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Home pregnancy tests specifically detect the beta subunit of hCG in urine for pregnancy diagnosis.

questions.text: Identify the procedure shown in the image: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Intra uterine balloon tamponade

 

The image shows an intrauterine balloon tamponade procedure, which is a mechanical method used to treat atonic postpartum hemorrhage. The illustration depicts a uterus with a balloon inserted into it, which is being filled with saline. This procedure creates pressure within the uterine cavity to compress bleeding vessels and control hemorrhage. The Bakri balloon is specifically designed for this purpose, though alternatives like condom catheters or Foley's catheters can also be used in resource-limited settings.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Endometrial ablation: This procedure uses a much smaller balloon and includes a thermal system to destroy the endometrial lining. 

 

Option C. Cervical ripening: This involves placing prostaglandin E2 gel (Dinoprostone) in the endocervical canal, not within the uterine cavity.

 

Option D. Parachute pack: A parachute pack, also known as a Logothetopoulos pack, is a transvaginal packing technique used to control bleeding after a hysterectomy or other obstetric procedures. It's used to compress bleeding areas against the pelvic bone and fascia. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Appearance and understand the use of intrauterine balloon tamponade as a mechanical method for managing postpartum hemorrhage.

questions.text: A 25-year-old primigravida is in labor, and her cardiotocogram (CTG) is shown. What does this CTG indicate? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Early decelerations

 

Early decelerations are characterized by:

 

  • When decelerations are in symmetry with the uterine contractions, the nadir corresponds to the peak of the contraction.
  • Early deceleration is seen when the head of the fetus is compressed in the second stage of the labor.
  • Early decelerations, specially in the second stage of the labor are normal

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Variable decelerations: Incorrect

 

  • Variable decelerations are seen typically when the cord is getting compressed. There is no relation between the deceleration and the uterine contraction. 
    • Seen in Oligohydramnios. 

 

 

Option C. Late decelerations: Incorrect

 

  • The start, nadir and end of the deceleration occurs after the start, peak and end of the contraction
    • These are dangerous as this means that there is fetal distress 

 

 

Option D. Normal CTG: Incorrect

 

  • because while early decelerations are reassuring, they represent a variation from the normal baseline pattern
  • Normal CTG shows no consistent decelerations with contractions

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Early decelerations are characterized by symmetrical drops in fetal heart rate with the nadir coinciding with the peak of uterine contractions, caused by head compression during labor, and are considered physiological

questions.text: Which of the following is an abnormal cardiovascular system examination finding during pregnancy? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Diastolic murmur

 

During pregnancy, several cardiovascular changes occur as normal physiological adaptations. However, a diastolic murmur is never considered normal and always requires further evaluation. Any diastolic murmur detected during pregnancy needs thorough investigation as it may indicate underlying cardiac pathology.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Soft systolic murmur: Incorrect because systolic murmurs are commonly heard during pregnancy due to increased blood volume and cardiac output. They are considered a normal physiological finding.

 

Option C. S3 (Third heart sound): Incorrect because S3 can be heard as a normal finding during pregnancy due to increased blood volume and ventricular filling.

 

Option D. Loud S1 (First heart sound): Incorrect because a loud S1 is a normal cardiovascular finding during pregnancy due to changes in cardiac position and increased blood flow.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

While systolic murmurs, S3, and loud S1 are normal cardiovascular examination findings in pregnancy, any diastolic murmur is always pathological and requires evaluation.

choices.text: Thin endometrium with no adnexal mass
Empty uterus with adnexal mass and fluid in pelvis

questions.text: A 25-year-old G2 presents with delayed menstrual cycles, mild abdominal pain, and vaginal bleeding. A urine pregnancy test is positive. What are the ultrasound features suggestive of an ectopic pregnancy? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Empty uterus with adnexal mass and fluid in pelvis

 

In ectopic pregnancy, transvaginal ultrasound is the first-line investigation. The most characteristic finding is an empty uterine cavity with a mass in the adnexa  and fluid collection in the pelvis. The fluid represents blood from either tubal abortion or rupture, which typically collects in the pouch of Douglas behind the uterus. These findings together strongly suggest an ectopic pregnancy.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Thin endometrium with no adnexal mass: Incorrect because in ectopic pregnancy, the presence of an adnexal mass is a key diagnostic feature. Without an adnexal mass, the diagnosis is incomplete.

 

Option C. Intra uterine gestational sac: Incorrect as this finding indicates a normal intrauterine pregnancy, not an ectopic pregnancy.

 

Option D. Thick endometrium: Incorrect because this finding alone is nonspecific and can be seen in various conditions. It does not help diagnose ectopic pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The classic ultrasound findings in ectopic pregnancy are:

 

1. Empty uterine cavity

 

2. Adnexal mass (Bagel sign/ Blob sign)

 

3. Gestational sac with yolk sav/ fetal pole in the adnexa

 

4. Ring of fire on Doppler

 

 

5. Free fluid in the pelvis (representing blood from abortion or rupture)

questions.text: A patient with a history of a difficult prolonged labor where she says the baby was stuck for a long time; followed by cesarean section presents watery vaginal discharge on the 7th post operative day. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vesico-vaginal fistula

 

In cases of prolonged obstructed labor where the fetal head remains impacted in the pelvis for an extended period before cesarean section, there is a high risk of bladder necrosis. The prolonged pressure from the fetal head against the anterior vaginal wall and bladder can cause tissue ischemia. After cesarean delivery, this damaged tissue may break down, creating a fistulous connection between the bladder and vagina (vesico-vaginal fistula), resulting in continuous urinary leakage through the vagina. This typically presents as persistent watery vaginal discharge in the postoperative period.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Hydrorrhoea gravidarum: Incorrect as this condition refers to excessive watery discharge during pregnancy due to excessive secretion from endocervical glands, not relevant in a post-cesarean scenario.

 

Option C. Urinary retention: Incorrect because urinary retention would present with inability to pass urine and bladder distension, not watery vaginal discharge.

 

Option D. Rectovaginal fistula: Incorrect as this would present with passage of fecal matter through vagina, not watery discharge. While it can occur after difficult labor, it's less common than vesico-vaginal fistula.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Vesico-vaginal fistula is a known complication of prolonged obstructed labor
  • This presents as continuous watery discharge from the vagina between the 7th-10th day post delivery.
  • Prevention involves prolonged catheterization (2-3 weeks) in cases of obstructed labor to allow continuous bladder drainage and proper bladder healing.

questions.text: In management of cervical cancer, which therapy is given along with radiotherapy? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Platinum based chemotherapy

 

In cervical cancer management, cisplatin-based chemotherapy (platinum-based) is given along with radiotherapy. Cisplatin acts as a radiosensitizer, which means it increases the sensitivity of the tissue to radiotherapy, making the treatment more effective. The combination of cisplatin followed by radiotherapy is a standard treatment protocol in cervical cancer management.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Immunotherapy: While immunotherapy has shown promise in some cancers, it is not the standard first-line treatment given along with radiotherapy in cervical cancer management.

 

Option C. Hormone therapy: Cervical cancer is not hormone-dependent, unlike some breast and endometrial cancers. Therefore, hormone therapy is not effective in its treatment.

 

Option D. Targeted therapy: Though targeted therapies are being studied, they are not the standard treatment given along with radiotherapy in cervical cancer management.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Remember that platinum-based chemotherapy (cisplatin) is used as a radiosensitizer along with radiotherapy in the management of cervical cancer.

questions.text: In which type of hysterectomy, is the risk of ureteric injury the least? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Vaginal

 

The risk of ureteric injury is least in vaginal hysterectomy compared to other approaches. This is due to the anatomical relationship between the ureter and uterine vessels. The ureter passes underneath the uterine artery (bridge over water concept) approximately 1.5-2 cm lateral to the uterus at the level of the isthmus. When performing a vaginal hysterectomy, the operating field and surgical dissection remains close to the uterus, reducing the risk of encountering and injuring the ureter.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Laparotomy: Incorrect because in abdominal approach (laparotomy), there is a higher risk of ureteric injury due to wider dissection and direct visualization of the area where ureter crosses under the uterine vessels.

 

Option B. Laparoscopy: Incorrect as laparoscopic approach, despite better visualization, still carries a higher risk of ureteric injury compared to vaginal approach due to the extensive lateral dissection required.

 

Option C. Robotic: Incorrect because robotic approach, similar to laparoscopy, involves lateral pelvic dissection which increases risk of ureteric injury.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Risk of ureteric injury in increasing order is:

 

  • Vaginal hysterectomy (least risk)
  • Abdominal hysterectomy 
  • Laparoscopic hysterectomy
  • Radical hysterectomy (highest)

questions.text: Following vasectomy, the man is advised to use additional contraception till when? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 3 months

 

Following a vasectomy procedure, men must use additional contraception for 3 months. After this period, they are called back for a semen analysis. Only after documenting azoospermia (complete absence of sperm in the semen) should they be given a certificate confirming sterility. This waiting period is necessary to ensure all remaining sperm have been cleared from the reproductive tract.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Following vasectomy, additional contraception must be used for 3 months until azoospermia is confirmed by semen analysis.

questions.text: Which hormone is responsible for this? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Oxytocin

 

The image shows a baby suckling at the breast, which triggers the milk ejection reflex (let-down reflex). When the baby suckles, sensory impulses from the nipple travel to the hypothalamus, stimulating the release of oxytocin from the posterior pituitary. Oxytocin causes contraction of myoepithelial cells around the alveoli and ducts, leading to milk ejection. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. TSH (Thyroid Stimulating Hormone): While thyroid hormones play a supportive role in lactation, TSH is not directly responsible for milk ejection. It's primarily involved in regulating thyroid function.

 

Option C. Growth Hormone: Although growth hormone has a role in mammary gland development and milk production, it's not responsible for the milk ejection reflex.

 

Option D. FSH (Follicle Stimulating Hormone): FSH is primarily involved in follicular development in the ovaries. It has no direct role in lactation or milk ejection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Oxytocin is the key hormone responsible for the milk ejection reflex during breastfeeding, triggered by infant suckling.

choices.text: Raised PSV on umbilical artery Doppler
Reduced PSV on umbilical artery Doppler

questions.text: A medical intern is observing an ultrasound for a patient with Rh isoimmunization. Which parameter is used to determine fetal anemia? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Raised PSV on MCA Doppler

 

Middle Cerebral Artery (MCA) Peak Systolic Velocity (PSV) is the gold standard non-invasive test for detecting fetal anemia. In fetal anemia, there is increased cardiac output and reduced blood viscosity, leading to faster blood flow. This results in increased PSV in the middle cerebral artery. A PSV value >1.5 MoM (Multiples of Median) for gestational age suggests significant fetal anemia and may indicate the need for further evaluation or intervention.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Reduced PSV on MCA Doppler: Incorrect because fetal anemia causes increased, not decreased, blood flow velocity in the MCA due to compensatory mechanisms.

 

Option C. Raised PSV on umbilical artery Doppler: While umbilical artery Doppler is useful for assessing placental function and fetal well-being, it is not the primary tool for diagnosing fetal anemia. Changes in umbilical artery flow are more indicative of placental resistance.

 

Option D. Reduced PSV on umbilical artery Doppler: This finding is more associated with placental insufficiency and does not specifically indicate fetal anemia.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Increased Peak Systolic Velocity (PSV) in the Middle Cerebral Artery (MCA) Doppler is the key non-invasive indicator of fetal anemia.

questions.text: Identify the stage of the embryo: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Blastocyst

 

The image shows a blastocyst stage of embryonic development. Key identifying features visible in the image include:

 

  • A fluid-filled cavity (blastocoele)
  • Inner cell mass (embryoblast) – forms the  future embryo
  • Outer layer of trophoblast cells lining the cavity – forms the future placenta

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Morula:

 

  • Incorrect because a morula is an earlier solid ball of cells without any cavity formation
  • Does not show differentiation into inner cell mass and trophoblast layers

 

Option C. Oocyte

 

  • Incorrect because an oocyte is a single unfertilized egg cell
  • Does not have multiple cells or organized structure seen in the image

 

Option D. Zygote

 

  • Incorrect because a zygote is the single cell formed immediately after fertilization
  • Does not show the complex multicellular organization visible in the image

 

Educational Objective: 

 

To identify the characteristic features of a blastocyst:

 

  • Fluid-filled cavity (blastocoel)
  • Inner cell mass (embryoblast)
  • Outer trophoblast layer
  • This stage occurs around day 5-6 post-fertilization and is ready for implantation

questions.text: A mother with gestational diabetes gave birth. The newborn has jitteriness, poor feeding and crying episodes. Which is likely to be seen in the fetus? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hypoglycemia

 

In infants born to mothers with gestational diabetes, hypoglycemia is a common complication. During pregnancy, the high maternal glucose levels cause increased insulin production in the fetus. After birth, when the constant glucose supply from the mother stops but the infant's insulin levels remain high, hypoglycemia develops. The classic clinical manifestations include:

 

  • Jitteriness
  • Poor feeding
  • Excessive crying
  • Lethargy
  • Seizures in severe cases

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Neonatal Sepsis:

 

  • While neonatal sepsis can cause similar symptoms, it is not directly related to maternal gestational diabetes
  • Would typically present with additional signs like temperature instability and respiratory distress

 

Option C. Hypothyroidism:

 

  • Hypothyroidism in newborns presents with different symptoms like prolonged jaundice and constipation
  • Not a direct complication of gestational diabetes

 

Option D. VSD (Ventricular Septal Defect):

 

  • While diabetic mothers have increased risk of fetal cardiac anomalies, VSD would not cause the acute symptoms described
  • VSD typically presents with failure to thrive and respiratory symptoms

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Infants of diabetic mothers are at risk of developing hypoglycemia in the immediate postnatal period due to persistent hyperinsulinemia after birth, manifesting as jitteriness, poor feeding, and crying episodes.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents with persistent nasal congestion, foul-smelling greenish-black nasal crusts, and anosmia. Examination reveals a dry nasal cavity with crust formation. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Atrophic rhinitis

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical presentation strongly suggests atrophic rhinitis. 

 

  • The presence of foul-smelling greenish-black discharge (due to Klebsiella ozaenae infection)
  • Anosmia (due to atrophy of nerve elements)
  • Crusting in nasal cavity (due to transformation of normal ciliated columnar epithelium to abnormal stratified squamous epithelium)
  • Female patient (consistent with demographics as atrophic rhinitis commonly affects females)
  • The disease process involves atrophy of nasal mucosa, leading to loss of defense mechanisms (cilia and mucous glands), resulting in secondary infections and crust formation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rhinoscleroma

 

  • While the first stage can mimic atrophic rhinitis, it typically doesn't present with anosmia
  • Characterized by painless nodules giving woody feel ("woody nose" or "hebra nose")
  • Caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis

 

 

Option C. Hypertrophic rhinitis

 

  • Presents with bilateral inferior turbinate hypertrophy
  • Shows mulberry appearance of turbinates
  • No crusting or anosmia

 

Option D. Allergic rhinitis

 

  • Presents with sneezing, itching, and watery discharge
  • IgE-mediated type 1 hypersensitivity reaction
  • No foul smell or crusting
  • Typically shows pale, boggy mucosa

 

Educational Objective:

 

Atrophic Rhinitis (Ozaenae)

questions.text: Following sign is seen in (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma

 

Explanation: 


The image shows the Holman-Miller sign (or antral sign), which is pathognomonic of juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA). This sign is characterized by:

 

  • Forward bowing/anterior displacement of the posterior wall of maxillary sinus
  • Occurs due to tumor extension from sphenopalatine foramen into pterygopalatine fossa
  • The tumor exerts pressure from behind, pushing the posterior maxillary wall forward
  • This finding is visible on CT scan and is a key diagnostic feature of JNA

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Nasopharyngeal carcinoma

 

  • Shows Trotter's triad (palatal palsy, ipsilateral neuralgia, conductive hearing loss)
  • No characteristic anterior bowing of posterior maxillary wall
  • Most commonly arises from fossa of Rosenmuller

 

Option C. Tear drop sign

 

  • Also called hanging drop sign
  • Seen in orbital floor fractures (blow-out fractures)
  • Not related to maxillary wall displacement

 

 

Option D. Rhinosporidiosis

 

  • Shows strawberry-like lesions in nasal cavity
  • Presents with epistaxis
  • No characteristic changes in maxillary sinus wall

 

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma

questions.text: What is the sign shown below: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Double target sign

 

Explanation:

 

The image shows the double target sign (also called target sign, halo sign, or double ring sign) which is seen in CSF rhinorrhoea. It is characterized by:

 

  • A central red spot (blood)
  • Surrounded by a peripheral halo (CSF)
  • This pattern appears when CSF mixed with blood drips onto filter paper or cloth
  • Commonly seen in traumatic CSF rhinorrhoea where blood is mixed with cerebrospinal fluid

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tear drop sign

 

  • Also called hanging drop sign
  • Radiological finding seen in blow-out fractures of orbit
  • Not related to CSF rhinorrhea

 

 

Option C. Beta 2 transferrin sign

 

  • This is not a visual sign but a laboratory test
  • Used to confirm the presence of CSF in nasal discharge
  • Tests for beta 2 transferrin which is specific to CSF

 

Option D. Handkerchief sign

 

  • Test where nasal discharge is placed on handkerchief
  • CSF doesn't stiffen the handkerchief while mucus does
  • Used to differentiate CSF from nasal mucus

 

Educational Objective:

 

CSF Rhinorrhea

questions.text: Type of tympanoplasty shown in image Below: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Type 4

 

Explanation:

 

The image shows Type 4 tympanoplasty (Wullstein classification) where:

 

  • The graft is placed directly on the stapes footplate
  • All ossicles (malleus, incus, and stapes suprastructure) are absent
  • Only the footplate remains
  • Also called cavum minor tympanoplasty

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Type 1

 

  • Simple myringoplasty with intact ossicular chain
  • Graft placed on handle of malleus
  • All ossicles are present and functional

 

Option B. Type 2

 

  • Graft placed on incus or remnant of malleus
  • Partial ossicular defect
  • Malleus absent but incus present

 

Option C. Type 3

 

  • Also called columella tympanoplasty
  • Graft placed on stapes head
  • Malleus and incus absent but stapes suprastructure present

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize Type 4 tympanoplasty as the procedure where the tympanic membrane graft is placed directly on the stapes footplate when all ossicles are absent except the footplate.

 

Tympanoplasty –

questions.text: A 49-year-old woman from Nagaland presents with right-sided hearing loss and tinnitus. On examination, there is a dull tympanic membrane, and lymph nodes in the posterior triangle of the neck are palpable. She is from a region endemic for nasopharyngeal carcinoma. What is the most appropriate management for this condition?  (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Radiotherapy (RT)

 

Explanation: 


Radiotherapy is the most appropriate management because:

 

  • The presentation suggests nasopharyngeal carcinoma with: 
    • Unilateral hearing loss due to serous otitis media (dull tympanic membrane)
    • Painless cervical lymphadenopathy
    • Patient from endemic region (Nagaland)
  • Nasopharyngeal carcinomas are highly radiosensitive tumors
  • This is the first-line treatment for nasopharyngeal carcinoma
  • Radiotherapy provides better outcomes compared to surgery due to: 
    • Difficult surgical access to nasopharynx
    • High risk of complications with surgery
    • Rich lymphatic drainage of the area

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Radical neck dissection

 

  • Only addresses lymph node metastases
  • Doesn't treat the primary tumor
  • Not first-line treatment without prior radiotherapy

 

Option B. Grommet insertion with steroids

 

  • Only treats the secondary middle ear effusion
  • Doesn't address the underlying malignancy
  • Can be considered as supportive treatment for hearing loss

 

Option D. Wait and watch

 

  • Inappropriate for suspected malignancy
  • Delays definitive treatment
  • Can lead to disease progression

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Radiotherapy is the primary treatment modality for nasopharyngeal carcinoma due to the tumor's high radiosensitivity and anatomical considerations.

 

Nasopharyngeal Carcinoma

questions.text: A pure tone audiometry (PTA) result shows an air-bone gap with normal bone conduction thresholds. What is the most likely type of hearing loss? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Conductive hearing loss (CHL)

 

Explanation: 


The PTA findings indicate conductive hearing loss because:

 

  • Bone conduction is normal (within 25 dB threshold).
  • Air conduction is affected (elevated threshold).
  • There is a gap between air and bone conduction curves.
  • This pattern indicates that sound transmission through the external/middle ear is impaired while inner ear function is normal.
  • The presence of air-bone gap with normal bone conduction is pathognomonic of conductive hearing loss.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL)

 

  • Both air and bone conduction would be affected
  • No significant air-bone gap
  • Curves would be close to each other in affected range

 

Option C. Mixed hearing loss

 

  • Both air and bone conduction would be affected
  • Air-bone gap present but bone conduction also abnormal
  • Both curves would be in affected range with a gap between them

 

Option D. Normal hearing

 

  • Both air and bone conduction would be within normal range (≤25 dB)
  • No air-bone gap
  • Both curves would be close together in normal range

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Air-bone gap with normal bone conduction thresholds on pure tone audiometry is diagnostic of conductive hearing loss.

choices.text: Conductive hearing loss in the left ear
Sensorineural hearing loss in the right ear
Conductive hearing loss in the right ear
Sensorineural hearing loss in the left ear

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents with hearing difficulty. On examination, the Rinne test is positive in the right ear and negative in the left ear. Weber's test shows lateralization to the right. Bone conduction is reduced in the left ear and normal in the right ear. What is the most likely interpretation of these findings? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Sensorineural hearing loss in the left ear

 

Explanation: 


The findings indicate severe unilateral sensorineural hearing loss in the left ear because:

 

  • Left ear shows Rinne negative test (false negative)
  • Weber lateralizes to right (better hearing) ear
  • Reduced bone conduction in left ear confirms inner ear pathology
  • This pattern occurs in severe unilateral SNHL where: 
    • Sound during bone conduction testing crosses to the normal ear (cross hearing)
    • Creates false impression of bone conduction better than air conduction
    • True pathology revealed by Weber test lateralizing away from affected ear
    • Reduced bone conduction confirms SNHL

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Conductive hearing loss in the left ear

 

  • Would show true Rinne negative
  • Weber would lateralize to affected (left) ear
  • Bone conduction would be normal

 

Option B. Sensorineural hearing loss in the right ear

 

  • Rinne would be positive in right ear (correct)
  • Weber would lateralize to left (unaffected) ear
  • Bone conduction would be reduced in right ear

 

Option C. Conductive hearing loss in the right ear

 

  • Rinne would be negative in right ear
  • Weber would lateralize to right ear
  • Bone conduction would be normal

 

Educational Objective:

 

A negative Rinne test with reduced bone conduction and Weber’s test lateralizing to the opposite ear suggests sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL) in the affected ear.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child with a past history of intubation presents to the OPD with shortness of breath that began during play, approximately 2 months after the intubation. A radiograph of the chest is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Croup

 

Explanation: 


The presentation suggests croup (acute laryngotracheobronchitis) because:

 

  • X-ray shows characteristic "steeple sign" (subglottic narrowing)
  • Age group is typical (6 months to 3 years)
  • History of recent intubation could predispose to viral infection

  • Clinical features match with croup: 

    • Gradual onset of respiratory distress
    • Inspiratory stridor
    • Usually caused by parainfluenza virus types I & II
    • Submucosal edema causes narrowing in subglottic region

     

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Acute epiglottitis

 

  • Shows "thumb sign" on lateral neck X-ray
  • More severe, rapid onset
  • Typically caused by H. influenzae
  • Child prefers sitting position (tripod sign)

 

 

Option C. Laryngomalacia

 

  • Most common congenital anomaly of larynx
  • Shows omega-shaped epiglottis on laryngoscopy
  • Symptoms improve in prone position
  • Present from birth

 

 

Option D. Bronchitis

 

  • Lower airway inflammation
  • No characteristic "steeple sign"
  • Different radiological findings
  • Usually presents with cough as primary symptom

 

Educational Objective: 

 

"steeple sign" on chest/neck X-ray as characteristic of croup, representing subglottic narrowing.

questions.text: A patient with a history of chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM) presents to the OPD with seizures, headache, vomiting, and photophobia. On further evaluation, homonymous hemianopia and episodes of epilepsy were observed. A CT scan of the brain was performed What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Temporal abscess

 

Explanation: 


The presentation indicates temporal lobe abscess because:

 

  • Clear space-occupying lesion in temporal lobe visible on CT
  • Classic symptoms of temporal lobe involvement: 
    • Seizures indicating brain parenchymal involvement
    • Homonymous hemianopia due to temporal lobe compression
    • Increased intracranial pressure symptoms (headache, vomiting, photophobia)
  • Common complication of CSOM due to: 
    • Direct extension through tegmen tympani

    • Temporal lobe is most common site for brain abscess in CSOM

       

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Meningitis

 

  • Most common intracranial complication of CSOM
  • No discrete abscess formation on imaging
  • Shows meningeal enhancement
  • Different clinical features (neck rigidity, Kernig's sign)

 

Option C. Subdural abscess

 

  • Collection between dura and arachnoid
  • Different imaging appearance
  • No discrete parenchymal involvement
  • Different clinical presentation

 

Option D. Extradural abscess

 

  • Collection outside dura but intracranial
  • Different imaging appearance
  • Less severe neurological symptoms
  • No parenchymal involvement

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Temporal lobe abscess is a serious complication of CSOM, presenting with seizures and characteristic CT findings of a space-occupying lesion in the temporal lobe.

questions.text: Identify the image shown below? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Maxillary sinusitis

 

Explanation: 

 

The CT image shows maxillary sinusitis because:

 

  • Clear hypodense thickening in the maxillary sinus
  • Involvement of maxillary sinus with mucosal thickening/opacification
  • Anatomical landmarks visible: 
    • Orbit above
    • Maxillary sinus below
    • Ethmoid cells medially
    • Cribriform plate superiorly
  • Disease appears to be spreading into nasal cavity, suggesting possible antrochoanal polyp

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Frontal sinusitis

 

  • Frontal sinuses not clearly visible in this cut
  • Would be located superior to orbits
  • Different radiological appearance

 

Option C. Ethmoidal sinusitis

 

  • Though ethmoid cells are visible medially
  • No significant pathology in ethmoid region
  • Would show opacification of ethmoid air cells

 

Option D. Sphenoidal sinusitis

 

  • Sphenoid sinus not visible in this cut
  • Would be seen at nasopharyngeal level
  • Located most posteriorly among all sinuses

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Most common in adults because ostium locates higher than floor level and drainage is against the gravity.
  • Pain over upper jaw present.

questions.text: Identify the marked structure: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Buccopharyngeal fascia

 

Explanation:


 The marked structure is buccopharyngeal fascia based on its anatomical position:

 

  • Located behind the muscular layer of pharynx
  • Forms outer covering of pharyngeal muscles
  • Lies anterior to retropharyngeal space
  • Follows the arrangement of pharyngeal wall layers from inside out: 
    1. Pharyngobasilar fascia (innermost)
    2. Muscular layer (longitudinal and circular)
    3. Buccopharyngeal fascia
    4. Retropharyngeal space
    5. Alar fascia
    6. Alar space
    7. Prevertebral fascia
    8. Prevertebral space
    9. Vertebra

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Pharyngobasilar fascia

 

  • Forms innermost layer lining pharyngeal cavity
  • Located beneath mucosa
  • Forms tonsillar capsule posteriorly

 

Option C. Alar fascia

 

  • Located posterior to retropharyngeal space
  • Forms anterior boundary of danger space
  • Extends to T4 vertebral level

 

Option D. Prevertebral fascia

 

  • Located most posteriorly before vertebral column
  • Forms posterior boundary of danger space
  • Extends to coccyx

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with respiratory distress after a history of eating peanuts. Clinical examination reveals an audible thud during breathing. What is the most likely location of the foreign body? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Trachea

 

Explanation: 

 

The foreign body is most likely in the trachea because:

 

  • Presence of audible thud during breathing is pathognomonic of tracheal foreign body
  • Foreign body in trachea moves up and down with respiration causing the thud sound
  • Peanuts are common aspirated foreign bodies in children
  • Acute presentation with respiratory distress after eating suggests aspiration
  • History of eating peanuts followed by immediate symptoms suggests aspiration pathway rather than ingestion

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Larynx

 

  • Would cause immediate severe respiratory distress
  • Stridor would be prominent
  • Voice changes would be present
  • Less likely to cause thud sound

 

Option B. Bronchus

 

  • More common final location but doesn't cause thud sound
  • Usually right main bronchus due to anatomical orientation
  • Would cause unilateral wheeze or decreased breath sounds
  • No up and down movement to cause thud

 

Option D. Oesophagus

 

  • Would cause dysphagia rather than respiratory distress
  • No audible thud during breathing
  • Drooling and inability to swallow would be prominent
  • Different management approach required

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Foreign bodies in the trachea cause biphasic stridor and audible thuds due to partial airway obstruction. Immediate intervention with bronchoscopy is required to prevent asphyxiation.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presents with respiratory distress, coughing, and an inability to speak after eating. What is the next best step in management? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bronchoscopy

 

Explanation:

 

 Bronchoscopy is the best next step because:

 

  • Child has already presented to the hospital with respiratory distress
  • Rigid bronchoscopy is both diagnostic and therapeutic
  • Allows direct visualization of the foreign body
  • Enables safe removal under controlled conditions
  • Most appropriate for hospital setting where proper equipment and expertise are available
  • Prevents complications from blind maneuvers

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Heimlich maneuver

 

  • More appropriate for immediate first aid in community setting
  • Better suited for adults than children
  • Risk of complications in young children
  • Not the best choice once patient is in hospital

 

Option C. Blind finger sweep

 

  • Contraindicated in children
  • Risk of pushing foreign body further down
  • Can cause trauma to oropharynx
  • May worsen the situation

 

Option D. Endotracheal intubation

 

  • Risk of pushing foreign body further down
  • Doesn't address removal of foreign body
  • May complicate the situation
  • Not appropriate without first visualizing foreign body

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Recognize that rigid bronchoscopy is the definitive management for foreign body aspiration in a hospital setting as it allows both diagnosis and therapeutic removal.

questions.text: Identify the following sign: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tear drop sign

 

Explanation: 


The image shows the tear drop sign (also called hanging drop sign) because:

 

  • Shows herniation of orbital contents into maxillary sinus
  • Appears as a tear-shaped shadow on imaging
  • Characteristic finding in orbital floor fractures (blow-out fractures)
  • Occurs due to disruption of orbital floor allowing downward displacement of orbital contents
  • Important radiological sign in trauma cases

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Steeple sign

 

  • Seen in croup
  • Shows subglottic narrowing on AP view
  • Appears as narrowing of upper airway
  • Different radiological appearance

 

 

Option C. Thumb sign

 

  • Seen in acute epiglottitis
  • Shows swollen epiglottis on lateral neck X-ray
  • Appears as thumb-like shadow
  • Different anatomical location

 

 

Option D. Sail sign

 

  • Not a commonly used radiological sign in ENT
  • Different appearance and location
  • Not related to orbital or sinus pathology

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Recognize the tear drop sign (hanging drop sign) as characteristic radiological finding in orbital floor fractures showing herniation of orbital contents into maxillary sinus

questions.text: A 35-year-old male undergoing hernia surgery was administered succinylcholine. After administration of anesthesia, he developed muscle rigidity, elevated temperature, and increased etCO2 levels. What is the appropriate treatment for this condition? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Dantrolene sodium

 

The clinical presentation described is characteristic of malignant hyperthermia, a genetic condition affecting the ryanodine receptor gene in muscles. It is triggered by exposure to succinylcholine or inhalational anesthetics. The pathophysiology involves:

 

  • Continuous muscle contraction due to calcium retention in muscle cells
  • Hypermetabolism leading to elevated temperature
  • Increased CO2 production causing elevated etCO2 levels

 

Dantrolene sodium is the specific antidote for malignant hyperthermia as it blocks calcium release from sarcoplasmic reticulum.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Diazepam: Incorrect as it is just a sedative and does not address the underlying pathophysiology of malignant hyperthermia

 

Option B. Midazolam: Incorrect as it is also just a sedative like diazepam and has no role in treating malignant hyperthermia

 

Option D. Adrenaline: Incorrect as it is primarily used in CPR and severe hypotension. It does not treat the underlying mechanism of malignant hyperthermia

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dantrolene sodium is the specific treatment for malignant hyperthermia, a condition triggered by succinylcholine and inhalational anesthetics characterized by muscle rigidity, hyperthermia, and increased etCO2.

questions.text: According to the latest AHA guidelines, what is the sixth link added to the "Chain of Survival" in CPR? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Recovery

 

The Chain of Survival is a series of critical steps that improve survival in cardiac arrest cases. The American Heart Association (AHA) recently updated the chain by adding a sixth link: Recovery.

 

Updated Chain of Survival: (Out of hospital cardiac arrest)

 

  1. Early recognition and activation of emergency response system
  2. Early CPR with high-quality chest compressions
  3. Rapid defibrillation
  4. Advanced resuscitation by emergency medical services (EMS)
  5. Post-cardiac arrest care in a hospital setting
  6. Recovery phase for physical and emotional rehabilitation

 

 

The Recovery phase focuses on post-resuscitation care, including physical rehabilitation, psychological support, and long-term follow-up to improve the patient’s quality of life.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Early CPR: CPR is already part of the existing chain but is not the newly added sixth link.

 

Option B. Post-cardiac arrest care: This is an essential part of the chain but was already included before the update.

 

Option C. Post MI care: Management after a myocardial infarction (MI) is important but not specific to cardiac arrest care.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The American Heart Association (AHA) has updated the Chain of Survival to include a sixth link: Recovery. This emphasizes the importance of post-cardiac arrest rehabilitation, psychological support, and long-term follow-up.

questions.text: A patient is scheduled for surgery. Which of the following medications should be adjusted or stopped before the procedure? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Stop Enalapril

 

Enalapril, an ACE inhibitor, should be stopped on the day of surgery because:

 

  • ACE inhibitors can cause refractory hypotension during surgery
  • This hypotension is resistant to fluid therapy and vasopressors
  • It occurs when the medication is taken within hours before surgery
  • The recommendation is to omit ACE inhibitors and ARBs on the morning of surgery


Other Options:

 

Options A & D. Aspirin: If taken in a prophylactic dose of 75 mg, it can be continued on the day of surgery. However, if taken in higher doses (150-300 mg), it increases the risk of surgical bleeding and should be stopped 3 days before surgery.

 

Option C. Metoprolol: Beta-blockers are safe to continue as they help maintain stable hemodynamics during surgery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Before surgery, ACE inhibitors like Enalapril should be stopped due to the risk of refractory hypotension, while beta-blockers can be continued, and aspirin should be managed based on its dosage.

 

Hypertensive patients on Antihypertensives 

 

  1. ACE Inhibitors - Omitted on day of surgery. 
  2. Angiotensin receptor blockers - Omitted on day of surgery. 
  3. Diuretics - Continued on the day of surgery. 
  4. Beta Blockers - Continue on the day of surgery. 
  5. Calcium channel blockers - Continue on the day of surgery. 
  6. Centrally acting alpha-2 agonists - Continue on the day of surgery. 

 

ANTICOAGULANTS 

 

  • Aspirin continued on day of surgery 
  • Clopidogrel - stopped 7 days prior to surgery 
  • Warfarin- stopped 5 days prior to surgery 
  • Heparin - stopped 4 hours prior to surgery 
  • LMWH-stopped 12 hours prior to surgery 
  • Ticlopidine - stopped 14 days prior to surgery 
  • BRIDGING DRUG - heparin.

questions.text: A child was intubated, and during auscultation, breath sounds were heard on the right side, but absent on the left side. What could be the most likely cause? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Endobronchial intubation

 

Endobronchial intubation occurs when the endotracheal tube is advanced too far and enters one of the main bronchi. In this case:

 

  • The ETT has likely entered the right main bronchus as the right bronchus is anatomically straighter, shorter, and more in line with the trachea
  • This results in ventilation of only one lung while the other lung collapses
  • Clinical signs include unilateral breath sounds
  • Can be confirmed by chest X-ray showing a hyperinflated ventilated lung and a collapsed contralateral lung

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tracheal intubation: Incorrect because normal tracheal intubation would result in bilateral breath sounds

 

Option C. Esophageal intubation: Incorrect because in esophageal intubation, there would be no breath sounds on either side and would have additional signs like gastric insufflation

 

Option D. Pneumothorax: Incorrect because pneumothorax would show absent breath sounds on the affected side with air in the pleural cavity alongwith severe hemodynamic changes, not due to selective bronchial intubation

 

Educational Objective:

 

Endobronchial intubation occurs when the ETT is advanced too far into one bronchus, leading to ventilation of only one lung and collapse of the other. Proper technique, including auscultation and chest X-ray confirmation, is necessary to ensure correct ETT placement.

 

X RAY OF Endobronchial intubation

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant is brought to the clinic with red, scaly rashes around the mouth and anus, a history of chronic diarrhoea, poor wound healing, and growth delay. Based on these symptoms, which of the following is the most likely deficiency responsible for this condition? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Zinc

 

Acrodermatitis enteropathica is a rare autosomal recessive disorder caused by defective intestinal absorption of zinc. This condition manifests as perioral, perivaginal, and perianal dermatitis, along with alopecia and diarrhea. Zinc deficiency is common in premature infants, children with malabsorption syndromes, and individuals on prolonged parenteral nutrition without adequate supplementation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Copper Deficiency: Copper deficiency presents with hypopigmentation, neutropenia, and anemia but does not typically cause a perianal rash.

 

Option B. Selenium Deficiency: Selenium deficiency is associated with Keshan disease, which can lead to dilated cardiomyopathy​

 

Option D. Cobalt Deficiency: Cobalt is an essential component of vitamin B12, and its deficiency leads to megaloblastic anemia, but it does not cause perianal rash.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Zinc deficiency should be suspected in pediatric patients presenting with perianal, perioral, and perivaginal rash, along with diarrhea and growth retardation. The condition, acrodermatitis enteropathica, requires zinc supplementation for treatment.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child came with complaints of fast breathing and distress. The image is shown below. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Croup

 

The case represents Croup (Laryngotracheobronchitis). The X-ray shows the characteristic "steeple sign" - a tapering narrowing of the subglottic airway, which is pathognomonic for croup. The most common causative agent is parainfluenza virus. Treatment includes dexamethasone (steroids) and adrenaline nebulization. The condition presents with inspiratory stridor, barking cough, and respiratory distress.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Acute epiglottitis: Incorrect. Epiglottitis presents with "thumb sign" on lateral neck X-ray, not steeple sign. It is a more severe condition requiring immediate airway management.

 

Option C. Bronchiolitis: Incorrect. Bronchiolitis typically affects infants under 2 years and shows hyperinflation with patchy infiltrates on chest X-ray, not upper airway narrowing.

 

Option D. None of the above: Incorrect. The image clearly shows the characteristic steeple sign of croup.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Croup (laryngotracheobronchitis) should be suspected in a child with barking cough, inspiratory stridor, and respiratory distress. The steeple sign on X-ray confirms the diagnosis. Management includes corticosteroids (dexamethasone) and nebulized epinephrine for severe cases.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child is being screened for malnutrition at a health center. According to WHO criteria, what mid-upper arm circumference (MUAC) measurement indicates severe acute malnutrition? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) < 11.5 cm

 

Mid-upper arm circumference (MUAC) less than 11.5 cm is diagnostic of severe acute malnutrition (SAM). This measurement is taken using a Shakir tape, which is color-coded for easy identification by health workers:

 

  • Red zone (< 11.5 cm): Severe malnutrition
  • Yellow zone (11.5-12.5 cm): Moderate malnutrition
  • Green zone (> 12.5 cm): Normal nutritional status

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. < 12.5 cm: Incorrect. MUAC < 12.5 cm but > 11.5 cm indicates moderate acute malnutrition, not severe.

 

Option C. > 12.5 cm: Incorrect. This indicates normal nutritional status.

 

Option D. > 13.5 cm: Incorrect. This also indicates normal nutritional status. This value is not used as a cutoff in standard MUAC measurements.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mid-upper arm circumference (MUAC) < 11.5 cm is one of the diagnostic criteria for severe acute malnutrition in children.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with disproportionate short stature with increased upper segment: lower segment ratio. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Achondroplasia

 

Achondroplasia is characterized by an increased upper segment to lower segment ratio. Normal US:LS ratio values are:

 

  • At birth: 1.7:1
  • At 3 years: 1.3:1
  • At 7-10 years: 1:1

 

When this ratio is increased, remember the mnemonic RHA:

 

  • R: Rickets
  • H: Hypothyroidism
  • A: Achondroplasia

 

In achondroplasia, FGFR3 gene mutation leads to:

 

  • Short limbed dwarfism with proximal limb shortening
  • Trident hand
  • Motor milestones delayed
  • Large head
  • Obesity
  • Decreased interpedicular distance

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Spondyloepiphyseal dysplasia: Incorrect. This primarily affects spine and epiphyses causing short trunk dwarfism, not increased US:LS ratio.

 

Option C. Alagille syndrome: Incorrect. Features butterfly vertebrae, peripheral pulmonary stenosis and bile duct paucity, but doesn't affect US:LS ratio.

 

Option D. TB spine: Incorrect. Causes vertebral destruction and gibbus deformity but doesn't characteristically alter US:LS ratio.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Achondroplasia presents with an increased upper segment:lower segment ratio due to short limbs with a relatively preserved trunk length. The condition is caused by an FGFR3 gene mutation and is the most common form of disproportionate short stature.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child is brought to the clinic by their parents due to bowing of the legs. On examination, the child has widening of the wrists and frontal bossing. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rickets

 

Bowing of the legs in a 2-year-old child is most commonly associated with rickets, a condition caused by vitamin D deficiency leading to defective bone mineralization​

 

Features of Rickets:

 

  • Bowing of legs (genu varum) in toddlers
  • Widening of wrists
  • Delayed fontanelle closure
  • Frontal bossing
  • Rachitic rosary (prominent costochondral junctions)
  • Harrison sulcus (groove in the lower rib cage due to diaphragmatic pull)
  • Growth retardation

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Scurvy: Caused by vitamin C deficiency, presenting with bleeding gums, corkscrew hairs, and perifollicular hemorrhages, but not bowing of legs.

 

Option C. Syphilis: Congenital syphilis can cause saber shins (anterior bowing of tibia), but it is less common and usually presents with other stigmata like Hutchinson’s teeth and saddle nose deformity.

 

Option D. Anemia: Does not cause bowing of the legs. Iron-deficiency anemia may cause fatigue and pallor but does not affect bone structure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rickets should be suspected in children with bowing of the legs, delayed fontanelle closure, and widened wrists. It is caused by vitamin D deficiency, leading to defective bone mineralization.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child came with complaints of fast breathing of RR 48 per minute with no chest in drawing. What is your diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pneumonia

 

According to the IMNCI (Integrated Management of Neonatal and Childhood Illness) guidelines, respiratory rate (RR) cutoffs for diagnosing pneumonia in children are as follows:

 

  • Age 0–2 months → RR > 60/min → Fast breathing
  • Age 2 months – 1 year → RR > 50/min → Fast breathing
  • Age 1–5 years → RR > 40/min → Fast breathing

 

The child in the question is 2 years old with a RR of 48/min, which is above the cutoff of 40/min for pneumonia, but there is no chest indrawing or danger signs. This is classified as "pneumonia" according to IMNCI​

 

Classification Based on IMNCI Guidelines:

 

  • No pneumonia (A): Normal breathing rate, no signs of distress.
  • Pneumonia (B) (This Case): Fast breathing (tachypnea) but no chest indrawing or danger signs.
  • Severe pneumonia (C): Fast breathing + chest indrawing or danger signs (e.g., inability to feed, convulsions, lethargy, cyanosis).
  • Very severe pneumonia (D): Not a recognized IMNCI category (IMNCI only classifies pneumonia as "pneumonia" or "severe pneumonia").

 

Educational Objective:

 

A respiratory rate of 48/min in a 2-year-old without chest indrawing is classified as pneumonia. IMNCI guidelines recommend oral amoxicillin for five days as the first-line treatment for non-severe pneumonia.

questions.text: Which of the following features is not part of the classic triad of congenital toxoplasmosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hepatosplenomegaly

 

The classic triad of congenital toxoplasmosis includes:

 

  1. Chorioretinitis – Inflammation of the retina and choroid, causing visual impairment.
  2. Intracranial Calcifications – Diffuse calcifications, commonly in the basal ganglia.
  3. Hydrocephalus – Ventricular enlargement due to CSF flow obstruction.

 

Hepatosplenomegaly, although commonly seen in congenital infections, is not a part of the classic triad of congenital toxoplasmosis​FMGE Jan 2025 pediatrics.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Congenital toxoplasmosis classically presents with the triad of chorioretinitis, intracranial calcifications, and hydrocephalus. Additional findings such as hepatosplenomegaly, jaundice, and seizures may occur but are not part of the classic triad.

questions.text: Which anthropometric parameter indicates chronic malnutrition in a child according to WHO growth standards? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Height for age

 

Using the WHO mnemonic (Weight, Height, Age):

 

  • Weight for height: indicates acute malnutrition (wasting)
  • Height for age: indicates chronic malnutrition (stunting)
  • Weight for age: indicates both acute and chronic malnutrition (underweight)

 

Chronic malnutrition leads to decreased height for age (stunting) due to long-term nutritional deficiency affecting linear growth.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Weight for height: Incorrect. This indicates acute malnutrition or wasting, representing current nutritional status.

 

Option C. Weight for age: Incorrect. This is a composite indicator that reflects both acute and chronic malnutrition.

 

Option D. BMI for age: Incorrect. While useful for assessing nutritional status, this is not the primary indicator for chronic malnutrition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic malnutrition is best measured by height-for-age, as it indicates long-term nutritional deficiencies leading to stunting. In contrast, weight-for-height reflects acute malnutrition (wasting), and weight-for-age is a mixed indicator.

questions.text: A baby presents with the clinical features shown in the image, including characteristic perioral and perianal rash along with a history of diarrhea, delayed wound healing. Which of the following is the most likely deficiency responsible for this condition? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Zinc deficiency

 

The case describes a classic presentation of zinc deficiency with the characteristic Features:

 

  1. Periorificial dermatitis (perioral and perianal rash as shown in images)
  2. Diarrhea
  3. Delayed wound healing

 

The mnemonic "HIDE" helps remember the key features of zinc deficiency:

 

  • H: Healing (delayed wound healing)
  • I: Immunity (decreased)
  • D: Dermatitis (periorificial/acral)
  • E: Enteropathy (diarrhea)

 

Additional features can include:

 

  • Alopecia (hair loss)
  • Growth retardation
  • Impaired taste sensation
  • Secondary infections due to compromised immunity

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Niacin deficiency (Incorrect):

 

  • Presents with pellagra characterized by 3Ds: Dermatitis, Diarrhea, Dementia
  • Dermatitis in pellagra shows casal’s Necklace appearance on sun-exposed areas, not periorificial
  • Dementia is not present in this case

 

Option C. Selenium deficiency (Incorrect):

 

  • Presents as Keshan disease with cardiomyopathy
  • Does not cause characteristic periorificial lesions or diarrhea
  • More common in areas with selenium-deficient soil

 

Option D. Magnesium deficiency (Incorrect):

 

  • Primarily presents with neuromuscular symptoms like tetany and seizures
  • Does not cause characteristic skin lesions or chronic diarrhea
  • Usually associated with malabsorption or alcoholism

 

Educational Objective:

 

Remember the characteristic clinical presentation of zinc deficiency using the mnemonic "HIDE" - Healing (delayed), Immunity (decreased), Dermatitis (periorificial), and Enteropathy (diarrhea). The periorificial distribution of dermatitis is pathognomonic for zinc deficiency.

questions.text: A patient present with gum bleeding, petechiae, poor wound healing, and other related symptoms. Which of the following vitamin deficiencies is most likely responsible for this presentation? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Vitamin C

 

The clinical features described are classic signs of Vitamin C deficiency (Scurvy)

 

  • Gum bleeding and inflammation
  • Petechiae (due to capillary fragility)
  • Poor wound healing
  • These occur because Vitamin C is essential for: 
  1. Collagen synthesis - hydroxylation of proline and lysine
  2. Maintaining blood vessel integrity
  3. Wound healing

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin A (Incorrect)

 

  • Deficiency presents with: 
    • Night blindness (earliest symptom)
    • Bitot's spots (most specific)
    • Xerophthalmia
    • Keratomalacia

 

Option B. Vitamin B6 (Incorrect)

 

  • Deficiency presents with: 
    • Neurological symptoms
    • Seborrheic dermatitis
    • Glossitis
    • Convulsions in infants

 

Option C. Vitamin B3 (Incorrect)

 

  • Deficiency leads to Pellagra characterized by 4Ds: 
    • Dermatitis (photosensitive)
    • Diarrhea
    • Dementia
    • Death

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Classic triad of scurvy (Vitamin C deficiency): gum bleeding, poor wound healing, and petechiae/easy bruising. Understand that these symptoms occur due to impaired collagen synthesis and compromised blood vessel integrity.

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes is dependent on Vitamin C for its activity? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Prolyl hydroxylase

 

Prolyl hydroxylase is a key enzyme in collagen synthesis that requires vitamin C (ascorbic acid) as a cofactor. This enzyme catalyzes the hydroxylation of proline residues to form hydroxyproline in collagen. The process is essential for:

 

  • Post-translational modification of collagen
  • Formation of stable collagen triple helix
  • Proper collagen cross-linking
  • Maintaining collagen strength and stability

 

In vitamin C deficiency, proline cannot be hydroxylated to hydroxyproline, leading to unstable collagen and symptoms of scurvy like:

 

  • Poor wound healing
  • Bleeding gums
  • Easy bruising

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lysyl dehydrogenase: Incorrect because this enzyme does not exist in collagen synthesis pathway. The actual enzyme involved in lysine modification is lysyl hydroxylase, which also requires vitamin C.

 

Option B. Lysyl oxidase: Incorrect because this enzyme requires copper as a cofactor, not vitamin C. It forms cross-links in collagen by oxidizing lysine and hydroxylysine residues.

 

Option C. Hydroxypropyl kinase: Incorrect because this is a non-existent enzyme name. No such enzyme is involved in collagen synthesis or vitamin C-dependent reactions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamin C is an essential cofactor for prolyl hydroxylase, which is crucial for collagen synthesis and stability. Deficiency of vitamin C leads to defective collagen formation resulting in scurvy.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presented with black deposit in the vertebrae visible on X-Ray LS spine and also over knee joint and sclera which shows ochronosis. Which enzyme deficiency has caused this condition? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Homogentisic acid oxidase

 

The clinical presentation describes Alkaptonuria, which is caused by deficiency of homogentisic acid oxidase (also known as homogentisate dioxygenase). This is an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by:

 

  • Accumulation of homogentisic acid which gets oxidized to form black colored alkapton bodies
  • These alkapton bodies deposit in various tissues causing ochronosis: 
    • Sclera (causing black discoloration)
    • Cartilage of joints (causing arthritis)
    • Vertebral column (visible on X-ray)
    • Skin showing bluish-black color
  • The condition typically presents in adults around 30-40 years
  • Homogentisic acid gets excreted in urine, causing urine to turn black on standing (characteristic feature)
  • FeCl3 test of urine is positive
  • Part of Garrod's tetrad (along with albinism, cystinuria, and pentosuria)

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Phenylalanine hydroxylase deficiency: Causes phenylketonuria (PKU) characterized by mental retardation, musty odor, and hypopigmentation. Does not cause ochronosis.

 

Option C. Tyrosine transaminase deficiency: Causes tyrosinemia type II (Richner-Hanhart syndrome) characterized by corneal ulcers and hyperkeratotic plaques. No ochronosis.

 

Option D. PHPP (para-hydroxy phenyl pyruvate) dioxygenase deficiency: Causes tyrosinemia type III characterized by mental retardation and ataxia but no ochronosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alkaptonuria is caused by homogentisic acid oxidase deficiency and presents with ochronosis (black deposits in connective tissues) and darkening of urine on standing.

questions.text: A patient with a history of strenuous exercise skipped a meal and later consumed alcohol at a party. Alcohol inhibits which of the following biochemical processes, potentially leading to hypoglycemia: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Gluconeogenesis

 

The question describes a clinical scenario where alcohol consumption after exercise and skipping meals leads to hypoglycemia. Alcohol inhibits gluconeogenesis through several mechanisms:

 

  1. Alcohol metabolism produces excess NADH through: 
    • Conversion of alcohol to acetaldehyde (ADH reaction)
    • Conversion of acetaldehyde to acetate (ALDH reaction)
  2. Excess NADH causes: 
    • Conversion of pyruvate to lactate
    • Conversion of oxaloacetate to malate
  3. This leads to depletion of pyruvate and oxaloacetate, which are essential substrates for gluconeogenesis
  4. Since the patient has exercised and skipped meals, glycogen stores are already depleted, making gluconeogenesis crucial for maintaining blood glucose

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Glycogenolysis - Incorrect

 

  • Alcohol does not directly inhibit glycogenolysis
  • However, after strenuous exercise and skipping meals, glycogen stores would already be depleted

 

Option C. Hexose Monophosphate (HMP) Shunt - Incorrect

 

  • Alcohol does not directly affect the HMP shunt
  • HMP shunt is primarily involved in NADPH production and not glucose homeostasis

 

Option D. Ketone Body Formation - Incorrect

 

  • Alcohol actually promotes ketone body formation due to increased Acetyl-CoA from alcohol metabolism
  • This leads to alcoholic ketosis rather than inhibition

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alcohol consumption inhibits gluconeogenesis by creating a high NADH/NAD+ ratio, which depletes gluconeogenic substrates (pyruvate and oxaloacetate), potentially leading to hypoglycemia, especially when glycogen stores are depleted.

questions.text: Which of the following amino acids primarily acts as a buffer in blood due to its ability to accept and donate protons at physiological pH? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Histidine

 

Histidine contains an imidazole ring in its side chain, which has a pKa close to physiological pH (~6.8-7.0).

 

The imidazole ring allows histidine to reversibly bind and release protons, making it an excellent buffer.

 

This buffering action is important in maintaining blood pH and plays a key role in hemoglobin function (part of the histidine residue in hemoglobin helps buffer blood pH changes).

 

"Histidine has an imidazole ring, which allows it to accept and donate protons at physiological pH."

 

"Histidine is the most effective buffer at physiological pH due to its imidazole ring."

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Arginine: Incorrect

 

  • Has a guanidinium group with pKa ~12.5, making it a strong base, but not an effective buffer at physiological pH (~7.4).
  • Arginine is the precursor of nitric oxide (NO), emphasizing its role in vasodilation rather than acid-base balance.

 

Option C. Tryptophan: Incorrect

 

  • Tryptophan is an aromatic amino acid and is used in the synthesis of niacin (Vitamin B3), serotonin, and melatonin.
  • Tryptophan contains an indole ring, making it non-polar and hydrophobic.
  • Since buffering depends on the ability to accept and donate protons near physiological pH (~7.4), tryptophan is not effective as a buffer.

 

Option D. Tyrosine: Incorrect

 

  • Tyrosine's is derived from phenylalanine and has a role in thyroid hormone synthesis, catecholamine production (dopamine, norepinephrine, epinephrine), and melanin production.
  • Tyrosine has a phenol (-OH) group, with a pKa of ~10.1, meaning it does not donate or accept protons effectively at physiological pH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Histidine is the best amino acid buffer in blood because of its imidazole ring, which has a pKa close to physiological pH (~7).

 

The imidazole group allows histidine to act as a proton donor or acceptor, making it an ideal buffer.

questions.text: Which of the following is accumulated in joint in the mucopolysaccharidosis associated with Natowicz disease? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hyaluronic acid

 

Natowicz disease (MPS type IX) is characterized by:

 

  • Enzyme deficiency: Hyaluronidase
  • Accumulated substance: Hyaluronic acid
  • Clinical features include joint pain and short stature
  • This is a rare form of mucopolysaccharidosis
  • The condition results from inability to break down hyaluronic acid due to hyaluronidase deficiency

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dermatan sulfate: Incorrect

 

  • Because dermatan sulfate accumulation is seen in MPS types I, II and VI
  • Its accumulation typically leads to cardiovascular manifestations like atherosclerosis

 

Option B. Heparan sulfate: Incorrect

 

  • Because heparan sulfate accumulation is seen in MPS types I, II and III
  • Its accumulation typically leads to mental retardation
  • Present on cell surfaces and has a role in cell-cell adhesion

 

Option C. Keratan sulfate: Incorrect

 

  • Because keratan sulfate accumulation is seen in MPS type IV
  • It is unique among GAGs as it does not contain uronic acid
  • Responsible for corneal transparency
  • Present in cornea and connective tissue

 

Educational Objective:

 

Natowicz disease (MPS type IX) is characterized by hyaluronidase deficiency leading to accumulation of hyaluronic acid in joints, causing joint pain and short stature.

questions.text: During starvation, which of the following hormones is primarily produced to maintain blood glucose levels? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Glucagon

 

Glucagon is the primary hormone produced during starvation to maintain blood glucose levels. During starvation:

 

  • Blood glucose levels decrease, triggering glucagon release from pancreatic α-cells
  • Glucagon acts antagonistically to insulin
  • It activates various catabolic pathways including: 
    • Glycogenolysis (breakdown of glycogen)
    • Gluconeogenesis (formation of new glucose)
    • Lipolysis through activation of hormone-sensitive lipase
  • Glucagon also increases during fasting state to maintain blood glucose through these mechanisms

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Insulin:

 

  • Incorrect because insulin is released during fed state when blood glucose is high
  • It promotes glucose uptake and storage
  • During starvation, insulin levels decrease to allow mobilization of glucose

 

Option C. Amylase:

 

  • Incorrect because amylase is a digestive enzyme, not a hormone
  • It breaks down carbohydrates in the digestive system
  • Has no direct role in blood glucose regulation during starvation

 

Option D. Somatostatin:

 

  • Incorrect because somatostatin inhibits both insulin and glucagon
  • While it plays a role in glucose homeostasis, it is not the primary hormone maintaining glucose during starvation
  • Its main function is to regulate other hormones' secretion

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Glucagon is the principal hormone responsible for maintaining blood glucose levels during starvation through activation of glycogenolysis, gluconeogenesis, and lipolysis. Its levels increase while insulin levels decrease during starvation.

 

Hormonal Regulation During Starvation

questions.text: The development of cataracts in patients with Diabetes Mellitus is primarily due to the accumulation of which of the following substances in the lens? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sorbitol

 

In diabetes mellitus, high blood glucose leads to increased glucose entry into the sorbitol pathway. Glucose is converted to sorbitol by aldose reductase using NADPH as a cofactor. 

 

Normally, sorbitol is further converted to fructose by sorbitol dehydrogenase. 

 

However, in diabetes, excess glucose leads to accumulation of sorbitol in the lens. Being hygroscopic, sorbitol draws water into lens cells causing osmotic stress and swelling, ultimately leading to snowflake cataract formation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Dulcitol: This is actually the same as galactitol, which accumulates in galactosemia causing oil drop cataracts, not diabetic cataracts. Dulcitol accumulation happens due to conversion of excess galactose by aldose reductase in galactosemia.

 

Option C. Mannitol: This is a sugar alcohol used therapeutically to decrease intracranial tension. It does not accumulate in diabetic cataracts.

 

Option D. Galactitol: This accumulates in galactosemia causing oil drop cataracts, not diabetic cataracts. It is formed when excess galactose is converted by aldose reductase.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Diabetic cataract (snowflake cataract) occurs due to sorbitol accumulation via the polyol pathway, whereas galactosemia leads to oil drop cataract due to galactitol/dulcitol accumulation.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presents with obesity and developmental delay. It is caused by paternal deletion and imprinted maternal allele. Which chromosome is involved? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 15

 

The clinical presentation describes Prader-Willi Syndrome (PWS). In PWS, chromosome 15 is involved, where under normal conditions:

 

  • The maternal allele is imprinted (inhibited)
  • Only the paternal allele is working When the paternal allele gets deleted while the maternal allele is already imprinted, both copies become non-functional, resulting in PWS. The condition affects chromosome15q11-q13 region.

 

Clinical features include:

 

  • Obesity
  • Developmental delay
  • Hypotonia (low muscle tone) in infancy
  • Hyperphagia (excessive eating) leading to obesity
  • Mild to moderate intellectual disability
  • Short stature and small hands and feet
  • Hypogonadism (underdeveloped genitals and delayed puberty)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chromosome 21: Incorrect

 

  • Chromosome 21 is associated with Down syndrome (trisomy 21)
  • Not involved in genomic imprinting disorders

 

Option B. Chromosome 11: Incorrect

 

  • While chromosome 11 shows genomic imprinting in some cases (like Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome), it's not associated with Symptoms mentioned in this scenario.

 

Option D. Chromosome 10: Incorrect

 

  • Chromosome 10 is not associated with major genomic imprinting disorders
  • Not involved in PWS or Angelman syndrome

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prader-Willi Syndrome involves chromosome 15, specifically:

 

  • Maternal allele is imprinted (naturally inhibited)
  • Paternal allele deletion
  • Results in both copies being non-functional

 

For remembering deletion pattern: 

 

"PAPA deleted in PWS"

 

Paternal deletion in Prader-Willi Syndrome

 

"Mothers are Angels"

 

Angelman syndrome = Maternal deletion

questions.text: Which of the following is the marker of apoptosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Phosphatidylserine

 

Phosphatidylserine is a key marker of apoptosis (programmed cell death). 

 

Under normal conditions, phosphatidylserine is located on the inner leaflet of the cell membrane.

 

 During apoptosis, it gets externalized to the outer leaflet, where it serves as a signal for phagocytes to recognize and engulf the apoptotic cell. 

 

This externalization of phosphatidylserine is one of the earliest detectable signs of apoptosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Phosphatidylethanolamine

 

  • Also known as cephalin, it is a membrane phospholipid found in cell membranes
  • While important for membrane structure, it is not a specific marker for apoptosis
  • It is involved in membrane fusion and cell signaling but not in apoptotic signaling

 

Option C. Phosphatidylcholine

 

  • Also known as lecithin
  • Major component of cell membranes and pulmonary surfactant
  • Important for membrane structure but not involved in apoptotic signaling
  • Acts as a surfactant in lungs

 

Option D. Sphingomyelin

 

  • A type of sphingolipid found in cell membranes
  • Important component of myelin sheath
  • While involved in cell signaling, it is not a specific marker for apoptosis

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Phosphatidylserine externalization is a specific marker of apoptosis and its role in recognition of apoptotic cells by phagocytes.

questions.text: Which enzyme is responsible for removal of Triglycerides from chylomicron? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lipoprotein lipase

 

Lipoprotein lipase (LPL) is present on the endothelium of blood vessels and is responsible for breaking down triglycerides in chylomicrons and VLDL into fatty acids. When chylomicrons travel via blood vessels, LPL acts on them to release fatty acids which can then be taken up by tissues. This enzyme is activated by Apo C-II (which acts as a cofactor) and insulin. LPL is considered an anabolic enzyme since it helps store fats in tissues during the fed state.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Amylase: This is incorrect because amylase is involved in carbohydrate metabolism, specifically the breakdown of starch. It has no role in triglyceride metabolism.

 

Option C. Hormone sensitive lipase: This is incorrect because HSL is present in adipose tissue and breaks down stored triglycerides during fasting/starvation. It is activated by glucagon and inhibited by insulin, unlike LPL which shows opposite regulation.

 

  • Insulin activate (love) Lipoprotein lipase
  • Insulin inhibit (hate) Hormone sensitive lipase

 

Option D. LCAT (Lecithin-cholesterol acyltransferase): This is incorrect because LCAT is involved in cholesterol metabolism, specifically the esterification of cholesterol in HDL particles. It has no direct role in triglyceride metabolism from chylomicrons.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Lipoprotein lipase is the key enzyme responsible for hydrolyzing triglycerides from circulating chylomicrons and VLDL at the endothelial surface, facilitating fatty acid uptake by tissues.

questions.text: What enzyme analysis will be done in a patient before starting anti-malarial drugs who had a family history of hemolytic anemia? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) G6PD analysis

 

G6PD (Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase) deficiency is the most common enzyme deficiency leading to hemolytic anemia. The enzyme G6PD is crucial in the HMP pathway, producing NADPH which is essential for:

 

  1. Converting oxidized glutathione to reduced glutathione in RBCs
  2. Protecting RBCs from oxidative stress
  3. Neutralizing harmful peroxides

 

When G6PD is deficient:

 

  • Reduced glutathione cannot be produced
  • RBCs become susceptible to oxidative stress
  • Hemolysis occurs when exposed to oxidative agents like antimalarial drugs
  • Being X-linked recessive, it shows family history and affects males more than females

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pyruvate kinase:

 

  • While this is the second most common enzyme deficiency causing hemolytic anemia, it's not specifically triggered by antimalarial drugs
  • Shows decreased RBC lactate levels, unlike G6PD deficiency where lactate levels are increased

 

Option C. Hexokinase:

 

  • First enzyme of glycolysis
  • Not specifically related to drug-induced hemolysis

 

Option D. Enolase:

 

  • Glycolytic enzyme converting 2-phosphoglycerate to phosphoenolpyruvate
  • Not related to drug-induced hemolysis

 

Educational Objective:
