G6PD analysis must be done before starting antimalarial therapy in patients with family history of hemolytic anemia, as G6PD deficiency is an X-linked recessive disorder where antimalarial drugs can trigger severe hemolysis due to oxidative stress.

questions.text: A 40-year-old electrical worker is brought to the emergency department after sustaining a high-voltage electric shock at work. He reports muscle pain, weakness, and dark-colored urine since the incident. Physical examination reveals tender, swollen muscles in the upper limbs. Laboratory tests show significantly elevated creatine kinase levels. What is the most likely substance found in his urine? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Myoglobin

 

The patient presents with classic signs of rhabdomyolysis - a condition where muscle damage leads to the release of muscle contents into circulation. The key findings supporting this diagnosis are:

 

  • History of high-voltage electric shock (a common cause of rhabdomyolysis)
  • Muscle pain and swelling
  • Dark-colored urine
  • Elevated creatine kinase (indicating muscle damage)

 

In rhabdomyolysis, damaged muscle cells release myoglobin into the bloodstream. Myoglobin is then filtered by the kidneys and appears in urine, giving it a dark or cola-colored appearance. Myoglobin in urine is a hallmark finding in rhabdomyolysis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Increased RBCs in urine: While hematuria can cause dark urine, the presence of elevated CK and muscle symptoms points toward myoglobinuria rather than hematuria. RBCs are not typically released from damaged muscle tissue.

 

Option C. Increased creatine kinase: While CK is elevated in the blood. CK is a marker of muscle damage but is not responsible for urine discoloration.

 

Option D. Increased bilirubin: While hyperbilirubinemia can cause dark urine, this patient's presentation is classic for myoglobinuria. There are no signs of liver disease or hemolysis to suggest bilirubinuria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rhabdomyolysis caused by muscle injury (such as electrical shock) leads to myoglobinuria, which causes dark-colored urine along with elevated serum creatine kinase levels.

questions.text: Which of the following is excreted in the urine of patients with Pentosuria? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) L xylulose

 

Pentosuria is caused by a defect in the uronic acid pathway where L-xylulose is not converted to D-xylitol due to deficiency of the xylulose reductase enzyme. This leads to:

 

  • Accumulation of L-xylulose which gets excreted in urine
  • The condition is benign/asymptomatic because the pentose sugar (L-xylulose) is excreted rather than accumulating in the body
  • Since L-xylulose is a monosaccharide (reducing sugar), urine will test positive with Benedict's test
  • Called "essential pentosuria" because excretion of the pentose sugar is essential to maintain asymptomatic state

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. D ribose: This is a pentose sugar but not involved in pentosuria. It is mainly involved in nucleotide synthesis through the HMP pathway.

 

Option C. D ribulose: This is an intermediate in the pentose phosphate pathway but not excreted in pentosuria.

 

Option D. D lactose: This is a disaccharide, not a pentose sugar. Its excretion is not associated with pentosuria.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Biochemical Features of Pentosuria

 

  • Enzyme Deficiency: Xylitol dehydrogenase
  • Affected Pathway: Uronic acid pathway
  • Accumulated Compound: L-xylulose
  • Excretion in Urine: L-xylulose (leading to pentosuria)
  • Reducing Sugar in Urine: Benedict’s test positive
  • Clinical Symptoms: None (benign condition)
  • Mode of Inheritance: Autosomal recessive (more common in Ashkenazi Jewish populations

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the regulation of enzyme activity through phosphorylation or dephosphorylation? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Covalent modification

 

Phosphorylation and dephosphorylation involve the covalent addition or removal of phosphate groups to/from enzymes. This is a type of covalent modification because:

 

  • Phosphate groups are attached through covalent bonds to specific amino acid residues (usually serine, threonine, or tyrosine)
  • The changes are reversible but require specific enzymes (kinases and phosphatases)
  • This process is regulated by hormones like glucagon (increases phosphorylation via cAMP) and insulin (promotes dephosphorylation)

 

Common examples include:

 

  • Glycogen metabolism enzymes: 
    • Glycogen phosphorylase is activated by phosphorylation
    • Glycogen synthase is inhibited by phosphorylation

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Competitive inhibition: Incorrect because

 

  • This involves reversible binding of inhibitor at active site
  • No covalent modification occurs
  • Competes with substrate for binding

 

Option B. Repression: Incorrect because

 

  • This regulates enzyme synthesis at gene level
  • Does not involve modification of existing enzyme
  • Acts by controlling transcription

 

Option C. Allosteric inhibition: Incorrect because

 

  • Involves non-covalent binding at regulatory site
  • Causes conformational changes
  • No chemical modification of enzyme structure

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phosphorylation/dephosphorylation represents a covalent modification mechanism for regulating enzyme activity through the addition or removal of phosphate groups.

questions.text: Acetyl CoA in prolonged starvation mostly will be used for: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ketogenesis

 

During prolonged starvation, acetyl CoA is primarily used for ketone body synthesis (ketogenesis). In starvation, there are three main fates of acetyl CoA:

 

  1. It enters TCA cycle to provide energy.
  2. Acetyl CoA is directed toward ketone body synthesis
  3. Acetyl CoA activates gluconeogenesis

 

The ketone bodies produced serve as alternative fuel source for vital organs like brain, heart and skeletal muscle. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glucose: Incorrect. Because acetyl CoA cannot be converted to glucose. While acetyl CoA activates gluconeogenesis, it is not a substrate for glucose formation. This is a key concept often tested.

 

Option C. Non-essential Fatty Acid synthesis: Incorrect. Because fatty acid synthesis occurs in fed state, not during starvation. During starvation, the pathway is inhibited due to low insulin levels.

 

Option D. Cholesterol synthesis: Incorrect. Because cholesterol synthesis, like fatty acid synthesis, is an anabolic process that occurs in fed state when insulin levels are high. During starvation, this pathway is suppressed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 During prolonged starvation, acetyl CoA is primarily directed toward ketone body synthesis to provide alternative fuel for vital organs, rather than being used for anabolic processes like fatty acid or cholesterol synthesis.

 

Fates of Acetyl-CoA

 

In Starvation:

 

  • TCA Cycle
  • Ketone Body Synthesis
  • Activation of Gluconeogenesis

 

In Fed State:

 

  • Fatty Acid/TG (Triglyceride) Synthesis
  • Cholesterol Synthesis
  • TCA Cycle

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presents to the emergency department with complaints of dizziness and weakness. She reports a history of binge eating followed by self-induced vomiting for weight control. Arterial blood gas analysis reveals the following: pH -7.50; Pco2 –48mmHg; HCO3-30meq/l? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Metabolic Alkalosis

 

Explanation: 

 

  • pH is 7.5 (elevated above normal 7.35-7.45) indicating alkalosis
  • PCO2 is 48 mmHg (elevated above normal 35-45 mmHg) indicating respiratory compensation
  • HCO3 is 30 meq/L (elevated above normal 22-26 meq/L)

 

This represents a primary metabolic alkalosis with respiratory compensation. The elevated HCO3 is the primary disorder causing the alkalosis. The elevated PCO2 represents appropriate respiratory compensation (hypoventilation) attempting to normalize the pH by retaining CO2.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Metabolic Acidosis: Incorrect because metabolic acidosis presents with low pH (<7.35) and low HCO3, which is opposite to the values given.

 

Option C. Respiratory Alkalosis:Incorrect because respiratory alkalosis presents with high pH but low PCO2, whereas here PCO2 is elevated.

 

Option D. Respiratory Acidosis:Incorrect because respiratory acidosis presents with low pH and high PCO2. While PCO2 is high here, the pH is alkalotic rather than acidotic.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In arterial blood gas interpretation, metabolic alkalosis is characterized by:

 

  • Elevated pH (>7.45)
  • Elevated HCO3 (>26 meq/L)
  • Compensatory elevation in PCO2 through hypoventilation

questions.text: A person is exercising via performing different muscle movement, which of the following is correct regarding the muscle zone? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Band I decreases

 

Explanation: 

 

During muscle contraction, the I band decreases in size due to increased overlapping between actin and myosin filaments. "When the muscle is going to start contracting, the overlapping between the actin and myosin is going to increase. And because of that, the I band (only actin) is going to decrease because more actin will be overlapped by the myosin."

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. M-line decreases – Incorrect: The M line is the midline between two adjacent Z lines. "M line will never change" during muscle contraction. It remains constant as it's a structural component.

 

Option B. M-line & I band decreases - Incorrect: While I band does decrease, M line remains constant during contraction. Therefore, this combination is incorrect.

 

Option C. Band A decreases – Incorrect: A band represents the complete myosin filament length. "A band is a complete myosin that is nothing but whether it is overlapped by the actin or non-overlap does not matter. It will stay as it is." The A band length remains constant during contraction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

During muscle contraction, while the M line and A band remain constant in length, the I band (containing only actin filaments) decreases in size due to increased actin-myosin overlap.

questions.text: Which one of the following leads to shift toward red curve in the given graph? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acidosis

 

Explanation: 

 

The oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve (OHDC) shows the relationship between PO2 and hemoglobin saturation. The red curve in the image represents a right shift. Acidosis causes a right shift of the curve, known as the Bohr effect. When blood pH decreases (acidosis), the affinity of hemoglobin for oxygen decreases, causing more oxygen to be released to the tissues. This is physiologically beneficial as tissues in acidotic conditions often need more oxygen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Less 2,3 BPG: Incorrect Less 2,3-BPG causes a left shift of the curve, not right

 

  • When 2,3-BPG levels decrease, hemoglobin's affinity for oxygen increases
  • This means oxygen binds more tightly to hemoglobin and less is released to tissues

 

Option C. Hypocarbia: Incorrect Hypocarbia means decreased CO2 levels

 

  • This leads to alkalosis which causes a left shift
  • Results in increased affinity of hemoglobin for oxygen

 

Option D. Hypothermia: Incorrect Lower temperature causes a left shift of the curve

 

  • Increases hemoglobin's affinity for oxygen
  • Reduces oxygen delivery to tissues

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acidosis causes a right shift of the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve (Bohr effect), while alkalosis, hypothermia, and decreased 2,3-BPG cause left shifts.

questions.text: Identify the cell marked as X in the given image: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Purkinje cells

 

Explanation: 

 

The image shows a histological section of the cerebellar cortex. The cells marked with X show characteristic features of Purkinje cells:

 

  • They are the largest neurons in the cerebellar cortex
  • Located in the Purkinje layer (between the molecular and granular layers)
  • Organized in a single row
  • Have distinctive large cell bodies and extensive dendritic trees
  • They are the only output cells from the cerebellar cortex

 

Purkinje cells are the only cells that give output from the cerebellum, making them functionally unique and essential for cerebellar function.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Basket cells: Incorrect 

 

  • Because basket cells are smaller interneurons found in the molecular layer
  • They make connections with Purkinje cell bodies
  • They have a characteristic "basket-like" axonal arborization

 

Option C. Granule cells: Incorrect

 

  • Because granule cells are the smallest and most numerous neurons in the cerebellum
  • They are located in the granular layer (seen as the dense purple layer in the image)
  • They have small round cell bodies

 

Option D. Golgi cells: Incorrect

 

  • Because Golgi cells are interneurons present in the granular layer
  • They are involved in local circuit processing
  • They do not have the characteristic large cell body and location seen in the image

 

Educational Objective:

 

Purkinje cells are the largest neurons in the cerebellar cortex, arranged in a single layer between molecular and granular layers, and serve as the sole output neurons of the cerebellar cortex.

choices.text: Inhibit Acetylcholine Release from presynaptic terminal

questions.text: Which of the following is correct regarding Mechanism of botulinum toxin: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Inhibit Acetylcholine Release from presynaptic terminal

 

Explanation: 

 

Botulinum toxin works by inhibiting acetylcholine release from presynaptic terminals. It specifically acts by:

 

  • Inhibiting Synaptobrevin, which is part of the SNARE protein complex
  • SNARE proteins are essential for neurotransmitter exocytosis
  • This inhibition prevents acetylcholine release into the synaptic cleft
  • Results in flaccid paralysis due to lack of neurotransmitter release
  • Clinically used in treating conditions like achalasia cardia, spasms, and contractures

 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Inhibit Acetylcholine reuptake: Incorrect because botulinum toxin doesn't affect reuptake mechanisms. It acts specifically on the release mechanism.

 

Option C. Block post synaptic Acetylcholine receptor: Incorrect. This is the mechanism of action for myasthenia gravis where antibodies target post-synaptic acetylcholine receptors. Botulinum toxin acts presynaptically.

 

Option D. Inhibit Acetylcholine esterase: Incorrect. This is the mechanism of action of drugs like neostigmine and pyridostigmine used in treating myasthenia gravis. They prevent the breakdown of acetylcholine in the synaptic cleft.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Botulinum toxin functions by inhibiting acetylcholine release through its action on SNARE proteins (specifically synaptobrevin) at the presynaptic terminal.

choices.text: Tricuspid valve bulging into Right atria

questions.text: In JVP ‘a ‘wave represents which one of the following? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Right atrial contraction

 

Explanation: 

 

The a-wave in the jugular venous pressure waveform corresponds to atrial contraction. When the right atrium contracts, it causes an increase in pressure that is transmitted backward into the jugular veins, creating the a-wave. This wave appears just before the carotid pulse and first heart sound (S1). The a-wave is one of the most easily visible waves in the JVP examination and is particularly important because its presence confirms that the patient is in sinus rhythm, as it indicates normal atrial contraction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Right atrial relaxation: Incorrect. Right atrial relaxation is represented by the 'x' descent in JVP, not the 'a' wave.

 

Option C. Tricuspid valve bulging into Right atria: Incorrect. This is represented by the 'c' wave in JVP, which occurs when the tricuspid valve bulges into the right atrium during early ventricular systole.

 

Option D. Right atrial filling: Incorrect. Right atrial filling is represented by the 'v' wave in JVP, which occurs during venous return when the tricuspid valve is closed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

a-wave in the jugular venous pressure waveform corresponds to atrial contraction and understand its clinical significance in assessing cardiac rhythm and right heart function.

questions.text: Which one of the following is related to the release of bicarbonate in exchange of Chloride in the RBC? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chloride shift

 

Explanation: 

 

Chloride shift (also known as Hamburger phenomenon) occurs when RBCs move towards the tissue. As RBCs enter venous blood, CO2 diffuses into them and combines with H2O to form H2CO3 under the influence of carbonic anhydrase. H2CO3 dissociates into H+ and HCO3-. The bicarbonate ion is then exchanged for chloride through an exchanger protein. When chloride enters the RBC, water follows due to osmosis, causing the RBCs to swell. This increases the hematocrit in venous blood compared to arterial blood.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bohr's effect: Incorrect. Because Bohr's effect refers to the right shift of oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve due to increased CO2, decreased pH, or increased temperature, leading to enhanced oxygen unloading in tissues.

 

Option B. Haldane effect: Incorrect. Because Haldane effect describes the enhanced unloading of CO2 in the lungs due to increased oxygenation of hemoglobin. It represents the left shift of the curve in lungs.

 

Option D. None of the above: Incorrect. Because chloride shift is the correct phenomenon describing the exchange of bicarbonate and chloride in RBCs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chloride shift (Hamburger phenomenon) involves the exchange of bicarbonate ions for chloride ions across the RBC membrane during tissue gas exchange, leading to increased RBC volume in venous blood.

questions.text: In a patient after giving a Noradrenaline injection heart rate started to decrease, what is the reason for it: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Stimulation of Baroreceptor

 

Explanation: 

 

When noradrenaline (a sympathetic agent) is administered, it activates the sympathetic system leading to an increase in blood pressure. This increased blood pressure activates baroreceptors, triggering a reflex response. Since noradrenaline has already bound to its receptors and cannot decrease blood pressure directly, the body activates the cardio inhibitory center (CIC) to inhibit the SA node. This inhibition leads to bradycardia, known as reflex bradycardia. This is a compensatory mechanism to help maintain blood pressure homeostasis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stimulation of alpha 2 receptors: Incorrect because heart does not have alpha 2 receptors. Alpha receptors are primarily involved in vasoconstriction.

 

Option C. Stimulation of beta 1 receptors: Incorrect because beta 1 receptor stimulation would cause an increase in heart rate (tachycardia), not a decrease.

 

Option D. Inhibition of Baroreceptor: Incorrect because inhibition of baroreceptors would lead to tachycardia, not bradycardia. Baroreceptor inhibition removes the "brake" on heart rate.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Baroreceptor stimulation due to increased blood pressure can cause reflex bradycardia as a compensatory mechanism, even when using sympathetic agents like noradrenaline.

questions.text: In Presence of ADH, Maximum osmolarity of tubular fluid will be in which of the following site of nephron? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Medullary CD

 

Explanation: 

 

ADH increases water permeability in the collecting ducts by inserting aquaporin channels. When ADH is present, as we move from the cortex towards the deep medulla, osmolarity keeps increasing. Though ADH acts on both cortical and medullary collecting ducts, the maximum change in osmolarity occurs in the medullary region due to the countercurrent multiplication system maintaining high osmolarity in the medullary interstitium.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. PCT: Incorrect because PCT mainly handles obligatory water reabsorption (60-70%) through osmosis, not regulated by ADH.

 

Option B. Cortical CD: Incorrect because although ADH acts here, the osmotic gradient in the cortex is much lower than in the medulla.

 

Option C. DCT: Incorrect because DCT has minimal water reabsorption (1-3%) without ADH and is not a major site for ADH action.

 

Educational Objective:

 

While ADH acts on both cortical and medullary collecting ducts, the maximum osmolarity of tubular fluid is achieved in the medullary collecting duct due to the high osmotic gradient maintained by the countercurrent multiplication system in the medulla.

questions.text: Which hormone is involved in the given scenario shown in the image? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Oxytocin

 

Explanation: 

 

The image shows breastfeeding, which involves the milk ejection/letdown reflex mediated by oxytocin. This is a positive feedback mechanism where suckling stimulates the release of oxytocin. milk letdown reflex is one of the classic examples of positive feedback mechanisms in the body (along with other "HCLAMP" mechanisms - Hodgkin's cycle, Clotting cascade, LH surge, Activation of digestive enzymes, Milk letdown, and Parturition reflex).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Adrenaline: Incorrect because adrenaline is a stress hormone released from adrenal medulla. It has no direct role in milk ejection/breastfeeding.

 

Option C. Cortisol: Incorrect because cortisol is a glucocorticoid involved in stress response and metabolism. While it may be present during breastfeeding, it is not the primary hormone responsible for milk ejection.

 

Option D. Thyroxin: Incorrect because thyroxine is involved in metabolism and growth. While it plays a supportive role in lactation by maintaining metabolic rate, it is not directly responsible for milk ejection during breastfeeding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Oxytocin is the key hormone responsible for milk ejection/letdown reflex during breastfeeding through a positive feedback mechanism.

choices.text: Total body water is more than adults

questions.text: Dehydration usually affects an infant’s more than adults. Which of the following is a true statement in this scenario related to infants / Newborn? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) ECF more than ICF

 

Explanation:

 

In newborns/infants, the ECF is greater than ICF, which makes them more susceptible to dehydration. 

 

  • ECF is greater than ICF in newborns
  • At 3-4 months of age, ICF equals ECF (50:50)
  • After 3-4 months, ICF gradually increases while ECF decreases
  • This higher ECF makes infants more vulnerable to fluid losses and dehydration

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. ICF more than ECF: Incorrect. Because in newborns, ECF is higher than ICF. ICF becomes greater than ECF only after 3-4 months of age.

 

Option C. Total body water is more than adults: Incorrect. Because while newborns have a higher percentage of total body water (75%) compared to adults (60%), the absolute amount of water is less in newborns due to their smaller body size.

 

Option D. ECF equals ICF: Incorrect. Because ECF equals ICF only at around 3-4 months of age, not in newborns.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In newborns, extracellular fluid (ECF) volume is greater than intracellular fluid (ICF) volume, which makes them more susceptible to dehydration compared to adults.

questions.text: FSH is inhibited by: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Inhibin

 

Explanation: 

 

FSH is inhibited by inhibin. This is a direct feedback mechanism where:

 

  • Inhibin is produced by the gonads (Sertoli cells in males and granulosa cells in females)
  • It specifically inhibits FSH secretion from the anterior pituitary
  • This creates a negative feedback loop that helps regulate FSH levels

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Estrogen Incorrect because estrogen is stimulated by FSH, not the other way around. FSH stimulates estrogen production from ovarian follicles.

 

Option C. Progesterone Incorrect because progesterone doesn't directly inhibit FSH. While progesterone can affect the hypothalamic-pituitary axis, it's not the primary inhibitor of FSH.

 

Option D. Testosterone Incorrect because testosterone doesn't directly inhibit FSH. While testosterone can affect the hypothalamic-pituitary axis through negative feedback, it's not the primary inhibitor of FSH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Inhibin is the primary and specific inhibitor of FSH secretion from the anterior pituitary gland.

questions.text: A patient with the respiratory difficulty and had a history of Chronic smoking. His pulmonary function testing showed decrease FEV1 %. What is the most probable diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) COPD

 

Explanation: 

 

This case presents a classic presentation of COPD with several key diagnostic features:

 

  • History of smoking (major risk factor)
  • Progressive dyspnea and chronic cough (typical symptoms)
  • PFT findings showing: 
    • Decreased FEV1 and FEV1/FVC ratio <70% (diagnostic criteria for airflow obstruction/Obstructive disease)
    • Fixed obstruction with minimal bronchodilator response(distinguishes from asthma very good improvement in FEV1) .
    • According to GOLD criteria, post-bronchodilator FEV1/FVC ratio <70% confirms the presence of persistent airflow limitation and COPD diagnosis in patients with appropriate symptoms and risk factors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pulmonary fibrosis: Incorrect because pulmonary fibrosis shows a restrictive pattern on PFTs with FEV1/FVC ratio >70% and reduced total lung capacity, not an obstructive pattern as seen here.

 

Option C. Interstitial lung disease (ILD): Incorrect because like pulmonary fibrosis, ILD demonstrates a restrictive pattern on PFTs, not obstruction. ILD would show decreased lung volumes with preserved FEV1/FVC ratio.

 

Option D. Asthma: Incorrect because although asthma can show decreased FEV1 and FEV1/FVC ratio, it typically demonstrates significant bronchodilator reversibility (>12% and >200mL improvement in FEV1), which is not seen in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diagnostic criteria for COPD: post-bronchodilator FEV1/FVC ratio <70% with minimal bronchodilator response in a patient with risk factors and appropriate symptoms.

questions.text: Test results of a hypertensive patient shows Hypernatremia, hypokalemia, alkalosis. What is the most probable diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Conn's Syndrome

 

Explanation: 

 

Conn's syndrome (primary hyperaldosteronism) is characterized by autonomous aldosterone secretion causing:

 

  • Hypernatremia due to increased Na+ reabsorption
  • Hypokalemia due to increased K+ excretion
  • Metabolic alkalosis due to increased H+ secretion and HCO3- reabsorption
  • Hypertension due to Na+ and water retention

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Addison's disease - Incorrect because:

 

  • Characterized by aldosterone deficiency leading to hyponatremia, hyperkalemia and metabolic acidosis
  • Presents with hypotension, not hypertension

 

Option C. Diabetes Insipidus - Incorrect because:

 

  • Primarily affects water balance causing hypernatremia but without significant effects on K+ or acid-base balance
  • No direct effect on blood pressure

 

Option D. Cushing's disease - Incorrect because:

 

  • While it can cause hypertension, the primary abnormalities are related to excess cortisol
  • Does not typically cause significant electrolyte disturbances like hypokalemia

 

Educational Objective:

 

Primary hyperaldosteronism (Conn's syndrome) presents with the triad of:

 

  • Hypernatremia
  • Hypokalemia
  • Metabolic alkalosis Along with hypertension due to mineralocorticoid excess.

questions.text: A patient experienced difficulty switching from one movement to another, along with uncontrollable hand movements. Identify the abnormality: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dysdiadochokinesia

 

Explanation: 

 

Dysdiadochokinesia refers to the inability to perform rapid alternating movements smoothly and refers to cerebellar dysfunction. From the clinical presentation described - difficulty switching movements and uncontrollable hand movements - this is a classic case of dysdiadochokinesia. 

 

  • Di: two
  • Docho: alternate
  • Kinesis: movement 

 

This is one of the key signs of cerebellar disease, specifically affecting the coordination of voluntary movements.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Intentional tremor: This occurs when a patient is performing a purposeful action and gets worse as they approach the target. 

 

Option C. Metamorphosis: This is seen in lesions of the amygdala or temporal lobe and refers to an uncontrollable urge to respond to every stimulus. It's not related to movement disorders.

 

Option D. Resting tremor: This is primarily seen in Parkinson's disease and occurs when the affected body part is at rest. 

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Dysdiadochokinesia is a cerebellar sign characterized by inability to perform rapid alternating movements smoothly.

questions.text: A renal biopsy of a patient is shown below. Identify the cells marked in the given histological image: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Macula densa

 

Explanation: 

 

"These which are marked with the green color they are nothing but inside the tubule which must be the end part of the ascending membrane group of Henle or the beginning of DCT. It is none other than macula densa cells, which act as key sensors in the nephron, sensing sodium (Na⁺) and chloride (Cl⁻) levels. Macula densa cells are columnar epithelial cells that act as chemosensors for Na+ and Cl-

 

  • They are part of the juxtaglomerular apparatus (JGA)
  • They are located in the distal tubule where it contacts the afferent arteriole
  • They play a crucial role in tubuloglomerular feedback

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. JG cells: Incorrect because JG cells are modified smooth muscle cells located in the wall of the afferent arteriole.

 

Option C. Lacis cells: Incorrect because Lacis cells (also called extraglomerular mesangial cells) are located between the afferent and efferent arterioles and have a supportive function.

 

Option D. Podocytes: Incorrect because Podocytes are specialized epithelial cells that form the visceral layer of Bowman's capsule and play a role in filtration barrier formation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Macula densa cells are specialized columnar epithelial cells located in the distal tubule, forming part of the juxtaglomerular apparatus (JGA). They function as chemosensors, detecting sodium (Na⁺) and chloride (Cl⁻) levels and regulating tubuloglomerular feedback to maintain glomerular filtration rate (GFR).

questions.text: A factory worker is exposed to phosphine gas during a pesticide fumigation process. He develops nausea, vomiting, dyspnea, and hypotension. Phosphine gas primarily causes which type of hypoxia? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Histotoxic

 

Explanation:

 

Phosphine gas causes histotoxic hypoxia by inhibiting cytochrome oxidase activity in the tissues. This leads to:

 

  • Decreased oxygen uptake by the tissues
  • Reduced mitochondrial function
  • Inability of cells to utilize available oxygen
  • Normal oxygen content in blood but tissues cannot use it
  • Results in cellular hypoxia despite adequate oxygen delivery

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anaemic Hypoxia: Incorrect

 

  • Occurs due to reduced oxygen-carrying capacity of blood
  • Normal alveolar oxygen but reduced hemoglobin or abnormal hemoglobin
  • Examples: Anemia, CO poisoning, methemoglobinemia
  • Not relevant here as phosphine doesn't affect hemoglobin

 

Option B. Hypoxic Hypoxia: Incorrect

 

  • Results from low atmospheric partial pressure of oxygen
  • Reduced oxygen gradient towards alveoli and pulmonary capillaries
  • Examples: High altitude, diffusion disorders, fibrosis
  • Phosphine doesn't affect atmospheric or alveolar oxygen levels

 

Option D. Stagnant Hypoxia: Incorrect

 

  • Due to reduced blood flow/circulation
  • Normal atmospheric oxygen, alveoli, and hemoglobin
  • Occurs in circulatory failure
  • Phosphine primarily affects cellular oxygen utilization, not circulation

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phosphine gas causes histotoxic hypoxia by inhibiting cytochrome oxidase in the mitochondria, preventing cellular oxygen utilization despite normal oxygen delivery to tissues.

questions.text: A patient presents with linear nodular lesions extending along the lymphatic drainage after sustaining a rose thorn injury. Examination reveals a chain of linear subcutaneous granulomas. What is the most likely causative organism? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sporothrix schenckii

 

A history of a rose thorn prick followed by linear subcutaneous granulomas is highly suggestive of Sporotrichosis also known as "rose gardener's disease."which is caused by Sporothrix schenckii. This is a dimorphic fungus commonly associated with gardening injuries, particularly from rose thorns. The infection typically follows a lymphocutaneous spread, forming a chain of nodules along lymphatic drainage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chromoblastomycosis: Characterized by chronic verrucous skin lesions and copper-colored sclerotic bodies (Medlar bodies) in tissue, typically due to traumatic implantation of fungi.

 

Option C. Nocardia: Causes cutaneous or pulmonary nocardiosis, which often presents with abscess formation but does not follow a linear spread along lymphatics.

 

Option D. Blastomyces: Causes Blastomycosis, a systemic fungal infection that primarily affects the lungs and disseminates to the skin and bones but does not present with lymphocutaneous nodular spread.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sporotrichosis, caused by Sporothrix schenckii, is a subcutaneous fungal infection commonly acquired through traumatic inoculation, such as a rose thorn prick. It presents as lymphocutaneous nodular lesions that spread along lymphatics in a linear pattern. Diagnosis is confirmed by culture on Sabouraud’s agar, and treatment is typically oral itraconazole for mild cases or amphotericin B for severe infections.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male with a history of diabetes mellitus presents with persistent weight loss, night sweats, and productive cough for the past two months. Which medium is most appropriate for isolating the causative organism? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lowenstein-Jensen (LJ) medium

 

The patient's presentation strongly suggests pulmonary tuberculosis (TB) based on:

 

  • Classic symptoms: persistent weight loss, night sweats, productive cough
  • Risk factor: diabetes mellitus (immunocompromised state)
  • Duration: symptoms lasting for two months (chronic course)

 

Mycobacterium tuberculosis, the causative organism, requires special culture media because:

 

  • It does not grow on ordinary culture media
  • It is a slow-growing organism requiring enriched media
  • It needs specific nutrients and pH conditions for growth

 

Lowenstein-Jensen (LJ) medium is the gold standard for TB culture because:

 

  • It is an egg-based enriched medium containing glycerol and asparagine
  • Provides optimal nutrients for mycobacterial growth
  • Contains malachite green that inhibits other bacteria
  • Allows for characteristic colony formation (rough, buff-colored colonies)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Loeffler serum slope (LSS):

 

  • Incorrect because:
  • Used primarily for Corynebacterium diphtheriae isolation

 

Option B. MacConkey agar:

 

  • Incorrect because:
  • Used for differentiating lactose-fermenting from non-lactose fermenting gram-negative bacteria

 

Option C. Tinsdale medium:

 

  • Incorrect because:
  • Used specifically for Corynebacterium diphtheriae isolation as it allows the formation of characteristic black colonies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lowenstein-Jensen (LJ) medium is the standard culture medium for isolating Mycobacterium tuberculosis from clinical specimens, as it provides the necessary enriched environment and selective conditions for optimal growth of this slow-growing organism.

 

 

CULTURE CHARACTERISTICS OF MYCOBACTERIUM TUBERCULOSIS

questions.text: A 67-year-old female with a history of diabetes mellitus underwent a prosthetic valve replacement surgery 4 weeks ago. She now presents with fever, fatigue, and a new murmur on examination. Blood cultures reveal the causative organism. Which is the most likely causative agent? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Staph epidermidis

 

This is a case of early prosthetic valve endocarditis (PVE) occurring within 4 weeks of valve replacement surgery. Staphylococcus epidermidis is the most common causative organism in early PVE, characterized by its occurrence within one year of surgery. The mnemonic "E for Early, E for Epidermidis" helps remember this association. Additionally, S. epidermidis is also the overall most common cause of prosthetic valve endocarditis regardless of timing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Enterococcus: While it can cause endocarditis, it is not the most common cause of early prosthetic valve endocarditis. It is more commonly associated with nosocomial urinary tract infections.

 

Option C. Staphylococcus aureus: S. aureus commonly seen in native valve endocarditis, particularly in patients with underlying valve disease.

 

Option D. Streptococcus viridans: This organism is typically associated with late prosthetic valve endocarditis (occurring after one year of valve replacement).

 

Educational Objective:

 

 Staphylococcus epidermidis is the most common causative organism in early prosthetic valve endocarditis (occurring within one year of valve replacement) and is also the overall most common cause of prosthetic valve endocarditis.

questions.text: A student consumed fried rice and presented shortly after with nausea and vomiting. What is the most likely causative organism? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bacillus cereus

 

The key clinical presentation here is the rapid onset of symptoms ("shortly after") following consumption of fried rice. Bacillus cereus causes two types of food poisoning: an emetic (vomiting) type and a diarrheal type. The emetic type, which is what we see in this case, has a very short incubation period of 1-4 hours and is commonly associated with consumption of fried rice. The bacteria produce a heat-stable toxin called cereulide that causes the rapid onset of nausea and vomiting.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Escherichia coli: Escherichia coli typically causes symptoms after 24-72 hours and is more commonly associated with undercooked meat or contaminated water

 

Option C. Neisseria species: Neisseria species are not typically food-borne pathogens and are instead associated with meningitis and gonorrhea

 

Option D. Clostridium species: Clostridium species (like C. perfringens) typically have longer incubation periods (8-16 hours) and cause primarily diarrheal illness

 

Educational Objective:

 

 Bacillus cereus food poisoning presenting with rapid onset nausea and vomiting (1-4 hours) after consuming fried rice is a classic presentation that must be recognized for proper diagnosis and management.

questions.text: A firefighter with a history of smoke inhalation presents with fever, cough, and signs of lung consolidation. Sputum culture reveals colonies with a green pigment and fluorescence under UV light. Which organism is most likely? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pseudomonas aeruginosa

 

The key diagnostic features here are the green pigment (pyocyanin) and fluorescence under UV light, which are characteristic of Pseudomonas aeruginosa. Pyocyanin is a diffusible pigment that gives colonies their distinctive green color. The history of smoke inhalation is also relevant as P. aeruginosa commonly causes opportunistic infections in damaged airways.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Streptococcus pneumoniae: Streptococcus pneumoniae produces alpha-hemolytic colonies without pigment or fluorescence

 

Option B. Klebsiella pneumoniae: Klebsiella pneumoniae produces mucoid colonies without pigment or fluorescence

 

Option C. Staphylococcus aureus: Staphylococcus aureus produces golden-yellow colonies without fluorescence

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pseudomonas aeruginosa's characteristic laboratory features: green pigment (pyocyanin) production and fluorescence under UV light, particularly in the context of respiratory infections following airway damage.

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant presents with a history of a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), sensorineural hearing loss. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Congenital rubella

 

The classic triad of congenital rubella syndrome (CRS) includes:

 

  • Patent ductus arteriosus (cardiac defect)
  • Sensorineural hearing loss (auditory defect)
  • Cataract/salt and pepper retinopathy (ocular defect)

 

The presence of PDA and sensorineural hearing loss strongly suggests congenital rubella infection. This occurs when a pregnant woman contracts rubella virus during pregnancy, particularly in the first trimester when organogenesis is occurring.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Congenital cytomegalovirus (CMV): Though it can cause sensorineural hearing loss, it typically presents with microcephaly, periventricular calcifications, and hepatosplenomegaly rather than PDA.

 

Option C. Congenital toxoplasmosis: Classical features include hydrocephalus, intracranial calcifications, and chorioretinitis. PDA is not a typical finding.

 

Option D. Congenital herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection: Usually presents with vesicular skin lesions, encephalitis, and keratoconjunctivitis. PDA and hearing loss are not typical features.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Congenital rubella syndrome is characterized by the triad of 

 

  • Patent ductus arteriosus (cardiac defect)
  • Sensorineural hearing loss (auditory defect)
  • Cataract/salt and pepper retinopathy (ocular defect)

questions.text: A 30-year-old sexually active female presents with painful genital ulcers on her vulva and bilateral painful inguinal lymphadenopathy. The ulcers have irregular edges and a soft base. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chancroid

 

The clinical presentation strongly suggests chancroid, caused by Haemophilus ducreyi. Key features include:

 

  • Painful genital ulcers
  • Irregular edges with soft base
  • Painful bilateral inguinal lymphadenopathy 
  • These ulcers are typically single rather than multiple, and they have irregular edges with a soft base rather than being fluid-filled.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Syphilis: Presents with painless ulcer (chancre) and non-tender lymphadenopathy

 

Option C. LGV: Causes painless ulcers with painful lymphadenopathy (buboes)

 

Option D. Genital herpes: Typically presents with multiple, fluid-filled vesicular lesions rather than ulcers with irregular edges

 

Educational Objective:

 

 Chancroid presents with painful genital ulcers having irregular edges and soft base, accompanied by painful bilateral inguinal lymphadenopathy.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents to follow-up after being treated for typhoid fever. His Laboratory findings reveal a Widal test with O antigen titer >1:20, H antigen titer >1:320, HA titer >1:20, and BH titer >1:20. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Recovery

 

In the Widal test, the O antigen titer is expected to be >1:100 in acute infection, while the H antigen titer >1:200 suggests a recent or past infection. Here, the O antigen is low (1:20) while H antigen is high (1:320), indicating that the patient is in the recovery phase rather than acute infection

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute infection: Would show high O antigen titers as O antigen rises early in infection

 

Option B. Chronic infection: Both O and H titers would be low/flat

 

Option C. Past infection: Both O and H titers would be low/flat

 

Educational Objective:

 

In enteric fever recovery phase, O antigen titers fall while H antigen titers remain elevated before gradually declining.

questions.text: A 3-week-old infant presents with seizures, hydrocephalus, and bilateral cataracts. The mother reports a febrile illness during the first trimester of pregnancy. Imaging reveals intracranial calcifications. What is the most likely causative organism? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Toxoplasma gondii

 

The clinical presentation strongly suggests congenital toxoplasmosis caused by Toxoplasma gondii. The classic triad of congenital toxoplasmosis includes:

 

  • Hydrocephalus
  • Intracranial calcifications
  • Chorioretinitis/cataracts

 

The history of maternal febrile illness during the first trimester is significant, as this is when the fetus is most vulnerable to congenital infections. T. gondii is an obligate intracellular parasite that can cross the placenta and cause severe damage to the developing fetal nervous system.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cytomegalovirus (CMV): While CMV can cause congenital infections, its classic presentation includes microcephaly rather than hydrocephalus, and hepatosplenomegaly is more common.

 

Option C. Herpes simplex virus (HSV): Typically presents with vesicular skin lesions and encephalitis in neonates. Transmission usually occurs during delivery rather than in the first trimester.

 

Option D. Rubella virus: Though it can cause congenital defects, its classic triad includes cataracts, deafness, and cardiac defects (particularly patent ductus arteriosus).

 

Educational Objective:

 

The classic triad of congenital toxoplasmosis: hydrocephalus, intracranial calcifications, and chorioretinitis/cataracts.

questions.text: A male patient presents with recurrent upper respiratory tract infections (URTI). Laboratory evaluation reveals low immunoglobulin levels, with IgG antibodies absent. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bruton's agammaglobulinemia

 

The presentation strongly suggests Bruton's agammaglobulinemia, characterized by:

 

  • Male patient (X-linked condition)
  • Recurrent upper respiratory infections
  • Absence of IgG antibodies (agammaglobulinemia)
  • B-cell deficiency due to BTK gene mutation

 

This condition can be remembered by the "B's":

 

  • Boys (male patients)
  • B-cells affected
  • BTK gene mutation

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Severe Combined Immunodeficiency (SCID): Affects both T and B cells, presents earlier in life with more severe manifestations including opportunistic infections.

 

Option C. Common Variable Immunodeficiency (CVID): Usually presents later in life and affects both males and females. Has variable immunoglobulin levels rather than complete absence.

 

Option D. Transient hypogammaglobulinemia of infancy: Temporary condition that resolves by age 2, with less severe manifestations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bruton's agammaglobulinemia as an X-linked condition characterized by absent B cells, agammaglobulinemia, and recurrent infections in male patients.

questions.text: A 42-year-old patient with HIV and a CD4 count of 50 cells/µL presents with severe headache, altered mental status, and impaired consciousness. CSF examination using India ink preparation reveals encapsulated yeast cells. Which organism is most likely responsible? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cryptococcus neoformans

 

This is a classic presentation of cryptococcal meningitis in an HIV patient with:

 

  • Advanced HIV (CD4 count <50 cells/µL)
  • Neurological symptoms (headache, altered mental status)
  • Positive India ink preparation showing encapsulated yeast cells
  • CSF involvement

 

Cryptococcus neoformans is an encapsulated yeast that commonly causes meningitis in immunocompromised patients, particularly those with HIV/AIDS and CD4 counts below 100 cells/µL.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Candida albicans: Rarely causes meningitis, and when it does, it's not visualized with India ink preparation.

 

Option B. Histoplasma capsulatum: Though it can cause systemic infection in HIV patients, it's not typically seen as encapsulated yeast in CSF and isn't visualized with India ink.

 

Option D. Candida tropicalis: Like C. albicans, it rarely causes meningitis and isn't visualized with India ink preparation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cryptococcus neoformans as the cause of meningitis in HIV patients with low CD4 counts, diagnosed by India ink preparation showing encapsulated yeasts in CSF.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man presents with a two-week history of headache, fever, and neck stiffness. His cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis shows increased opening pressure and positive India ink staining for encapsulated yeast. What is the recommended treatment? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Amphotericin B (AMB) + Flucytosine

 

The clinical presentation and CSF findings are consistent with cryptococcal meningitis caused by Cryptococcus neoformans. The positive India ink staining revealing encapsulated yeast cells is diagnostic. For complicated cases involving CNS infection, the recommended first-line treatment is combination therapy with Amphotericin B and Flucytosine. This combination provides synergistic antifungal activity and better penetration into the CNS.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fluconazole: While fluconazole can be used for uncomplicated cryptococcal infections or as maintenance therapy, it is not the first-line treatment for cryptococcal meningitis.

 

Option B. Amphotericin B: Although effective, monotherapy with Amphotericin B is less effective than combination therapy.

 

Option D. Fluconazole + Amphotericin B: This combination is not the standard recommended therapy for cryptococcal meningitis.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The recommended first-line treatment for cryptococcal meningitis is combination therapy with Amphotericin B and Flucytosine.

choices.text: Blocks the release of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with blurred vision, dry mouth, and progressive muscle weakness after consuming improperly canned food. The symptoms are attributed to a neurotoxin. What is the mechanism of action of Clostridium botulinum toxin? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Blocks the release of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction


Clostridium botulinum produces a potent neurotoxin that specifically blocks the release of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction. This blockage prevents muscle contraction, resulting in flaccid paralysis. The classic symptoms include blurred vision, dry mouth, and descending muscle weakness due to the toxin's effect on cholinergic synapses.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Inhibits acetylcholine receptors: The toxin does not inhibit receptors but blocks neurotransmitter release. 

 

Option B. Inhibits GABA release: Botulinum toxin specifically affects acetylcholine, not GABA.

 

Option D. Increases EF-2 activity: This is not the mechanism of botulinum toxin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 Botulinum toxin causes flaccid paralysis by blocking the release of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction.

questions.text: A farmer presents with fever, muscle pain, and jaundice after working in flooded fields. Laboratory tests reveal a positive microscopic agglutination test. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Leptospirosis

 

The clinical presentation and exposure history are classic for leptospirosis. The key diagnostic findings include:

 

  • Occupational exposure (farmer working in flooded fields)
  • Classic triad of fever, muscle pain, and jaundice
  • Positive microscopic agglutination test (MAT), which is the gold standard diagnostic test for leptospirosis

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Syphilis: Diagnosed using different serological tests, not MAT.

 

Option B. Mycobacterium infection: Does not typically present with acute jaundice and is not diagnosed using MAT. 

 

Option C. Bacillus infection: Not associated with exposure to flooded fields or diagnosed using MAT.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Microscopic agglutination test (MAT) is the gold standard diagnostic test for leptospirosis, which typically occurs after exposure to contaminated water or soil.

questions.text: A 45-year-old forest ranger presents with sudden onset high fever, severe headache, and a characteristic rash that began on his trunk and spread to his extremities suspecting typhus (rickettsial) infection, a Weil-Felix test is performed using Proteus antigens. What type of antigen is used in this test? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Heterophile antigen

 

The Weil-Felix test uses Proteus antigens to diagnose rickettsial infections because Proteus shares epitopes with Rickettsia. These shared epitopes allow antibodies produced against rickettsial antigens to cross-react with Proteus antigens. This type of cross-reactivity between antigens from different species is called heterophile antigenicity.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Isoantigen: Refers to antigens that are identical within the same species. 

 

Option B. Superantigen: These are antigens that cause non-specific T-cell activation. 

 

Option D. Sequestered antigen: These are normally hidden from the immune system.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Heterophile antigens are antigens from different species that share epitopes, allowing cross-reactivity in diagnostic tests like the Weil-Felix test.

questions.text: A 32-year-old healthcare worker presents with fatigue, low-grade fever, and mild right upper quadrant discomfort for the past 2 weeks. He reports a needlestick injury 3 months ago while drawing blood from a patient with unknown hepatitis status. Physical examination reveals mild icterus and tender hepatomegaly. Laboratory investigations show elevated ALT and AST levels. Serological testing shows the presence of HBsAg and IgM anti-HBc. What does the presence of IgM anti-HBc indicate? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Acute infection

 

IgM anti-HBc indicates acute hepatitis B infection. The presence of IgM antibodies generally indicates recent or ongoing infection in any disease, and hepatitis B is no exception. When combined with elevated liver enzymes (ALT and AST) and HBsAg, this pattern is diagnostic of acute hepatitis B infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Carrier: Carriers typically have HBsAg but negative IgM anti-HBc.

 

Option B. Chronic infection: Chronic infection is characterized by HBsAg persistence and IgG (not IgM) anti-HBc.

 

Option D. Supercarrier: This is not a standard medical term in hepatitis B infection classification.

 

Educational Objective:

 

IgM anti-HBc is the key serological marker for diagnosing acute hepatitis B infection, especially when accompanied by HBsAg and elevated liver enzymes.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with painful vesicular lesions on her lips. A Tzanck smear from the lesions shows multinucleated giant cells. What is the most likely causative agent? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Herpes simplex virus (HSV)

 

HSV is the causative agent in this case, as evidenced by the characteristic painful vesicular lesions on the lips and the presence of multinucleated giant cells on Tzanck smear. HSV typically causes painful, fluid-filled vesicles that can occur on the lips (usually HSV-1) or genitals (usually HSV-2). The Tzanck smear finding of multinucleated giant cells is pathognomonic for herpes virus infections.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Epstein-Barr virus (EBV): Typically causes mononucleosis with systemic symptoms and doesn't cause vesicular lesions on the lips.

 

Option C. Cytomegalovirus (CMV): Usually causes systemic infection in immunocompromised patients and doesn't typically cause oral lesions.

 

Option D. Human papillomavirus (HPV): Causes warts and papillomas, not vesicular lesions. It also doesn't show multinucleated giant cells on Tzanck smear.

 

Educational Objective:

 

HSV infection is characterized by painful vesicular lesions and the presence of multinucleated giant cells on Tzanck smear, which is a key diagnostic feature.

questions.text: A guy gets beaten up by 4-5 people and comes to the hospital with serious injuries. He decides to give a dying declaration. Which of the following is true for a dying declaration in India? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Oath not taken

 

Explanation:

 

A dying declaration is the statement made by a person on their deathbed regarding the cause of their death or the circumstances leading to it. In India, it holds significant evidentiary value in a court of law. The aspects of a dying declaration include:

 

  • Oath is not taken: Unlike a court deposition where witnesses take an oath before testifying, a dying declaration does not require an oath. This is because the fundamental assumption is that a dying person is unlikely to lie.
  • Anyone can record it: Although a magistrate is preferred, if the victim is in a critical condition and a magistrate is unavailable, a doctor, police officer, or any responsible person can record the statement.
  • No cross-examination: Unlike a dying deposition, a dying declaration is a direct statement of the victim and is not subjected to cross-examination.
  • Leading questions are not allowed: The person recording the dying declaration should only document what the victim states, without suggesting or influencing their answers.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Only a magistrate can record:  Incorrect While a magistrate is preferred, anyone, including a doctor or police officer, can record a dying declaration if necessary​

 

Option C. Presence of a defense lawyer is required: Incorrect Unlike a formal dying deposition, where legal procedures like cross-examination apply, a dying declaration does not require the presence of a defense lawyer

​

Option D. Leading questions are asked: Incorrect Leading questions (which suggest an answer) are not allowed while recording a dying declaration. The statement must be made voluntarily and without external influence​ 

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A female died due to unnatural causes within 7 years of marriage with an allegation of dowry. The inquest will be done under which section? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 196 BNSS and 176 CrPC

 

Explanation:

 

A dowry death refers to the death of a woman within 7 years of marriage under unnatural circumstances, and where there is an allegation of dowry related harassment. In such cases, a Magistrate inquest is mandatory instead of a regular police inquest. It is conducted under 196 BNSS (Previously 176 CrPC)

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 194 BNSS and 174 CrPC : Incorrect. These section deal with Police inquest, which is not applicable in dowry deaths. 

 

Option C. 196 BNS and 176 IPC: Incorrect. BNS (Bhartiya Nyaya Sanhita) deals with substantive criminal law (formerly IPC), whereas inquests fall under BNSS (earlier CrPC). Hence, this option is incorrect.

 

Option D. 194 BNS and 174 IPC: Incorrect. BNS (Bhartiya Nyaya Sanhita) deals with substantive criminal law (formerly IPC), whereas inquests fall under BNSS (earlier CrPC). Hence, this option is incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A dowry death (unnatural death within 7 years of marriage with a dowry allegation) requires a Magistrate inquest under 196 BNSS (earlier 176 CrPC), rather than a police inquest​. 

 

Types of inquest are as follows:

 

1) Police Inquest: Conducted under 194 BNSS. This is the most common inquest in India, and the minimum rank of a police officer to conduct it is Head Constable.

 

2) Magistrate Inquest: Conducted under 196 BNSS. It is carried out in specific circumstances, such as:

 

  • Dowry deaths (death within seven years of marriage and related to dowry).
  • Exhumation (digging out buried bodies, performed by an Executive Magistrate).
  • Deaths in Judicial Custody (e.g. police custody, jail, rehabilitation homes, etc.).

  • Any other situation where a magistrate believes the police inquest was insufficient (e.g.  family requests a magistrate-led inquest)

     

3) Coroner's Inquest: Not conducted in India, but in the UK, it is done by judicial officers.

 

4) Medical Examiner System: Not present in India but used in the USA, where doctors conduct the inquest, considered the most comprehensive method.

choices.text: Family is not satisfied with police

questions.text: In which condition both police and magistrate can do the inquest, but magistrate inquest will be preferred? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Family is not satisfied with police

 

Explanation:

 

An inquest is a legal investigation into the cause of death. In India, inquests are generally conducted under BNSS (formerly CrPC). Two types of inquests exist:

 

  1. Police Inquest (194 BNSS, earlier 174 CrPC):
    • Conducted by the police officer (minimum rank: Head Constable).
    • Most commonly used in cases of unnatural death (e.g., accidents, suicides, homicides).
  2. Magistrate Inquest (196 BNSS, earlier 176 CrPC):
    • Conducted by an Executive or Judicial Magistrate.
    • Mandatory in special cases such as:
      • Dowry Deaths
      • Custodial Deaths
      • Exhumation (digging out a buried body)
      • However, apart from above, in any case where usually the inquest is done by police, if a magistrate believes the police inquest was insufficient (e.g.  family requests a magistrate-led inquest), the magistrate can do additional inquest 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Death in police custody: Incorrect

 

  • Only a Magistrate inquest is allowed (196 BNSS, earlier 176 CrPC).

  • Police cannot conduct an inquest in custodial deaths

    ​

Option C. Dowry death: Incorrect

 

  • Only a Magistrate inquest is allowed (196 BNSS, earlier 176 CrPC).
  • Dowry deaths must be investigated by a Magistrate, not the police

 

Option D. Death by firing: Incorrect

 

  • Only a Police inquest is done (194 BNSS, earlier 174 CrPC).
  • A Magistrate inquest is not mandatory in cases of death by firing​

     

Educational Objective:

 

If the family is not satisfied with a police inquest, they can appeal for a Magistrate inquest, which will be preferred to ensure justice. However, custodial deaths and dowry deaths require mandatory Magistrate inquests, while deaths by firing are handled by police inquests​

questions.text: Leading questions can be allowed in? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cross Examination

 

Explanation:

 

Leading questions (questions whose answers can be given in yes/no format) are specifically allowed in:

 

  1. Cross examination
  2. Dying deposition
     For example: "Has Ram killed Shyam?" is a leading question, while "Who killed Shyam?" is not This restriction helps ensure unbiased testimony during direct examination and re-examination​

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Direct Examination: Incorrect. Leading questions are not allowed in direct examination unless a witness becomes hostile

​

Option C. Re-Direct Examination: Incorrect. Leading questions are not permitted unless required to clarify contradictions arising from cross-examination​

 

Option D. Any Time: Incorrect. Leading questions are not allowed freely in all legal proceedings. They are only allowed in cross-examination and dying depositions​

 

Educational Objective:

 

Leading questions 


Ans can be given in Yes/ No
E.g.,
Has Suresh killed Madan? – is a leading question 
Who killed Madan? - It is not a leading question
 

Leading Questions


When leading conditions can be asked

  1. Dying deposition 
  2. Cross examination 
  3. As an exception in Examination in chief if witness turns hostile

     

When leading questions cannot be asked 

  1. Dying declaration 
  2. Examination in chief 
  3. Re – examination

questions.text: A lady died under unnatural death within 3 years of marriage. Who will do the inquest? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Magistrate

 

Explanation:

 

Magistrate inquest is mandatory in cases of dowry death, which is defined as:

 

  • Death of a woman within 7 years of marriage
  • Death is unnatural
  • Death has association with dowry allegations This comes under Section 196 BNSS (previously 176 CrPC) and is one of the three specific conditions requiring magistrate inquest along with custodial deaths and exhumation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Police: Incorrect Police inquest (194 BNSS) is not permitted in dowry death cases due to their sensitive nature and to ensure impartial investigation.

 

Option C. Advocate: Incorrect Advocates are not authorized to conduct inquests. They may represent parties in legal proceedings but cannot conduct death investigations.

 

Option D. Coroner: Incorrect Coroner system is not practiced in India. It was previously followed in some cities like Mumbai but has been abolished. Coroner system is currently practiced in countries like UK and USA.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Attend the summon which was received earlier
Don't attend any court, inform both the courts and wait for second summon

questions.text: A forensic doctor is facing criminal charges for malpractice in a district criminal court and is also summoned to provide expert testimony in a district civil court for which he will be provided compensation. What is the correct statement in this scenario? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Attend Criminal Court

 

Explanation:


When receiving summons from multiple courts, the priority is determined by the following factors:

 

  1. Court Rank: Higher courts take precedence over lower courts.
  2. Case Type: Criminal cases are prioritized over civil cases.
    The ranking of the court is more significant than the type of case. For instance, if one summons is from a higher court for a civil case and another is from a lower court for a criminal case, the higher court should be attended.
  3. Timeliness: If both court rank and case type are the same, the court whose summons was received first should be attended.

 

In this case:

 

  • Both courts are of same rank (district court)
  • One case is criminal and other is civil
  • Criminal cases take precedence over civil cases even if compensation is offered

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Attend Civil Court: Incorrect. Even though compensation is offered, civil court attendance does not take precedence over criminal court when summons are received simultaneously.

 

Option C. Attend the summon which was received earlier: Incorrect. While timing of summons receipt is a criterion, it only applies when both courts are of same rank and type. Criminal cases take precedence regardless of when summons was received.

 

Option D. Don't attend any court, inform both the courts and wait for second summon: Incorrect. Ignoring court summons and waiting for second summons is not appropriate. One must attend according to the priority.

 

Educational Objective:


Order of Court Ranking (Highest to Lowest):

 

  1. Supreme Court & High Court
  2. Sessions Court / District Court / Additional Sessions Judge / Additional District Judge
  3. Assistant Sessions Judge
  4. Chief Judicial Magistrate (CJM) / Chief Metropolitan Magistrate (CMM)
  5. 1st Class Judicial Magistrate (JM) / Metropolitan Magistrate (MM)
  6. 2nd Class Judicial Magistrate (JM)

questions.text: A boy fell while playing and suffered an abrasion injury on his knees. The dark brown scab will be seen in how many days? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 4-7 days

 

Explanation:

 

Abrasions heal in a predictable manner, forming a scab due to drying of blood, serum, and tissue fluids. The color of the scab changes over time, providing a reliable estimate of injury duration:

 

Timeline of Scab Formation in Abrasions

 

  1. Day 1 (Fresh wound) → Bright red due to oozing blood & lymph.
  2. 12-24 hours → Reddish scab begins to form.
  3. 2-3 days → Reddish-brown scab develops.
  4. 4-7 days → Dark brown to black scab appears as the wound dries​
  5. >7 days → Scab begins to peel off, leaving a depigmented area that gradually fades.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Day 1:  Incorrect. Fresh abrasion will appear bright red with oozing blood and lymph, not a dark brown scab.

 

Option B. 2-3 days:  Incorrect. Scab forms but is reddish-brown, not dark brown.

 

Option D. >7 days:  Incorrect. By >7 days, the scab starts falling off, revealing new epithelium underneath.

 

Educational Objective:


Age of Abrasion

questions.text: Two friends were working together at a construction site. A hammer fell from one friend's hand and hit the other friend’s head. The X-ray revealed a fracture. What type of fracture is this? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Depressed Fracture

 

Explanation:

 

A depressed fracture occurs when a heavy object with a small surface area (such as a hammer) strikes the skull, causing the bone to get pushed inward.

 

Characteristics of a Depressed Fracture:

 

  • Caused by blunt force trauma with a small, focused impact area (e.g., hammer, stone, rod).
  • Bone fragments get displaced inwards, compressing brain tissue.
  • Visible on X-ray or CT scan as a concave depression in the skull bone.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Linear Fracture: Incorrect

 

  • Appears as a thin line without bone displacement.
  • Caused by broad-surface impact (e.g., falls, RTA).

  • Most common type of skull fracture but not caused by a hammer

     

Option C. Gutter Fracture:  Incorrect

 

  • Occurs when a bullet or projectile grazes the skull, forming a trough-like depression.

  • Not caused by a falling hammer

    ​

Option D. Ping Pong Fracture: Incorrect

 

  • Seen in infants due to the soft, elastic nature of their skulls.
  • Skull buckles inward without breaking (resembles a ping pong ball dent).

  • Not seen in adults or due to a hammer injury

    ​

Educational Objective:

 

Types of Skull Fractures

questions.text: A cephalic index of 82 belongs to which racial group? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mongoloid

 

Explanation:

 

Cephalic Index (CI) Formula:

 

Cephalic index =  (Maximum breadth of skull/Maximum length of skull) × 100 


Classification based on cephalic index:

 

  • Dolichocephalic (70-75): Found in Aryans, Negroes, Aborigines (ANA)
  • Mesaticephalic (75-80): Found in Europeans (Caucasians), Indians, Chinese
  • Brachycephalic (80-85): Found in Mongoloids 

 

A cephalic index of 82 falls in the brachycephalic range, which is characteristic of Mongoloid populations

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Negroid: Incorrect. Negroid skulls are Dolichocephalic (CI 70- 75), meaning they have a long, narrow skull

​

Option C. Caucasian: Incorrect. Caucasian skulls are Mesaticephalic (CI: 75-80), meaning they have a medium-sized skull

​

Option D. Chinese: Incorrect. Chinese skulls are Mesaticephalic (CI: 75-80), meaning they have a medium-sized skull

​

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A dead body was found with Rigor Mortis all over the body, including hands and feet. The body was cold to touch, and post-mortem lividity was fixed and present all over the dependent areas. What is the estimated time since death? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 12-24 hrs

 

Explanation:

 

Post-mortem interval (PMI), 

 

1. Rigor Mortis (Post-Mortem Stiffening)

 

  • Begins: 2 hours after death (first appears in Myocardium, then upper eyelids)
  • Developing Stage: 2 hrs- 12 hours after death (extends from upper parts of body to lower parts, with last in hands and feet).
  • Developed Stage: 12-24 hours after death (Remains fully developed in whole body)
  • Passing stage: 24-36 hours (it passes way in the same order as it developed, that is top to bottom) 

 

2. Post-Mortem Lividity (Livor Mortis)

 

  • Begins: 1 hours after death.
  • Fully develops: 6 hours after death.
  • Gets fixed: Between 8-12 hours after death (it no longer shifts if the body is moved).

 

3. Algor Mortis (Cooling of the Body)

 

  • Starts: 1 hours after death.
  • Fully cold to touch: 20 hours after death.

 

In this case:

 

  • Rigor Mortis is present all over the body, including hands and feet → At least 12 hours have passed.
  • Post-Mortem Lividity is fixed → At least 8 hours have passed.
  • Body is cold to touch → Since temperature is not given, so this information does not help much in getting time since death

 

Based on these findings, the minimum time since death is 12 hours. So it can be more than 12 hours but not less. Hence most appropriate answer is 12-24 hours

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1-2 hrs: Incorrect.

 

  • Rigor mortis does not develop fully within 1-2 hours; it takes at least 6-12 hours to be fully established.

 

Option B. 4-6 hrs: Incorrect.

 

  • Rigor mortis would only be developing, not fully spread to hands and feet.
  • Post-mortem lividity would not yet be fixed.

 

Option C. 6-12 hrs: Incorrect.

 

  • Rigor Mortis would still be in the developing stage.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

 

Sequence of Rigor Mortis (Nysten’s Rule)

questions.text: Corneal transplant is allowed until how much time after death? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 6 hours

 

Explanation:

 

  • While most organs can be transplanted, only while body is still on ventilator, and blood circulation is maintained, in case of cornea, the transplantation is possible even if a person is died at home because cornea is avascular (lacks blood supply) 
  • It Can be done up to 6 hours after death in India 
  • In western countries, can be extended up to 12 hours 
  • Time limit is shorter in India due to tropical climate causing faster decomposition 
  • Other organs require continuous blood supply and must be harvested while patient is on ventilator 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1 hour: Incorrect. Corneas do not deteriorate this quickly and can be used for transplantation for several hours post-mortem.

 

Option B. 2 hours: Incorrect. The minimum accepted timeframe is up to 6 hours, not just 2 hours.

 

Option C. 4 hours: Incorrect. Though corneal tissue remains viable for more than 4 hours, the standard practice extends the limit up to 6 hours in India.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A corneal transplant can be performed within 6 hours after death because the cornea is avascular and does not deteriorate as rapidly as other organs​

questions.text: A person was stabbed in the thigh by a knife, with a wound measuring 1×3×5 cm. What kind of wound is this? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Penetration

 

Explanation:

 

A wound is classified based on depth, entry and exit points, and the type of weapon used.

 

In this stab wound:

 

  • Depth (5 cm) > length (3 cm) > width (1 cm)
  • Penetrates deep into tissue
  • No exit wound mentioned 
  • Penetrating: Extends deep into cavity/tissue without exit
  • Perforating: Has both entry and exit wounds
  • Puncture: Only involves superficial tissues 

 

Types of stab wounds based on depth:

 

This case shows penetrating wound as it's deep (5 cm) but doesn't exit the body

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Perforating Wound: Incorrect

 

  • Involves both entry and exit wounds.
  • Example: A stab wound passing through the body and weapon coming out from other side.
  • Here, no exit wound is mentioned, ruling out this option.

 

Option C. Incision: Incorrect

 

  • Length is greater than depth (e.g., surgical cuts, knife slashes).
  • Here, depth (5 cm) is greater than length (1 cm), ruling out an incision.

 

Option D. Puncture Wound: Incorrect

 

  • Shallow depth, usually involving only the superficial layers.
  • Seen in  nail, or small pointed object injuries.
  • Here, the depth is significantly deep (5 cm), making it penetrating, not puncture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A penetrating wound is defined as a deep wound where depth > length, caused by sharp-pointed objects (e.g., knife, dagger, spear). A perforating wound would require both an entry and exit wound, which is not present here​

questions.text: A 1-year-old baby was brought to the hospital with burn injuries on the right side of the body, including the upper limb, chest, abdomen, and leg, mostly on the front. What is the estimated burn percentage? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 15-25%

 

Explanation:

 

To calculate the burn percentage in infants, the Lund & Browder chart is used.

 

  • In children surface area of Head is more, and  Lower limbs less as compared to adults:
    • Head is “18% - Age”; 
    • Each lower limb is “14% + (0.5 X Age)”
  • Above rule applicable till about 9 years of age (because after that almost similar to adults, so rule of 9 can be used)
  • Other Body Parts (Trunks, Upper limbs): same proportion of body in child as that of Adults
  • So in a 1 year child:
    • Head: 18%- 1= 17% (Front 8.5% + Back 8.5%)
    • Each Lower limb: 14% + 0.5 (1)= 14.5% (Front 7.25% + Back 7.25%) 
    • Chest: 18% (Front 9% + Back 9%): Same As Adults
    • Abdomen: 18% (Front 9% + Back 9%): Same As Adults
    • Each Upper limb: 9% (Front 4.5% + Back 4.5%): Same As Adults

    • Perinium: 1%: Same As Adults

       

Calculating Burn Area for the Right Side (Front Only) for a 1 year child

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 5-10% : Incorrect. The actual burn area is 17%, so this estimate is too low.

 

Option C. 25-35% : Incorrect. The actual burn area is 17%, so this estimate is high.

 

Option D. >50% : Incorrect. This would require extensive burns covering most of the body, which is not observed in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In infants, the burn percentage is calculated differently than in adults, using the Lund & Browder chart. In this case, burns affecting the only right side of body and only on front on upper limb, chest, abdomen, and leg contribute to 15-25% total body surface area (TBSA)​

questions.text: After a myocardial infarction (MI), staining was done using Triphenyl Tetrazolium Chloride (TTC) Most myocardial tissue got stained in brick red color, while some tissue remained pale. What is the minimum survival time required post MI for this color change to appear? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2-3 hours

 

Explanation:

 

The Triphenyl Tetrazolium Chloride (TTC) test is used to detect early myocardial infarction (MI) by staining viable cardiac tissue.

 

  • The minimum survival time required Post MI is generally around 12 hours for any  gross changes in the heart to be visible.
  • The minimum survival time required Post MI is generally around 6 hours for any  microscopic changes in the heart to be visible.

 

However, with the use of TTC staining, gross changes in the heart can be observed as early as 2-3 hours post-MI.

 

  • In normal tissue, mitochondrial enzymes such as dehydrogenases are present, which reduce TTC, resulting in a brick-red color.
  • In infarcted tissue, the infarcted area remains pale due to the absence of these mitochondrial enzymes, which are affected by the lack of blood supply.
