  • Complete mitochondrial enzyme death typically requires at least 2-3 hours of survival time, post-MI.

 

Other Option:

 

Option A. 1 hour: Incorrect. The TTC reaction typically requires at least 2-3 hours of survival time after MI for a clear distinction between infarcted and normal tissue to be visible.

 

Option C. 6-12 hours: Incorrect. While TTC can detect MI after 2-3 hours, the question specifically asks about the minimum time, not a broader window.

 

Option D. > 24 hours: Incorrect. The TTC test can detect MI much earlier than 24 hours. The question is asking about the minimum time needed for the color change to appear.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The TTC test is used to detect early MI. A brick-red color appears in viable myocardium, while the infarcted area remains pale after 2-3 hours post-MI. 

 

Note that some sources suggest a minimum survival time of 4 hours for TTC positivity instead of 2-3 hours.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic presents with hallucinations, seeing snakes, tremors, disorientation and inability to recognize his own family members, after cessation of alcohol for 2 days due to festive season. Diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Delirium Tremens

 

Explanation:


 The case presents classic features of delirium tremens:

  • Occurs after alcohol cessation in chronic alcoholics
  • Onset typically 2-3 days after stopping alcohol
  • Symptoms include: 
    • Visual hallucinations 
    • Tremors
    • Disorientation
    • Confusion and inability to recognize family
  • It's a withdrawal symptom of alcohol

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Wernicke's Encephalopathy Incorrect: Wernicke's encephalopathy is not a withdrawal symptom but results from thiamine deficiency, characterized by:

 

  • Global confusion
  • Ophthalmoplegia
  • Ataxia ("GOA" triad)

 

Option C. Korsakoff psychosis Incorrect: Korsakoff psychosis presents with:

 

  • Amnesia
  • Confabulation
  • No visual hallucinations

 

Option D. Alcoholic Hallucinosis Incorrect: Alcoholic hallucinosis presents with:

 

  • Only auditory hallucinations
  • Noother symptoms occur as mentioned in the question

 

Educational Objective:

 

Symptoms After Cessation of Alcohol Intake

questions.text: A young male patient, aged 20, presents with increasing localized pain that developed gradually over time. Imaging via X-ray revealed sunray appearance. What is the most probable diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Osteosarcoma 

 

  • Osteosarcoma is the most common primary malignant bone tumor, accounting for approximately 20% of all cases. 
  • It most commonly occurs in the extremities. 
  • Approximately 75% of patients < 25 years of age; the average at diagnosis is 20 years are affected.
  • High-grade conventional intramedullary osteosarcoma is the most common subtype. 
  • It is a biologically complex and aggressive tumor involving a long bone's metaphysis, usually adjacent to a physis with the most significant growth, such as the proximal humerus, distal femur, or proximal tibia.
  • It has a slightly increased incidence in males than females. 
  • High-grade intramedullary osteosarcoma comprises approximately 80% of all osteosarcomas; 42% occur in the femur, 19% in the tibia, and 10% in the humerus. 
  • Symptoms of may be present for a significant amount of time, sometimes weeks to months, before patients seek evaluation. 
  • Most commonly, the presenting symptom is bone pain, particularly with activity. 
  • A history of traumatic musculoskeletal injury may or may not be reported. 
  • Pain and swelling at the local site, usually at the growing ends of an extremity or long bones, are the most common presenting symptoms. 
  • Physical examination findings include:
    • A palpable, tender mass
    • Decreased range of motion of adjacent joint, with possible effusion
    • Pain on weight-bearing or inability to bear weight
    • Local or regional lymphadenopathy (unusual)
    • Respiratory findings with metastatic forms
  • Radiographs of the conventional osteosarcoma usually demonstrates medullary and cortical bone destruction with mixed lytic and blastic appearance.
  • High-grade osteosarcoma is often described as having a permeative or moth-eaten appearance with a "sunburst" configuration due to aggressive periostitis or "codman triangle" configuration due to elevation of the periosteum away from the bone.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ewing sarcoma: Ewing sarcoma is an aggressive tumor of adolescents and young adults. It is the second most common primary bone malignancy in adolescents and young adults with a median age of 15 years. Patients often present with local symptoms such as pain, stiffness, or swelling for a few weeks or months. More than 50% of patients have intermittent pain that worsens at night. It is commonly found in the diaphysis of long bones but can occur in different locations with varying presentations. Bone or metastatic lesions within the long bone can present as pathological fractures. The pelvic location of Ewing sarcoma can present as back pain. The presence of systemic symptoms, including fever and weight loss, often indicates metastatic disease. Plain radiographs of the affected area may show destructive confluent '' moth-eaten" lesions, "Codman triangle" of the elevated periosteum, or multilayered "onion-skin" periosteal reaction.

 

 

Option B. Gout: Gout is among the most prevalent etiologies of chronic inflammatory arthritis, characterized by monosodium urate (MSU) monohydrate crystals deposition within tissues. It is characterized biochemically by extracellular fluid urate saturation, which is reflected by hyperuricemia in the blood, with plasma or serum urate concentrations exceeding 6.8 mg/dL. The etiology of is usually multifactorial, including genetic predisposition, medical comorbidities, and dietary factors. Older age and male sex are the common risk factors. The initial manifestation is an acute attack of arthritis, usually monoarticular, marked by the abrupt onset of severe pain and swelling. Maximum inflammation occurs within 12-24 hours. Gout flares are typically monoarticular, with 85-90% occurring in the lower extremities. The first metatarsophalangeal joint is the most commonly involved. The talar, subtalar, ankle, and knee can also be involved. On physical examination, the affected joint is red, swollen, warm, and tender. Tophi, subcutaneous deposits of urate which form nodules, can be found in patients with persistent hyperuricemia. Radiographically, joints show joint effusion (earliest sign), preservation of joint space until late stages of the disease, absence of periarticular osteopenia, eccentric erosions, and “punched-out” erosions with sclerotic margins in a marginal and juxta-articular distribution, with overhanging edges. The bone mineralization is normal. 

 

 

Option D. Chondrosarcoma: Chondrosarcomas are malignant cartilaginous neoplasms that account for 20% of all primary malignant tumors of the bone. They usually arise in the pelvis or long bones. The majority of chondrosarcomas are sporadic, but they may develop from the malignant transformation of osteochondromas and enchondromas. Chondrosarcoma is a tumor of adulthood and older age. The majority of patients are older than 50 years of age, with a slight male predominance. The most common locations of involvement include the axial skeleton (pelvis, scapula, sternum, and ribs) followed by the proximal femur and proximal humerus. Involvement of the hands and feet is rare. Local swelling and pain are the most common presenting symptoms. The symptoms are usually of long duration (months to years). Plain radiography is used for initial evaluation as it allows the identification of the cartilaginous nature and the aggressiveness of the lesion. Plain x-rays may reveal lytic lesions in 50% cases, intralesional calcifications in 70% cases (popcorn calcification or rings and arcs calcification), endosteal scalloping, permeative or moth-eaten appearance in high-grade chondrosarcomas, and cortical remodeling, thickening, and periosteal reaction.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Osteosarcoma is the most common primary bone cancer, and it often presents in adolescents and young adults (like this 20-year-old patient). 
  • A "sunray appearance" on X-ray is a classic sign of osteosarcoma, where bony spicules radiate outward from the tumor.

questions.text: Which nerve is most likely affected, based on the hand posture shown in the image? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ulnar nerve

 

  • Claw Hand deformity is a condition where the fingers are bent into a position that looks like a claw. 
  • It may affect all of the fingers or only some of them depending on its cause. 
  • Claw Hand is a hand deformity with hyperextension of the MCP joints and flexion of the IP joints due to weakness of the intrinsic muscles of the hand. 
  • Claw Hand deformity can be complete when it involves all the digits due to both ulnar and median nerve palsy, or it can be incomplete/partial where it involves only ulnar 2 digits due to isolated ulnar nerve palsy.
  • Signs and Symptoms:
    • Muscle wasting of the interrosseous and hypothenar
    • Numbness along the nerve involved
    • Inability to extend the IP joints during extension of the fingers, to abduct and adduct fingers
    • Unopposed action of the extensors and the flexors digitorum profundus as the lumbricals of digits 4 and 5 are paralyzed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Median nerve: Compression, stretch, or traumatic disruption of the nerve may result in median nerve palsies. Most commonly, palsies of the median nerve are caused by compression at the carpal tunnel, known as carpal tunnel syndrome. Women have 3 times higher incidence of carpal tunnel syndrome compared to men. It peaks around age 50 but also frequently present in the older population. Patients with diabetes and thyroid disease are at an increased risk for carpal tunnel syndrome. With carpal tunnel syndrome, weakness in the thenar eminence is observed. Isolation of the opponens pollicis power is done by asking the patient to palmarly abduct the thumb. 

 

Option C. Musculocutaneous nerve: Isolated injuries of the Musculocutaneous Nerve are rare. It may become injured by brachial Plexus damage, compression injury, dislocation of the shoulder, shoulder surgery, or entrapment of the nerve at the elbow. Most significant is the entrapment of the musculocutaneous nerve within the coracobrachialis muscle, leading to biceps brachii and brachialis weakness and atrophy with accompanying loss of sensation in the lateral forearm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given image shows Claw hand deformity wherein the MCP joint of the fingers is hyperextended while the IP joint is flexed in the 4th and 5th digits. 
  • This occurs due to weakness of the intrinsic muscles of the hand which are supplied by the ulnar nerve. 
  • Thus, ulnar nerve palsies lead to claw hand deformity.

questions.text: Identify the instrument shown in the image. (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Bohler Braun splint 

 

  • It is a common splint used in wards for immobilization and reduction of most lower limb fractures and treatment of other lower limb pathologies.
  • Structure:
    • It consists of an iron frame with a set of 4 pulleys for application of mobile traction. 
    • It is modified from Braun splint which consists of only 1 pulley for distal tibia or calcaneal skeletal traction. 
    • Bohler’s Modification was addition of 2 more pulleys for proximal tibia and distal femur traction.
  • Uses of 4 pulleys:
    • Lowermost pulley is used for tibia and fibular injuries
    • Second from bottom is used for supracondylar fracture femur
    • 3rd (directed away from patient) is used for fracture shaft femur middle third
    • 4th (topmost and directed towards the patient) is used to prevent foot drop
  • Uses:
    • With traction:
      • For lower limb injuries with displacement/fragment overlap. 
      • The skeletal traction is given via a K wire, Steinman pin, Bohler's pin, etc.
      • In leg fracture, pin goes through calcaneal tuberosity
      • In femur fracture, pin goes through tibial tuberosity in adults, and just above the condyles in children
    • Without traction:
      • Compound fracture with no overlap – for dressing and wound care, and possible immobilization
      • Soft tissue injury to leg
      • In case of cellulitis, gangrene, amputation, etc.
  • Advantages:
    • Mobile traction – especially useful in cases where transportation is necessary as the traction unit is self-contained
    • Places the limb in comfortable position
    • Wound care is possible
    • Multipurpose application
    • Angle of traction can be changed by changing the pulleys without changing the arrangement 
    • Simultaneous traction through Calcaneal/distal tibia and proximal tibia/distal femur can be given
  • Disadvantages & complications:
    • Non-ambulatory
    • Stiffness/contracture
    • Urination and defecation becomes difficult
    • Common peroneal nerve compression
    • Other complications of recumbancy like bed sore, hypostatic pneumonia etc.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thomas splint: The Thomas' splint aims to immobilise the limb and consists of a padded metal ring (either continuous or with an opening, and a strap and buckle on the lateral side) covered with soft leather, attached to an angled bar that extends down the length and both sides of the leg. The bar is usually angled over the hip at the greater trochanter and the two side bars join in a “W” shape at the foot. The ring is available in different sizes to enable it to fit appropriately around the patients' groin (over the ischial tuberosity) and across the gluteal fold. This enables the splint to fit the patient as closely as possible. 

 

 

Option B. Volkmann splint: The Volkmann splint, also known as the Volkmann's turnbuckle splint, is a specialized orthopedic device used to treat Volkmann's contracture. Volkmann's Contracture is a condition that occurs when there is a lack of blood flow to the muscles of the forearm, leading to permanent shortening and tightening of the muscles, resulting in a claw-like deformity of the hand. The Volkmann splint is designed to gradually stretch and lengthen the shortened muscles. It works on a 3-point fixation mechanism and has a turnbuckle that controls and adjusts the tension.

 

 

Option D. Cramer wire: The Cramer splint is a simple but effective medical device that is used to fix fractures. Structurally, it is a reusable medical part in the form of a narrow ladder made of steel or aluminium wire, the flexible elements of which are soldered together. It can be given any shape, anatomically following the contours of the injured limb. It is used for fractures of the lower and upper extremities – shoulder, forearm, hip, ankle, ankles and fingers. In addition, it is used for reliable fixation of the patient’s upper spinal column and head. Immobilization of injured limb using a Cramer splint reduces the level of pain and prevent from additional damage during transportation of the patient.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given image shows the Bohler-Braun splint which is used in the immobilization of the lower limb fractures. 
  • The splint consists of a system of pulleys to provide traction and allow for fracture healing.

questions.text: Identify the marked area in the image shown below. (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pressure epiphysis 

 

  • A pressure epiphysis is the portion of the long bone that shapes the joint. 
  • Pressure epiphyses are the regions of the bone that are under pressure during movement or locomotion and aid in transmitting the weight of the human body. 
  • The head of the humerus, femoral and tibial condyles, ankle joint are the examples. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Atavistic epiphysis: A phylogenetically independent bone that has been fused with another bone. The coracoid process of the scapula, which has been fused in humans but is distinct in four-legged animals, is an example of atavistic fused bones. Another example of atavistic epiphysis is the os trigonum (posterior tubercle of the talus).

 

Option C. Traction epiphysis: The non-articular regions of the long bone, which are not involved in joint formation. These areas do not aid in weight transmission. The supporting ligaments and tendons bind to these areas of the bone due to their proximity to the pressure epiphysis site. Pressure epiphyses ossify first, followed by traction epiphyses. Tubercles of the humerus and trochanters of the femur are examples of traction epiphyses.

 

Option D. Aberrant epiphysis: These epiphyses are not necessarily present and are deviated from the standard. The epiphysis at the head of the first metacarpal bone, as well as the epiphysis at the base of other metacarpal bones, are examples.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given image shows the ankle joint. 
  • The joints are formed by the pressure epiphysis regions which are weight bearing areas. 
  • Thus, the ankle joint is an example of pressure epiphysis.

questions.text: Identify the image shown below in a patient who presented with a history of fall. (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anterior shoulder dislocation 

 

  • Anterior shoulder dislocation is the commonest type of dislocation and usually results from forced abduction, external rotation and extension of the shoulder. 
  • The more prevalent age group are young adult men who sustained high-energy injuries to the shoulder. 
  • On physical examination, the arm is abducted and externally rotated.
  • There is "squaring" of the shoulder i.e., loss of rounded appearance of the humeral head, and sharp prominence of the acromion ("squaring"). 
  • Due to axillary nerve neuropraxia, there can be reduced sensation over the lateral side of the shoulder. 
  • Radiograph shows the humeral head displaced medially and overlies the glenoid. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Posterior shoulder dislocation: Posterior dislocation of shoulder takes place when the trauma occur with the arm in a flexed, adducted, and internally rotated position. The patient presents with limited external rotation, shoulder locked in internal rotation, and pain on flexion, adduction and internal rotation of the shoulder. Radiograph may show a 'lightbulb' sign on AP view. Axillary lateral view X-ray is the best view to demonstrate dislocation. 

 

 

Option C. Intrathoracic dislocation of shoulder: An intrathoracic shoulder dislocation is a rare injury, usually the result of high-energy trauma. It often occurs in conjunction with thoracic, pelvic, and long bone injuries. In addition, there is often significant injuries to the shoulder girdle and chest wall associated with neurovascular compromise. The shoulder is forced into a position of abduction and external rotation, combined with a compressive force. The patient may present with severe pain in the shoulder and chest area, difficulty breathing, swelling and bruising in the chest and shoulder, limited or no movement in the affected arm. 

 

 

Option D. Subglenoid dislocation of shoulder: Subglenoid shoulder dislocation is a type of anterior shoulder dislocation where the head of the humerus is displaced in front of the glenoid cavity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given image shows the anterior dislocation of the shoulder. 
  • In the given X-ray, the humerus head is down and out i.e., it lies beneath the glenoid cavity and the arm is abducted. 
  • In the posterior dislocation, on x-ray, the humeral head is up and in i.e., lying above the glenoid with the arm adducted.

questions.text: A 42-year-old female labourer complains of soft, fluctuating swelling in front of the knee, directly over the patella. She reports discomfort and difficulty while moving her knee. MRI results confirm the findings. What is the most probable diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Housemaid’s knee

 

  • Prepatellar bursitis or housemaid’s knee is the swelling and inflammation of the anterior knee bursa associated with pain with kneeling. 
  • The bursa affected lies anterior to patella. 
  • It occurs commonly due to excessive kneeling and also seen in wrestlers. 
  • On MRI, an oval shaped fluid-filled sac is seen anterior to the patella. 
  • The wall of the bursa may show increased thickness and irregularity.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Subdermal abscess: A subdermal abscess in the knee is a pocket of pus that forms under the skin on the knee. It is usually caused by a bacterial infection. Symptoms of a subdermal abscess knee include pain, swelling, redness, and warmth in the knee. The abscess may also be visible as a raised, red bump on the skin.

 

 

Option C. Gout: Gout is an inflammatory arthropathy caused by long-standing hyperuricemia. Patients are usually asymptomatic for many years before developing symptoms and before radiographic evidence of disease. The first metatarsophalangeal joint is the most commonly involved joint. Involvement of the knee is not uncommon, but involvement of the patella is rare. MRI may demonstrate changes of gout arthritis including nodular thickening of the distal quadriceps tendon and erosion of the superior aspect of the patella. There can also be diffuse thickening of the prepatellar soft tissues , patellar tendon, and nodular thickening of the iliotibial band. 

 

 

Option D. Rheumatoid arthritis: Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is a chronic inflammatory autoimmune disease of unknown etiology that affects approximately 1% of the world population, with approximately 50% of adults being unable to work within 10 years of disease onset. The disease involves synovial joints and leads to progressive joint destruction. The knee joint is commonly involved in RA. Damage to the cartilage is associated with irreversible physical disability. The articular cartilage of the femoral condyles is destroyed early in the disease process, including roughening, softening, and fibrillation. MRI is the best non‐invasive modality to evaluate RA. It identifies synovial thickening, including inflammatory and fibrous proliferation, joint effusion, marginal erosions and subchondral cysts, periarticular soft tissue swelling, popliteal cysts, and tendon thickening. 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given image shows an inflammation anterior to the patella. 
  • This is seen in prepatellar bursitis, also called housemaid’s knee.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child was brought with bow legs and on x-ray of wrist, following were the findings. The child also had low serum calcium and low serum phosphate values. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rickets

 

  • Vitamin-D, calcium, and phosphorus are the main factors that influence bone maturation and mineralization. 
  • Defective mineralization can lead to rickets and/or osteomalacia. 
  • Rickets is characterized by a defect in mineralization and the widening of the epiphyseal plates.
  • Rickets occurs exclusively in children.
  • Nutritional rickets is the most common cause of bone disease.
  • Vitamin D deficiency is the most common cause of nutritional rickets.
  • Any defect in osteoid mineralization may cause rickets.
  • In all types of rickets, the characteristic features occur at the growth plate. 
  • In rickets, the calcium level is either normal or low; phosphate levels are low; and ALP and PTH are high.
  • The potential lower limb deformities include bow legs (genu varus), knock knees (genu valgus), and joints (knees and ankles) swelling, whereas the deformities of the upper limbs include the wrist widening.
  • The ulna grows relatively rapidly and hence, it is significantly affected.
  • The characteristic radiographic features of rickets are thickening and widening of growth plate (physis), indistinct and hazy metaphysis that is abnormally wide (splaying) with cupping or flaring (Brush-like appearance), bowing of diaphysis with thinning of cortices.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Scurvy: Scurvy is a condition caused by dietary lack of vitamin C (ascorbic acid), hence is also called hypovitaminosis C. It is characterized by an increased bleeding tendency, impaired collagen synthesis resulting in osteoporosis, and impaired wound healing. It is rarely seen in adults. Young children and elderly are more predisposed to scurvy due to diet or overheating of food. It does not occur before 6 months of age. Patients present with lethargy, malaise, bone pain, bleeding diathesis, and impaired wound healing. Pediatric radiographic features include generalized osteopenia, cortical thinning (pencil-point cortex), periosteal reaction due to subperiosteal hemorrhage, expansion of costochondral junctions (scorbutic rosary), hemarthrosis, Wimberger ring sign (circular, opaque shadow around epiphyseal centers of ossification, due to bleeding). 

 

 

Option C. Hypophosphatemia: Hypophosphatemia is defined as an adult serum phosphate level < 2.5 milligrams per deciliter (mg/dL). Normal serum phosphate levels in children are considerably higher, 4-7 mg/dL. Hypophosphatemia is a relatively common laboratory abnormality and is often an incidental finding. Most patients with hypophosphatemia are asymptomatic, and the most common symptom is generalized mild to moderate weakness. Clinical symptoms usually appear with moderate or severe hypophosphatemia. Neurologic symptoms include altered mental status, dysarthria, seizures, and numbness or reflexive weakness. Cardiac and respiratory failure can occur in severe cases. In addition to muscle weakness, muscle pain may signify hypophosphatemia-related rhabdomyolysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given image of the child’s hands and wrists shows cupping and splaying of the radius and the ulna. 
  • The patient presents with bow legs, and decreased levels of serum calcium and phosphate. 
  • These are common findings of rickets caused by defective bone mineralization or nutritional deficiency of vitamin D in children.
